The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.

div.p: PLUTARCHS LIVES.
Tranlated From the GREEK BY SEVERAL HANDS.
To which is prefixt the LIFE of PLUTARCH.
The Firt Volume.
LONDON, Printed for Jacob Tonon, at the Sign of the Judges-head in Chancery-lane near Fleet-treet, 1683.

div.head: TO HIS GRACE THE DUKE OF Ormond, &c.
div.p:
Lcretius, endeavouring to prove from the principles of his Philoophy, that the world had a caual beginning from the concoure of Atomes; and that Men, as well as the ret of Animals, were produc'd from the vital heat and moiture of their Mother Earth; from the ame principles is
bound to anwer this objection, why Men are not daily form'd after the ame manner, which he tells us is, becaue the kindly warmth, and procreative faculty of the ground is now worn out: The Sun is a diabled Lover, and the Earth is pat her teeming time.

Though Religion has inform'd us better of our Origine, yet it appears plainly, that not only the Bodies, but the Souls of Men, have decreas'd from the vigour of the firt Ages; that we are not more hort of the tature and trength of thoe gygantick Heroes, than we are of their undertanding, and their wit. To let pas thoe happy Patriarchs, who were triplings at fourcore, and had afterwards even or eight hundred years before them to beget Sons and Daughters; and to conider Man in reference only to his mind, and that no higher
than the Age of Socrates: How vat a difference is there betwixt the productions of thoe Souls, and thee of ours? How much better Plato, Aritotle, and the ret of the Philoophers undertood nature; Thucydides, and Herodotus adorn'd Hitory; Sophocles, Eurypides and Menander advanc'd Poetry, than thoe Dwarfs of Wit and Learning who ucceeded them in after times? That Age was mot Famous amongt the Greeks, which ended with the death of Alexander; amongt the Romans Learning eem'd again to revive and flourih in the Century which produc'd Cicero, Varro, Salut, Livy, Lucretius and Virgil: And after a hort interval of years, (wherein Nature eem'd to take a breathing time for a econd birth,) there prung up under the Vepaians, and thoe excellent Princes who ucceeded them, a race of memorable Wits; uch as were
the two Plinies, Tacitus, and Suetonius; and as if Greece was emulous of the Roman learning, under the ame favourable Contellation, was born the famous Philoopher and Hitorian Plutarch. Then whom Anquity has never produc'd a Man more generally knowing, or more vertuous; and no ucceeding Age has equall'd him. His Lives both in his own eteem, and that of others, accounted the Noblet of his Works, have been long ince render'd into Englih: But as that Tranlation was only from the French, o it uffer'd this double diadvantage, firt that it was but a Copy of a Copy, and that too but lamely taken from the Greek Original: Secondly that the Englih Language was then unpolih'd, and far from the perfection which it has ince attain'd: So that the firt Verion is not only ungrammatical and
ungraceful, but in many places almot unintelligible. For which reaons, and leat o ueful a piece of Hitory, hou'd lie oppres'd under the rubbih of Antiquated words, ome ingenious and learned Gentlemen, have undertaken this Task: And what wou'd have been the labour of one Mans Life, will, by the everal endeavours of many, be now accomplih'd in the compas of a year. How far they have ucceeded in this laudable attempt, to me it belongs not to determine; who am too much a party to be a Judge: But I have the honour to be Commiion'd from the Tranlators of this Volum, to incribe their labours and my own, with all humility, to your Graces Name and Patronage. And never was any Man more ambitious of an employment, of which he was o little worthy. Fortune has at lat gratify'd that earnet
deire I have always had, to hew my devotion to your Grace; though I depair of paying you my acknowledgments. And of all other opportunities I have happen'd on the mot favourable to my elf; who, having never been able to produce any thing of my own, which cou'd be worthy of your view, am upply'd by the aitance of my friends, and honour'd with the preentation of their labours. The Author they have Tranlated, has been long familiar to you: Who have been converant in all orts of Hitory both Ancient and Modern; and have form'd the Idea of your mot Noble Life from the intructions and Examples contain'd in them; both in the management of publick affairs, and in the private Offices of vertue; in the enjoyment of your better fortune, and utaining of your wore; in habituating your elf
to an eaie greatnes; in repelling your Enemies, in uccouring your Friends, and in all traveres of fortune, in every colour of your Life, maintaining an inviolable fidelity to your Soveraign. Tis long ince that I have learn'd to forget the art of praiing; but here the heart dictates to the pen; and I appeal to your Enemies, (if o much generoity and good nature can have left you any) whether they are not concious to themelves that I have not flatter'd.

Tis an Age indeed, which is only fit for Satyr; and the harpet I have hall never be wanting to launce its Villanies, and its ingratitude to the Government: There are few Men in it, who are capable of upporting the weight of a jut and deerv'd commendation: But amongt thoe few there mut always tand excepted the Illutrious Names of Ormond
and of Oory: A Father and a Son, only Worthy of each other. Never was one Soul more fully infus'd into anothers breat: Never was o trong an impreion made of vertue, as that of your Graces into him: But though the tamp was deep, the ubject which receiv'd it was of too fine a compoition to be durable. Were not priority of time and nature in the cae, it might have been doubted which of you had been mot excellent: But Heaven natch'd away the Copy to make the Original more precious. I dare trut my elf no farther on this ubject; for after years of mourning, my orrow is yet o green upon me, that I am ready to tax Providence for the los of that Heroick Son: Three Nations had a general concernment in his Death, but I had one o very particular, that all my hopes are almot dead with
him; and I have lot o much that I am pat the danger of a econd Shipwreck. But he leeps with an unenvy'd commendation: And has left your Grace the ad Legacy of all thoe Glories which he deriv'd from you. An acceion which you wanted not, who were o rich before in your own vertues, and that high reputation which is the product of them. A long decent of Noble Ancetors was not neceary to have made you great: But Heaven threw it in as over-plus when you were born. What you have done and uffer'd for two Royal Maters has been enough to render you Illutrious; o that you may afely wave the Nobility of your birth, and relie on your actions for your fame. You have cancell'd the debt which you ow'd to your Progenitors, and reflect more brightnes on their memory than
you receiv'd from them. Your native Country, which Providence gave you not leave to preerve under one King, it has given you opportunity under another to retore. You cou'd not ave it from the Chatiement which was due to its Rebellion, but you rais'd it from ruin after its repentance: So that the Trophies of War were the portion of the Conquerour, but the Triumphs of peace were reerv'd for the vanquih'd. The misfortunes of Ireland were owing to it elf, but its happines and Retoration to your Grace. The Rebellion againt a Lawful Prince, was punih'd by an Uurping Tyrant: But the fruits of his Victory were the rewards of a Loyal Subject. How much that Noble Kingdom has flourih'd under your Graces Government, both the Inhabitants and the Crown are enible. The
riches of Ireland are increas'd by it, and the Revenues of England are augmented. That which was a charge and burden of the Government is render'd an advantage and upport: The Trade and Interet of both Countries are united in a mutual benefit; they conpire to make each other happy; the dependance of the one is an improvement of its Commerce, the preeminence of the other is not impair'd by the intercoure, and common neceities are upply'd by both. Ireland is no more a Cyon, to uck the nourihment from the Mother Tree; neither is it overtop'd, or hinder'd from growth by the uperiour branches; but the Roots of England, diving (if I may dare to ay it,) underneath the Seas, rie at a jut ditance on the Neighbouring Shore; and there hoot up, and bear a product carce inferiour to the Trunk
from whenee they prung. I may raie the commendation higher, and yet not fear to offend the truth: Ireland is a better Penitent than England: The Crime of Rebellion was common to both Countries; but the repentance of one Iland has been teady; that of the other, to its hame, has uffer'd a relape: Which hews the Converions of their Rebels to have been real, that of ours to have been but counterfeit. The Sons of Guilty Fathers there have made amends for the diloyalty of their Families: But here the decendants of pardon'd Rebels have only waited their time to copy the wickednes of their Parents, and if poible to out do it: They didain to hold their Patrimonies by acts of Grace and of Indempnity: and by maintaining their old Treaonable principles, make it apparent that they are till peculative Traytors.
For whether they are zealous Sectaries or prophane Republicans, (of which two orts they are principally compos'd) both our Reformers of Church and Sate, pretend to a power uperiour to Kinghip. The Fanaticks derive their Authority from the Bible; and plead Religion to be antecedent to any ecular obligation: By vertue of which Argument, taking it for granted that their own Worhip is only true, they arrogate to themelves the right of dipoing the Temporal power according to their pleaure; as that which is ubordinate to the Spiritual: So that the ame Reaons, and Scriptures, which are urg'd by Popes for the depoition of Princes, are produc'd by Sectaries for altering the Succeion. The Epicopal Reformation has manumiz'd Kings from the Uurpation of Rome; for it preaches obedience and reignation
to the lawful Secular power: but the pretended Reformation of our Schimaticks, is to et up themelves in the Papal Chair; and to make their Princes only their Trutees. So that whether they or the Pope were uppermot in England, the Royal Authority were equally depres'd: The Prion of our Kings wou'd be the ame; the Gaolers only wou'd be alter'd. The broad Republicans are generally Men of Atheitick principles, nominal Chritians, who are beholding to the Font, only that they are o call'd, otherwie Hobbits in their politicks and Morals: Every Church is oblig'd to them that they own themelves of none; becaue their Lives are too candalous for any. Some of the Sectaries are o proud, that they think they cannot in; thoe Common-wealth Men are o wicked, that they conclude there is no in. Lewdnes,
Rioting, Cheating and Debauchery, are their work a day practie: Their more olemn crimes, are unnatural Luts, and horrid Murthers. Yet thee are the Patrons of the Nonconformits; thee are the Swords and Bucklers of Gods caue; if his caue be that of Separatits and Rebells. Tis not but thee Aociates know each other at the bottom, as well as Simeon knew Levi: The Republicans are atisfy'd that the Schimaticks are Hypocrites, and the Schimaticks are aur'd that the Republicans are Atheits: But their common principles of Government are the chaines that link them: For both hold Kings to be Creatures of their own making, and by inference to be at their own dipoing. With this difference, notwithtanding, that the Canting party face their pretences with a call from God, the debauch'd party
with a Commiion from the people. So that if ever this ill contriv'd and equivocal aociation hou'd get uppermot, they wou'd infallibly contend for the upream right; and as it was formerly on their mony, o now it wou'd be in their interets; God with us wou'd be et up on one ide, and the Common-wealth of England on the other. But I the les wonder at the mixture of thee two natures, becaue two Salvage beats of different pecies and Sexes hut up together, will forget their Enmity to atisfie their common lut; and 'tis no matter what kind of Monter is produc'd betwixt them, o the brutal appetite be erv'd. I more admire at a third party, who were Loyal when Rebellion was uppermot, and have turn'd Rebells (at leat in principle,) ince Loyalty has been Triumphant. Thoe of them whoe ervices have not been rewarded,
have ome pretence for dicontent; and yet they give the World to undertand, that their Honour was not their principle, but their Interet. If they are old Royallits, 'tis a ign their vertue is worn out; and will bear no longer; if Sons to Royallits they have probably been grafted on Whig tocks, and grown out of kind; like China Oranges in Portugal: Their Mothers part has prevail'd in them, and they are degenerated from the Loyalty of their Fathers.

But if they are uch, as many of them evidently are, whoe ervice has been, not only fully but lavihly recompens'd, with Honours and preferment, theirs is an ingratitude without parallel; they have detroy'd their former merits, diown'd the caue for which they fought, bely'd their youth, dihonour'd their age; they have wrought
themelves out of preent enjoyments, for imaginary hopes, and can never be truted by their new friends, becaue they have betray'd their old. The greater and the tronger ties which ome of them have had, are the deeper brands of their Apotacy: For Arch-Angels were the firt and mot glorious of the whole Creation: They were the morning work of God; and had the firt impreions of his Image, what Creatures cou'd be made: They were of kin to Eternity it elf; and wanting only that acceion to be Deities. Their fall was therefore more opprobrious than that of Man, becaue they had no clay for their excue: Though I hope and wih the latter part of the Allegory may not hold, and that repentance may be yet allow'd them. But I delight not to dwell on o ad an object: Let this part of the Landchape be cat into
hadows, that the heightnings of the other may appear more beautiful. For as Contraries the nearer they are plac'd are brighter, and the Venus is illutrated by the Neighbourhood of the Lazar, o the unblemih'd Loyalty of your Grace, will hine more clearly, when et in competition with their tains. When the Malady which had eiz'd the Nobler parts of Britain threw it elf out into the limbs, and the firt ores of it appear'd in Scotland, yet no effects of it reach'd your Province: Ireland tood untainted with that pet: The care of the Phyician prevented the dieae, and preerv'd the Country from infection. When that Ulcer was rather top'd than cur'd, (for the caues of it till remain'd) and that dangerous Symptoms appear'd in England; when the Royal Authority was here trodden under
foot, when one Plot was proecuted openly, and another ecretly fomented, yet even then was Ireland free from our contagion: And if ome venemous Creatures were produc'd in that Nation, yet it appear'd they could not live there: They hed their poyon without effect: They depair'd of being uccesfully wicked in their own Country, and tranported their Evidence to another, where they knew 'twas vendible: Where accuation was a Trade, where forgeries were countenanc'd, where perjuries were rewarded, where wearing went for proof, and where the Merchandize of Death was gainful. That their Tetimony was at lat dicredited, proceeded not from its incoherence: For they were known by their own party when they firt appear'd; but their folly was then manag'd by the cunning
of their Tutors; they had till been believ'd, had they till follow'd their Intructors: But when their witnes fell foul upon their friends, then they were proclaim'd Villains, dicarded and diown'd by thoe who ent for them; they eem'd then firt to be dicover'd, for what they had been known too well before; they were decry'd as inventours of what only they betray'd: Nay their very wit was magnified let being taken for fools, they might be thought too imple to forge an accuation. Some of them till continue here deteted by both ides, believ'd by neither: (for even their betters are at lat uncas'd,) and ome of them have receiv'd their hire in their own Country: For perjury, which is malice to Mankind, is always accompanied with other Crimes: and tho not punihable by our Laws with death,
yet draws a train of vices after it: The Robber, the Murderer and the Sodomite, have often hung up the forworn villain: And what one in took on trut, another in has pay'd. Thee travelling Locuts are at length wallow'd up in their own Red-Sea. Ireland as well as England is deliver'd from that flying Plague; for the Sword of Jutice in your Graces hand, like the Rod of Moes, is tretcht out againt them: And the third part of his Majeties Dominions is owing for its peace to your Loyalty and vigilance.

But what Plutarch can this age produce to immortallize a life o Noble? May ome excellent Hitorian at length be found, ome Writer not unworthy of his Subject, but may his employment be long deferr'd: May many happy years continue you to this Nation and your own; may your praies be celebrated
late; that we may enjoy you living rather than adore you dead. And ince yet, there is not rien up amongt us, any Hitorian who is equal to o great an undertaking, let us hope that Providence has not aign'd the workman, becaue his employment is to be long delay'd; becaue it has reerv'd your Grace for farther proofs of your unwearyed duty, and a farther enjoyment of your fortune. In which tho no Man has been les envy'd, becaue no other has more Nobly us'd it, yet ome droppings of the Ages venom have been hed upon you: The Supporters of the Crown are plac'd too near it, to be exempted from the torm which was breaking over it. 'Tis true you tood involv'd in your own Vertue, and the Malice of your Libellers cou'd not ink through all thoe folds to reach you. Your
Innocence has defended you from their attacks, and your pen has o Nobly vindicated that Innocence, that it tands in need of no other econd. The difference is as plainly een, betwixt Sophitry and truth, as it is betwixt the tile of a Gentleman, and the clumy tifnes of a Pedant. Of all Hitorians God deliver us from Bigots; and of all Bigots from our Sectaries. Truth is never to be expected from Authors whoe undertandings are warp'd with Enthuiam: For they judge all actions and their caues by their own pervere principles; and a crooked line can never be the meaure of a treight one. Mr. Hobbs was us'd to ay, that a Man was alwaies againt reaon, when reaon wasagaint a Man: So thee Authors are for obcuring truth, becaue truth would dicover them. They are not Hitorians of an Action,
but Lawyers of a party: They are retain'd by their principles, and brid'd by their interets: Their narrations are an opening of their caue; and in the front of their Hitories, there ought to be written the Prologue of a pleading, I am for the Plaintiff, or I am for the Defendant. We have already een large Volumes of State Collections, and Church Legends, tuffd with detected forgeries in ome parts, and gaping with omiions of truth in others: Not penn'd I uppoe with o vain a hope as to cheat Poterity, but to advance ome deign in the preent Age: For thee Legerdemain Authors, are for telling tories, to keep their trick undicover'd; and to make their conveyance the more clean. What calumny your Grace may expect from uch Writers, is already evident: But it will fare with them, as it does with ill
Painters; a Picture o unlike in all its features and proportions, reflects not on the original, but on the Artit: For malice will make a piece more unreembling than ignorance: And he who tudies the life, yet bungles, may draw ome faint imitation of it; But he who purpoely avoids nature, mut fall into groteque, and make no likenes. For my own part I am of the former ort: And therefore preume not to offer my unskillfulnes for o excellent a deign as is your illutrious life: To pray for its properity and continuance is my duty; as it is my Ambition to appear on all occaions,

closer.signed: Tour Graces mot obedient and devoted Servant, JOHN DRYDEN.

div.head: THE Publiher to the Reader.
div.p:
YO have here, the firt Volume of Plutarchs Lives, turn'd from the Greek into Englih; And (give me leave to ay) the firt attempt of doing it from the Originalls. You may expect the Remainder, in four more; One after another as fat as they may conveniently be dipatch'd from the Pres. It is not my buines, or pretence, to judge of a work of this quality, neither do I take upon me to recommend it to the world any farther, then under the Office of a fair, and a careful Publiher, and in dicharge of a trut depoited in my hands for the ervice of my Country, and for a Common good. I am not yet o inenible of the Authority and Reputation of o great a Name, as not to conult the Honour of the Author, together with the benefit, and atisfaction of the Bookeller, as well as of the Reader, in this undertaking. In order to which ends, I have with all poible Repect, and Indutry, Beought, Sollicited, and Obtain'd the Aitance of perons equal to the enterprize, and not only Criticks in the Tongue, but Men of known fame, and Abilities, for tyle and Ornament, but I hall rather refer you to the Learned and Ingenious Tranlators of this firt part, (whoe
Names you will find in the next page) as a Specimen of what you may promie your elf from the Ret?

After this Right done to the Greek Author, I hall not need to ay what profit, and delight will accrue to the Englih Reader from this verion, when he hall ee this Illutrious piece, in his own Mother Tongue; and the very Spirit of the Original, Transfus'd into the Traduction. And in one word; Plutarchs Worthies made yet more famous, by a Tranlation that gives a farther Lutre, even to Plutarch himelf.

Now as to the Bookellers Part; I mut jutifie my elf, that I have done all that to me belonged: That is to ay, I have been punctually Faithful to all my Commiions toward the Correctnes, and the Decency of the Work, and I have aid to my elf, that which I now ay to the Publick;
It is impoible, but a Book that comes into the World with o many circumtances of Dignity, uefulnes, and eteem, mut turn to account.

div.head: THE LIFE OF PLUTARCH.
div.p:
He was born at Chaeronea a mall City of Boeotia in Greece, between Attica and Phocis, and reaching to both Seas. The Climate not much befreinded by the Heavens; for the air is thick and foggy; and conequently the Inhabitants partaking of its influence, gros feeders, and fat witted; brawny, and unthinking, jut the contitution of Heroes:
Cut out for the Executive and brutal buines of War; but o tupid in the deigning part, that in all the revolutions of Greece they were never Maters, but only in thoe few years, when they were led by Epaminondas, or Pelopidas. Yet this foggy ayre, this Country of fat weathers, as Juvenal calls it, produc'd three wits, which were comparable to any three Athenians: Pyndar, Epaminondas, and our Plutarch, to whom we may add a fourth, Sextus Chaeronenis, the Praeceptor of the learned Emperour Marcus Aurelius; and the Nephew of our Authour.

Choercnea, (if we may give credit to Pauanias, in the ninth Book of his decription of Greece) was anciently call'd Arnè; from Arnè the Daughter of Aeolus; but being cituated to the wet of Parnaus in that low land country, the natural unwholomnes of the Ayre was augmented by
the evening Vapours cat upon it from that Mountain, which our late Travellers decribe to be full of moiture and marhy ground inclo'd in the inequality of its acents: And being alo expos'd to the winds which blew from that quarter, the Town was perpetually unhealthful, for which reaon, ayes my Author, Chaeron, the Son of Apollo and Thero, made it be rebuilt, and turn'd it towards the riing Sun; From whence the Town became healthful and conequently populous; in memory of which benefit it afterwards retain'd his name. But as Etymologies are uncertain, and the Greeks, above all Nations, given to fabulous derivations of Names, epecially, when they tend to the Honour of their Country, I think we may be reaonably content to take the denomination of the Town from its delightful or chearful tanding; as
the word Chaeron ufficiently implies.
But to loe no time, in thee grammatical Etymologies, which are commonly uncertain ghees, 'tis agreed that Plutarch was here born; the year uncertain; but without dipute in the reign of Claudius.

Joh. Gerrard Voius has aign'd his birth in the latter end of that Emperour: Some other Writers of his Life, have left it undecided, whether then, or in the beginning of Nero's Empire: But the mot accurate Rualdus (as I find it in the Paris Edition of Plutarch's Works) has manifetly prov'd him to be born in the middle time of Claudius, or omewhat lower: For Plutarch in the incription at Delphos, of which more hereafter, remembers that Ammonius his Mater diputed with him and his Brother Lamprias concerning it, when Nero made his progres into Greece; which was in his twelfth year;
and the Quetion diputed cou'd not be manag'd with o much learning as it was, by meer Boyes; therefore he was then ixteen, or rather eighteen years of age.

Xylander has oberv'd that Plutarch himelf, in the Life of Pericles, and that of Anthony, has mentioned both Nero and Domitian, as his Contemporaries. He has alo left it on Record in his Sympoiaques, that his Family was ancient in Chaeronea; and that for many decents, they had born the mot coniderable Offices in that petty Common-wealth. The cheifet of which was known by the name of Archon amongt the Grecians; by that of Praetor rbis among the Romans; and the Dignity and Power was not much different from that of our Lord Mayor of London. His Great Grand-Father Nicarchus perhaps injoy'd that Office in the diviion of the Empire betwixt
Augutus Caear and Mark Anthony. And when the Civil Wars enued betwixt them, Chaeronea was o hardly us'd by Anthonies Lieutenant or Commiary there, that all the Citizens without exception, were ervilely imployed to carry on their houlders a certain proportion of Corn from Chaeronea to the Coat over againt the Iland of Antycira, with the Scourge held over them, if at any time they were remis: Which duty after once performing, being enjoynd the Second time with the ame everity, jut as they were preparing for their journey, the welcom news arriv'd that Mark Anthony had lot the Battel of Actium, whereupon both the Officers and Souldiers, belonging to him in Chaeronea, immediately fled for their own afety; and the proviions thus collected, were ditributed among the Inhabitants of the City.

This Nicarchus, the Great Grand-Father of Plutarch, among other Sons, had Lamprias, a Man eminent for his Learning; and a Philoopher, of whom Plutarch has made frequent mention in his Sympoiaques, or Table Converations, and amongt the ret, there is this obervation of him, that he diputed bet, and unravell'd the difficulties of Philoophy with mot ucces when he was at Supper, and well warm'd with Wine. Thee Table Entertainments were part of the Education of thoe times, their dicoures being commonly the canvaing and Solution of ome quetion, either Philoophical or Philological, alwayes intructive, and uually pleaant; for the Cups went round with the debate; and Men were merry and wie together, according to the Proverb. The Father of Plutarch is alo mention'd, in thoe Dicoures, whom
our Author repreents as arguing of everal points in Philoophy; but his name is no where to be found in any part of the works remaining to us. But yet he peaks of him, as a Man not ignorant in Learning and Poetry, as may appear by what he ays, when he is introduc'd diputing in the Sympoiaques; where alo his prudence and humanity are commended, in this following Relation. Being yet very young (ays Plutarch) I was joyn'd, in Commiion with another in an Embay to the Proconul, and my Collegue falling ick was forc'd to tay behind, o that the whole buines was Tranacted by me alone. At my return, when I was to give account to the Common-wealth of my proceedings, my Father, riing from his Seat, openly enjoyn'd me not to name my elf in the ingular Number, I did thus, or thus, I ay'd
to the Proconul, but thus we did and thus we ay'd, alwaies aociating my Companion with me, though abent in the management: this was done to oberve, as I uppoe, the point of good manners with his Collegue, that of repect to the Government of the City, who had commiion'd both, to avoid envy, and perhaps more epecially, to take off the forwardnes of a pert young Miniter, commonly too apt to overvalue his own ervices, and to quote himelf on every inconiderable occaion. The Father of Plutarch had many Children beides him; Timon and Lamprias, his Brothers, were bred up with him, all three intructed in the Liberal Sciences, and in all parts of Philoophy. 'Tis Manifet from our Author that they liv'd together in great friendlines, and in great veneration to their Grand-father
and Father. What affection Plutarch bore in parricular to his Brother Timon may be gather'd from thee words of his. As for my elf, though fortune on everal occaions has been favourable to me, I have no obligation o great to her, as the kindnes, and entire friendhip, which my Brother Timon has alwayes born, and till bears me: and this is o evident that it cannot but be noted, by every one of our acquaintance. Lamprias, the younget of the three, is introduc'd by him in his Morals, as one of a weet and pleaant Converation, inclin'd to Mirth and Raillery; or, as we ay in Englih, a well humour'd man, and a good Companion. The whole Family being thus addicted to Philoophy, 'tis no wonder if our Author was initiated betimes in Study, to which he was naturally inclin'd. In puruit of which he
was o happy, to fall into good hands at firt; being recommended to the care of Ammonius an Egyptian, who, having taught Philoophy with great Reputation at Alexandria, and from thence travelling into Greece, ettled himelf at lat in Athens, where he was well receiv'd, and generally repected. At the end of Themitocles his Life, Plutarch relates, that being young, he was a Pentioner in the houe of this Ammonius; and in his Sympoiaques he brings him in diputing with his Scholars, and giving them intruction. For the cutom of thoe times was very much different from thee of ours, where the greatet part of our Youth is pent in learning the words of dead languages: The Grecians, who thought all Barbarians but themelves, depis'd the ue of Forreign tongues; o that the firt Elements of their
breeding was the knowledge of Nature, and the accommodation of that knowledge by Moral precepts, to the ervice of the publick, and the private offices of vertue. The Maters imploying one part of their time in reading to, and dicouring with their Scholars, and the ret in appointing them their everal Exercies either in Oratory or Philoophy; and eting them to declaim and to dipute amongt themelves. By this liberal ort of Education, tudy was o far from being a burden to them, that in a hort time, it became a habit, and Philoophical quetions, and criticims of humanity, were their uual recreations at their Meals. Boyes liv'd then, as the better ort of Men do now; and their converation was o well bred and Manly, that they did not plunge out of their depth into the World, when
they grew up; but lid eaily into it, and found no alteration in their Company. Amongt the ret, the Reading and Quotations of Poets were not forgotten at their Suppers, and in their Walks; but Homer, Euripides, and Sophocles, were the entertainment of their hours of freedom. Rods and Ferula's were not us'd by Ammonius, as being properly the punihment of laves, and not the correction of ingenuous free-born Men. At leat to be only exercis'd by parents, who had the power of life and death over their own Children. As appears by the Example of this Ammonius, thus related by our Author.

Our Mater (ayes he) one time, perceiving, at his afternoon Lecture; that ome of his Scholars had eaten more largely than became the moderation of Students, immediately commanded one of his Free-Men to take
his own Son, and Scourge him in our ight; becaue, ayd the Philoopher, my young Gentleman cou'd not eat his Dinner, without Poynant auce, or Vinegar; and at the ame time he cat his eye on all of us: So that every Criminal was given to undertand, that he had a hare in the reprehenion, and that the punihment was as well deerv'd by all the ret, had the Phyloopher not known, that it exceeded his Commiion to inflict it.

Plutarch therefore having the aitance of uch a Mater, in few years advanc'd to admiration in knowledge: And that without firt Travelling into Forreign parts, or acquiring any Forreign tongue; though the Roman Language at that time was not only vulgar in Rome it elf, but generally through the extent of that vat Empire, and in Greece, which was a Member of it, as our Author
has remark'd towards the end of his Platonick quetions. For like a true Philoopher, who minded things, not words, he trove not even to cultivate his Mother Tongue with any great exactnes. And himelf confees in the beginning of Demothenes his life, that during his abode in Italy, and at Rome, he had neither the leiure to tudy, nor o much as to exercie the Roman language; (I uppoe he means to write in it, rather than to peak it,) as well by reaon of the affairs he manag'd, as that he might acquit himelf to thoe who were deirous to be intructed by him in Philoophy. In o much that till the declination of his age, he began not to be converant in Latin books; in reading of which it happened omewhat oddly to him, that he learnt not the knowledge of things by words; but by the undertanding and ue he
had of things, attain'd to the knowledge of words which ignified them. Jut as Adam (etting aide divine illumination) call'd the Creatures by their proper Names, by firt undertanding of their natures. But for the delicacies of the Tongue, the turns of the Expreion, the figures and connexions of words, in which conit the beauty of that language, he plainly tells us, that tho he much admir'd them, yet they requir'd too great labour for a Man in Age, and plung'd in buines to attain perfectly. Which Compleplement I hou'd be willing to believe from a Philoopher, if I did not conider, that Dion Caius, nay even Herodian, and Appian after him, as well as Polybius before him, by writing the Roman Hitory in the Greek language, had hewn as manifet a contempt of Latin, in repect of the other, as French Men
now do of Englih, which they didain to peak, while they live among us: But with great advantage to their trivial conceptions, drawing the dicoure into their own language, have learnt to depie our better thoughts, which mut come deform'd and lame in converation to them, as being tranmitted in a Tongue of which we are not Maters. This is to arrogate a uperiority in nature over us, as undoubtedly the Grecians did over their Conquerours, by etablihing their language for a Standard; it being become o much a mode to peak and write Greek in Tully's time, that with ome indignation I have read his Epitles to Atticus, in which he deires to have his own conulhip written by his friend in the Grecian language; which he afterwards perform'd himelf; a vain attempt in my opinion, for any Man to endeavour to excel
in a Tongue which he was not born to peak. This, tho it be digreion, yet deerves to be conider'd at more leiure; for the honour of of our Wit and Writings, which are of a more olid make than that of our Neighbours, is concern'd in it. But to return to Plutarch, as it was his good fortune to be moulded firt by Maters the mot excellent in their kind, o it was his own vertue, to uck in with an incredible deire, and earnet application of mind, their wie intructions; and it was alo his prudence o to manage his health by moderation of diet and bodily exercie, as to preerve his parts without decay to a great old age; to be lively and vigorous to the lat, and to preerve himelf to his own enjoyments, and to the profit of Mankind. Which was not difficult for him to perform, having receiv'd from nature a contitution capable
of labour; and from the Dometick example of his Parents, a paring obriety of diet, a temperance in other pleaures, and above all an Habitude of commanding his paions in order to his health. Thus principled, and grounded, he conider'd with himelf, that a larger Communication with learned Men was neceary for his accomplihment; and therefore, having a Soul inatiable of knowledge, and being ambitious to excell in all kinds of Science, he took up a reolution to Travel. Egypt was at that time, as formerly it had been, famous for learning; and probably the Myteriounes of their Doctrine might tempt him, as it had done Pythagoras and others, to convere with the Priet-hood of that Country, which appears to have been particularly his buines by the Treatie of Iis and Oyris, which he has left us. In
which he hews himelf not meanly vers'd, in the ancient Theology and Philoophy of thoe wie Men. From Egypt returning into Greece, he viited in his way all the Academies, or Schools of the everal Philoophers, and gather'd from them many of thoe obervations with which he has enrich'd Poterity.

Beides this, he applyed himelf, with extream diligence, to collect not only all books which were excellent in their kind, and already publih'd, but alo all ayings and dicoures of wie Men, which he had heard in converation, or which he had receiv'd from others by Tradition. As likewie the Records and publick Intruments, preerv'd in Cities, which he had viited in his Travels; and which he afterwards catter'd through his works. To which purpoe he took a particular
Journy to Sparta, to earch the Archives of that famous Commonwealth, to undertand throughly the model of their ancient Government, their Legilators, their Kings, and their Ephori, digeting all their memorable deeds and ayings, with o much care, that he has not omitted thoe even of their Women, or their private Souldiers; together with their Cutomes, their Decrees, their Ceremonies, and the manner of their publick and private living, both in peace and war. The ame methods he alo took in divers other Commonwealths, as his Lives, and his Greek and Roman Quetions ufficiently tetifie. Without thee helps it had been impoible for him to leave in writing o many particular obervations of Men and manners, and as impoible to have gatherd them,
without converation and commerce with the learned Antiquaries of his time. To thee he added a curious Collection of Ancient Statues, Medals, Incriptions, and Paintings, as alo of proverbial ayings, Epigrams, Epitaphs, Apothegmes, and other Ornaments of Hitory, that he might leave nothing unwept behind him. And as he was continually in Company with Men of learning, in all profeions, o his memory was always on the tretch, to receive and lodge their dicoures; and his Judgment perpetually employ'd in eparating his notions, and ditinguihing which were fit to be preerv'd, and which to be rejected.

By benefit of this, in little time he inlarg'd his knowledge to a great extent in every Science; himelf in the beginning of the Treatie
which he has compos'd of Content, and Peace of mind, makes mention of thoe Collections, or Common places, which he had long ince drawn together for his own particular occaions: And 'tis from this rich Cabinet that he has taken out thoe excellent peices, which he has ditributed to Poterity, and which give us occaion to deplore the los of the reidue, which either the injury of time, or the negligence of Coppiers have denyed to us. On this account, tho we need not doubt to give him this general commendation, that he was ignorant of no ort of learning, yet we may jutly add this farther, that whoever will conider through the whole body of his Works, either the deign, the method, or the contexture of his Dicoures, whether Hitorical or Moral, or Quetions of natural Philoophy, or SoSolutions
of Problems Mathematical, whether he arraigns the opinions of others Sects, or etablihes the Doctrines of his own, in all thee kinds there will be found, both the harmony of order and the beauty of eaines. His reaons o olid and convincing, his inductions o pleaant and agreeable to all orts of Readers, that it mut be acknowledged he was Mater of every Subject which he treated, and treated none but what were improveable to the benefit of Intruction. For we may perceive in his Writting the deire he had to imprint his Precepts in the Souls of his Readers; and to lodge Morality in Families, nay even to exalt it to the Thrones of Soveraign Princes, and to make it the Rule and meaure of their Government. Finding that there were many Sects of Philoophers then in vogue, he earch'd
into the foundation of all their principles and opinions; and not content with this diquiition, he trac'd them to their everal fountains. So that the Pythagorean, Epicurean, Stoick and Peripatetick Philoophy were familiar to him. And tho it may be eaily oberv'd that he was chiefly inclin'd to follow Plato (whoe memory he o much reverenc'd, that Annually he celebrated his Birth-day, and alo that of Socrates;) yet he modetly contain'd himelf within the bounds of the latter Academy, and was content, like Cicero, only to propound and weigh opinions, leaving the Judgment of his Readers free without preuming to decide Dogmatically. Yet it is to be confes'd, that in the midt of this moderation, he oppos'd the two extreams of the Epicurean and Stoick Sects: Both which he has judiciouly combatted
in everal of his Treaties, and both upon the ame account, becaue they pretend too much to certainty, in their Dogma's; and to impoe them with too great arrogance; which he, who (following the Academits,) doubted more and pretended les, was no way able to upport. The Pyrrhonians, or groer ort of Scepticks, who bring all certainty in quetion, and tartle even at the notions of Common ene, appear'd as aburd to him on the other ide; for there is a kind of poitivenes in granting nothing to be more likely on one part than on another, which his Academy avoided by inclining the ballance to that hand, where the mot weighty reaons, and probability of truth were viible. The Moral Philoophy therefore was his chiefet aym; becaue the principles of it admitted of les doubt; and
becaue they were mot conducing to the benefit of human life. For after the Example of Socrates he had found, that the peculations of Natural Philoophy, were more delightful than olid and profitable; that they were abtruce and thorny, and much of Sophim in the olution of appearances. That the Mathematicks indeed, cou'd reward his pains with many demontrations, but tho they made him wier, they made him not more vertuous, and therefore attain'd not the end of happines: For which reaon tho he had far advanc'd in that tudy, yet he made it but his Recreation, not his buines. Some Problem of it, was his uual divertiement at Supper, which he mingled alo with pleaant and more light dicoures. For he was no owr Philoopher; but pas'd his time as merrily as he cou'd,
with reference to vertue: He forgot not to be pleaant while he intructed; and entertain'd his friends with o much chearfulnes and good humour, that his learning was not naueous to them; neither were they affraid of his Company another time. He was not o Autere as to depie Riches, but being in poeion of a large Fortune, he liv'd tho not plendidly, yet plentifully; and uffer'd not his friends to want that part of his Etate, which he thought uperfluous to a Philoopher.

The Religion he profes'd, to peak the wore of it, was Heathen. I ay the Religion he profes'd; for 'tis no way probable, that o great a Philoopher, and o wie a Man, hould believe the Supertitions and Fopperies of Paganim: But that he accommodated himelf to the ue and receiv'd Cutomes of his Country.
He was indeed a Priet of Apollo, as himelf acknowledges, but that proves him not to have been a Polytheit.

I have ever thought, that the Wie-men in all Ages, have not much differ'd in their opinions of Religion; I mean as it is grounded on human Reaon: For Reaon, as as far as it is right, mut be the ame in all Men; and Truth being but one, they mut conequently think in the ame Train. Thus it is not to be doubted, but the Religion of Socrates, Plato, and Plutarch was not different in the main: Who doubtles beleiv'd the identity of one Supream Intellectual Being, which we call GOD. But becaue they who have written the Life of Plutarch in other languages, are contented barely to aert that our Authour believ'd one God, without quoting thoe paages of his
which wou'd clear the point; I will give you two of them, amongt many, in his Morals. The firt is in his Book of the Ceation of Oracles; where arguing againt the Stoicks (in behalf of the Platonits,) who diputed againt the plurality of Worlds with this Argument; That if there were many Worlds, how then cou'd it come to pas, that there was one only Fate, and one Providence to guide them all? (for it was granted by the Platonits that there was but one:) and why hould not many Jupiters or Gods be neceary, for Government of many Worlds? To this Plutarch anwers, That this their captious quetion was but trifling: For where is the neceity of uppoing many Jupiters, for this plurality of Worlds; when one excellent being, indued with mind and reaon, uch as he is, whom we acknowledge to be the Father and Lord of all things, is ufficient
to direct and Rule thee Worlds; whereas if there were more Supream Agents, their decrees mut till be the more aburd and contradictious to one another. I pretend not this paage to be Tranlated word for word, but 'tis the ence of the whole, tho the order of the Sentence be inverted. The other is more plain: 'Tis, in his Comment on the Word EI or thoe two Letters incrib'd on the Gates of the Temple at Delphos. Where having given the everal opinions concerning it, as firt that < in non-Latin alphabet > fignifies if, becaue all the quetions which were made to Apollo began with If; as uppoe they ask'd, if the Grecians hould overcome the Perians; if uch a Marriage hou'd come to to pas, &c. And afterwards that < in non-Latin alphabet > might ignifie thou art, as the econd peron of the preent tene of < in non-Latin alphabet > intimating thereby the being
or perpetuity of being belonging to Apollo, as a God; in the ame ene that God expres'd himelf to Moes, I am hath ent thee; Plutarch ubjoyns, (as inclining to this latter opinion) thee following words, < in non-Latin alphabet > ayes he, ignifies thou art one, for there are not many Deities; but only one. Continues, I mean not one in the aggregate ene, as we ay one Army, or one Body of Men, contituted of many individuals; but that which is, mut of neceity be one; and to be, implies to be One. One is that which is a imple being, uncompounded, or free from mixture: Therefore to be One in this ene, is only conitent with a Nature, pure in it elf, and not capable of alteration, or decay.

That he was no Chritian is manifet: Yet he is no where found to have poken with contumely of our Religion, like the other Writers of his Age, and thoe who ucceeded
him. Theodoret ays of him, that he had heard of our holy Gopel; and inerted many of our Sacred Myteries in his Works, which we may eaily believe, becaue the Chritian Churches were then pread in Greece; and Pliny the younger was at the ame time converant amongt them in Aia, tho that part of our Authors Workes is not now extant, from whence Theodoret might gather thoe paages. But we need not wonder that a Philoopher was not eaie to embrace the divine Myteries of our Faith. A modern God, as our Saviour was to him, was of hard digetion to a Man, who probably depis'd the vanities and fabulous Relations of all the old. Beides a Crucfy'd Saviour of Mankind, a Doctrine atteted by illiterate Diciples, the Author of it a Jew, whoe Nation at that time was depicable, and his Doctrine but an innovation among
that depis'd people, to which the Learned of his own Country gave no credit, and which the Magitrates of his Nation punih'd with an ignominious death; the Scene of his Miracles acted in an obcure Corner of the world; his being from Eternity, yet born in time, his Reurrection and Acenion, thee and many more particulars, might eaily choke the Faith of a Philoopher, who believ'd no more than what he cou'd deduce from the principles of Nature; and that too with a doubtful Academical aent, or rather an inclination to aent to probability: which he judg'd was wanting in this new Religion. Thee circumtances conider'd, tho they plead not an abolute invincible ignorance in his behalf, yet they amount at leat to a degree of it; for either he thought them not worth weighing, or rejected them when
weigh'd; and in both caes he mut of neceity be ignorant, becaue he cou'd not know without Revelation, and the Revelation was not to him. But leaving the Soul of Plutarch, with our Charitable wihes, to his Maker, we can only trace the ret of his opinions in Religion from his Philoophy: Which we have aid in the General to be Platonick; tho it cannot alo be denyed, that there was a tincture in it of the Electick Sect, which was begun by Potamon under the Empire of Augutus, and which elected from all the other Sects, what eem'd mot probable in their opinions, not adhering ingularly to any of them, nor rejecting every thing. I will only touch his belief of Spirits. In his two Treaties of Oracles, the one concerning the reaon of their Ceation, the other enquiring why they were not given in vere, as
in former times; he eems to aert the Pythagorean Doctrine of Tranmigration of Souls. We have formerly hewn, that he own'd the the Unity of a Godhead; whom according to his Attributes, he calls by everal names, as Jupiter from his Almighty Power, Apollo from his Widom, and o of the ret; but under him he places thoe beings whom he tyles Genii, or Daemons, of a middle nature, betwixt Divine and Human: for he thinks it abur'd that there hou'd be no mean betwixt the two extreams, of an Immortal and a Mortal Being: That there cannot be in nature o vat a flaw, without ome intermedial kind of life, partaking of them both; as therefore we find the intercoure betwixt the Soul and body, to be made by the Animal Spirits, o betwixt Divinity and humanity there is this pecies of Daemons:
Who, having firt been Men, and following the trict Rules of vertue had purg'd off the grones and faeculency of their earthly being, are exalted into thee Genii; and are from thence either rais'd higher into an Aetherial life, if they till continue vertuous, or tumbled down again into Mortal Bodies, and inking into fleh after they have lot that purity, which contituted their glorious being. And this ort of Genii, are thoe, who, as our Author imagines, preided over Oracles: Spirits which have o much of their terretrial principles remaining in them, as to be ubject to paions and inclinations; uually beneficent, ometimes Malevolent to Mankind, according as they refine themelves, or gather dros, and are declining into Mortal Bodies. The Ceation, or rather the decreae of Oracles, (for ome of them were till
remaing in Plutarchs time) he Attributes either to the death of thoe Daemons, as appears by the tory of the Egyptian Thamus, who was Commanded to declare that the great God Pan was dead, or to their foraking of thoe places, where they formerly gave out their Oracles; from whence they were driven by tronger Genii, into banihment for a certain Revolution of Ages. Of this lat nature, was the War of the Gyants againt the Gods, the dipoeion of Saturn by Jupiter, the banihment of Apollo from Heaven, the fall of Vulcan, and many others; all which according to our Authours, were the battles of thee Genii or Daemons amongt themelves. But uppoing, as Plutarch evidently does, that thee Spirits adminiter'd, under the Supream Being, the affairs of Men, taking care of the vertuous, punihing the
bad; and ometimes communicating with the bet, as particularly the Genius of Socrates, always warn'd him of approaching dangers, and taught him to avoyd them.

I cannot but wonder that every one, who has hitherto written Plutarchs Life, and particularly Rualdus, the mot knowing of them all, hould o confidently affirm that thee Oracles, were given by bad Spirits according to Plutarch: As Chritians, indeed we may think them o; but that Plutarch o thought, is a mot apparent falhood: 'Tis enough to convince a reaonable Man that our Author in his old age, (and that then he doted not, we may ee by the Treatie he has written, that old Men ought to have the management of publick Affairs) I ay that then he initiated himelf, in the Sacred Rities of Delphos; and dyed, for ought we know, Apollo's Priet.
Now it is not to be imagin'd, that he thought the God he erv'd a Cacodaemon, or as we call him a Devil. Nothing cou'd be farther from the opinion and practice of this holy Philoopher than o gros an impiety. The tory of the Pythias, or Prietes of Apollo, which he relates immediately before the ending of that Treatie, concerning the Ceation of Oracles, confirms my aertion, rather then hakes it: For 'tis there deliver'd, That going with great reluctation, into the Sacred place to be inpir'd; he came out, foaming at the mouth, her eyes gogling, her breat heaving, her voice unditinguihable, and hril, as if he had an Earthquake within her, labouring for vent; and in hort, that thus tormented with the God, whom he was not able to upport, he died ditracted in few dayes after. For he had ayd before,
that the Devineres ought to have no perturbations of mind, or impure paions at the time when he was to conult the Oracle, and if he had, he was no more fit to to be inpir'd, than an intrument untun'd, to render an harmonious ound: And he gives us to upect, by what he ays at the cloe of this Relation, That this Pythias had not liv'd Chatly for ome time before it. So that her death appears more like a punihment inflicted for looe living by ome holy power, than the meer malignancy of a Spirit delighted naturally in michief. There is another obervation which indeed comes nearer to their purpoe, which I will digres o far, as to relate, becaue it omewhat appertains to our own Country. There are many Ilands (ays he) which lie cattering about Britain, after the manner of our Sporades: They are unpeopled,
and ome of them are call'd the Ilands of the Heroes, or the Genii. One Demetrius was ent by the Emperour, (who by computation of the time mut either be Caligula or Claudius) to dicover thoe parts, and arriving at one of the Ilands next adjoyning to the foremention'd, which was inhabited by ome few Britains, (but thoe held Sacred and inviolable by all their Country-men,) immediatly after his arrival, the air grew black and troubled, trange Apparitions were een, the winds rais'd a Tempet, and fiery pouts or Whirlwinds appear'd dancing towards the Earth. When thee prodigies were ceas'd the Ilanders inform'd him, that ome one of the aerial Beings, uperior to our Nature, then ceas'd to live. For as a Taper while yet burning, affords a pleaant harmles light, but is noyome and offenive when extinguih'd,
o thoe Hero's hine benignly on us, and do us good, but at their death turn all things topie turvy, raie up tempets, and infect the air with petilential vapours. By thoe holy and inviolable men, there is no quetion but he means our Druydes, who were nearet to the Pythagoreans of any Sect; and this opinion of the Genii might probably be one of theirs: Yet it proves not that all Daemons were thus malicious; only thoe who were to be Condemn'd hereafter into human bodies, for their midemeanours in their aerial Being. But 'tis time to leave a ubject, o very fanciful, and o little reaonable as this: I am apt to imagine the natural vapours, ariing in the Cave where the Temple afterwards was Built, might work upon the Spirits of thoe who enter'd the holy place, as they did on the Shaphard Coretas, who firt found
it out by accident; and encline them to Enthuiam and prophetick madnes. That as the trength of thoe vapours diminih'd, (which were generally in Caverns as that of Mopus, of Trophonius, and this of Delphos,) o the inpiration decrea'd by the ame meaures: That they happen'd to be tronger, when they kill'd the Pythias, who being concious of this, was o unwilling to enter. That the Oracles ceas'd to be given in Vere, when Poets ceas'd to be the Priets, and that the Genius of Socrates, (whom he confes'd never to have een, but only to have heard inwardly, and unperceiv'd by others,) was no more than the trength of his imagination; or to peak in the Language of a Chritian Platonit, his Guardian Angel.

I pretend not to an exactnes of method in this Life, which I am
forc'd to collect by patches from everal Authors; and therefore without much regard to the connection of times which are o uncertain.

I will in the next place peak of his Marriage. His Wifes name, her Parentage, and Dowry are no where mention'd by him, or any other, nor in what part of his age he Married: Tho 'tis probable, in the flower of it: But Rualdus has ingeniouly gather'd from a convincing circumtance, that he was called Timoxena: Becaue Plutarch in a Conolatory Letter to her, occaion'd by the Death of their Daughter in her Infancy, ues thee words: Your Timoxena is depriv'd (by death) of mall enjoyments; for the things he knew were of mall moment, and he cou'd be delighted only with triffles. Now it appears by the Letter, that the Name of this Daughter was the ame with her Mothers, therefore
it cou'd be no other than Timoxena. Her knowledge, her conjugal vertues, her abhorrency from the vanities of her Sex, and from upertition, her gravity in behaviour and her contancy in upporting the los of Children, are likewie Celebrated by our Author. No other wife of Plutarch is found mention'd; and therefore we may conclude he he had no more: By the ame reaon for which we Judge that he had no other Mater than Ammonius, becaue 'tis evident he was o grateful in his nature, that he would have preerv'd their Memory.

The number of his Children was at leat five; o many being mention'd by him. Four of them were Sons; of the other Sex only Timoxena, who died at two years old, as is manifet from the Epitle abovemention'd. The French Tranlater Amiot, from whom our old
Englih Tranlation of the Lives was made, uppoes him to have had another Daughter, where he peaks of his Son-in-Law Crato. But the word < in non-Latin alphabet > , which Plutarch there ues, is of a larger ignification; for it may as well be expounded Father-in-law, his Wifes Brother, or his Siters Husband, as Budaeus notes: This I the rather mention, becaue the ame Amiot is task'd for an infinite number of mitakes, by his own Country-men of the preent Age; which is enough to recommend this Tranlation of our Authour into the Englih tongue, being not from any Copy, but from the Greek Original. Two other Sons of Plutarch were already deceas'd, before Timoxena. Hs eldet Autobulus, mention'd in his Sympoiaques, and another whoe Name is not Recorded. The younget was called Charon, who alo dyed in his Infancy: The
two remaining are uppos'd to have urviv'd him. The Name of one was Plutarch, after his own; and that of the other Lamprias, o call'd in memory of his Grand-father. This was he, of all his Children, who eems to have inherited his Fathers Philoophy: And to him we owe the Table or Catalogue of Plutarchs Writings, and perhaps alo the Apothegms. His Nephew, but whether by his Brother or Siter remains uncertain, was Sextus Chaeroneus, who was much honour'd by that learned Emperour Marcus Aurelius, and who taught him the Greek tongue, and the principles of Philoophy: This Emperour profeing Stoicim, (as appears by his Writings,) inclines us to believe, that our Sextus Chaeroneus, was of the Stoick Sect; and conequently, that the World has generally been mitaken, in uppoing him to have been the ame man
with Sextus Empiricus the Sceptick; whom Suidas plainly tells us to have been an African: Now Empiricus cou'd not but be a Sceptick, for he oppoes all Dogmatits, and particularly them. But I heard it firt oberv'd by an ingenious and Learned old Gentleman lately decea'd, that many of Mr. Hobbs his eeming new opinions, are gather'd from thoe which Sextus Empiricus expos'd. The Book is extant, and I refer the curious to it, not pretending to arraign, or to excue him. Some think the Famous Critick Longinus was of Plutarchs Family, decended from a Siter of his; but the proofs are o weak, that I will not inert them: They may both of them rely on their proper merits; and tand not in want of a Relation to each other. Tis needles to init on his behaviour in his Family: His Love to his Wife, his Indulgence to his
Children, his care of their Education are all manifet in that part of his Works which is call'd his Morals. Other parts of his dipoition have been touch'd already; as that he was courteous and humane to all Men; free from incontancy, anger, and the deire of revenge; which qualities of his, as they have been prais'd by the Authority of other Writers, may alo be recommended from his own Tetimony of himelf. I had rather, ays he, be forgotten in the memory of Men, and that it hou'd be aid, there neither is, nor was a Man call'd Plutarch, then that they hould report, this Plutarch was uncontant, changeable in his temper, prone to anger and revenge on the leat occaions. What he was to his Slaves you may believe from this, that in general he accues thoe Maters of extream hardnes and injutice, who ue Men like Oxen;
ell them in their age when they can drudge no longer. A Man ays he, of a merciful dipoition, ought not to retrench the fodder from his Cattle, nor the provender from his Hores when they can work no longer, but to cherih them when worn out and old. Yet Plutarch, tho he knew how to moderate his anger, was not on the contrary, ubject to an inenibility of wrongs; not o remis in exacting duty, or o tame in uffering the diobedience of his Servants, that he cou'd not correct when they deerv'd it: As is manifet from the following tory, which Aulus Gellius had from the mouth of Taurus the Philoopher concerning him. Plutarch had a certain Slave, a aucy tubborn kind of fellow; in a word, one of thoe pragmatical Servants, who never make a fault, but they give a reaon for it; his jutifications one time wou'd not erve his turn, but his Mater commanded
him to be trip'd; and that the Law hould be laid on his backide. He no ooner felt the mart, but he mutter'd that he was unjutly punih'd, and that he had done nothing to deerve the Scourge. At lat he began to bawl out lowder; and, leaving off his groaning, his ighs and, his lamentations, to argue the matter with more hew of reaon: And, as under uch a Mater, he mut needs have gain'd a mattering of learning, he cryd out that Plutarch was not the Philoopher he pretended himelf to be, That he had heard him waging War againt all the paions; and maintaining that anger was unbecoming a wie Man: Nay, that he had written a particular Treatie, in commendation of Clemency. That therefore he contradicted his precepts by his practies, ince abandoning himelf over to his Choler, he exercis'd uch inhumane cruelty on the body of his fellow Creature. How's
this, (Mr. Varlet,) anwered Plutarch, by what ignes and tokens, can you prove I am in paion? Is it by my Countenance, my voice, the colour of my face, by my words, or by my getures, that you have dicover'd this my fury? I am not of opinion, that my eyes parkle, that I foam at mouth, that I gnah my teeth, or that my voice is more vehement, or that my colour is either more pale or more red than at other times; that I either hake or tamp with madnes, that I ay or do any thing unbecoming a Philoopher: Thee, if you know them not, are the Symptoms of a Man in rage: In the mean (turning to the Officer who courg'd him) while he and I dipute this matter, mind you your buines on his back.

His love to his Friends and his gratitude to his Benefactors are every where obervable, in his dedications of his everal Works, and
the particular Treaties he has written to them on everal occaions, are all uitable either to the characters of the Men, or to their preent condition, and the circumtances under which they were. His love to his Country, is from hence conpicuous, that he profees to have written the Life of Lucullus, and to have preerv'd the memory of his actions, becaue of the favours he conferr'd on the City of Chaeronea; which tho his Country receiv'd o long before, yet he thought it appertain'd to him to repay them, and took an interet in their acknowledgment. As alo that he vindicated the Baeotians from the calumnies of Herodotus the Hitorian in his Book concerning the malignity of that Author. In which tis obervable, that his zeal to his Country tranported him too far; for Herodotus
had aid no more of them, than what was generally held to be true in all Ages, concerning the grones of their wits, their voracity, and thoe other national vices, which we have already noted on this account; therefore Petrarch has accus'd our Authour of the ame malignity, for which he tax'd Herodotus: But they may both tand acquitted, on different accounts: Herodotus for having given a true Character of the Thebans, and Plutarch for endeavouring to palliate the vices of a people from whom he was decended. The ret of his manners without entering into particulars, were unblameable, if we excue a little pronenes to upertition: And regulating his actions by his dreams: But how far this will bear an accuation I determine not, tho Tully has endeavour'd to hew the vanity of Dreams, in his
Treatie of Divinations, whether I refer the curious.

On what occaion he repair'd to Rome; at what time of his age he came thither; how long he dwelt there; how often he was there, and in what year he return'd to his own Country, are all uncertain: This we know, that when Nero was in Greece, which was in his eleventh and twelfth years, our Author was at Delphos, under Ammonius, his Mater; as appears by the diputation then manag'd, concerning the Incription of the two letters E. I. Nero not living long afterwards, 'tis almot indiputable that he came not to Rome in all his Reign. 'Tis improbable that he wou'd undertake the Voyage during the troubleome times of Galba, Otho and Vitellius; and we are not certain that he liv'd in Rome in the Empire of Vepatian: Yet we may gues that
the mildnes of this Emperours Dominion, his fame and the vertues of his Son Titus aum'd into the Empire afterwards by his Father, might induce Plutarch, amongt other coniderations, to take this Journy in his time. Tis argu'd from the following tory, related by himelf; that he was at Rome either in the joynt Reign of the two Vepatians, or at leat in that of the urvivour Titus. He ays then, in his lat Book concerning Curioity. Reaoning, or rather reading once, at Rome, Arulenus Ruticus, the ame Man whom afterwards Domitian put to death out of envy to his Glory, tood hearkning to me amongt my Auditors: It o happen'd, that a Souldier, having Letters for him, from the Emperour, (who was either Titus or his Father Vepatian, as Rualdus thinks) broke through the crowd, to deliver him
thoe Letters from the Emperour. Oberving this, I made a paue in my diertation, that Ruticus might have the leiure to read the Mandate which was ent him; but he abolutly refus'd to do it, neither wou'd he be intreated to break the Seals till I had wholly made an end of my Speech, and dimis'd the Company. Now I uppoe the tres of the Argument, to prove that this Emperour was not Domitian, lies only in this claue (whom Domitian afterwards put to death:) but I think it rather leaves it doubtful, for they might be Domitians Letters which he then receiv'd, and conequently he might not come to Rome till the Reign of that Emperour. This Ruticus was not only a learned but a good Man: He had been Tribune of the people under Nero, was Praetor in the time of Vitellius, and ent Ambaadour
to the Forces, rais'd under the Name of Vepatian, to perwade them to a peace. What Offices he bore afterwards we know not, but the caue of his death, beides the envy of Domitian to his fame, was a certain Book, or ome Commentaries of his, wherein he had prais'd too much the Sanctity of Thraea Paetus whom Nero had Murther'd: And the praie of a good Citizen was inupportable to the Tyrant; being, I uppoe, exaperated farther by ome reflections of Ruticus, who could not commend Thraea, but at the ame time he mut inveigh againt the oppreour of the Roman Liberty. That Plutarch was Married in his own Country, and that before he came to Rome is probable; that the fame of him was come before him, by reaon of ome part of his works already publih'd, is alo credible, becaue he had o great reort of the
Roman Nobility, to hear him read immediately, as we believe, upon his coming: That he was invited thither by the correpondence he had with Soius Senecio, might be one reaon of his undertaking that Journey, is almot undeniable. It likewie appears he was divers times at Rome; and perhaps, before he came to inhabit there, might make acquaintance with this worthy Man Senecio, to whom he Dedicated almot all thee Lives of Greeks and Romans. I ay almot all, becaue one of them, namely that of Aratus, is incrib'd in mot expres words to Polycrates the Sicyonian the great Grand-Son of the aid Aratus. This worthy Patron and friend of Plutarch, Senecio, was four times Conul; the firt time in the hort Reign of Cocceius Nerva, a vertuous and a learned Emperour; which opinion I rather follow than that of Aurelius
Caicdorus, who puts back his Conulhip into the lat of Domitian, becaue it is not probable that vitious Tyrant hould exalt to that Dignity a Man of Vertue. This year falls in with the year of Chritninty nine.

But the great inducement of our Authour to this journy was certainly, the deire he had to lay in materials for his Roman Lives; that was the deign which he had form'd early, and on which he had reolv'd to build his fame. Accordingly we have oberv'd that he had travell'd over Greece to perue the Archives of every City; that he might be able to write properly, not only the Lives of his Grecian Worthyes, but the Laws, the Cutoms, the Rites, and Ceremonies of every place. Which that he might treat with the ame Matery of skill, when he came to draw his Parallels
of the Romans he took the invitation of his friends, and particularly of our Soius Senecio to viit this Mitres of the World, this imperial City of Rome; and, by the favour of many great and learned men then living, to earch the Records of the Capitol, and the Libraries, which might furnih him with intruments for o noble an undertaking. But that this may not eem to be my own bare opinion, or that of any modern Author, whom I follow, Plutarch himelf has deliver'd it as his motive, in the life of Demothenes: The words are thee, Whooever deigns to write an Hitory, (which tis impoible to form to any excellency from thofe materials, that are ready at hand, or to take from common report, while he its lazily at home in his own Study, but mut of neceity be gather'd from Forreign obervations
and the catter'd writings of various Authours) it concerns him to take up his Habitation in ome renoun'd and populous City, where he may Command all orts of Books, and be acquainted alo with uch particulars as have ecap'd the pens of Writers, and are only extant in the memories of Men. Let him inquire diligently, and weigh judiciouly, what he hears and reads, let he publih a lame Work, and be detitute of thoe helps which are requir'd to its perfection. Tis then mot probable, that he pas'd his days at Rome, either in reading Philoophy of all kinds, to the Roman Nobility, who frequented his Houe, and heard him, as if there were omewhat more than humane in his words; and his nights (which were his only hours of private Study) in earching and examining Records,
concerning Rome. Not but that he was intruted alo with the management of publick affairs in the Empire, during his reidence in the Metropolis: Which may be made out by what Suidas relates of him. Plutarch (ays he) liv'd in the time of Trajan, and alo before his Reign: That Emperour betow'd on him the Dignity of Conul, (tho the Greek, I uppoe, will bear, that he made him Conul with himelf, at leat tranferr'd that honour on him:) An Edict was alo made in favour of him, that the Magitrates or Officers of Illyria hould do nothing in that Province without the knowledge and approbation of Plutarch. Now 'tis my particular gues (for I have not read it any where) that Plutarch had the affairs of Illyria (now call'd Sclavonia) recommended to him, becaue Trajan, we know, had Wars on that ide the Empire with Decebalus
King of Dacia; after whoe defeat and death, the Province of Illyria might tand in need of Plutarchs Widom to compoe and civilize it: But this is only hinted, as what poibly might be the reaon of our Philoophers uperintendency in thoe quarters; which the French Author of his Life, eems to wonder at, as having no relation either to Chaeronea, or Greece.

When he was firt made known to Trajan is like the ret uncertain, or by what means, whether by Senecio, or any other, he was introduc'd to his acquaintance: But 'tis mot likely, that Trajan then a private Man, was one of his Auditors, amongt others of the Nobility of Rome. Tis alo thought, this wie Emperour made ue of him in all his Councils, and that the happines which attended him in his undertakings, together with the adminitration
of the Government, which in all his Reign was jut and regular, proceeded from the intructions which were given him by Plutarch. Johannes Sarisberienis, who liv'd above ix hundred years ago, has trancrib'd a Letter written, as he uppos'd, by our Author to that Emperour; whence he had it is not known, nor the original in Greek to be produc'd; but it pas'd for Genuine in that age, and if not Plutarchs, is at leat worthy of him, and what might well be uppos'd a Man of his Character would write; for which reaon I have here Tranlated it.

body.head: Plutarch to Trajan.
body.p:
I Am atisfied that your modety ought not the Empire, which yet you have always tudied to deerve by the excellency of your manners. And
by o much the more are you eteem'd worthy of this honour, by how much you are free from the Ambition of deiring it. I therefore congratulate both your vertue, and my own good fortune, if at leat your future Government hall prove anwerable to your former merit: Otherwie you have involv'd your elf in dangers, and I hall infallibly be ubject to the Cenures of detracting Tongues; becaue Rome will never upport an Emperour unworthy of her, and the faults of the Scholar will be upbraided to the Mater. Thus Seneca is reproach'd, and his fame till uffers for the Vices of Nero. The micarriages of Quintilians Scholars, have been thrown on him, and even Socrates himelf is not free from the imputation of remines on the account of his Pupil (Alcibiades.) But you will certainly adminiter all things as becomes you, if you till continue what you are, if you recede not from
your elf, if you begin at home, and lay the foundation of Government on the command of your own paions, if you make vertue the cope of all your actions, they will all proceed in harmony and order: I have et before you the force of Laws and Civil contitutions of your Predeceours; which if you imitate and obey, Plutarch is then your Guide of living; if otherwie, let this preent Letter be my Tetimony againt you, that you hall not ruine the Roman Empire, under the pretence of the Counel and Authority of Plutarch.

div.p:
It may be conjectur'd, and with ome hew of probability, from hence, that our Author not only collected his materials, but alo made a rough draught of many of thee parallel Lives at Rome; and that he read them to Trajan for his intruction in Government; and o
much the rather I believe it, becaue all Hitorians agree, that this Emperour, tho naturally prudent and inclin'd to vertue, had more of the Souldier than the Scholar in his Education, before he had the happines to know Plutarch; for which reaon the Roman Lives, and the inpection into ancient Laws might be of neceary ue to his direction. And now for the time of our Authors abode in the Imperial City, if he came o early as Vepatian, and departed not till after Trajan's death, as is generally thought, he might continue in Italy near forty years. This is more certain, becaue gather'd from himelf, that his Lives were almot the latet of his Works; and therefore we may well conclude, that having model'd, but not finih'd them at Rome, he afterwards reum'd the work in his own Country; which perfecting in his old
age, he dedicated to his friend Senecio till living, as appears by what he has written, in the Proem to his Lives.

The deire of viiting his own Country, o natural to all Men, and the approaches of old age, (for he could not be much les than ixty,) and perhaps alo the death of Trajan, prevail'd with him at lat to leave Italy; or if you will have it in his own words, he was not willing his little City, hou'd be one the les by his abence: After his return he was, by the unanimous conent of his Citizens, choen Archon, or Chief Magitrate of Chaeronea; and not long after admitted himelf in the number of Apollo's Priets; in both which employments he eems to have continued till his death: Of which we have no particular account, either as to the manner of it, or the year; only tis evident that he liv'd
