to a great old age, always continuing his Studies; that he dyed a natural death, is only preum'd, becaue any violent accident to o famous a Man would have been recorded: And in whatoever Reign he deceas'd, the days of Tyranny were overpas'd, and there was then a Golden Series of Emperours, every one emulating his Predeceours vertues.

Thus I have Collected from Plutarch himelf, and from the bet Authors, what was mot remarkable concerning him. In performing which I have labour'd under o many uncertainties, that I have not been able to atisfie my own curioity, any more than that of others. 'Tis the Life of a Philoopher, not varyed with accidents to divert the Reader: More pleaant for himelf to live, than for an Hitorian, to decribe. Thoe Works of his, which
are irrecoverably lot, are nam'd in the Catalogue made by his Son Lamprias, which you will find in the Paris Edition, dedicated to King Lewis the thirteenth: But 'tis a mall comfort to a Merchant, to perue his bill of fraight, when he is certain his Ship is cat away: Mov'd by the like reaon I have omitted that ungrateful task: Yet that the Reader may not be impos'd on, in thoe which yet remain, tis but reaonable to let him know, that the Lives of Hannibal and Scipio, tho they pas with the ignorant for Genuine, are only the Forgery of Donato Acciaiolo a Florentine. He pretends to have Tranlated them from a Greek Manucript, which none of the Learned have ever een, either before or ince. But the cheat is more manifet from this reaon which is undeniable, that Plutarch did indeed write the Life of Scipio, but he compar'd
him not with Hannibal, but with Epaminondas: As appears by the Catalogue, or Nomenclature of Plutarchs Lifes, drawn up by his Son Lamprias, and yet extant. But to make this out more clearly, we find the Florentine, in his Life of Hannibal, thus relating, the famous Conference betwixt Scipio and him. Scipio at that time being ent Ambaadour from the Romans, to King Antiochus, with Publius Villius: It happen'd then, that thee two great Captains met together at Epheus, and amongt other dicoure, it was demanded of Hannibal by Scipio, whom he thought to have been the greatet Captain? To whom he thus anwer'd; In the firt place Alexander of Macedon, in the econd Pyrrhus of Epyrus, and in the third himelf: To which, Scipio mileing thus rereply'd; And what wou'd you have thought, had it been your fortune
to have vanquih'd me? to whom Hannibal, I hould then have adjudg'd the firt place to my elf: Which anwer was not a little pleaing to Scipio, becaue by it, he found himelf not dieteem'd, nor put into comparion with the ret, but by the delicacy and gallantry of a well turn'd compliment, et like a Man divine above them all.

Now this relation is a meer compendium of the ame conference, from Livy. But if we can conceive Plutarch to have written the Life of Hannibal, tis hard to believe, that he hould tell the ame tory after o different, or rather o contrary a manner, in another place. For, in the life of Pyrrhus, he thus writes. Hannibal adjudg'd the praeeminence to Pyrrhus above all Captains, in conduct, and Military skill: Next to Pyrrhus he plac'd Scipio, and after Scipio, himelf; as we have
declar'd in the Life of Scipio. Tis not that I wou'd excue Plutarch, as if he never related the ame thing diverely; for 'tis evident, that through want of advertency he has been often guilty of that errour; of which the Reader will find too frequent Examples in thee Lives; but in this place, he cannot be charg'd with want of memory or care, becaue what he ays here is relating to what he had aid formerly: So that he may mitake the tory, as I believe he has done, (that other of Livy, being much more probable,) but we mut allow him to remember what he had before written. From hence I might take occaion to note ome other lapes of our Author, which yet amount not to falification of truth, much les to partiality, or envy, (both which are manifet in his Country-man Dion Caius who writ not long after him,) but are only
the frailties of humane nature; mitakes not intentional, but accidental. He was not altogether o well vers'd either in the Roman language, or in their coyns, or in the value of them; in ome Cutomes, Rites, and Ceremonies, he took paages on trut from others, relating both to them and the Barbarians, which the Reader may particularly find recited in the Animadverions of the often prais'd Rualdus on our Author. I will name but one to avoyd tediounes, becaue I particularly oberv'd it, when I read Plutarch in the Library of Trinity Colledge in Cambridge, (to which foundation I gratefully acknowledge a great part of my Education;) 'tis that Plutarch in the life of Cicero, peaking of Verres, who was accus'd by him, and repeating a mierable jeat of Tullys, ays that Verres, in the Roman language, ignifies a barrow
Pig, that is one which has been guelded. But we have a better account of the ignification from Varro, whom we have more reaon to believe, that the Male of that kind, before he is cut, is called Verres; after cutting Majalis, which is perhaps a diminitive of Mas, tho generally the reaon of the Etymology is given from its being a Sacrifice to the Goddes Maja. Yet any Man, who will candidly weigh this and the like errours, may excue Plutarch, as he wou'd a tranger, mitaking the propriety of an Englih word: And beides the humanity of this excue, 'tis impoible in nature, that a Man of o various learning, and o covetous of ingroing all, hould perfectly diget uch an infinity of notions in many Sciences, ince to be excellent in one is o great a labour.

It may now be expected, that having written the Life of an Hitorian,
I hould take occaion to write omewhat concerning Hitory it elf: But I think to commend it is unneceary: For the profit and pleaure of that tudy are both o very obvious, that a quick Reader will be before hand with me, and imagine fater than I can write. Beides that the pot is taken up already, and few Authors have travell'd this way, but who have trewed it with Rhetorick, as they pas'd. For my own part, who mut confes it to my hame, that I never read any thing but for pleaure, it has alwayes been the mot delightful Entertainment of my life. But they who have employ'd the tudy of it as they ought, for their intruction, for the regulation of their private manners, and the management of publick affairs, mut agree with me, that it is the mot pleaant School of Widom.

Tis a familiarity with pat Ages, and an acquaintance with all the Heroes of them. 'Tis, if you will pardon the imilitude, a Propective-Glas carrying your Soul to a vat ditance, and taking in the farthet objects of Antiquity. It informs the undertanding by the memory: It helps us to judge of what will happen, by hewing us the like revolutions of former times. For Mankind being the ame in all ages, agitated by the ame paions, and mov'd to action by the ame interets, nothing can come to pas, but ome Preident of the like nature has already been produc'd, o that having the caues before our eyes, we cannot eaily be deceiv'd in the effects, if we have Judgment enough but to draw the parallel.

God, tis true with his divine Providence, over-rules and guides all actions to the ecret end he has ordain'd
them; but in the way of humane caues, a wie Man may eaily dicern, that there is a natural connection betwixt them; and tho he cannot foreee accidents, or all things that poibly can come, he may apply examples, and by them foretell, that from the like Counels will probably ucceed the like events: And thereby in all concernments, and all Offices of life, be intructed in the two main points, on which depend our happines, that is, what to avoid and what to chooe. The Laws of Hitory in general are truth of matter, method, and clearnes of expreion. The firt propriety is neceary to keep our undertanding from the impoitions of falhood: For Hitory is an Argument fram'd from many particular examples, or inductions: If thee Examples are not true, then thoe meaures of life, which we take from
them, will be fale, and deceive us in their conequence: The econd is grounded on the former, for if the method be confus'd: if the words or expreions of thought are any way obcure, then the Idea's which we receive mut be imperfect; and if uch, we are not taught by them what to elect, or what to hun. Truth therefore is requir'd, as the foundation of Hitory, to inform us; dipoition and perpicuity, as the manner to inform us plainly: One is the being, the other the wellbeing of it. Hitory is principally divided into thee three pecies. Commentaries or Annals; Hitory properly o called; and Biographia, or the Lives of particular Men.

Commentaries or Annals are (as I may o call them) naked Hitory: Or the plain relation of matter of fact, according to the ucceion of time, deveted of all other Ornaments.
The prings and motives of actions are not here ought, unles they offer themelves, and are open to every Mans dicernment. The method is the mot natural that can be imagin'd, depending only on the obervation of months and years, and drawing, in the order of them, whatoever happen'd worthy of Relation. The tile is eaie, imple, unforc'd, and unadorn'd with the pomp of figures; Counels, guees, politick obervations, entences, and Orations are avoyded: In few words a bare Narration is its buines. Of this kind the Commentaries of Caear are certainly the mot admirable; and after him the Annals of Tacitus may have place. Nay even the Prince of Greek Hitorians, Thucydides, may almot be adopted into the number. For tho he intructs every where by Sentences, tho he gives the caues of
actions, the Counels of both parties, and makes Orations where they are neceary; yet it is certain, that he firt deign'd his work a Commentary; every year writing down like an unconcern'd pectator as he was, the particular occurrences of the time, in the order as they happen'd, and his Eighth book is wholly written after the way of Annals; tho, out-living the War, he inerted in his others thoe Ornaments, which render his work the mot compleat, and mot intructive now extant.

Hitory properly o call'd may be decrib'd by the addition of thoe parts, which are not requir'd to Annals: And therefore there is little farther to be aid concerning it: Only that the dignity and gravity of tile is here neceary. That the guees of ecret caues, inducing to the actions, be drawn at leat
from the mot probable circumtances, not perverted by the malignity of the Author to initer interpretations, (of which Tacitus is accus'd;) but candidly laid down, and left to the Judgment of the Reader. That nothing of concernment be omitted, but things of trivial moment are till to be neglected, as debaing the Majety of the Work. That neither partiality or prejudice appear: But that truth may every where be Sacred, (ne quid fali dicere audeat, ne quid veri non audeat Hitoricus.) That he neither incline to upertition, in giving too much credit to Oracles, Prophecies, Divinations, and Prodigies; nor to irreligion, in diclaiming the Almighty Providence: But where general opinion has prevail'd of any miraculous accident or portent, he ought to relate it as uch, without impoing his opinion on our belief. Next to Thucydides
in this kind, may be accounted Polybius amongt the Grecians; Livy, tho not free from upertition, nor Tacitus from ill nature, amongt the Romans: Amongt the modern Italians, Guicchiardine, and D'Avila, if not partial; but above all Men in my opinion, the plain, incere, unaffected, and mot intructive Philip de Commines amongt the French; tho he only gives his Hitory the humble Name of Commentaries. I am orry I cannot find in our own Nation (tho it has produc'd ome commendable Hitorians) any proper to be ranked with thee. Buchanan indeed for the purity of his Latin, and for his learning, and for all other endowments belonging to an Hitorian, might be plac'd amongt the greatet, if he had not too much lean'd to prejudice, and too manifety declar'd himelf aparty of a
caue, rather than an Hitorian o it. Excepting only that, (which I deire not to urge too far, on o great a Man, but only to give caution to his Readers concerning it,) our Ile may jutly boat in him, a Writer comparable to any of the Moderns, and excell'd by few of the Ancients.

Biographia, or the Hitory of particular Mens Lives, comes next to be conider'd; which in dignity is inferiour to the other two; as being more confin'd in action, and treating of Wars and Counels, and all other publick affairs of Nations, only as they relate to him, whoe Life is written, or as his fortunes have a particular dependance on them, or connection to them: All things here are circumcrib'd, and driven to a point, o as to terminate in one: Conequently if the action, or Counel were manag'd by Collegues,
ome part of it mut be either lame or wanting; except it be upply'd by the Excurion of the Writer: Herein likewie mut be les of variety for the ame reaon; becaue the fortunes and actions of one Man are related, not thoe of many. Thus the actions and atchievements of Sylla, Lucullus, and Pompey are all of them but the ucceive parts of the Mithridatick War: Of which we cou'd have no perfect image, if the ame hand had not given us the whole, tho at everal views, in their particular Lives.

Yet, tho we allow, for the reaons above alledg'd, that this kind of writing is in dignity inferiour to Hitory and Annalls, in pleaure and intruction it equals, or even excells both of them. 'Tis not only commended by ancient practice, to celebrate the memory of great and worthy Men, as the bet thanks
which Poterity can pay them; but alo the examples of vertue are of more vigor, when they are thus contracted into individuals. As the Sun beams, united in a burning-glas to a point, have greater, force than when they are darted from a plain uperficies; o the vertues and actions of one Man, drawn together into a ingle tory, trike upon our minds a tronger and more lively impreion, than the catter'd Relations of many Men, and many actions; and by the ame means that they give us pleaure they afford us profit too. For when the undertanding is intent and fix'd on a ingle thing, it carries cloer to the mark, every part of the object inks into it, and the Soul receives it unmixt and whole. For this reaon Aritotle Commends the unity of action in a Poem; becaue the mind is not capable of
digeting many things at once, nor of conceiving fully any more than one Idea at a time. Whatoever ditracts the pleaure, leens it. And as the Reader is more concern'd at one Mans fortune, than thoe of many; o likewie the Writer is more capable of making a perfect Work, if he confine himelf to this narrow compas. The lineaments, features, and colourings of a ingle picture may be hit exactly; but in a Hitory-piece of many figures, the general deign, the ordinance or dipoition of it, the Relation of one figure to another, the diverity of the poture, habits, hadowings, and all the other graces conpiring to an uniformity, are of o difficult performance, that neither is the reemblance of particular perons often perfect, nor the beauty of the piece compleat: For any coniderable errour in the parts, renders the
whole diagreeable and lame. Thus then the perfection of the Work, and the benefit ariing from it are both more abolute in Biography than in Hitory: All Hitory is only the precepts of Moral Philoophy reduc'd into Examples: Moral Philoophy is divided into two parts, Ethicks and Politicks; the firt intructs us in our private offices of vertue; the econd in thoe which relate to the management of the Common-wealth. Both of thee teach by Argumentation and reaoning: Which ruh as it were into the mind, and poes it with violence: But Hitory rather allures than forces us to vertue. There is nothing of the Tyrant in Example; but it gently glides into us, is eaie and pleaant in its paage, and in one word reduces into practie, our peculative notions. Therefore the more powerful the Examples are,
they are the more ueful alo: And by being more known they are more powerful. Now unity, which is defin'd is in its own nature more apt to be undertood, than multiplicity, which in ome meaure participates of infinity. The reaon is Aritotles.

Biographia, or the Hitories of particular Lives, tho circumcrib'd in the ubject, is yet more extenive in the tile than the other two: For it not only comprehends them both, but has omewhat uperadded, which neither of them have. The tile of it is various, according to the occaion. There are proper places in it, for the plainnes and nakednes of narration, which is acrib'd to Annals; there is alo room reerv'd for the loftines and gravity of general Hitory, when the actions related hall require that manner of expreion. But
there is withal, a decent into minute circumtances, and trivial paages of life, which are natural to this way of writing, and which the dignity of the other two will not admit. There you are conducted only into the rooms of tate; here you are led into the private Lodgings of the Heroe: you ee him in his undres, and are made Familiar with his mot private actions and converations. You may behold a Scipio and a Lelius gathering Cockle-hells on the hore, Augutus playing at bounding tones with Boyes; and Ageilaus riding on a Hobby-hore among his Children. The Pageantry of Life is taken away; you ee the poor reaonable Animal, as naked as ever nature made him; are made acquainted with his paions and his follies, and find the Demy-God a Man. Plutarch himelf, has more than
once defended this kind of Relating little paages. For in the Life of Alexander he ays thus. In writing the Lives of Illutrious Men I am not tyed to the Laws of Hitory: Nor does it follow, that becaue an action is great, it therefore manifets the greatnes and vertue of him who did it; but on the other ide ometimes a word, or a caual jet, betrays a Man more to our knowledge of him, than a Battel fought wherein ten thouand Men were lain, or acking of Cities, or a coure of Victories. In another place he quotes Xenophon on the like occaion: The ayings of great Men, in their familiar dicoures and amidt their Wine, have omewhat in them, which is worthy to be tranmitted to Poterity. Our Author therefore needs no excue, but rather deerves a commendation, when he relates, as pleaant, ome ayings of his Heroes, which appear, (I mut confes
it) very cold and inipid mirth to us. For 'tis not his meaning to commend the jet, but to paint the Man; beides, we may have lot omewhat of the Idiotim of that Language in which it was poken; and where the conceit is couch'd in a ingle word, if all the ignifications of it are not critically undertood, the grace and the pleaantry are lot. But in all parts of Biography, whether familiar or tately, whether ublime, or low, whether erious or merry, Plutarch equally excell'd: If we compare him to others, Dion Caius is not o incere, Herodian, a lover of truth, is often times deceiv'd himelf, with what he had fally heard reported; then the time of his Emperours exceeds not in all above ixty years; o that his whole Hitory will carce amount to three Lives of Plutarch. Suetonius and Tacitus may be call'd
alike, either Authors of Hitories, or Writers of Lives: But the firt of them runs too willingly into obcene decriptions, which he teaches while he relates; the other beides what has already been noted by him, often falls into obcurity; and both of them have made o unlucky a choice of times, that they are forc'd to decribe rather Monters than Men; and their Emperours are either extravagant Fools, or Tyrants, and mot uually both. Our Author on the contrary, as he was more inclin'd to commend than to dipraie, has generally choen uch great Men as were famous for their everal vertues; at leat uch whoe frailties or vices were over-pois'd by their excellencies; uch from whoe Examples we may have more to follow than to hun. Yet, as he was impartial, he diguis'd not the faults of any Man. An
Example of which is in the Life of Lucullus; where, after he has told us, that the double benefit which his Country-men, the Chaeroneans, receiv'd from him, was the chiefet motive which he had to write his Life, he afterwards rips up his Luxury, and hews how he lot, through his mi-management, his Authority, and his Souldiers love. Then he was more happy in his digreions than any we have nam'd. I have alwayes been pleas'd to ee him, and his imitator, Montaign, when they trike a little out of the common road: For we are ure to be the better for their wandring.

The bet quarry lies not always in the open field: And who would not be content to follow a good Huntman over Hedges and Ditches when he knows the Game will reward his pains? But if we mark him more narrowly, we may oberve,
that the great reaon of his frequent tarts, is the variety of his Learning: He knew o much of Nature, was o vatly furnih'd with all the treaures of the mind, that he was uneaie to himelf, and was forc'd, as I may ay, to lay down ome at every paage, and to catter his riches as he went: Like another Alexander or Adrian, he built a City, or planted a Colony in every part of his progres; and left behind him ome memorial of his greatnes. Sparta, and Thebes, and Athens, and Rome, the Mitres of the World, he has dicover'd in their foundations, their intitutions, their growth, their heigth, the decay of the three firt, and the alteration of the lat. You ee thoe everal people in their different laws, and policies, and forms of Government, in their Warriours, and Senators, and Demagogues. Nor are the Ornaments
of Poetry, and the illutrations of imilitudes forgotten by him; in both which he intructs as well as pleaes: Or rather pleaes that he may intruct.

This lat reflection leads me naturally, to ay omewhat in general of his tile, tho after having jutly prais'd him for copiounes of learning, integrity, perpicuity, and more than all this for a certain air of goodnes which appears through all his Writings, it were unreaonable to be critical on his Elocution: As on a tree which bears excellent fruit, we conider not the beauty of the blooms: For if they are not pleaant to the eye, or delightful to the cent, we know at the ame time that they are not the prime intention of Nature, but are thrut out in order to their product; o in Plutarch, whoe buines was not to pleae the ear, but to charm and
to intruct the mind, we may eaily forgive the cadences of words, and the roughnes of expreion: Yet for manlines of Eloquence, if it abounded not in our Author, it was not wanting in him: He neither tudyed the ublime tile, nor affected the flowry. The choice of words, the numbers of periods, the turns of Sentences, and thoe other Ornaments of peech, he neither ought, nor hun'd. But the depth of ence, the accuracy of Judgment, the dipoition of the parts and contexture of the whole, in o admirable and vat a field of matter, and latly the copiounes, and variety of words, appear hining in our Author. Tis indeed, oberv'd of him, that he keeps not always to the tile of proe, but if a Poetical word, which carries in it more of Emphais or ignification, offer it elf at any time, he refues it not becaue
Homer or Eurypides have us'd it: But if this be a fault I know not how Xenophon will tand excus'd. Yet neither do I compare our Author with him, or with Herodotus in the weetnes and graces of his tile, nor with Thuyidides in the olidity and cloenes of expreion. For Herodotus is acknowledg'd the Prince of the Ionick, the other two of the Attick eloquence. As for Plutarch, his tile is o particular, that there is none of the Ancients, to whom we can properly reemble him. And the reaon of this is obvious; for being converant in o great variety of Authors, and collecting from all of them, what he thought mot excellent, out of the confuion, or rather mixture of all their tiles, he form'd his own, which partaking of each, was yet none of them; but a compound of them all, like the Corinthian metal, which had
in it Gold, and Bras, and Silver, and yet was a pecies by its elf. Add to this, that in Plutarchs time, and long before it, the purity of the Greek Tongue was corrupted, and the native plendour of it had taken the tarnih of Barbarim, and contracted the filth and pots of degenerating Ages. For the fall of Empires always draws after it the language and Eloquence of the people: They, who labour under misfortunes or ervitude, have little leiure to cultivate their mother Tongue: To conclude, when Athens had lot her Soveraignity to the Peloponneians, and her liberty to Philip, neither a Thucydides, nor a Demothenes were afterwards produc'd by her.

I have formerly acknowledg'd many lapes of our Author, occaion'd through his inadvertency, but he is likewie tax'd with faults, which reflect on his Judgment in matters
of fact, and his Candour in the comparions of his Greeks and Romans. Both which are o well vindicated by Montaign, that I need but barely to tranlate him. Firt then he is accus'd of want of Judgment, in reporting things incredible: For proof of which is alledg'd the tory he tells of the Spartan boy, who uffer'd his bowels to be torn out by a young Fox which he had tolen, chooing rather to hide him under his Garment till he died, then to confes his robbery. In the firt place this example is ill choen, becaue tis difficult to et a bound to the force of our internal faculties, tis not defin'd how far our reolution may carry us to uffer: The force of bodies may more eaily be determin'd than that of Souls: Then of all people the Lacedemonians, by reaon of their rigid intitution, were mot harden'd to undergo labours,
and to uffer pains. Cicero, before our Authors time, tho then the Spartan vertue was degenerated, yet avows to have een himelf ome Lacedemonian boys, who to make tryal of their patience, were plac'd before the Altar of Diana, where they endur'd courging, till they were all over bloody, and that not only without crying, but even without a igh or groan: Nay, and ome of them o ambitious of this reputation, that they willingly reign'd their Lives under the hands of their tormentors. The ame may be aid of another tory, which Plutarch vouches with an hundred witnees, that in the time of Sacrifice, a burning coal by chance, falling into the leeve of a Spartan boy, who held the Cener, he uffer'd his Arm to be corch'd o long without moving it, that the cent of it reak'd up
to the Noes of the Aitants.

p.q:
For my own part, who have taken in o vat an Idea of the Lacedemonian magnanimity, Plutarchs tory, is o far from eeming incredible to me, that I neither think it wonderful nor uncommon: For we ought not to meaure poibilities or impoibilities by our own tandard, that is, by what we our elves cou'd do or uffer. Thee, and ome other light examples, are made ue of, to leen the opinion of Plutarchs Judgment: But the common exception againt his candor, is, that in his parallels of Greeks and Romans, he has done too much honour to his Countrymen in matching them with Heroes, with whom they were not worthy to be compar'd. For intances of this, there are produc'd the comparions of Demothenes
and Cicero, Aritides and Cato, Lyander and Sylla, Pelopidas and Marcellus, Ageilaus and Pompey: Now the ground of this accuation is mot probably the lutre of thoe Roman names, which trikes on our imagination. For what proportion of glory is there betwixt a Roman Conul, or Proconul of o great a Common-wealth, and a imple Citizen of Athens? But he who coniders the truth more nearly, and weighs not honours with honours, but Men with Men, which was Plutarchs main deign, will find in the Ballance of their manners, their vertues, their endowments and abilities, that Cicero and the Elder Cato, were far from having the overweight againt Demothenes and Aritides. I might as well complain againt him in behalf of his own Country-men: For neither was Camillus o famous
as Themitocles; nor were Tiberius and Cajus Gracchus comparable to Agis and Cleomenes in regard of dignity: Much les was the widome of Numa to be put in Ballance againt that of Lycurgus, or the modety and temperance of Scipio, againt the olid Philoophy and perfect vertue of Epaminondas: Yet the diparity of victories, the reputation, the blaze of Glory, in the two lat were evidently on the Roman ide. But as I aid before, to compare them this way, was the leat of Plutarchs aim; he openly declares againt it: For peaking of the coure of Pompeys fortune, his exploits of War, the greatnes of the Armies which he commanded, the plendour and number of his Triumphs, in his comparion betwixt him and Ageilaus, I believe, ays he, that if Xenophon were now alive, and would indulge himelf
the liberty to write all he could to the advantage of his Heroe Ageilaus, he would be aham'd to put their acts in competition. In his comparion of Sylla and Lyander; there is, ays he, no manner of equality, either in the number of their victories, or in the danger of their Battels; for Lyander only gain'd two naval fights, &c. Now this is far from partiality to the Grecians. He who wou'd convince him of this vice, mut hew us in what particular Judgment he has been too favourable to his Countrymen, and make it out in general where he has faild in matching uch a Greek with uch a Roman; which mut be done by hewing how he could have pair'd them better; and naming any other in whom the reemblance might have been more perfect. But an equitable Judge who takes things
by the ame handle which Plutarch did, will find there is no injury offer'd to either party, tho there be ome diparity betwixt the perons: For he weighs every circumtance by it elf, and judges eparately of it: Not comparing Men at a lump, nor endeavouring to prove they were alike in all things, but allowing for diproportion of quality or fortune, hewing wherein they agreed or diagreed, and wherein one was to be preferr'd before the other.

div.p:
I thought I had anwer'd all that cou'd reaonably be objected againt our Authors judgement; but caually cating my eye on the works of a French Gentleman, deervedly famous for Wit and Criticim, I wonder'd, amongt many commendations of Plutarch, to find this one reflection. As for his Comparions,
they eem truly to me very great; but I think he might have carried them yet farther, and have penetrated more deeply into humane nature: There are folds and recees in our minds which have ecap'd him; he judges man too much in gros; and thinks him not o different, as he is often from himelf: The ame peron being jut, unjut, merciful, and cruel; which qualities eeming to bely each other in him, he Attributes their inconitences to forreign caues: Infine, if he had dicrib'd Catiline, he wou'd have given him to us, either prodigal or Covetous: That alieni appetens ui profuus, was above his reach. He could never have reconcil'd thoe contrarieties in the ame ubject, which Salut has o well unfolded, and which Montaign o much better undertood.

This Judgment, cou'd not have
proceeded, but from a man who has a nice tate in Authors; and if it be not altogether jut 'tis at leat delicate, but I am confident, that if he pleae to conider this following paage taken out of the life of Sylla, he will moderate, if not retract his cenure.

p.q:
In the ret of his manners he was unequal, irregular different from himelf: < in non-Latin alphabet > . He took many things by rapine, he gave more: Honour'd men immoderately, and us'd them contumeliouly: was ubmiive to thoe of whom he tood in need, inulting over thoe who tood in need of him: So that it was doubtful, whether he were more form'd by nature to arrogance or flattery. As to his uncertain way of punihing, he would ometimes put men to death on the leat occaion; at other times he would pardon the
greatet Crimes: So that judging him in the whole, you may conclude him to have been naturally cruel, and prone to vengeance, but that he could remit of his everity, when his interets requir'd it.

div.p:
Here methinks our Author eems to have ufficiently undertood the folds and doubles of Sylla's dipoition; for his Character is full of variety, and inconitences. Yet in the concluion, 'tis to be confes'd that Plutarch has aign'd him a bloody nature: The clemency was but artificial and aum'd, the cruelty was inborn: But this cannot be aid of his rapine, and his prodigality; for here the alieni appetens, ui profuus is as plainly decrib'd, as if Plutarch had borrow'd the ene from Salut: And as he was a great Collector, perhaps he did. Nevertheles
he judg'd rightly of Sylla, that naturally he was cruel: For that quality was predominant in him; and he was oftener revengeful than he was merciful. But this is ufficient to vindicate our Authors Judgment from being uperficial, and I deire not to pres the Argument more trongly againt this Gentleman, who has Honour'd our Country by his long Reidence amongt us.

It eems to me, I mut confes that our Author has not been more hardly treated by his Enemies, in his comparing other Men, than he has been by his friends, in their comparing Seneca with him. And herein, even Montaign himelf is carcely to be defended. For no man more eteem'd Plutarch, no man was better acquainted with his excellences, yet this notwithtanding, he has
done too great an honour to Seneca, by ranking him with our Philoopher and Hitorian, him, I ay, who was o much les a Philoopher, and no Hitorian: Tis a Reputation to Seneca, that any one has offer'd at the comparion: The worth of his Adverary makes his defeat advantagious to him; and Plutarch might cry out with Jutice; Qui cum victus erit, mecum certae feretur. If I had been to find out a parallel for Plutarch, I hould rather have pitch'd on Varro the mot learned of the Romans, if at leat his Works had yet remain'd; or with Pomponius Atticus, if he had written. But the likenes of Seneca is o little, that except the ones being Tutor to Nero, and the other to Trajan, both of them trangers to Rome, yet rais'd to the highet dignities in that City, and both Philoophers tho of everal Sects; (for
Seneca was a Stoick, Plutarch a Platonician, at leat an Academick, that is, half Platonit half Sceptick:) beides ome uch faint reemblances as thee, Seneca and Plutarch eem to have as little Relation to one another, as their native Countries, Spain and Greece. If we conider them in their inclinations or humours, Plutarch was ociable, and pleaant, Seneca moroe, and melancholly. Plutarch a lover of converation, and ober feats: Seneca reerv'd; uneaie to himelf when alone, to others when in Company. Compare them in their manners, Plutarch every where appears candid, Seneca often is cenorious. Plutarch, out of his natural humanity, is frequent in commending what he can; Seneca, out of the owrnes of his temper, is prone to Satyr, and till earching
for ome occaion to vent his gaul. Plutarch is pleas'd with an opportunity of praiing vertue; and Seneca, (to peak the bet of him,) is glad of a pretence to reprehend vice. Plutarch endeavours to teach others, but refues not to be taught himelf; for he is always doubtful and inquiitive: Seneca is altogether for teaching others, but o teaches them, that he impoes his opinions; for he was of a Sect too imperious and dogmatical, either to be taught or contradicted. And yet Plutarch writes like a man of a confirm'd probity, Seneca like one of a weak and taggering vertue. Plutarch eems to have vanquih'd vice, and to have triumph'd over it: Seneca eems only to be combating and reiting, and that too but in his own defence. Therefore Plutarch is eaie in his dicoure,
as one who has overcome the difficulty: Seneca is painful, as he who till labours under it. Plutarchs Vertue is humble and civiliz'd: Seneca's haughty and illbred. Plutarch allures you, Seneca commands you. One wou'd make Vertue your Companion, the other your Tyrant. The tyle of Plutarch is eaie and flowing; that of Seneca precipitous and harh. The firt is even, the econd broken. The Arguments of the Grecian drawn from reaon, work themelves into your undertanding, and make a deep and l ••• ing impreion in your mind: Thoe of the Roman drawn from wit, flah immediately on your imagination, but leave no durable effect. So this tickles you by tarts with his argutenes, that pleaes you for continuance • , with his propriety. The coure of their fortunes eems alo
to have partaken of their tiles; for Plutarchs was equal, mooth, and of the ame tenour: Seneca's was turbid, uncontant and full of revolutions. The Life of Plutarch was unblameable, as the Reader cannot but have oberv'd; and of all his Writings there is nothing to be noted as having the leat tendency to vice; but only that little Treatie, which is intituled < in non-Latin alphabet > , wherein he peaks too broadly of a in, to which the Eatern and Southern parts of the World are mot obnoxious: But Seneca is aid to have been more libertine than uited with the gravity of a Philoopher, or with the auterity of a Stoick. An ingenious Frenchman, eteems as he tells us, his peron rather than his works; and values him more as the Praeceptor of Nero, a Man ambitious of the Empire, and as the gallant
of Agrippina, than as a teacher of Morality. For my part I dare not puh the commendation o far: His courage was perhas praie worthy, if he endeavour'd to deliver Rome from uch a Monter of Tyranny, as Nero was then beginning to appear: His ambition too was the more excuable, if he found in himelf an ability of governing the World, and a deire of doing good to human kind: But as to his good fortunes with the Empres, I know not what value ought to be et on a wie Man for them. Except it be that Women generally liking without Judgment, it was a Conquet for a Philoopher once in an age, to get the better of a fool. However methinks there is omething of aukward in the adventure: I cannot imagine without laughter, a Pedant, and a Stoick, making
love in a long gown; for it puts me in mind of the civilities which are us'd by the Cardinals and Judges in the dance of the Rehearal: If Agrippina wou'd needs be o lavih of her favours, ince a Sot grewn aueous to her, becaue he was her Husband, and nothing under a Wit, cou'd attone for Claudius, I am half orry that Petronius was not the Man: We cou'd have born it better from his Character, than from one who profes'd the everity of vertue, to make a Cuckold of his Emperour and Benefactour. But let the Hitorian anwer for his own Relation: Only, if true, 'tis o much the wore, that Seneca, after having abus'd his bed, cou'd not let him leep quiet in his grave. The Apocolocynthiis, or mock deification of Claudius was too harp and inulting on his memory: And Seneca
tho he could Preach forgivenes to others, did not practice it himelf in that Satyr: Where was the patience and inenibility of a Stoick, in revenging his Banihment with a Libel? Where was the Morality of a Philoopher, in defaming and expoing of an harmles fool? And where was common humanity, in railing againt the dead? But the tallent of his malice is viible in other places: He cenures Mecenas, and I believe jutly, for the looenes of his manners, the voluptuounes of his life, and the effeminacy of his tyle; but it appears that he takes pleaure in o doing; and that he never forc'd his nature, when he poke ill of any Man. For his own tile, we ee what it is, and if we may be as bold with him, as he has been with our old Patron, we may call it a hatter'd Eloquence,
not vigorous, not united, not embodied; but broken into fragments; every part by it elf pompous, but the whole confus'd and unharmonious. His Latin, as Monieur St. Evremont has well oberv'd, has nothing in it of the purity, and elegance of Augutus his times; and 'tis of him and of his imitators, that Petronius aid; pace vetrâ liceat dixie, primi omnium eloquentiam perdiditis. The Controveriae ententiis vibrantibus pictae, and the vanus Sententiarum trepitus, make it evident that Seneca was tax'd under the peron of the old Rhetorician. What quarrel he had to the Unckle and the Nephew, I mean Seneca and Lucan, is not known; but Petronius plainly points them out; one for a bad Orator, the other for as bad a Poet: His own eay of the Civil War is an open defiance
of the Pharalia; and the firt Oration of Eumolpus, as full an arraignment of Seneca's fale Eloquence. After all that has been aid, he is certainly to be allowed a great wit, but not a good Philoopher: Not fit to be compar'd with Cicero, of whoe reputation he was emulous, any more than Lucan is with Virgil: To um up all in few words, conider a Philoopher declaiming againt riches, yet vatly rich himelf; againt avarice, yet puting out his Mony at great Extortion here in Britain; againt honours, yet aiming to be Emperour; againt pleaure, yet enjoying Agrippina, and in his old age married to a beautiful young Woman: And after this, let him be made a Parallel to Plutarch.

And now, with the uual vanity of Dutch Prefacers, I could load
our Author with the praies and commemorations of Writers: For both Ancient and Modern have made Honourable mention of him. But to cumber pages with this kind of tuff were to raie a ditrut in common Readers that Plutarch wants them. Rualdus indeed has Collected ample Tetimonies of them; but I will only recite the names of ome, and refer you to him for the particular quotations. He reckons Gellius, Euebius, Himerius the Sophiter, Eunapius, Cyrillus of Alexandria, Theodoret, Agathias, Photius and Xiphilin Patriarchs of Contantinople, Johannes Sarisberienis, the famous Petrarch, Petrus Victorius, and Jutus Lipius.

But Theodorus Gaza, a Man learned in the Latin Tongue, and a great retorer of the Greek, who liv'd above two hundred years ago,
deerves to have his uffrage et down in words at length: For the ret have only commended Plutarch more than any ingle Author, but he has extoll'd him above all together.

Tis aid that having this extravagant quetion put to him by a friend, that if learning mut uffer a general Shipwrack, and he had only his choice left him of preerving one Author, who hould be the Man he would preerve; he anwer'd Plutarch; and probably might give this reaon, that in aving him, he hould ecure the bet Collection of them all.

The Epigram of Agathias, deerves alo to be remember'd: This Author flourih'd about the year five hundred, in the Reign of the Emperour Jutinian: The Veres are extant in the Anthologia, and
with the Tranlation of them, I will conclude the praies of our Author; having firt admonih'd you, that they are uppos'd to be written on a Statue erected by the Romans to his memory.

q.l: Cheronean Plutarch, to thy deathles praie,
Does Martial Rome this grateful Statue raie:
Becaue both Greece and he thy fame have har'd;
(Their Heroes written, and their Lives compar'd:)
But thou thy elf cou'dt never write thy own;
Their Lives have Parallels but thine has none.

div.head: THE LIFE OF THESEUS.
div.byline: Englih'd from the Greek, By R. Duke, Trin. Coll. Cant. Soc.
div.head: Volume I.
div.p:
AS Hitorians, in their geographical decriptions of Countries, croud into the farthet parts of their Maps thoe places that ecape their knowledge, with ome uch Remarks in the Margin as thee; All beyond is nothing but drie and deart Sands, or unpaable Bogs, or Scythian Cold, or a frozen Sea: o in this Work of mine, wherein I have compared
the Lives of the greatet Men with one another, having run through that time whereunto probable reaon could reach, and through which the truth of Hitory could pas, I may very well ay of thoe that are farther off; All beyond is nothing but montrous and tragical Fictions: there the Poets and there the Inventers of Fables dwell; nor is there any further to be expected ought deerving of Credit, or that carries any appearance of Truth. Yet having publihed an Account of Lycurgus, the Law-giver, and Numa, the King, methought I might not without reaon acend as high as to Romulus, being brought by my Hitory o near to his time. Conidering therefore with my elf
Whom with o great a man hall I compare?
Or whom oppoe? who can the tryal bear?
(as Aechylus exprees it) I found none o fit as him that peopled the mot celebrated City of Athens to be et in oppoition with the Father of the invincible and renowned City of Rome. And here it were to be wih't that this Account cou'd be o purg'd by right reaon from the fabulous part, as to obey the Laws and receive the character of an exact Hitory. But whereever it hall chance too boldly to contemn the bounds of
credibility, and will endure no mixture of what is probable, we hall beg that we may meet with can did Readers, and uch as will favourably receive what can be related concerning things of o great Antiquity.

Now Theeus eems to reemble Romulus
The comparion between Theeus and Romulus. in many particulars. Both of 'em born out of Wedlock and of uncertain Parentage had the repute of being prung from the Gods.
Both Warriours; that by all the world's allow'd. Homer.
Both of them had joyn'd with trength of Body an equal vigour of Mind; and of the two mot famous Cities of the World, the one built Rome, and the other made Athens be inhabited. Both were famous for the Rape of Women; neither of them cou'd avoid dometick misfortunes, nor the envy of their Country-men; but both are aid to have died by the hands of their own offended Citizens, if we will believe there is any truth in relations that are delivered with the leat appearance of trange or Poetical Fictions.

The Lineage of Theeus by his Father's The Family of Theeus. ide acends as high as to Erectheus and the
< in non-Latin alphabet > . firt inhabitants of Attica. By his Mother's ide he was decended of Pelops: For Pelops was the mot powerfull of all the Kings of Peloponneus, not o much for the greatnes of his Riches as the multitude of
his Children; having match't many Daughters to perons of the greatet Quality, and made many Sons Governours of Provinces round about him. One whereof nam'd Pittheus, Grandfather to Theeus, was founder of the mall City of the Troezenians, and had the repute of a man of the greatet knowledge and wiedom in his time: Which then it eems conited chiefly in uch grave Sentences as the Poet Heiod got his great eteem by in his Book of Works and Days. And even among them is one that they acribe to Pittheus,
< in non-Latin alphabet > . Let a friend's ervices meet full reward. Which alo Aritotle witnees, and Euripides when he calls Hippolytus Scholar of the acred Pittheus, hews the opinion that the world had of that great man. About this time Aegeus, being deirous of Children, and conulting the Oracle of Delphos, receiv'd that o celebrated anwer which forbad him the ue of any woman before his return to Athens. But the Oracle being o obcure as not to atisfie him that he was clearly forbid this, he went to Troezene and communicated to Pittheus the voice of the God, which was in this manner,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
I warn thee, Warriour, not to broach
Thy Goatskin full of generous Juice:
Nor footlong Spigot to produce,
Till thou to Athens halt approach.
Pittheus therefore taking advantage from the obcurity of the Oracle prevail'd upon him, it is uncertain whether by perwaion or deceit, to lie with his Daughter Aethra. Aegeus afterwards knowing her whom he had lain with to be Pittheus's Daughter, and upecting her to be with Child by him, he left a Sword and a pair of Shoes, hiding them under a great Stone that had a hollownes exactly fitting them, making her onely privy to it, and commanding her that if he brought forth a Son who when he came to man's etate hou'd be able to lift up the Stone and take away what he had left there, he hou'd end him away to him with thoe things with all ecrecy, enjoyning him as much as poible to conceal his Journey from all men: For he fear'd extremely the Pallantidae, who were continually mutinying againt him, and depis'd him for his want of Children, they themelves being fifty Brothers all of the Sons of Pallas.

When Aethra was deliver'd of a Son, ome report that he was immediately nam'd
Theeus, from the Tokens which his Father had put under the Stone: But others ay
< in non-Latin alphabet >
ignifies a putting any thing,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
ignifies to adopt or acknowledge one for his Son. The Education of Theeus. that he receiv'd his name afterwards at Athens, when Aegeus acknowledg'd him for his Son. He was brought up under his Grandfather Pittheus, and had by him a Governour and Tutour et over him nam'd Connidas, to whom the Athenians even to this time, the day before the Feat that is dedicated to Theeus, acrifice a Ram, giving this honour to his memory upon a much juter account than that which they gave to Silanio and Parrhaius, for having onely made Pictures and Statues of Theeus. There being then a cutom for the Grecian Youth upon their firt coming to man's etate to go to Delphos and offer Firt-fruits of their Hair to the God of the place, Theeus alo went thither, and they ay that the place to this day is yet nam'd Theea from him. But he hav'd onely the fore-part of his head, as Homer reports to be the cutom of the Abantes. And this ort of Tonure was from him nam'd Theeis. But the Abantes firt us'd this ort of having, not having learnt it from the Arabians, as ome imagin, nor in imitation of the Myians, but, being a warlike people, and us'd to cloe fighting, and above all other Nations accutom'd chiefly to engage hand to hand; as Archilochus witnees in thee Veres,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
Slings they depie, and corn to end from far
The flying Dart, and wage a ditant War;
But hand to hand the truty Swords they weild
Doe all the dreadfull buines of the Field.
This is the way of fight th' Euboeans know,
Nor Bow nor Sling they trut, but trike themelves the blow.
Therefore that they might not give their Enemies that advantage of eiing them by the Hair, they were hav'd in this manner. They write alo that this was the reaon why Alexander gave command to his Captains that all the Beards of his Macedonians hou'd be hav'd, as being the readiet hold for an Enemy.

Aethra for ome time conceal'd the true Parentage of Theeus; and there was a report Theeus reputed the Son of Neptune. given out by Pittheus that he was begotten by Neptune: for the Troezenians have Neptune in the highet veneration. He is their Tutelar God, to him they offer all their Firt-fruits, and in his honour tamp't their Money with a Trident.

Theeus in his youth dicovering not onely a great trength of Body but an equal force of Mind and firmnes of Undertanding, his Mother Aethra, conducting him to the Stone, and informing him who was his true Father, commanded him to take from thence the Tokens that Aegeus had left, and to ail to Athens. He, without any difficulty, lifted up the Stone and took 'em from thence; but refued to take his Journey by Sea, though it was much the afer way, and though he was continually pret to it by the intreaties of his Grandfather and Mother. For it was at that time very dangerous to go by Land to Athens, no place of the Country being free from Thieves and Murtherers: for that Age produc'd a ort of men, for trength of Armes, and wiftnes of Feet, and vigour of Body, excelling the ordinary rate of men; and in labours and exercie indefatigable: yet making ue of thee gifts of Nature to nothing either good or profitable to mankind, but rejoycing and taking pride in inolence, and pleaing themelves in the enjoyment of their inhumanity and cruelty, and in eiing, forcing and committing all manner of outrages upon every thing that fell into their hands: who thought civility, and jutice, and equity, and humanity which many prais'd, either out of want of courage
to commit injuries or fear to receive 'em, nothing at all to concern thoe who were the mot daring and mot trong. Some of thee Hercules detroy'd and cut off in his paing through thee Countries, but ome who ecap'd him, for fear fled and hid themelves, or were par'd by him in contempt of their abject ubmiion: but after that Hercules fell into misfortune, and having lain Iphitus, retir'd to Lydia, and for a long time was there Slave to Omphale, a punihment which he had impos'd upon himelf for the murther; then indeed the Lydian affairs enjoyed all peace and ecurity, but in Greece and the Countries about it the like Villanies were again reviv'd and broke out, there being none to repres or chatie their inolence. It was therefore a very hazardous journey to travel by Land from Athens to Peloponneus: and Pittheus, giving him an exact account of each of thee Thieves and Villains, of what trength they were, and with what cruelty they us'd all trangers, perwaded Theeus to go by Sea; but he, it eems, had long ince been ecretly fir'd with the glory of Hercules, and had him in the highet etimation, and was never more atisfy'd than in hearing thoe that gave an account of him; epecially thoe that had een him, or had been preent at any Action or Saying of his that was remarkable. Inomuch
that he was altogether in the ame condition that, in after-ages Themitocles was when he aid that the Trophies of Miltiades wou'd not uffer him to leep: o he having in uch admiration the vertue of Hercules, in the night his dreams were all of that Heroes actions, and in the day a continual emulation tirr'd him up to perform the like. Beides, they were nearly related, being born of Couin Germains. For Aethra was His relation to Hercules. the Daughter of Pittheus, and Alcmena of Lycidice, and Lycidice and Pittheus Brothers and Siters by Hippodamia. He thought it therefore a dihonourable thing and not to be endur'd, that Hercules hou'd every where purge both the Land and Sea from thoe wicked Men, and that he himelf hou'd flie from the like Adventures that o fairly offer'd themelves to him; digracing his Reputed Father by a mean flight by Sea, and not hewing his True one as manifet a character of the greatnes of his Birth by noble and worthy Actions as by the tokens that he brought with him, the Shoes and the Sword.

With this mind and thee thoughts he et forward, with a deign to doe injury to no body, but to repel and revenge himelf of all thoe that hou'd offer any. And firt of all, in a et combate, he lew Periphetes in Epidauria, who us'd a Club for his Arms, He lew Periphetes.
and from thence had his name of Corynetes, or the Club-bearer, who eis'd upon him, and forbad him to go forward in his Journey. Being pleas'd with the Club, he took it, and made it his weapon, having the ame ue of it as Hercules had of the Lion's Skin; for that he wore as evidence of what a prodigious greatnes the monter was that He lew, and to the ame end Theeus carry'd about him this Club; overcome indeed by him, but now, in his Hand, invincible.

Paing on further towards the Ithmus of He kills Sinnis. Peloponneus he lew Sinnis, that, from the way of murther he us'd, was irnam'd the
< in non-Latin alphabet > . bender of Pines, after the ame manner that he himelf had detroy'd many others before. And this he did, not having either practis'd or ever learnt the art of bending thee Trees, to hew that natural trength is above all art. This Sinnis had a Daughter of mot excellent beauty and more than ordinary tature, call'd Perigune, who, when her Father was kill'd, fled, and was ought after with all diligence by Theeus; but he, flying into a place overgrown with many Shrubs and Ruhes and wild Aparagus, innocently made her complaint to them, as if they cou'd have a ene of her misfortune, and begg'd 'em to helter her, with vows that if he ecap'd he wou'd never cut 'em down or burn 'em: but Theeus calling upon
her and giving her his promie that he wou'd ue her with all repect and offer her no injury, he came forth; and being enjoy'd by Theeus bore a Son to him nam'd He begets Menalippus of Perigune the Daughter of Sinnis. Menalippus; but afterwards he was married to Deioneus the Son of Euritus, the Oechalian, Theeus himelf giving her to him. And Ioxus, the Son of this Menalippus who was born to Theeus, accompany'd Ornytus in the Colony that he carried with him into Caria, from whom the people call'd Ioxides have their name; who have this cutom deriv'd down to 'em from their Fathers, never to burn either Shrubs or Ruhes or wild Aparagus, but to honour and worhip 'em.

About this time the Cromyonian Sow, which they call'd Phaea, was a Beat not to be Slays the Cromyonian Sow Phaea. pat by or depis'd, being of great fiercenes and very hard to be overcome, her Theeus kill'd, going out of his way to meet and engage her, that he might not eem to perform all his great exploits out of mere neceity; being alo of opinion that it was the part of a brave man, not onely to chatie villainous and wicked Men, but alo to fight and expoe himelf to the fury of the mot fierce and hurtfull Monters and wild Beats. Others relate that this Phaea was a Woman, a Robber full of cruelty and lut, that liv'd in Cromyon, and had the name of Sow given
her from the beatlines of her life and converation, and that afterwards he was kill'd by Theeus. He lew alo Sciron, upon the Kills Sciron. borders of Megara, cating him down from the Rocks, being, as mot report, a notorious robber of all paengers; and, as others ay, accutom'd out of inolence and wantonnes to tretch forth his feet to trangers commanding them to wah 'em, and then with a kick to thrut them down the Rock into the Sea: but the Writers of Megara, in contradiction to the receiv'd report, and, as Simonides exprees it, fighting with all antiquity, contend that Sciron was neither a Robber nor committer of injuries and affronts, but a puniher of all uch, and full of all humanity and friendhip to good and jut men; that Aeacus was ever eteemed a man of the greatet anctity of all the Greeks, and that Cychreus, the Salaminian, was honoured at Athens with divine worhip, and that the vertue of Peleus and Telamon were not unknown to any one; and that Sciron was Son-in-law to Cychreus and Father-in-law to Aeacus, and Grandfather to Peleus and Telamon, who were both of 'em Sons of Erideis the Daughter of Sciron and Carichlo: that therefore it was not probable that the bet hou'd make thee alliances with the wort of men, giving and receiving mutually what was of greatet value and mot dear
to 'em: but they relate that Theeus did not lay Sciron in his firt Journey to Athens, but afterwards, when he took Eleuis, a City of the Megarians, having circumvented Diocles the Governour, whom, together with Sciron, he there lew. Thee are the contradictions which are between the Writers of this Story. In Eleuis he kill'd Cercyon,
Kills Cercyon, the Arcadian, in a wretling Match. And going on a little further, in the City Hermione, he lew Damates, otherwie call'd Procrutes, by force making him even and Procrutes. to his own Beds, as he himelf was us'd to doe with all trangers; this he did in imitation of Hercules. For he, returning always to the committers of thee outrages the ame ort of violence that they offer'd to others, acrific'd Buyris, wretled with Antaeus, fought with Cycnus hand to hand, and kill'd Termerus by breaking his Skull in pieces, (from whence they ay comes the Proverb of A Termerian Michief) for it eems Termerus kill'd paengers that he met by running, with all his force, his Head againt theirs. Thus proceeded Theeus in the punihment of evil men, who underwent the ame torments from him, which they had inflicted upon others; jutly uffering after the manner of their own injutice.

As he went forward on his Journey, and was come as far as the River Cephius ome
of the race of the Phytalidoe met him and aluted him, and upon his deire to ue the purifications, then in cutom, they perform'd them with all the uual Ceremonies, and having offer'd propitiatory Sacrifices to the Gods, they invited him and entertain'd him at their Houe, who before in all his Journey had not met the like civility.

On the eighth day of June which was then call'd Cronius he arriv'd at Athens, where he found the publick affairs full of Arrives at Athens. all confuion, and divided into Parties and Factions, Aegeus alo and his whole private Family labouring under the ame ditemper; for Medea, having fled from Corinth, and promis'd Aegeus to make him, by her Art, capable of having Children, was entertain'd by him and admitted to his Bed; he had the firt knowledge of Theeus, whom as yet Aegeus did not know, and he being in years, full of jealouies and upicions, and fearing every thing by reaon of the Faction that was then in the City, he eaily Aegeus perwaded to poion him, not knowing him to be his Son. perwaded him to poion Theeus at a Banquet to be prepar'd for him as a civility to a Stranger. He coming to the Entertainment thought it not fit to dicover himelf firt, but being willing to give his Father the occaion of firt finding him out; the meat being on the Table he drew his Sword as if He is dicovered to his Father. he deign'd to cut with it, Aegeus upon the
udden, perceiving the Token, threw down the Cup of poion, and dicovering his Son embrac'd him, and having gather'd together all his Citizens, he own'd him publickly before them, who receiv'd him with great atisfaction for the fame of his Greatnes and Bravery: and 'tis aid that when the Cup fell, the poion was pilt there where now is the encloure in the Delphinian Temple, for in that place tood Aegeus's Houe, and the Statue of Mercury on the Eat ide of the Temple is call'd the Mercury of Aegeus his Gate.

Now the Sons of Pallas, who before were The Pallantidae rebell. quiet, upon hopes and expectation of recovering the Kingdom, at leat after Aegeus's death, who was without Iue, as oon as Theeus appear'd, and was acknowledg'd the Succeour to the Crown, highly reenting that Aegeus firt, an adopted Son onely of Pandion, and not at all related to the Family of Erectheus, hou'd obtain the Kingdom, and that after, Theeus, one of another Country again, and a tranger, hou'd obtain the Crown, broke out into an open War. And dividing themelves into two Companies, one part of them march'd openly from Sphetta with their Father againt the City, the other, hiding themelves in the Village of Gargettus, lay in ambuh with a deign to et upon the Enemy on both
ides: They had with them a Cryer of the Town of Agnus, nam'd Leo, who dicover'd to Theeus all the deigns of the Pallantidae: He immediately fell upon them that lay in Ambucade and cut 'em all off; which Pallas and his company hearing fled and were They are overcome and dipers'd by Theeus. dipered.

From hence they ay is deriv'd the cutom among the Palleneans to have no marriages or any alliance with the people of Agnus, nor to uffer their Cryers to pronounce in their Proclamations thee words, olemnly us'd in all other parts of the Country, < in non-Latin alphabet > , (Hear ye People) o great is their hatred to the very name of Leo for the foulnes of his Treaon.

Now Theeus, longing to be in action, and withall deirous to make himelf popular, left Athens to fight with the Bull of Marathon; which did no mall michief to He takes the Bull of Marathon alive. the inhabitants of Tetrapolis. And having overcome it, he brought it alive in triumph through the City, and afterwards acrific'd it to Apollo. And as to what concerns Hecale and the tory of her receiving and entertaining Theeus in this expedition, it eems to be not altogether void of truth; for from hence the people round about, meeting upon a certain day, offer'd a Sacrifice, which they call'd Hecaleium, to Jupiter Hecalion, in honour of Hecale,
whom, by a diminutive name, they call'd Hecalene, becaue he, (as the cutom of ancient people is,) hew'd her affection to Theeus by uch diminutive names: and having made a vow to Jupiter for him as he was going to the fight, that if he return'd in afety, he wou'd offer Sacrifices in thanks of it, and dying before he came back, he receiv'd this return of her hopitality by the command of Theeus, as Philochorus relates the tory.

Not long after arrived the third time from Crete the collectours of the Tribute which the Athenians paid 'em upon the following occaion. Androgeus having been treacherouly The murther of Androgeus. murther'd about the confines of Attica, not onely Minos put the Athenians to extreme inconveniences by a perpetual War, but the Gods alo laid wate their Country; for both Famine and Petilence lay heavy upon 'em, and even their Rivers were dried up. But being told by the Oracle, that if they appeas'd and reconcil'd Minos, the anger of the Gods wou'd ceae, and they hou'd enjoy ret from the mieries they labour'd under; they ent Ambaadours, and, with much upplication, were at lat reconcil'd, having entred into an agreement to end to Crete the pace of nine years a Tribute of even young Men and as many Virgins, as the general Writers agree;
and the mot tragical tory that goes about concerning this matter ays, that the Minotaure detroy'd them, or that they wandring in the Labyrinth, and finding no poible means of getting out, mierably ended their lives there. And that this Minotaure was (as Euripides hath it)
A mingled form, where two trange hapes combin'd;
And different Natures, Bull and Man were joyn'd.
But Philochorus writes that the Cretans will by no means allow the truth of this, but ay that the Labyrinth was onely an ordina • y Prion having no other ill in it, than that it ecur'd the Prioners from ecaping, and that Minos, having intituted Games in honour of Androgeus, gave as a reward to the Victors thoe that till that time had been prioners in the Labyrinth. And that the firt that overcame in thoe Games was one of the greatet power and command among 'em nam'd Taurus, a man of no mercifull or weet dipoition, but that carried himelf towards the Athenians that were made his prize in a mot proud and inolent manner; and even Aritotle himelf in the account that he gives of the Government of the Bottieans, is manifetly
of an opinion that thee youth were not lain by Minos, but that they pent the remainder of their days in lavery at Crete; and that the Cretans, to acquit themelves The Cretans Offering to Apollo. of an ancient Vow which they had made, were us'd to end an Offering of the firt fruits of their Men to Apollo of Delphos, and that ome decendants of thee Athenian Slaves were mingled with 'em and ent amongt 'em; and of thee they that were not able to get their living there remov'd from thence, firt into Italy, and inhabited the Country round about Japygia; from thence again that they remov'd to Thrace and were nam'd Bottieans, and that this is the reaon why in a certain Sacrifice the Bottiean Women ing a Hymn beginning thus Let us go to Athens. And from this that it appear'd how dangerous it was to incurr the hatred of a City that was Mitres of Eloquence and a Mue. For Minos was always ill poken of, and repreented ever as a very ill man upon the Athenian Stages, neither did Heiod at all help him when he calls him The mot Royal Minos, nor Homer when he tyles him The Companion of Jupiter. But the Tragedians prevailing made him alway appear from the Stage as a cruel and inhumane Prince. But that really Minos was a very good King and Law-giver, and that Rhadamanthus was a Judge under
him and a preerver of the Statutes that he ordain'd.

Now when the time of the third Tribute was come, and that the Fathers who had any young men for their Sons were to proceed by lot to the choice of thoe that were to be ent, there aroe freh dicontents and accuations againt Aegeus among the people, who were full of grief and indignation, that he, who was the caue of all their mieries, was the onely peron exempt from the punihment; but ettling his Kingdom upon a Batard and a foreign Son, took no notice of them whom he left detitute and without Children. Thee things very enibly Theeus offers himelf voluntarily to be ent to Crete. affected Theeus, who thinking it but jut not to avoid, but rather partake of, the ufferings of his fellow Citizens, offer'd himelf for one without any lot; all the ret admiring him for the greatnes of his Spirit and loving him for his care of the publick: and Aegeus, after all his prayer and intreaty, finding him inflexible and not to be perwaded, proceeded to the chooing of the ret by lot. But Helanicus writes that the Athenians did not end the young Men and Virgins as they were choen by lot, but that Minos himelf coming thither made his own choice, and that he pitch'd upon Theeus before all others, upon conditions agreed between 'em, that the Athenians
hou'd furnih 'em with a Ship, and that the young men that were to ail with him hou'd carry no weapon of War; but that if the Minotaure was detroy'd, this Tribute hou'd ceae.

The two former times of the payment of the Tribute there appearing no hopes of afety or return, they ent forth the Ship with a black Sail, as to unavoidable detruction: but now Theeus encouraging his Father, and peaking greatly of himelf, as confident that he hou'd kill the Minotaure, he gave the Pilot another Sail which was White, commanding him as he return'd, if Theeus ecap'd, to make ue of that, but if not to ail with the Black one, and to hang out that ign of his misfortune and orrow. But Simonides ays that the Sail which Aegeus deliver'd to the Pilot was not White but Purple dyed in Grain, with the Flower of a certain Tree, commanding him to
< in non-Latin alphabet >
Ilicis. hang out this as a ign of their ecape. Amaryadas Phereclus, as Simonides writes, was Pilot of the Ship. But Philochorus ays that Theeus had a Pilot ent him by Scirus, from Salamis, nam'd Nauitheus, and another Sailor, nam'd Phaeax, they as yet not applying themelves to Navigation; and that Scirus did this becaue one of the young men, Menethes, was his Nephew, and this
< in non-Latin alphabet > , < in non-Latin alphabet > . the Monuments of Nauitheus and Phaeax,
built by Theeus near the Temple of Sciron, witnes. He adds alo that the Feat nam'd Cyberneia was intituted in their honour. The lot being cat, and Theeus having receiv'd out of the Prytenaeum thoe upon whom it fell, he went to the Delphinean Temple, and made an Offering to Apollo His Offering at the Delphinian Temple. for their afe return, which was a Bough of a conecrated Olive Tree bound about with white Wool.

Having thus perform'd his Devotion he went to Sea, the ixth day of March, on which day even till this time the Athenians end their Virgins to the ame Temple to make upplication to the Gods. It is farther reported that he was commanded by the Oracle at Delphos to make Venus his guide, and to invoke her as the Companion and Conductres of his Voyage, to whom as he was acrificing a he Goat by the Sea ide it was uddenly chang'd into a He, and for this caue that Goddes had the name of
< in non-Latin alphabet > , ignifying a Goat.
Epitragia.

When he arriv'd at Crete, as mot of the His Arrival at Crete, and Adventures there. ancient Hitorians as well as Poets write, having a Clew of thred given him by Ariadne, who had faln in love with him, and being intructed by her the ue of it, which was to conduct him through all the windings of the Labyrinth, he ecap'd out of it and lew the Minotaure, and ail'd back,
taking along with him Ariadne and the young Athenian Captives. Pherecydes adds that he bored holes in the Keels of the Cretan Ships to hinder their puruit. And Demon writes that Taurus, the chief Captain of Minos, was lain in a naval Combat by Theeus in the mouth of the Haven, immediately before he et ail for Athens. But Philochorus gives us the Story thus. That at the etting forth of the yearly Game by King Minos, Taurus, who they thought would certainly bear away the prize from all as he had done before, laboured under Taurus envied by the Cretans. the envy of all Crete. For his power grew grievous and inupportable by reaon of the inolence of his manners, and beides he had been accus'd of two near a familiarity with Paiphae the Queen: Which was the reaon that, when Theeus deir'd the Combat, Minos o eaily comply'd. And as it was a cutom in Crete that the Ladies alo hould be admitted to the ight of thee Games, Ariadne, being preent, was trangely urpris'd Ariadne in love with Theeus. at the manly beauty of Theeus, and truck with admiration with the vigour and addres which he hew'd in the Combat, overcoming all that encountred with him. Minos too being extremely pleas'd with him, epecially becaue he had engag'd and overthrown Taurus, voluntarily gave up the young Captives to Theeus, and
remitted the Tribute to the Athenians. But Clidemus gives an account of thee things peculiar to himelf, very prolix and beginning a great way off. That it was a Decree conented to by all Greece, that no Veel from any place containing above five perons hould be permitted to ail, Jaon onely excepted, who was made Captain of the great Ship Argo to ail about and cour the Sea of Pyrates. But Daedalus, having ecap'd from Crete, and flying by Sea to Athens, and Minos, contrary to this Decree, puruing him with his great Ships, was forc'd by a torm upon Sicily, and there ended his life. After his deceae, Deucalion Deucalion's Meage to Athens. his Son, deiring a quarrel with the Athenians, ent to them, commanding that they hould deliver up Daedalus to him, threatning, upon their refual, to put to death all the young Athenians which his Father had receiv'd as Hotages from the City. To this angry Meage Theeus return'd a very Theeus's Anwer. gentle and mild Anwer, excuing himelf that he could not deliver up Daedalus, who was o nearly related to him, being his Couin Germain; for his Mother was Merope, the Daughter of Erectheus. In the He fits out a Navy. mean while he ecretly prepar'd a Navy, part of it at home near the Village of the Thymaetades, being a place of no reort and far from any common Roads, the other part
by his Grandfather Pittheus's permiion, he caus'd to be built and fitted out at Troezene, that o his deign might be carried on with the greatet ecrecy. As oon as ever his Fleet was in readines he et ail, and none of the Cretans having any knowledge of his coming, but imagining, when they aw his Fleet, that they were Friends, and Veels of their own, he oon made himelf mater of the Haven, and immediately making a decent farther into the Iland, and having with him Daedalus and the other Fugitives for his Guides, he arriv'd at Cnous,
The Surprial of Cnous. the City of the King's reidence, before any notice of his coming before the Gates of the Labyrinth, and in a hort skirmih put Deucalion and all his Guards to the Sword. The Government by this means falling to Ariadne, he made a League with her, and receiv'd the Captives of her, and ratify'd a perpetual Friendhip between the Athenians and the Cretans, whom he engag'd under an Oath never again to make War with Athens.

There are yet many other reports about thee things, and as many concerning Ariadne, but none of any certainty or truth. For ome relate that he hang'd her elf being deerted by Theeus. Others that he was carry'd away by his Sailors to the Ile of Naxos, and married to Onarus, one of
the Priets of Bacchus, and that Theeus left her becaue he fell in love with another
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
For Aegle's love had pierc'd his manly Breat.
For this Vere, as Hereas the Megarian witneeth, was formerly in the Poet Heiod's Works, but put out by Piitratus, in like manner as he added this other in Homer's decription of Hell, to gratifie the Athenians,
< in non-Latin alphabet > . Theeus, Pirithous, both Sons of Gods.
Others report that Ariadne had two Sons by Theeus, Oenopion and Staphylus, and among thee is the Poet Ion, of Chios, who writes thus of his own native City
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
Built by Oenopion the great Theeus's Son.
But all that the Poets have ung of thee matters, or that Fables have made more famous than ordinary, every body (as I may ay) hath it in his mouth. But Paeon the
Amathuian, has et forth a different relation of thee things that has omewhat peculiar in it. For he writes that Theeus, being driven by a Storm upon the Ile of Cypros, and having aboard with him Ariadne, Ariadne left in Cypros. big with Child, and extremely dicompos'd with the rowling of the Sea, et her on Shore, and left her there alone in that weak condition, to return to and help the Ship, where, on a udden, by a violent Wind, he was again forc'd out to Sea. That the Women of the Iland receiv'd Ariadne very kindly, and adminitred all manner of comfort to her, that was extremely afflicted and almot dead with grief for being left behind. That they counterfeited kind Letters and deliver'd them to her, as ent from Theeus, and, when he fell in Labour, were very diligent in performing to her all the offices that belong to Women. But that he dy'd in Child-bed before he could be deliver'd, Her death. and was by them honourably interr'd. That oon after Theeus return'd, and was greatly afflicted for her los, and at his departure left a coniderable um of money among thoe of the Iland, ordering them to acrifice and pay divine honour to Ariadne; and caued two little Images to be made and dedicated to her, one of Silver and the other of Bras. Moreover that on the econd day of September, which is
acred to Ariadne, they have this Ceremony A Ceremony intituted in memory of Her. among their Sacrifices, to have a youth lye in, and with his voice and geture counterfeit all the pains of a Woman in Travail; and that the Amathuians call the Grove in which they hew her Tomb the Grove of Venus Ariadne.

Different yet from this account ome of the Naxians write, that there were two Minos's and two Ariadne's, one of which, they ay, was married to Bacchus, in the Ile of Naxos, and bore a Son nam'd Staphylus. But that the other, of a later age, was ravihed by Theeus, and being afterwards deerted by him, retir'd to Naxos, with her Nure Corcyna, whoe Grave they yet hew. That this Ariadne alo dy'd there, and was worhip'd by the Iland, but in a different manner from the former; for her day is celebrated with Feats, and Revels and an univeral Joy: but all the Sacrifices perform'd to the latter are mingled with orrow and mourning.

Now Theeus, in his return from Crete, Theeus his return from Crete. put in at Delos, and having acrific'd to the God of the Iland, and dedicated to the Temple the Image of Venus, which Ariadne had given him, he danc'd with the young Athenians a Dance, that, in memory of him, is till preerv'd among the Inhabitants of Delos, which in a certain order had turnings
and returnings that imitated the intricate windings of the Labyrinth. And this Dance, as Dicaearchus writes, is call'd among the Delians, The Crane. This he danc'd round the Ceratonian Altar, o call'd from its being compacted together and adorn'd onely with Horns taken from the left ide of the Head. They ay alo that he intituted Games in Delos, where he was the firt that began the cutom of giving a Palm to the Victors.

When they were come near the coat of Attica, o great was the joy for the happy ucces of their Voyage that, neither Theeus
His and his Pilots forgetfulnes fatal to Aegeus. himelf, nor the Pilot, remembred to hang out the Sail which hould have been the token of their afety to Aegeus, who, knowing nothing of their ucces, for grief threw himelf headlong from a Rock and perih'd in the Sea. But Theeus being arriv'd at the Port of Phalera, paid there the acrifices which he had vow'd to the Gods at his etting out to Sea, and ent a Herald to the City to carry the news of his afe return. At his entrance into the City the Herald found the people for the mot part full of grief for the los of their King, others, as may be well believ'd, as full of joy for the meage that he brought, and wholly bent to make much of him and crown him with Garlands for o acceptable news;
