which he indeed accepted of, but hung them upon his Heralds taff; and thus returning to the Sea ide before Theeus had finih'd his libation to the Gods, he tay'd without, for fear of diturbing the holy Rites; but as oon as the Sacrifice was ended he entred and related the whole tory of the King's Death: upon the hearing of which, with great lamentations and a confued tumult of grief they ran with all hate to the City. And from hence, they ay, it comes that at this day, in the Feat Ocophoria the Herald is not crown'd but his taff, and that the People then preent till break out at the Sacrifice into this hout, < in non-Latin alphabet >
(eleleu, iou, iou) of which confus'd ounds the firt was wont to be ued by men in hate, or at a triumph, the other is proper to thoe that are in great conternation or trouble.

Theeus, after the Funeral of his Father, paid his Vows to Apollo the eventh day of October; for on that day the Youth that return'd with him afe from Crete made their entry into the City. They ay alo that the cutom of boyling Pule at this Feat is deriv'd from hence, becaue the young men that ecap'd, put all that was left of their proviion together, and boiling it in one common Pot feated themelves with it, and with great rejoycing did eat all together.
Hence alo they carry about an Olive branch bound about with Wool (uch as they then made ue of in their upplications) which they call Eireione, crown'd with all orts of Fruits, to ignifie that carcity and barrennes was ceas'd; inging in their Proceion this Song,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
Eireione Figs produce,
And wholome Bread and cheerfull Oil,
And Honey, labouring Bees weet toil,
But above all Wines noble juyce,
Then Cares thou in the Cup halt teep,
And full of joy receive oft leep.
Although ome hold opinion that this Ceremony is retain'd in memory of the Heraclidae, who were thus entertain'd and brought up by the Athenians. But mot are of the opinion which we have above deliver'd. The Ship wherein Theeus and Theeus his Ship. the Youth of Athens return'd had thirty Oars, and was preerv'd by the Athenians down even to the time of Demetrius Phalareus, for they took away the old Planks as they decay'd, putting in new and tronger Timber in their place, inomuch that this
Ship became a tanding Example among the Philoophers, when-ever they diputed about things that encreae, one ide holding, That the Ship remain'd the ame, and the other as fiercely contending that it was not the ame.

The Feat call'd Ocophoria, or the Feat of Boughs, which to this day the Athenians celebrate, was then firt intituted by Theeus. For he took not with him the full number of Virgins, which by lot were to be carri'd away, but elected two Youths, with whom he had an intimate familiarity, of fair and womanih faces, but of a manly and forward pirit, and having by frequent Baths, and avoiding the heat and corching of the Sun, with a contant ue of all the Oyntments, and Wahes, and Drees, that erve to the adorning of the Head, or moothing the Skin, or improving the Complexion, in a manner chang'd them from what they were before, and having taught them further to counterfeit the very voice, and carriage, and gate of Virgins, o that there could not be the leat difference perceiv'd, he undicover'd by any, put them into the number of the Athenian Maids deign'd for Crete. At his return he and thee two Youths led up a olemn Proceion, with Boughs and Vine-branches
in their hands, and in the ame habit that is now worn at the celebration of the Feat of Boughs. Thee Branches they carri'd in honour of Bacchus and Ariadne, for the ake of their Story before related; or rather becaue they happen'd to return in Autumn, the time of gathering the Grapes. The Women whom they call Deipnophorae, or Supper-carriers, are taken into thee Ceremonies, and ait at the Sacrifice, in remembrance and imitation of the Mothers of the young Men and Virgins upon whom the lot fell, for thus buily did they run about bringing Banquets and Refrehments to their Children, and becaue the good Women then told their Sons and Daughters a great many fine Tales and Stories, to comfort and encourage them under the danger they were going upon, it has till continu'd a Cutom, that at this Feat, old Fables and Tales hould be the chief Dicoure. And for all thee Particularities we are beholden to the Hitory of Demon. There was then a Place choe out, and a Temple erected in it to Theeus, and thoe Families out of whom the Tribute of the Youth was gather'd, were obliged to pay a Tax to the Temple for Sacrifices to him. And the Houe of the Phytalidae, had the overeeing of thee Sacrifices,
Theeus doing them that Honour in recompence of their former Hopitality.

Now after the death of his Father Aegeus, framing in his mind a great and wonderful Perwades the Inhabitants of Attica to reide together in one City. deign, he gather'd together all the Inhabitants of Attica into one Town, and made them one People of one City, that were before dipers'd, and very difficult to be aembled upon any Affair, tho' relating to the common benefit of them all. Nay, often uch Differences and Quarrels happen'd between them, as occaion'd Bloud-hed and War; thee he by his Perwaions appeas'd, and going from People to People and from Tribe to Tribe, propos'd his deign of a common agreement between them. Thoe of a more private and mean condition readily embracing o good advice, to thoe of greater Power and Interet he promis'd a Commonwealth, wherein Monarchy being laid aide, the power hould be in the People, and that, reerving to himelf only to be continued the Commander of their Arms, and the Preerver of their Laws, there hould be an equal ditribution of all things ele between them, and by this means brought them over to his Propoal. The ret fearing his Power, which was already grown very formidable, and knowing his courage and reolution,
choe rather to be perwaded than forc'd into a Compliance. He then diolv'd all the ditinct Courts of Jutice, and Council-Halls, and Corporations, and built one common Prytaneum and Council-Hall, where it tands to this day; and out of the old and the new City he made one, which he nam'd Athens, ordaining a common Feat and Sacrifice to be for ever oberv'd, which he call'd Panathenaea, or the Sacrifice of all the United Athenians. He intituted alo another Sacrifice, for the ake of Strangers that would come to fix in Athens, call'd Metaecaea, ( < in non-Latin alphabet > ) ignifies Tranmigration. Lays down his Regal Power.
Metaecaea, which is yet celebrated on the 16th. day of June. Then, as he had promis'd, he laid down his Regal Power, and ettled a Commonwealth, entring upon this great change, not without advice from the Gods. For having ent to conult the Oracle of Delphos, concerning the Fortune of his new Government and City, he receiv'd this Anwer:
< in non-Latin alphabet > ,
< in non-Latin alphabet > ,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
Hear, Theeus, Pittheus Daughters Son,
Hear what Jove for thee has done.
In the great City, thou hat made,
He has, as in a Store-houe, laid
The ettled Periods and fixt Fates
Of many Cities, mighty States.
But know thou neither Fear nor Pain,
Solicit not thy elf in vain.
For, like a Bladder that does 'bide
The fury of the angry Tide,
Thou from high Waves unhurt hall bound,
Always tot but never drown'd.
Which Oracle, they ay, one of the Sibyls long after did in a manner repeat to the Athenians, in this Vere:
< in non-Latin alphabet > . The Bladder may be wet, but never drown'd. Farther yet deigning to enlarge his City, he invited all Strangers to come and enjoy equal Priviledges with the Natives, and ome are of opinion that the common form of Proclamation in Athens, Come hither all ye People, were the words that Theeus caued to be proclaim'd, when he thus et up a Commonwealth, coniting, in a manner, of all Nations. Yet he uffer'd not his State, by the promicuous
Multitude that flow'd in, to be turn'd into Confuion, and be left without any order or degree, but was the firt that divided the Commonwealth into three ditinct Ranks, the Noblemen, the Hubandmen, and Artificers. To the Nobility he committed the choice of Magitrates, the teaching and dipening of the Laws, and the interpretation of all holy and Religious things; the whole City, as to all other Matters, being as it were reduc'd to an exact Equality, the Nobles excelling the ret in Honour, the Husbandmen in Profit, and the Artificers in Number. And Theeus was the firt, who, as Aritotle ays, out of an inclination to Popular Government parted with the Regal Power, and which Homer alo eems to witnes in his Catalogue of the Ships, where he gives the Name of People, to the Athenians only.

He then coyned Money, and tamp'd it with the Image of an Ox, either in memory of the Marathonian Bull, or of Taurus whom he vanquih'd, or ele to put his People in mind to follow Husbandry, and from this Coin came the expreion o frequent among the Greeks, of a thing being worth ten or a hundred Oxen. After this he joyned Megara to Attica, and erected that famous Pillar in the Streights
of Peloponneus, which bears an Incription of two lines, hewing the bounds of the two Countreys that meet there. On the Eat-ide the Incription is thus:
This is not Peloponneus but Ionia. And on the Wet-ide thus:
This is Peloponneus, not Ionia. He alo intituted annual Games, in emulation of Hercules, being ambitious, that as the Greeks by that Hero's appointment celebrated the Olympian Games to the Honour of Jupiter, o by his intitution they hould celebrate the Ithmian Games to the Honour of Neptune. For thoe that were there before oberv'd, dedicated to Melicerta, were perform'd privately and in the night, and conited rather of Religious Ceremonies, than of any open Spectacle or publick Feat. But ome there are who ay, that the Ithmian Games were firt intituted in memory of Sciron, at the Expiation which Theeus made for his Murder, upon the account of the nearnes of kindred which was between them, Sciron being the Son of Canethus and Heniocha, the Daughter of Pittheus; tho' others write, that Sinnis and not Sciron
was their Son, and that to his Honour and not to the others thee Games were ordain'd by Theeus; and Hellanicus and Andro of Halicarnaus write, that at the ame time he made an agreement with the Corinthians, that they hould allow them that came from Athens to the celebration of the Ithmian Games, as much pace to behold the Spectacle in, as the Sayl of the Ship that brought them thither tretcht to its full extent could cover, and that in the firt and mot honourable Place. Concerning the Voyage His Voyage into the Euxine Sea. that he made in the Euxine Sea, there are different Relations; for Philochorus and ome others write, that he undertook this Expedition with Hercules, offering him his Service in the War againt the Amazons, and had Antiope given him for the reward of his Valour: but others, as Pherecydes, Hellanicus and Herodorus write, that he made this Voyage many years after Hercules, with a Navy under his own Command, and took the Amazon Prioner; and indeed this eems to come nearet the truth, for we do not read that any other of all thoe that accompani'd him in this Action, took any Amazon Prioner. Different from the former, Bion writes, that he tole her away by deceit, and fled; for the Amazons (he ays) being naturally
Lovers of Men, were o far from flying from Theeus when he touch'd upon their Coats, that they entertain'd him with great civility, and ent him Preents to his Ship; but he having invited Antiope, who brought them, to come aboard, immediately et Sayl and carri'd her away. Menecrates, that wrote the Hitory of Nicaea in Bithynia, adds, that Theeus having Antiope aboard his Veel, cruied for ome time about thoe Coats, and that there were in the ame Ship three young Noblemen of Athens, that accompani'd him in this Voyage, all Brothers, whoe Names were Euneus, Thoas, and Soloon. The lat of thee fell deperately in Love with Antiope, but conceal'd it with all poible care; only to one of his mot intimate acquaintance he reveal'd the Secret, and employ'd him to break his paion to Antiope; he rejected his pretences with a very harp denial, yet carri'd her elf to him with all outward appearances of Civility, and very prudently made no complaint to Theeus of any thing that had happen'd; but Soloon, urg'd by depair, leap'd into a River near the Sea-ide, and drowned himelf. As oon as Theeus was acquainted with his Death, and his unhappy Love that was the caue of it, he was extreamly concern'd,
and in the heighth of his grief, an Oracle which he had formerly receiv'd at Delphos, came into his mind; for he had been commanded by the Prietes of Apollo Pythius, that where-ever in his Travels he was mot orrowful, and under the greatet affliction, he hould build a City there, and leave ome of his Followers to be Governours of the Place. For this caue he there founded a City, which he call'd from the Name of Apollo, Pythopolis,
He builds Pythopolis. and in honour of the unfortunate Youth, he nam'd the River that runs by it, Soloon, and left the two urviving Brothers entruted with the care of the Government and Laws, joyning with them Hermus, one of the Nobility of Athens, from whom a certain Place in the City is call'd, The Houe of Hermus; tho' by an error in the accent of the word, it has been fally taken for the Houe of Hermes, or Mercury, and the Honour that was deign'd to the Heroe, transferr'd to the God. And this was the rie and ground of the Amazonian War, a War of no mall conequence, or in which the Athenians might think they had to do with Cowards or Women. For it is impoible that they hould have plac'd their Camp in the very City, and joyn'd Battel in the middle of it, near the Temple of the Mues,
unles having firt conquer'd the Country round about, they had without any delay or fear mov'd boldly on to Athens. That they made o long a Journey by Land, and paed an Arm of the Cimmerian Bophorus that was frozen, as Hellanicus writes, is difficult to be believ'd. This is certain, that they encamp'd in the City, and may be ufficiently confirm'd by the Names that the Places thereabout yet retain, and the Graves and Monuments of thoe that fell in the Battel. Both Armies now being in ight, there was a long paue and doubt on each ide which hould give the firt Onet: At lat Theeus having acrific'd to Fear, in obedience to the Command of an Oracle he had receiv'd, gave them Battel; and this happen'd in the Gives Battel to the Amazons. Month of Augut, in which to this very day the Athenians celebrate the Feat, that is nam'd from that Month wherein this Battel was fought. But Clidemus, deirous to be very nice in each particular of this Affair, writes, that the left Wing of the Amazons mov'd towards the Place which is yet call'd Amazonium, and the right to a Place call'd Pnyx, near Chrya, upon which the Athenians, iuing from behind the Mues Temple, fell upon them; and that this is true, the Graves of thoe that were lain, to be een in the Street
that leads to the Gate call'd Piraica, by the Temple of the Hero Chalcodus, are a ufficient proof. And here it was that the Athenians were routed, and hamefully turn'd their backs to Women, as far as to the Temple of the Furies. But freh upplies coming in from Palladium, Ardettus, and Lyceum, charg'd their right Wing, and beat them back into their very Tents, in which Action a great number of the Amazons were lain. At length, after four months, a Peace was concluded Peace concluded. between 'em by the mediation of Hippolyta, (for o this Hitorian calls the Amazon which Theeus marri'd, and not Antiope) tho' others write that he was lain with a Dart by Molpadia, fighting by Theeus ide, and that the Pillar which tands by the Temple at the entring into the Olympian ground, was erected to her Honour. Nor is it to be wonder'd that the Hitory of things o very ancient, hould be o various and uncertain. It is farther aid, that thoe of the Amazons that were wounded, were privately ent away by Antiope to Chalcis, where many by her care recover'd, but thoe that dy'd were buri'd in the Place that is to this time call'd Amazonium. That this War was ended by a mutual League and Agreement, is evident both from the Name of
the Place adjoyning to the Temple of Theeus, call'd from the olemn Oath there taken, Horcomoium, and alo from the ancient Sacrifice which is celebrated to the Amazons, the day before the Feat of Theeus. The Megarians pretend alo that ome of the Amazons were buried in their City, and hew for one of their Monuments, a Tomb in the figure of a Lozenge, in the paage from the Market-place to a Place call'd Rhus. It is aid likewie, that others of 'em were lain near Chaeronea, and buried near a little Rivulet, formerly call'd Thermodon, but now Haemon, of which I have formerly wrote in the Life of Demothenes. It appears further, that the Paage of the Amazons through Thealy was not without oppoition, for there are yet to be een many of their Sepulchres near Scotuaea and Cynocephalae. And this is as much as is worthy the Relation, concerning the Amazons. For the account which the ancient Author of a Poem call'd Theeis, gives us, of this Invaion of the Amazons, how that Antiope, to revenge her elf upon Theeus, for refuing her and marrying Phaedra, came down upon the City with her Train of Amazons, was defeated, and had mot of her Followers lain by Hercules, is manifetly nothing ele but Fable, and the Invention
of a Poet. It is true indeed that Theeus marri'd Phaedra, but that was after the death of Antiope, by whom he had a Son call'd Hippolytus, or, as Pindar writes, Demophoon. As to the Calamities which befel both Theeus and his Son, ince none of the Hitorians have contradicted the Tragick Poets that have written of them, they are altogether to be receiv'd for truths, as they are deliver'd from the Stage. There are alo other Reports concerning the Marriages of Theeus, His Marriages the beginnings of which were neither honourable, nor their events fortunate, which yet were never repreented in the Grecian Plays. He forc'd Anaxo, the Traezenian; having lain Sinnis and Cercyon, he ravih'd their Daughters; he marri'd Peribaea the Mother of Ajax, and then Pheribaea, and then Jope the Daughter of Iphicles. Further he is accus'd for deerting Ariadne, (as is before related) being in Love with Aegle the Daughter of Panopeus, an action neither jut nor honourable. And latly for the Rape of Helen, which fill'd all Attica with War and Blood, and was in the end the occaion of his Banihment and Death, as hall hereafter be related.

Herodorus is of opinion, that tho' there were many famous Expeditions undertaken
by the bravet and mot honourable Captains of his Time, yet Theeus never made One amongt them, nor appear'd in any great and publick Action; once only excepted, when he joyn'd with the Lapithae in their War againt the Centaurs: but others ay that he accompani'd Jaon to Colchos, and Meleager to the laying of the Calydonian Boar, and that hence this came to be a Proverbial Speech, Not without Theeus. Alo that Theeus without any aid of the Heroes of his Time, did himelf perform very many and very great Exploits, and that from the high eteem the World et upon his Valour, it grew into a Proverb, This is another Theeus.
In mot of the printed Copies it is read, This is another Hercules, but ome Manucripts read it better, as it is here tranlated. He was alo very intrumental to Adratus, in recovering the Bodies of thoe that were lain before Thebes, but not, as Euripides in his Tragedy ays, by force of Arms, but by perwaion and mutual agreement and compoition, for o the greater part of Hitorians write; nay, Philochorus adds farther, that this was the firt Treaty that ever was made for the recovering and burying the Bodies of the dead; tho' the Hitory of Hercules ays, that he was the firt that ever gave leave to his Enemies to carry off the Bodies of their lain. The Burying-places of the Common Souldiers are yet to be een in
the Village call'd Eleutherae, and thoe of the Commanders at Eleuis, where Theeus allotted them a Place for their Interment, to oblige Adratus. And that the dead Bodies were thus recover'd, Aechylus is Witnes in his Tragedy call'd the Eleuinians, where Theeus himelf is brought in relating the Story as it is here told, which quite overthrows what Euripides writes on this Subject, in his Play call'd The Suppliants.

The extraordinary and o much celebrated Friendhip between Theeus and The occaion of the Friendhip between Theeus and Peirithous. Peirithous, is aid to have been thus begun. The Fame of the matchles Strength and Valour of Theeus being pread through all Greece, Peirithous was enflam'd with a deire to be atisfi'd, and make a tryal himelf of what he had heard o much by Report; to this end he eized a Herd of Oxen which belong'd to Theeus, and was driving them away from Marathon, when News was brought that Theeus puru'd him in Arms; upon which, didaining to fly, he turn'd back and went on to meet him. But as oon as ever they had view'd one another, each o admir'd the Gracefulnes and Beauty, and was eiz'd with uch a Reverence for the Bravery and Courage of the other, that they forgat all thoughts of Fighting; and Peirithous
firt tretching out his hand to Theeus, bade him be Judge in this Cae himelf, and promis'd to ubmit willingly to what-ever he demanded, in atisfaction for the injury he had done. But Theeus not only forgave him all the damages he had utain'd, but entreated him to be his Friend and Brother in Arms; and there immediately they wore an inviolable friendhip to each other. After this Perithous married Deidamia, and invited Theeus to the Wedding, entreating him to come and ee his Countrey, and enter into alliance with the Lapithae; he had at the ame time invited the Centaurs to the Feat, who growing hot with Wine began to be very inolent and lewd, and offer'd violence to the Women, which o enrag'd the Lapithae, that they took immediate revenge upon them, laying many of them upon the Place; and afterwards having overcome them in Battel, drove the whole Race of them out of their Countrey, Theeus all along taking their part, and fighting on their ide. But Herodotus gives a different Relation of thee things. That Theeus came not to the aitance of the Lapithae till the War was already begun, and that it was in this Journey that he had the firt ight of Hercules, having made it his buines to find
him out at Trachine, where he had choen to ret himelf after all his wandrings and his labours, and that this Enterview was honourably perform'd on each part with extream Civility, Repect and Admiration of each other. Yet it is more credible what other Hitorians write, that there were before frequent Enterviews between them, and that it was by the means of Theeus that Hercules was initiated and admitted to the Ceremonies of the Goddes Ceres, having, by his interceion alo, been firt purifi'd, upon the account of everal rah Actions of his former Life.

Theeus was now fifty years old, as Hellanicus reports, when he ravih'd Helen, who was very young, and not of Age to be marri'd. Wherefore ome Writers, to take away this Accuation of one of the greatet Crimes that is laid to his charge, ay, that he did not teal away Helen himelf, but that Idas and Lynceus were the Ravihers, who brought her to him, and committed her to his charge, and that therefore he refus'd to retore her at the demand of Cator and Pollux; or, according to others, that her own Father Tyndarus ent her to be kept by him, for fear of Enarphorus the Son of Hippocoon, who would have carri'd her away by force
when he was yet a Child. But the mot probable Relation, and that which has mot Witnees on its ide, is this: Theeus and Peirithous went both together to The Rape of Helen. Sparta, and having eiz'd the young Lady as he was dancing in the Temple of Diana Orthia, fled away with her. There were preently Men in Arms ent to purue the Ravihers, but they followed the puruit no farther than to Tegea; and Theeus and Peirithous being now out of danger, having ecap'd out of Peloponneus, made an agreement between themelves, that he to whom the lot hould fall, hould have Helen to his Wife, but hould be oblig'd to be ready with his aitance to procure another for his Friend. The lot fell upon Theeus, who convey'd her to Aphidnae, not being yet marriageable, and deliver'd her to one of his Allies call • d Aphidnus, and having ent his Mother Aethra after to take care of her Education, deir'd him to keep them o ecretly, that none might know where they were. Which done, to return the ame ervice to his Friend Peirithous, he accompani'd him in his Journey to Epirus, in order to Accompanies Peirithous to Epirus. teal away the King of the Moloians Daughter. This King, his own Name being Aidoneus or Pluto, call'd his Wife and his Daughter, Proerpina, and a
great Dog which he kept, Cerberus, with whom he order'd all that came as Suitors to his Daughter to fight, and promis'd her to him that hould overcome the Beat. But having been inform'd, that the deign of Peirithous his coming was not to court his Daughter, but to force her away, he caued them both to be eized, and threw Peirithous to be torn in pieces by his Dog, and clapt up Theeus Peirithous's Death. Theeus in Prion. into Prion, and kept him in Chains.

About this time, Menetheus, the Son of Peteus, who was great Grandon to Erectheus, the firt Man that is recorded to have affected Popularity, and ingratiated himelf with the Multitude, tirr'd up and exaperated the mot eminent Men of the City, who had long born a ecret grudge to Theeus, and poet them with a belief that Theeus had taken from them their everal little Kingdoms and Lordhips, that o having pent them all up in one City, he might ue them as his Subjects and Slaves. He put alo the meaner Menetheus tirs up the Athenians againt Theeus. ort into no mall Commotion, by accuing them harply, that being deluded with a meer dream of Liberty, tho' indeed they were depriv'd both of that, and of their Countreys and their Temples, intead of many good and gracious Kings of their own, they had given themelves up
to be lorded over by a New comer and a Stranger. Whilt he was thus bui'd in infecting the minds of the Citizens, the War that Cator and Pollux brought againt Cator and Pollux invade Athens for the recovery of Helen. Athens, came very opportunely to further the Sedition he had been promoting, and ome ay that he by his perwaions was wholly the caue of their invading the City. At their firt approach they committed no acts of Hotility, but peaceably demanded their Siter Helen; but the Athenians returning anwer, that they knew not where he was dipos'd of, they prepar'd to aault the City; when Academus (by what means he came to the knowledge of it, is uncertain) dicover'd to them that he was ecretly kept at Aphidnae. For which Reaon he was both extreamly honour'd during his Life by Cator and Pollux, and the Lacedaemonians, when in after-times they made everal Incurions into Attica, and detroy'd all the Countrey round about, par'd the Academy for his ake. But Dicaearchus writes, that there were two Arcadians in the Army of Cator and Pollux, the one call • d Echedemus, and the other Marathus; from the firt that which is now call'd the Academy, was then nam'd Echedemia, and the Village Marathon had its Name from the other, who according to the Oracle willingly
offer'd up himelf a Sacrifice for the properous ucces of the Army. As oon as the Lacedaemonians were arriv'd at Aphidnae, they firt overcame their Enemies They take Aphidnae. in a et Battel, and then aaulted it, and took the Town. And here, they ay, Alycus, the Son of Sciron, was lain on the Lacedaemonians ide, from whom a Place in Megara, where he was buri'd, is call'd Alycus to this day. And Hereas writes, that it was Theeus himelf that kill'd him, in witnes of which he cites thee Veres concerning Alycus:
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
And Alycus on fair Aphidna's Plain,
By Theeus in the Caue of Helen lain.
Tho' it is not at all probable, that Theeus himelf was there when both the City and his own Mother were taken. Aphidnae being now won by Cator and Pollux, and the whole City of Athens being in great Conternation, Menetheus perwaded the People to open their Gates, and receive them with all manner of Civility and Friendhip, who, he told them, deign'd no violence or injury to any but
Theeus, who had firt done them wrong, but were Benefactors and Saviours to all Mankind beide. And their behaviour to the conquer'd gave credit to what Menetheus promis'd; for having made themelves abolute Maters of the Place, they demanded no more than to be initiated in the Ceremonies of the Goddes Ceres, ince they were as nearly related to their City as Hercules was, who had receiv'd the ame Honour. This their Deire they eaily obtain'd, and were adopted by Aphidnus, as Hercules had been by Pylius. They were honour'd alo like Gods, and were call'd by a new Name Anaces, either from the In Greek,
< in non-Latin alphabet > . ceation of the War, or from the ingular care they took that none hould uffer any injury, tho' there was o great an Army within the Walls of the City, for the Phrae ( < in non-Latin alphabet > ) ignifies as much, from whence it is likely that Kings were call'd Anactes. Others ay, that from the appearance of their Star in the Heavens, they were thus call'd, for in the Attick Dialect this Name comes very near the words
< in non-Latin alphabet > , and
< in non-Latin alphabet > . that ignifie Above.

Some ay that Aethra, Theeus his Mother, was here taken Prioner, and carri'd to Lacedaemonia, and from thence went away with Helen to Troy, alledging this
Vere of Homer, to prove that he waited upon Helen:
< in non-Latin alphabet >
Aethra of Pittheus born; and Clymene. Others reject this Vere as none of Homers, as they do likewie the whole Fable of Munychus, who, the Story ays, was the Son of Demophoon and Laodice, and was brought up privately by Aethra at Troy. But Itrus in the 13th. Book of his Attic Hitory, gives us an account of Aethra, different yet from all the ret: That after the Fight, wherein Achilles and Patroclus overcame Paris in Thealy, near the River Sperchius, Hector ack'd and plunder'd the City of the Troezenians, and took Aethra Prioner there. But this eems to be an aburd and groundles Tale.

Now it happen'd that Hercules paing once by the Countrey of the Moloians, was entertain'd in his way by Aidoneus the King, who in Dicoure accidentally fell upon a Relation of the Journey of Theeus and Peirithous into his Dominions, and what they had deign'd to do, and what they were forc'd to uffer. Hercules was extreamly concern'd for the inglorious
Death of the one, and the mierable condition of the other: As for Peirithous, he thought it but in vain to expotulate with the King concerning his being put to Death; but Theeus being yet kept in Prion, he begg'd to have him releas'd for his ake, and obtain • d that Favour Hercules procures the releae of Theeus. He returns to Athens. from the King. Theeus being thus et at liberty, return'd to Athens, where his Friends were not yet wholly uppres'd, and dedicated to Hercules all the Temples which the City had erected to himelf, changing their Names from Theea to Heraclea, four only excepted, as Philochorus writes. And now deigning to preide in the Commonwealth, and manage the State as before, he oon found himelf fall'n into a Net of Faction and Sedition; he dicover'd that thoe who of a long time had hated him, had now added to Slighted by the Athenians. their hatred of his Peron a contempt of his Authority; and eeing the minds of the People o generally corrupted, that, intead of obeying with ilence and ubmiion what-ever was commanded, they expected to be flatter'd and ooth'd into their duty, he had ome thoughts to have reduc'd them by force, but by the prevalence of the Faction, and continual Diorders, he was deterr'd from the Attempt. And at lat depairing of any good ucces
of his Affairs in Athens, he ent away his Children privately to Eubaea, commending them to the care of Elephenor the Son of Chalcodus; and he himelf having olemnly curs'd the People of Athens, in the Village of Gargettus, in which there yet remains the Place call'd Araterion, or the Place of Curing, ail'd to Scyrus, where He ails to Scyrus. he had Lands left him by his Father, and, as he perwaded himelf, a great Friendhip with all thoe of the Iland. Lycomedes was then King of Scyrus, Theeus therefore addreed himelf to him, and deir'd to have his Lands put into his poeion, as deigning to ettle and to dwell there, tho' others ay, that he came to beg his aitance againt the Athenians. But Lycomedes, being either jealous of the Glory of o great a Man, or to gratifie Menetheus, having led him up to the highet Cliff of the Iland, on pretence of howing him from thence the Lands that he deir'd, threw him headlong down from the Rock, and kill'd him. But others His Death. ay, he fell down of himelf by an unfortunate lip of his Foot, as he was walking there after Supper according to his uual cutom. At that time there was no notice taken, nor were any concern'd for his Death, but Menetheus quietly poes'd himelf of the Kingdom of
Athens. His Sons were brought up in a private condition, and accompani'd Elephenor to the Trojan War, but after the deceae of Menetheus, who dy'd in the ame Expedition, they return'd to Athens, and recover'd the Government to themelves. But in ucceeding Ages there were everal remarkable Accidents, that mov'd the Athenians to honour Theeus as a demy-God. For in the Battel which was fought at Marathon againt the Medes, many of the Souldiers aw an Apparition of Theeus all in Arms fighting in the head of them, and ruhing on upon the Barbarians. And after the Median War, Phaedo being Archon of Athens, the Athenians conulting the Oracle at Delphos, were commanded to gather together the Bones of Theeus, and laying 'em in ome honourable Place, keep them as acred in the City. But it was very difficult to recover thee Reliques, or o much as to find out the Place where they lay, by reaon of the inhopitable and avage temper of the barbarous People that inhabited the Iland. But afterwards when Cimon took the Iland, (as is related in his Life) and had a great deire to find out the Place where Theeus was buried, he by chance py'd an Eagle upon a riing ground pecking it with her Beak, and tearing up the
Earth with her Talons, when on the udden it came into his mind, as it were by ome divine Inpiration, to dig there, and earch for the Bones of Theeus. There was found in that Place a Coffin of a Man of more than ordinary ize, and the head of a bras Lance, and a Sword lying by it, all which he took aboard his Gally, and brought with him to Athens. The Athenians having notice of this, went out to meet and receive the Reliques of this great Man in a plendid and pompous Proceion, and did acrifice to them, and were as much tranported, as if Theeus himelf was return'd alive to their City. After that they interr'd them in the middle of the City, near the Place where the Youth perform their Wretlings, and other Exercies of Body. His Tomb is a Sanctuary and Refuge for Slaves, and all thoe of mean condition, that fly from the Perecution of Men in Power, in memory that Theeus while he lived, was an Aiter and Protector of the Ditres'd, and never refus'd the Petitions of the Afflicted, that fled to him for Succour and Defence. The chief and mot olemn Sacrifice which they celebrate to him, is kept on the 8th. day of October, in which he return'd with the Athenian young Men from Crete. Beides which they acrifice
to him on the 8th. day of every Month, either becaue he return'd from Traezene the 8th. day of June, as Diodorus the Geographer writes, or ele thinking that number of all others to be mot proper to him, becaue he was reputed to be born of Neptune, for they acrifice to Neptune on the 8th. day of every Month; for the Number Eight being the firt Cube of an even Number, and the double of the firt Square, eemed to be an Emblem of the tedfat and immoveable Power of this God, who from thence has the Names of Aphalius and Gaeiochus, that is, the Etabliher and Stayer of the Earth.

div.head: THE LIFE OF ROMULUS.
div.byline: Englih'd from the Greek, By Mr. James Smalwood, Fel. of Trin. Col. in Cambridge.
div.head: Volume I.
div.p:
BY whom, and for what reaon, the City of Whence Rome was o call'd.
Rome, a Name o great in glory, and famous in the mouths of all men, was o firt call'd, Authors do
not agree. Some are of opinion that the Pelagians, after they had over-run the greater part of the habitable World, and ubdued mot Nations, fix'd themelves here, and from their own great trength in War [which is the ignification of the word in Greek] call'd the City Rome. Others that after the taking of Troy, ome few that ecap'd the Enemy, fortunately meeting with Shipping, put to Sea, and being driven upon the Coats of Thucany, came to an Anchor off from the mouth of the River Tyber, where, their Women being mierably tir'd and haras • d by the toilomnes of the Voyage, it was propos'd by one whoe Name was Roma, a Peron of the bet Quality, and eemingly of the bet Undertanding too amongt em, to burn the Ships: Which being done, the Men at firt were very much offended at it; but afterwards, of neceity, eating themelves near Palatium, where things in a hort while ucceeded far better than they could hope, in that they found the Countrey very good, and the People courteous, they not only did the Lady Roma all other great Honours, but they added this alo, of calling the City they had built after her Name. From this, they ay, came that Cutom at Rome for Women to alute their Kinfmen and Hubands
with Kies, becaue thee Women after they had burnt the Ships, did make ue of uch like Allurements to pacifie their Husbands, and allay the dipleaure they had conceiv'd. Divers Opinions of the Name of Rome. Some ay, that Roma, from whom this City was o call'd, was Daughter of Italus and Leucaria; others, of Telephus, Hercules's Son, who was married to Aeneas; others again, of Acanius, Aeneas's Son. But then ome ay, Romanus, the Son of lyes and Circe, built it; ome that Romus, the Son of Emathion, whom Diomede ent from Troy; and others that it was founded by Romus, King of the Latines, that drove out the Thucans, who came originally from Thealy into Lydia, and from thence into thoe Parts of Italy. Nay, thoe very Authors, who by the clearet Reaons make it appear, that Of Romulus's Birth.
Romulus gave Name to that City, do yet trangely differ concerning his Birth and Family: For ome write, he was Son to Aeneas and Dexithea, Daughter of Phorbas, who with his Brother Remus, in their Infancy, was carried into Italy, and being on the River when the Waters were very rough, all the Ships were cat away except only that where the young Children were, which being afely landed on a level Bank of the River, they were both unexpectedly av'd, and from them
the Place was call'd Rome. Some ay, Roma, Daughter of that Trojan Lady who was married to Latinus, Telemachus's Son, was Mother to Romulus; others, that Aemilia, Daughter of Aeneas and Lavinia, had him by the God Mars; and others give you little les than meer Fables of his Original. As to Tarchetius, King of Alba, who was a mot wicked and cruel Man, appear'd in his own Houe a trange Viion, which was the Figure of a Man's Yard, that roe out of a Chimney-hearth, and tay'd there for many days. Whereupon the Oracle of Tethys in Thucany being conulted, the reult of it was that ome young Virgin hould accept of its Court, and he hould have a Son famous in his Generation, eminent for Vertue, good Fortune, and trength of Body. Tarchetius told the Prophecy to one of his own Daughters, and commanded her to entertain the Lover; but he lighting the Matter, put her Woman on the execution of it. Tarchetius hearing this, in great indignation imprion'd the Offenders, purpoing to put 'em to death; but being deterr'd from Murder by the Goddes Veta in a Dream, enjoyn'd them for their punihment the working a piece of Cloth, in their Chains as they were, which when they finih'd, they hould be
uffer'd to marry; but what-ever they work'd by day, Tarchetius commanded others to unravel in the night. In the mean time the Waiting-woman was deliver'd of two Boys, whom Tarchetius gave into the hands of one Teratius, with trict Command to detroy 'em; but he expos'd 'em to Fortune by a River-ide, where a Wolf contantly came and uckled 'em, and the Birds of the Air brought little morels of Food, which they put into their mouths; till a Neat-herd pying 'em, was firt trangely urpriz'd, but venturing to draw nearer, took the Children up in his arms. This was the manner of their preervation, and thus they grew up till they et upon Tarchetius, and overcame him. This Promathion ays, that writ the Hitory of Italy; but Diocles Peparethius deliver'd firt amongt the Graecians the mot principal Parts of the Hitory that has mot credit, and is generally receiv'd; him Fabius Pictor in mot things follows. Yet here too are till more Scruples rais'd: As for Example; The Kings of Alba decending lineally from Aeneas, the Succeion devolv'd at length upon two Brothers, Numitor and Amulius. Amulius to divide things into two equal hares, put in equivalency to the Kingdom all the Treaury and Gold that was
brought from Troy. Numitor choe the Kingdom; but Amulius having the Money, and being able to do more with that than Numitor, he both with a great deal of eae took his Kingdom from him, and withal fearing let his Daughter might have Children, made her a Vetal Nun, in that condition for ever to live a ingle and Maiden Life. This Lady ome call'd His Mother. Ilia, others Rhea, and others Sylvia; however not long after he was, contrary to the etablih'd Laws of the Vetals, dicover'd to be with Child, and hould have uffer'd the mot cruel punihment, had not Antho, the King's Daughter, mediated with her Father for her; nevertheles he was confin'd, and debarr'd all humane converation, that he might not be deliver'd without his knowledge. In time he brought forth two Boys, extraordinary both in the bignes and beauty of their Bodies: Whereupon Amulius becoming yet more fearful, commanded a Servant to take and cat 'em away; this Man ome call Fautulus; others ay, Fautulus was the Man who brought them up; Fautulus. who-ever the Servant was, he put the Children in a mall Trough, and went towards the River with a deign to cat them in; but eeing the Waters flow, and pouring in mighty urges upon him, he
fear'd to go nigher, but dropping the Children near the Bank, went himelf off; the River overflowing, the Flood at lat bore up the Trough, and gently wafting it, landed 'em on a very pleaant Plain, which they now call Cermanum. Cermanum, formerly Germanum, perhaps from Germani, which ignifies Brothers. Near this Place grew a wild Fig-tree, which they call'd Ruminalis, either from Romulus, (as it is vulgarly thought) or from Ruminor ignifies to chew the Cud.
Ruminating, becaue Cattel did uually in the heat of the day eek Cover under it, and there chew the Cud; or chiefly from the uckling of thee Children there; for the Ancients call'd the Dug or Teat of any Creature, Ruma, and the tutelar Goddes of all young Children they till call Rumilia. Rumilia, in acrificing to whom they made no ue of Wine, but Milk. While the Infants lay here, Hitory tells us, a he-Wolf nurs'd 'em, and a little
< in non-Latin alphabet > . Woodpecker contantly fed and foter'd 'em; thee Creatures are eteem'd holy to the God Mars, and for the Woodpecker, the Latines till egregiouly worhip and honour it. Whence it was not altogether incredible what the Mother of the Children aid, that he conceiv'd with Child by the God Mars, tho' they ay that mitake was put upon her by Amulius himelf,
being by him robb'd of her Honour, who appear'd to her all in Armour, and o committed a Rape upon her Body.

Others think the firt rie of this Fable came from the Childrens Nure, purely upon the ambiguity of a word; for the Latines not only call'd Wolves, Lupae, but alo lewd and protitute Women: And uch an one was the Wife of Fautulus, who nurtur'd thee Children, Acca Laurentia by Name; to her the Romans offer Sacrifices, and to her in the Month April the Priet of Mars does offer up a pecial Libation, and they call it the Laurentian Feat; they honour alo another Laurentia much upon the like occaion; as thus:

The Keeper of Hercules's Temple having, it eems, little ele to do, propos'd to his Deity a Game at Dice, laying down, that if he himelf won, he would have omething valuable of the God, but if he was beaten, he would pread him a noble Table, and procure withal a fair Lady to lye with him. Upon thee terms, reckoning firt the Chances that were thrown for the God, and then for himelf, he found plainly he had lot: nevertheles being willing Matters hould be adjuted, and thinking it honet to tick to the Propoals he made himelf, he both
provided the Deity a good Supper, and feeing Laurentia, who was a fine Creature, tho' not as yet a fam'd Beauty, treated her in the Temple, where he had alo laid a Bed, and after Supper lock'd her in, as if the God were really to enjoy her; and indeed it is aid, the Deity did truly bed the Lady, and commanded her in the Morning to walk the Streets, and whatever Man he met firt, him to alute, and make her Friend. The Man he met was by Name Tarrutius, far tricken in years, but of a competent ubitence, without Children, and had always liv'd a ingle Life: This Man
< in non-Latin alphabet > . knew Laurentia, and lov'd her well, and at his death left her ole Heir of all his large and fair Poeions, mot of which he in her lat Will and Tetament bequeath'd to the People. It was reported of her, being now a celebrated Beauty, and eteem'd the Mitres of a God, that he uddenly diappear'd near the Place where the firt Laurentia lay buried; the Place is at this day call'd Velabrum. Velabrum, becaue, the River frequently overflowing, they went over in Ferryboats much about this Place to the Market, which manner of Waftage the Latines call Velatura; others derive the Name from Velum a Veil, becaue the Exhibiters of publick Shews, generally making
their Proceion from the Market-place to the Circus maximus [or common Shew-place] did always veil that pace between. Upon thee accounts is the econd Laurentia o highly honour'd at Rome.

The Children all this while Fautulus, Amulius's Neat-herd, educated privately Romulus his Education. from the knowledge of all Men; but, as ome ay, and with the greatet likelihood too, Numitor was concious all along to the thing, and made Allowances under-hand to their Tutors; for it is aid, they were at Gabii well intructed in Letters, and all other Accomplihments befitting their Birth and Quality. The reaon of their Names (Romulus and Remus) was, as you find it in Story, becaue they were een Ruma ignifying a Dug. ucking of the Wolf. In their very Infancy, the noble tructure of their Bodies preently dicover'd the natural greatnes of their Minds and Thoughts; and when they grew up, they both prov'd of great Bravery and Manhood, attempting all Enterprizes that eem'd hazardous, and hewing till a Courage altogether undaunted. But Romulus eem'd rather to excel in Widom, and to have an Undertanding more adapted to politick Affairs, in his Life and Converation amongt his Neighbours, both in feeding his Flock, and managing
his Dogs for Hunting, raiing a great opinion in all, that he was born rather to rule and govern than be a Subject. To their Comrades, nay Inferiors, they were affable and courteous; but the King's Servants, his Bayliffs and Overeers, as being in nothing better Men than themelves, they depis'd and lighted, nor were the leat concernd at their commands and menaces. They us'd honet Patimes, and liberal Studies, eteeming Sloth and Idlenes not to be commendable, but rather Exercies, as Hunting and Running, catching of Robbers, taking of Thieves, and delivering the wrong'd and oppreed from injury. Upon this account they became famous.

Now there happening a Quarrel betwixt Numitor's and Amulius's Neatherds, The occaion of Romulus and Remus being known. the latter not enduring the driving away of their Cattel by the others, fell foul upon them, and put 'em to flight, and recued withal the greatet part of the prey. At which Numitor being highly incens'd, they little regarded it, but reunited their Forces, and picking up a great many needy Fellows and Servants, began a editious and mutinous Riot; and Romulus employing himelf then at a Sacrifice, (for he was a lover of holy Ceremonies and Prophecies) Numitor's Neatherds
meeting with Remus, upon a mall Journey he was making, fell upon him, and ome few Blows and Wounds paing between them, took Remus Prioner, who being carried before Numitor, and there accus'd of Midemeanors, he would not punih him himelf, fearing his Brother might be angry, but went to him, and deir'd Jutice might be done him, as he was his Brother, and was affronted by his Servants. The Men of Alba likewie reenting the thing ill, and thinking the Man dihonourably us'd, Amulius was induced to deliver Remus up into Numitor's hands, to ue him as he thought fit. He therefore took and carried him home, and being truck with admiration of the Youth's Peron, in proportion and trength of Body exceeding all Men, and perceiving in his very Countenance the courage and preence of his Mind, which tood undaunted and unhaken in his preent Calamities, and hearing farther all the Enterpries and Actions of his Life, were anwerable to what he aw of him, but chiefly (as it eem'd) God influencing and directing the Intruments of great Works, he having a deire and opportunity to enquire into the truth of him, in gentle terms and with a kind apect raiing a confidence and hope in him, ask'd
him, Who he was, and whence he was deriv'd. He taking heart, poke thus: I will, Sir, hide nothing from you, for you Remus's Speech
eem to be of a more Princely temper than Amulius, in that you give a hearing, and examine fairly, before you punih, but he condemns before the Caue is heard. Firt then, We (for we are Twins) thought our elves the Sons of Fautulus and Laurentia, the King's Servants; but ince we have been accus'd, and apers'd with Calumnies, and brought in peril of our Lives here before you, we hear great things of our elves, the truth whereof will appear from the iue of this danger we are in. Our Birth is aid to have been miraculous, our fotering and nurture in our Infancy till more trange; by Birds and Beats, to whom we were cat out, by them were we fed, that is, by the Milk of a Wolf, and the mall morels of a Woodpecker, as we lay in a little Trough by the ide of a River; the Trough is now in being, and is preerv'd with bras plates round it, and an Incription in old obcure Characters on it, which may prove hereafter but very inignificant tokens to our Parents, when we are dead and gone. Numitor, upon thee words, and recollecting the time too, according to the young Man's Looks, lighted not the hope that flatter'd him, but took care how to come at his Daughter
privately, (for he was till kept under retraint) to talk with her concerning thee Matters.

Amulius now being dead, and Matters quietly dipos'd, the two Brothers would neither dwell in Alba without governing there, nor were they willing to take the Government into their own hands, during the Life of their Grandfather. Having therefore deliver'd the Dominion up into his hands, and paid their Mother uch Repects as their Duty oblig'd 'em to, The firt deign of building Rome. they reolv'd to live by themelves, and build a City in the ame Place where they were in their Infancy brought up; for
this was the mot pecious pretence they could make, of their departure; tho' perhaps it was neceary, o many hoals of Slaves and Fugitives continually flocking to 'em, either to be totally diolv'd, by dipering them, or ele to plant a Colony elewhere with 'em; for that the Inhabitants of Alba did not think Fugitives worthy of being receiv'd and incorporated Citizens among them, firt plainly appear'd, from the Adventure upon their Women, which really was not attempted out of any violent lut, but deliberately, purely out of want and neceity of lawful Wives, whom they afterwards extreamly lov'd and honour'd.

Not long after the firt foundation of the City, they opened a Sanctuary of Refuge for all Fugitives, which they call'd the Temple of the God Aylaeus, where they receiv'd and protected all, delivering none back, either the Servant to his Mater, the Debtor to his Creditors, or the Murtherer into the hands of the Magitrate, aying, it was a priviledg'd Place, and they could o maintain it by an Order of the Holy Oracle; inomuch that the City grew preently very populous, for they ay, it conited at firt of no more than a 1000 Houes: But of that hereafter.

When Remus knew the Cheat, he was much dipleas'd; and as Romulus was cating up a Ditch, where he deign'd the foundation of the City-Wall, ome pieces of the Work he turn'd to ridicule, others he trampled on and purn'd at; at lat as he was in contempt skipping over the Work, ome ay, Romulus himelf troke him; others, that Celer, one of his Companions: however there fell Remus; in that Scuffle Remus is lain. alo was Fautulus lain, and Plitinus, who being Fautulus's Brother, Story tells us, help'd to bring up Romulus: Celer upon this fled intantly into Thucany, and
from him do the Romans call all Men that are wift of foot, Celeres; and becaue Quintus Metellus, at his Father's Funeral, in a few days time gave the People a Shew of Sword-playing, they admiring his expedition, gave him the Name of Celer.

Romulus, having buried his Brother Remus, together with his two Foter-fathers, on the Mount Remonius, fell a building his City; and ent for Surveyors out of Thucany, who directed him in Romulus begins to build. all the Ceremonies to be oberv'd, and intructed him, by drawing of Schemes, how every thing hould be done. Firt, They dug a Trench round that which is now the Comitium, or Hall of Jutice, and into it did they olemnly throw the Firtfruits of all things, either good by Cutom, or neceary by Nature; latly, every Man taking a mall Turf of Earth of the Countrey from whence he came, they all threw 'em in promicuouly together. This Trench they call'd Mundus, (the whole World) making which their Center, they deign'd the City in a Circle round it. Then the Founder fitted to a Plow a brazen Plow-hare, and yoking together a Bull and a Cow, drew himelf a deep Line or Furrow round the Bounds; the buines of them that follow'd after,
was to ee what-ever Earth was thrown up, hould be turn'd all inwardly towards the City, and not to lip a Clod that fell outwards. With this Line did they decribe the Wall, all within which were the Territories of the City, which they call'd Pomaerium, from Pot murum, or Pone maenia, by the cutting off or changing ome Letters; where they deign'd to make a Gate, there they lifted up the Plow, and left a pace for it; whereupon they eteem the whole Wall as holy, only where the Gates are; for had they adjudged them alo acred, they could not, without offence to Religion, have had a free ingres and egres for the Necearies of humane Life, ome whereof are in themelves unclean. As for the day they began to build the City, 'tis confes'd of The day when. all hands to be the 21t. of April, and that day the Romans do anniverarily keep holy, calling it their Countreys Birth-day; at firt, they ay, they acrificed no living Creature on this day, thinking it very decent and behoveful to celebrate the Feat of their Countreys Birth-day purely, and without the tain of blood; nevertheles before the City was ever built, there was a Feat of the Herdmen and Shepherds kept on this day, which went by the Name of Palilia. But now the
Roman and Graecian Months have little or no Analogy; thee ay, the day Romulus began to build was infallibly the 30th. of the month, at which time there was an Eclipe of the Moon, which happen'd in the 3d. year of the 6th. Olympiad, which the Graecians imagine Antimachus the Teian Poet aw. In the Times of Varro the Philoopher, a Man very well read in Roman Hitory, liv'd one Tarrutius, his familiar Friend and Acquaintance, both a good Philoopher and a skilful Mathematician, and one too that out of curioity of Speculation, had tudied the way of drawing Schemes and Tables, and eem'd to be excellent in the Art; to him Varro propounded to cat Romulus's Nativity, even to the firt day and hour, and to make his Deductions from the everal Events of the man's Life which he hould be inform'd of, as the olutions of Geometrical Problems do require; for it belongs to the ame Science both to foretel a man's Life, by knowing the time of his Birth, and alo to find out his Birth by the knowledge of his Life. This Task Tarrutius undertook, and firt looking into the Actions and Caualties of the man, together with the time of his Life and manner of his Death, and then comparing all thee Remarks together, he very confidently
and poitively pronounc'd, that Romulus was conceiv'd in his Mothers Womb, the firt year of the 2d. Olympiad, the 23d. day of the month the Aegyptians call Chaeac, (which may be aid to anwer our December) and the 3d. hour after Sunet; that he was born the 21t. day of the month Thoch, (which is September) about Sun-riing; and that the firt Stone of Rome was laid by him the 9th. day of the month Pharmuthi, (April) between the 2d. and 3d. hour; for, as to the Fortune of Cities, as well as Men, they think they have their certain periods of Time prefix'd, which may be collected and foreknown from the Poitions of the Stars at their firt foundation. Thee and the like Relations may perhaps rather take and delight the Reader with their Novelty and Extravagancy, than offend him becaue they are fabulous.

The City now being built, all that He divides the People. were of Age to bear Arms, Romulus lited into military Companies, each Company coniting of 3000 Footmen and 300 Hore. Thee Companies were call'd From lego, to chooe.
Legions, becaue they were the choicet and mot elect of the People for Fighting-men; the ret of the Multitude he call'd [Populus] the People. An hundred of the mot eminent Men he choe for his Counellors;
thee he tyl'd Patricians, and the whole Body of 'em, the Senate, which ignifies truly a
< in non-Latin alphabet > . Conitory of venerable old Men. The Patricians, ome ay, were o call'd, becaue they were the Fathers of honet and lawful Children; others, becaue they could give a good account who their Fathers were, which every one of the Rabble that pour'd into the City at firt could not do; others, from Patrocinium, a Patronage, by which they meant an Autority over the common People, and do till, attributing the origine of the word to Patronus, one of thoe that came over with Evander, a Man ignal for being a protector and defender of the weak and needy: But perhaps the mot probable Judgement might be, that Romulus eteeming it the duty of the chiefet and wealthiet men, with a fatherly care and concern to look after the meaner, and withal encouraging the Commonalty not to dread or be aggriev'd at the Honours of their Superiors, but with all good will to make ue of 'em, and to think and call 'em their Fathers, might from hence give them the Name of Patricians. For at this very time all Foreigners tyle thoe that it in Council, Lords and Preidents; but the Romans making ue of a more honourable and les invidious Name, call them,
Patres Concripti; at firt indeed imply Patres, but afterwards, more being added, Patres Concripti; and by this honourable Title was the Senate ditinguih'd from the Populacy; the ret of the wealthier ort he ditinguih'd from the common People, by calling Them Patrons, and Thee their Clients, by which means he created a wonderful Love and Amity betwixt 'em, which begat great jutice in their dealings. For They were always their Clients Councellors in litigious Caes, their Advocates in Judgements, in fine, their Adviers and Overeers in all Affairs what-ever. Thee again faithfully erv'd their Patrons, not only paying them all repect and deference, but alo, in cae of Poverty, helping them to place their Children, and pay off their Debts; and for a Patron to witnes againt his Client, or a Client againt his Patron, that no Law nor Magitrate could enforce; but in after-Times, all other Offices of Equity continuing till between 'em, it was thought a bae and dihonourable thing, for the better ort to take Money from their Inferiors. And o much of thee Matters.

In the 4th. month, after the City was His Stratagem upon the Sabine Virgins. built, (as Fabius writes) the Adventure of tealing Women was attempted; and, ome ay, Romulus himelf, being naturally
a Martial man, and predipos'd too perhaps by ome certain Oracles, as if the Fates had ordain'd the future growth and greatnes of Rome hould depend upon the benefit of War, did begin to ue violence to the Sabins, and that he took away only 30 Virgins, rather to give an occaion of War, than out of any want of Women; tho' this is not very probable, but rather that he oberving his City preently fill'd by a Confluence of Foreigners, few of whom had Wives, and that the Multitude in general, coniting of a mixture of mean and obcure Creatures, fell under contempt, and eem'd to be of no long continuance together, and hoping farther, after the Women were appeas'd, to make this Injury in ome meaure an occaion of Confederacy and mutual Commerce with the Sabines, took in hand this Exploit after this manner: Firt he gave it out, as if he had found an Altar of a certain God hid under ground; the God they call'd Conus, or the God of Council, (for they till call a Conult, Conilium, and their chief Magitrates, Conules, namely Counellors) this God is Neptune, the Inventer of Hore-riding; for the Altar is kept cover'd in the greater Cirque or Tilt-yard at other times, only at Hore-racing then it appears to publick view;
and ome ay, it was not without reaon, that this God had his Altar hid under ground, becaue all Councils ought to be ecret and conceal'd. Upon dicovery of this Altar, Romulus by Proclamation appointed a day for a plendid Sacrifice, and for publick Games and Shews, to entertain all orts of People, and many flock'd thither, he himelf ate uppermot, amidt his Nobles, clad in Purple. Now the Sign of their falling on was to be, whenever he roe and gather'd up his Robe, and threw it over his Body; his Men tood all ready arm'd, with their eyes intent upon him, and when the Sign was given, drawing their Swords, and falling on with a great hout, ravih'd away the Daughters of the Sabines, they themelves flying without any let or hindrance; they ay, there were but 30 taken, and from them were the Tribes or Parihes nam'd, but Valerius Antias ays, 527. Jubas, 683 Virgins, which was the greatet excue Romulus made, that they had taken never a married Woman ave one only, Herilia by Name, and her too unknowingly, which was a means of their reconciliation, for hence it appear'd, they did not for an affront or injury commit this Rape, but with a deign purely to joyn Families, and unite with 'em upon the
greatet and uret Bonds. This Herilia, ome ay, Hotilius married, a mot eminent Man among the Romans; others, Romulus himelf, and that he bare two Children to him, a Daughter, who by reaon of Primogeniture was call'd Prima, and one only Son, whom from the great concoure of Citizens to him at that time, he call'd Aollius, but after-Ages, Abillius. But thee things Zenodotus the Trazaenian
< in non-Latin alphabet > , congrego, to gather together. writes, which are contradicted by many.

Among thoe who committed this Rape upon the Virgins, there were, they ay, as it o then happen'd, ome of the meaner The reaon of the word Talaius at Weddings. ort of Men, who were carrying off a Damel, far excelling all both in beauty and comelines of Stature, whom, when
< in non-Latin alphabet > . ome Gentlemen that met 'em, attempted to take her from 'em, they cried out, they were carrying her to Talaius, a young Man indeed, but a brave and worthy Peron; hearing that, they commended and applauded them highly, inomuch that ome turning back, accompanied them with great joy and gladnes, houting and extolling the Name of Talaius. Hence do the Romans to this very time at their Weddings ing Talaius for their Nuptial word, as the Greeks do Hymenaeus, becaue, ay they, this Lady proved a fortunate and
happy Match to him. But Sextius Sylla the Carthaginian, a Man wanting neither Learning nor Ingenuity, told me, Romulus gave this word as a Sign when to begin the Onet; every body therefore who made prize of a Virgin, cried out, Talaius, and for that Reaon the Cutom continues o now at Marriages. But mot are of opinion, (of whom Jubas particularly is one) this word was us'd to new married Women, by way of admonihment and incitement to good Huwifery, the Greek word < in non-Latin alphabet > , ignifying Spinning, and the Italian words not being then mix'd with the Greek. But if this be not fale, and the Romans did at that time ue the word < in non-Latin alphabet > , as we Graecians do, a Man might fancy a more probable Reaon of the Cutom. For when the Sabines, after the War againt the Romans, were reconcil'd, Conditions were made concerning their Women, that they hould be obliged to do no other ervile Offices to their Husbands but what concern'd Spinning; it was cutomary therefore ever after at Weddings, for thoe that gave the Bride, or led her, or for any one ele preent, portingly to ay Talaius, intimating thereby, how he was now brought to no other Servitude but what was in Spinning. Moreover it is a Cutom at
this very day, for the Bride of her elf not to enter her Husband's Threhold, but to be lifted over, in memory that the Sabine Virgins were carried in by violence, and would not enter freely. Some ay too, the Cutom of parting the Brides Hair with the head of a Spear, was in token their Marriages began at firt by War, and Acts of Hotility; of which I have poken more fully in my Book of Quetions.
This Rape was committed the 18th. day of the month Sextilis, which is now Augut, on which the Solemnities of the Conualia are kept.

The Sabines were a numerous and martial People, but liv'd in mall unfortified The Ceninenfian's War againt Romulus. Villages, as it became them, who were a Colony of the Lacedaemonians, to be naturally of great courage, and fear nothing; nevertheles eeing themelves by great Hotages bound up to their good behaviour, and being olicitous for their Daughters, they ent Ambaadors to Romulus with fair and equitable Requets, that he would return their young Women, and retract that act of Violence, and afterwards in all Reaon and Equity etablih a friendly and neighbourly correpondence between both Nations. But Romulus would not part with the young Women,
yet propoed to the Sabines to enter into an alliance with 'em; upon which Point ome conulted and demurr'd long, but Acron King of the Ceninenes, a Man of great Courage, and well experienced in War, who had all along a jealouie of Romulus's bold Attempts, and conidering particularly from this Exploit upon the Women, he would grow formidable to all People, and indeed inufferable, were he not chatied, was the firt that roe up in Arms, and with a powerful Army made head againt him. Romulus like-wie prepared t • receive him; but when they came within ight, and viewed each other, they made a Challenge to fight a ingle Duel, the Armies tanding unconcerned by; hereupon Romulus prayed and made a Vow to Jupiter, if he did conquer his Enemy, to dedicate his Adverary's Armour to his Honour; upon which he both overcame him in Combat, and after Battel was joyn'd, routed his Are conquered. Army alo, and then took his City, but did thoe he found in it no injury, only commanded them to demolih the Place, and attend him to Rome, there to be made Citizens equally capable of all Priviledges: and indeed there was nothing did more advance the Greatnes of Rome, than that he did always unite and incorporate
whom he conquer'd into her elf. Romulus, that he might perform his Vow in the mot acceptable manner to Jupiter, and withal make the Pomp of it delightful to the eye of the City, cut down a tall Oak which he aw growing in the Camp, which he adorn'd like a Trophy, and faten'd thereon Acron's whole Suit of Armour, in its right ymmetry of Parts; then he himelf girding his Garment about him, and crowning his Head with a Laurel-Garland, his Hair gracefully flowing, carried the Trophy lying at length upon his right Shoulder, and o march'd on, inging Songs of Triumph, and his whole Army following after, the Citizens all receiving him with Acclamations of Joy and Wonder; the Pomp of this day was the caue, and rais'd the Emulation of all after-Triumphs. This Trophy was dedicated to Jupiter irnamed Feretrius, from ferire, which in Latin is to mite; for Romulus pray'd he might mite and overthrow his Enemy. Thee Opima polia, or royal Spoyls, are o call'd (ays Varro) from their Richnes, which the word Opes ignifies; the one would more probably conjecture from Opus, a Deed or Act; for when the General of an Army with his own hand kills his Enemy's General, to him alone is granted the Honour of offering
the Opima polia, as being the ole performer of that Act or Deed of Bravery. And on three only of the Roman Captains did this Honour ever happen to be conferr'd: Firt on Romulus, upon killing Acron the Ceninenian; next on Cornelius Cous, for laying Volumnius the Thucan; and latly on Claudius Marcellus, upon his conquering Viridomarus, King of the Gauls. The two latter, Cous and Marcellus, made their Entries in triumphant Chariots, bearing their Trophies themelves, but that Romulus made ue of a Chariot, Dionyius is in the wrong; for Hitory ays, Tarquinius, Damaratus's Son, was the firt that brought Triumphs to this great Pomp and Grandeur; others, that Publicola was the firt that rode in Triumph; however all the Statues of Romulus in Triumph are to be een in Rome on Foot.

After the Overthrow of the Ceninenians, the Sabines till protracting the time in Preparations, the People of Fidena, Crutumerium, and Antemna, joyn'd their Forces againt the Romans; Battel was no ooner joyn'd, but they were likewie immediately defeated, & urrendred up to Romulus their Cities to be poil'd, their Lands and Territories to be divided, & themelves to be tranplanted to a Colony at Rome.
All the Lands which Romulus acquir'd, he ditributed among the Citizens, except only what the Parents of the tolnvirgins had, and them he uffer'd to poes their own: the ret of the Sabines being enraged here-at, chooing Tatius their Captain, march'd traight againt Rome; the City was almot The Sabines beiege Rome. inacceible, having for its Fortres that which is now the Capitol, where a trong Guard was placed, and Tarpeius was their Captain, not Tarpeia the Virgin, (as ome ay, who would make Romulus guilty of a foolih Action.) But till Tarpeia, the Captain's Daughter, coveting the golden Bracelets he aw them wear, betrayed the Fort into the Sabines hands, and asked in reward of her Treachery, Tarpeia betrays it. all they wore on their left Arms. Tatius conditioning thus with her, in the night he opened one of the Gates, and received the Sabines in: And truly (for ought I ee) it is not Antigonus alone that aid, He lov'd Betrayers, but hated them after they had betrayed; nor Caear, when he told Rhymitalces the Thracian, that He lov'd the Treaon, but hated the Traitor; but it is a general kind of Affection, all Men, who have occaion for wicked Perons, bear towards them; much uch as they have for venomous Creatures, when they tand in need of their poyon and
gall; for as they love them while they are of ue, o they abhor their ill qualities when that is over. And thus did Tatius behave himelf towards Tarpeia, for he commanded the Sabines, in regard to their Contract, not to refue her the leat part of what they wore on their left Arms; upon that he himelf firt took his Bracelet off his Arm, and threw that together with his Buckler at her, and all the ret following, he, being born down and And is kill'd in recompence. quite mother'd with the multitude of Gold and their Shields, died under the great weight and preure of them; nay, Tarpeius himelf being proecuted by Romulus, was found guilty of Treaon, as Juba ays, Sulpitius Galba relates. Thoe who write otherwie concerning Tarpeia, as that he was the Daughter of Tatius the Sabine Captain, and being forcibly detain'd by Romulus, acted and uffer'd thus by her Father's contrivance, peak very aburdly: of whom Antigonus is one; but Smylus, the Poet of all Men, who thinks Tarpeia betrayed the Capitol not to the Sabines, but the Gauls, having fallen in Love with their King, does plainly dote. Thus he writes:
Tarpeia 'twas, who dwelling cloe thereby,
Open'd the Walls of Rome to th' Enemy.
She hot in lut of the beieging Gaul,
Betray'd the City's Strength, the Capitol.
And a little after peaking of her Death:
But yet the Gauls, that trong and numerous Foe,
Drown'd not the Traitres in the Waves of Po,
But, with their Shields thrown on, her Body overlaid,
So died, and was entomb'd at once the wretched Maid.
Tarpeia afterwards was buried there, and the Hill from her was call'd Tarpeius, until the Reign of King Tarquin, who dedicated the Place to Jupiter, at which time her Bones were removed, and o it lot her Name, except only that part of the Capitol which they till call the Tarpeia Rupes. Tarpeian Rock, from whence they are wont to cat down headlong Malefactors.

The Sabines being poes'd of the Hill, Romulus in great fury bade them Battel, and Tatius put on the courage to accept The Sabines and Romans fight. it, perceiving, if they were o contrain'd, where he might make a ecure Retreat. The Level in the middle, where they were to joyn Battel, being urrounded with many little Hills, eem'd to enforce both Parties to a mart and deperate Conflict, by reaon of the Difficulties of the
Place, which had but a few narrow Outlets, inconvenient either for refuge or puruit. It happen'd too, the River having overflowed not many days before, there was left behind in the Plain, where now the Market tands, a deep blind Mud and Slime, which, tho' it did not appear much to the eye, and was not eaily avoided, yet at bottom was very deceitful and dangerous; upon which the Sabines being unwarily about to enter, had good luck befel them; for Curtius, a gallant Man, eager of Honour, and of apiring thoughts, being mounted on Hore-back, gallop'd a good ditance before the ret, but his Hore was mired, and he endeavour'd a while by Whip and Spur to diintangle him, but finding it impoible, he quitted his Hore, and aved himelf; the Place from him to this very time is call'd the Curtian Lake. The Sabines having ecaped this danger, began the Fight very martly, the fortune of the day being very dubious, tho' many were lain; amongt whom was Hotilius, who, they ay, was Husband to Herilia, and Grandfather to that Hotilius who reign'd after Numa. It is probable there were many other Battels in a hort time after, but the mot memorable was the lat, in which Romulus having receiv'd a Wound on his
Head by a Stone, and being almot fell'd to the ground by it, and diabled to utain the Enemy, the Romans upon that yielded ground, and being driven out of the Field, fled to the Palatium. Romulus by this time recovering his Wound a little, running upon his Men in flight, remanded them to their Arms again, and with a loud voice encouraged them to tand and fight. But being overpowr'd with the number, and no body daring to face about, he tretching out his hands to Heaven, pray'd to Jupiter to top the Army, and not to neglect but rather maintain the Roman Caue, which was now in extream danger. This Prayer both wrought a great Reverence in many for their Prince, and a trange reolution too on the udden in their minds. The Place they firt tood at was, where now is the Temple of Jupiter Stator, (which may be interpreted the Stayer) there they rallied their Forces, and repuls'd the Sabines even to the Place call'd now Rhegia, and the Temple of Veta; where both Parties preparing to renew the Fight, were prevented by a trange and unexpreible ight; for the Daughters of the Are parted by the Women. Sabines which were formerly toln, came running, in great confuion, ome on this ide, ome on that, with mierable cryes
and lamentations, like ditracted Creatures, into the midt of the Army, and among the dead Bodies, to come at their Husbands and at their Fathers, ome with their young Babes in their Arms, others their Hair looe about their Ears, but all calling now upon the Sabines, then upon the Romans, in the mot tender and endearing words. Hereupon both melted into compaion, and fell back, that they might tand betwixt the Armies. Now did a trange lamentation eize all, and great grief was conceiv'd at the ight of the Women, and at their Speech much more, which from Expotulations and high words, ended in Entreaties and Supplications.

Wherein (ay they) have we injured or offended you, that we formerly have, and now do uffer under thee Calamities? We were ravih'd away unjutly and violently by thoe whoe now we are; that being done, we were o long neglected by our Fathers, our Brethren, and Countreymen, that time, having now by the trictet bonds united us to thoe whom we once mortally hated, has brought it about, that the very Men, who once ued violence to us, we now have a tendernes for in War, and lament their deaths. So that you do not now come to vindicate our Honour, as Virgins, from them that injured
us, but to force away Wives from their Hubands, and Mothers from their Children, making this your recue more grievous to us Wretches, than your former betraying and neglect of us was; o great is their Love towards us, and uch your Compaion; if you make War upon any other occaion, for our akes you ought to deit, who are our Fathers, our Grandfathers, our Relations and Kindred; if for us, take us and your Sons-in-law, and retore us to our Parents and Kinsfolk, but do not rob us (we humbly beeech you) of our Children and Husbands, let we again become Captives. Herilia having poken many uch words as thee, and others earnetly praying, a Truce was made, and the chief Officers came to a Treaty, the Women, during that time, brought and preented their Husbands and Children to their Fathers and Brethren; gave thoe, that would eat, Meat and Drink; and carried the wounded home to be cured; and hewed alo how much they govern'd within doors, and how indulgent their Husbands were to 'em, in demeaning themelves towards 'em with all kindnes and repect imaginable. Upon this, Conditions were agreed upon, that A Peace made. what Women pleas'd might tay where they were, exempt from all drudgery and labour but Spinning; that the Romans
and Sabines hould inhabit the City promicuouly together; that the City hould be call'd Rome from Romulus, but the Romans, Quirites, from the Countrey of Tatius; and that they both hould govern and command in common: The Place of this Ratification is till call'd Comitium, from Coire to agree.
