The City being thus doubled in number, an 100 of the Sabines were elected Senators, and the The City ettled Legions were increas'd to 6000 Foot, and 600 Hore; then they divided the People into three Tribes; the firt, from Romulus, were named Rhamnenes; the econd, from Tatius, Tatienes; the third were call'd Luceres, from the Lucus or Grove where the Aylum tood, whither many fled for Sanctuary, and were received into the City; and that they were jut three, the very Name of Tribe and Tribune does tetifie; each Tribe contained then ten Curiae or Wards, which, ome ay, took their Names from the Sabine Women; but that eems to be fale, becaue many had their Names from different Regions. Tho', 'tis true, they then contituted many things in honour to the Women: As to give them the way where-ever they met them; to peak no ill word in their preence; not to appear naked before them; that they hould not
be ummon'd into Court before a Judge itting on Caes of Blood; that their Children hould wear an Ornament about their Necks call'd the Bulla, (becaue it was like a Bubble) and the Praetexta, a Garment edged with purple.

The Princes did not immediately joyn in Council together, but at firt each met with his own Hundred, afterwards all aembled together. Tatius dwelt where now the Temple of Moneta tands; and Romulus cloe by the
< in non-Latin alphabet >
Steps, as they call them, of the fair Shore, near the decent from the Mount Palatine to the Circus Maximus. There, they ay, grew the Holy Cornel-tree, of which, they report, that Romulus once to try his trength, threw a Dart from the Aventine Mount, (the Staff of which was made of Cornel) which truck o deep into the ground, that no one, of many that tryed, could pluck it up: Now the Soyl, being fertil, nourih'd the Wood, and ent forth Branches, and produced a Trunk of coniderable bignes; this did Poterity preerve and worhip as one of the mot acred things, and therefore wall'd it about, and if to any one it appear'd not green nor flourihing, but inclining to fade and wither, he preently made outcry to all he met, and they with one accord cryed for
Water, as in a Fire, and would run from all Parts with Buckets full to the Place. But, they ay, when Caius Caear was repairing the Steps about it, ome of the Labourers digging too cloe, the Root corrupted, and the Tree quite withered.

The Sabines received the ue of Roman Months: of which, what-ever is remarkable, The rie of everal Cutoms and Feats. is mention'd in the Life of Numa. Romulus again took up their manner of Shields, for which he exchanged both his own and all the Romans Armour, who before wore mall Targets, after the manner of the Argives. But for Feats and Sacrifices, they partaked of them in common, not abolihing any either Nation oberv'd before, and intituting everal new ones: Of which one was the Matronalia, intituted in honour of the Women, for their diolving the War. As like-wie the Carmentalia: This Carmenta, ome think a Detiny preiding over the Generation of Men, wherefore Mothers much revere and worhip her. Others ay, he was the Wife of Evander the Arcadian, being a Prophetes, and wont to deliver her Oracles in Vere, and from Carmen a Vere, was call'd Carmenta, whereas it is generally confes'd her proper Name was Nicotrata. Others more probably derive Carmenta from Carens mente,
as being bereft of her wits, by reaon of her wild Enthuiams. Of the Feat of Palilia we have poke before. The Lupercalia, by the time of its Celebration, may eem to be a Feat of Purification, for it is olemnized on the Dies nefati, or non-Court-days of the month February, which a Man may interpret Purifying, and the very day of the Feat was anciently call'd Februaca: But the Name of it in Greek ignifies as much as the Feat of
< in non-Latin alphabet > . Wolves, and it eems upon this account to be of great Antiquity, and brought in by the Arcadians who came with Evander. But this is a trivial Fancy, for it may come as well from the Wolf that nured Romulus, and we ee the Luperci, the Priets, do begin their coure from the Place where they ay Romulus was expoed. But the Ceremonies that then pas, render the Original of the thing more difficult to be gues'd at; for there are Goats kill'd, then two young Noblemen's Sons being brought, ome are to tain their Foreheads with the bloody Knife, others preently to wipe it off with Wool dipt in Milk; then the young Boys mut laugh after their Foreheads are wiped; that done, having cut the Goats-skins into Thongs, they run about naked, only with omething about their middle, lahing
all they meet; the young Wives do never avoid their trokes, fancying it does help Conception and Child-birth. Another thing is proper to this Feat, for the Luperci to acrifice a Dog. Butas, a certain Poet, who writ a fabulous account of the Roman Cutoms in Elegies, ays, that Romulus, after the Conquet of Amulius, ran joyfully to the Place where the Wolf gave them uck, and that in imitation of that, this Feat was, and that two young Noblemen ran:
Striking at all, as when from Alba Town,
Romulus and Remus with their Swords did run,
And that the bloody Knife applied to their Foreheads, was a ign of the danger they were then in of being lain, and the cleaning of them in Milk, was in remembrance of their food and nourihment. But Caius Aulius writes, that before the City was built, the Cattel of Romulus and Remus on a day going atray, they, praying to the God Faunus, ran about to eek them naked, that they might not be troubled with weat, and that for that Reaon the Luperci run naked. And if this Sacrifice be by way of Purification, a Man might gues they ued a Dog for that very purpoe; for the Graecians in their Lutrations,
or Sacrifices of Purging, do carry out Dogs, and evermore ue that Ceremony they call, < in non-Latin alphabet > , or a acrificing of a Dog. But if they perform this as an act of Gratitude to the Wolf, that nourih'd and preerv'd Romulus, they do not aburdly in killing a Dog, as being an Enemy to Wolves, unles it is perhaps for hindering the Luperci when they run.

They ay too, Romulus was the firt that conecrated holy Fire, and intituted holy Virgins, call'd Vetals; others acribe it to Numa Pompilius; nevertheles they write, Romulus was otherwie eminently religious, and well skill'd in the Art of Prophecying, and upon that carri'd a Lituus, which is a crooked Rod, wherewith the Soothayers decribe the Quarters of the Heavens. This of his, being kept in the Palatium, was lot when the City was taken by the Gauls, and afterwards that barbarous People being driven out, was found in the Ruines under a great heap of Rubbih, untouch'd by the fire, all things about it being conumed and burnt. He contituted alo certain Laws, one whereof is omewhat evere, which uffers not a Wife to leave her Husband, but grants a Husband to turn off his Wife, either upon poyoning her
Children, or counterfeiting his Keys, or Adultery; but if the Husband upon any other occaion put her away, he ordered one moiety of his Etate to be given to the Wife, the other to fall to the Goddes Ceres; and who ever did cat off his Wife, to make an Atonement by Sacrifice to the
< in non-Latin alphabet > . Gods of the Earth. This too is obervable as a ingular thing in Romulus, that he appointed no punihment for real Parricide, but call'd all Murder o, thinking the latter a detetable in, but the other impoible, and for a long time he eem'd to have rightly thought uch a in could never be, for in almot 600 years together, no body committed the like in Rome; and Lucius Otius, after the Wars of Hannibal, is recorded to have been the firt Parricide. But let thus much uffice concerning thee Matters.

In the 5th. year of the Reign of Tatius, ome of his Friends and Kinmen meeting The occaion of the death of Tatius. Ambaadors coming from Laurentum to Rome, attempted on the Road to take away their Money by force, which they not uffering, but defending themelves, they kill'd them. So great a Villany being acted, Romulus thought it fitting preently to punih the Malefactors; but Tatius huffled off and deferr'd the execution of it; and this only thing was the firt beginning
of an open Quarrel betwixt them, for otherwie they carried themelves fairly one to another, and adminitred Affairs together with the greatet unanimity. The Relations of them that were lain, being debarr'd of jutice by reaon of Tatius, fell upon him as he was acrificing with Romulus at Lavinium, and lew him, commending and extolling Romulus for a jut Prince. Romulus took the Body of Tatius, and buried it very plendidly in the Aventine Mount, near the Place call'd Armilutrium, but altogether neglected revenging his Murder. Some Authors write, the City of Laurentum, fearing the conequence, delivered up the Murderers of Tatius; but Romulus pas'd it over, aying, One Murder was requited with another. This gave occaion of Talk and Jealouie, as if he were well pleas'd at the removal of his Copartner in the Government. Nothing of thee things either diturbed or rais'd any Feud among the Sabines, but ome out of Love to him, others out of fear of his Power, ome again reverencing him as a God, they all lived peacefully in admiration and awe of him; many foreign Nations too did much admire Romulus; the ancient Latines they ent, and enter'd into League and Confederacy with him. Fidenae he
took, a neighbouring City to Rome, by Romulus tak • s Fidenae. a Party of Hore, as ome ay, whom he ent before with Commands to cut down the Hinges of the Gates, and he himelf afterwards unexpectedly came upon them. Others ay, they having firt made the Invaion, in foraging and poyling the Countrey and Suburbs, Romulus lay in ambuh for them, and o having kill'd many of their Men, took the City, nevertheles he did not raze or demolih it, but made it a Roman Colony, and ent thither on the Ides of April 2500 Inhabitants. Preently after a Plague broke out, which kill'd uddenly without any manner of A Plague at Rome. Sicknes; it infected alo the Corn with Unfruitfulnes, and Cattel with Barrennes; there rained Blood too in the City, inomuch as beides the Evils which came of conequence, Men dreaded the wrath of the Gods. But when the ame Michiefs fell upon Laurentum, then every body judged it was divine Vengeance that fell upon both Cities, for the neglect of executing Jutice, upon the Murder of Tatius and the Ambaadors. But the Murderers on both ides being deliver'd up and punih'd, the Petilence viibly abated, and Romulus purified the Cities with Lutrations, which, they ay, even now are perform'd at the Gate call'd Ferentina.
But before the Plague ceaed, the Camerians invaded the Romans, and over-ran the Countrey, thinking, by reaon of the Ditemper, they were unable to withtand them; but Romulus preently made Head againt them, and gain'd the Victory, with the laughter of 6000 Men; he then took their City, and brought half of them he found there to Rome, and ent from Cameria is taken.
Rome to Cameria double the number he left there. This was done the 1t. of Augut; o many Citizens had he to pare, in 16 years time he inhabited Rome. Among other Spoyls he took a brazen Chariot from Cameria, which he placed in the Temple of Vulcan, adding thereon his own Statue crown'd with Victory.

The Roman Caue thus daily gathering trength, the weaker Neighbours ubmitted, and willingly embraced ecurity; the tronger, out of Fear or Envy, thought they ought not to give way to Romulus, but to curb him, and put a top The Veientes ubdued. to his Greatnes. The firt were the Veientes, a People of Thucany, who had large Poeions, and dwelt in a pacious City; they took an occaion to commence a War, upon remanding of Fidenae, as belonging to them; this was not only unreaonable but very ridiculous, that they who did not ait them in the greatet
Extremities of War, but permitted them to be lain, hould challenge their Lands and Houes when in the hands of others. But being cornfully retorted upon by Romulus in his Anwers, they divided themelves into two Bodies; with one they attack'd the Garrion of Fidenae, the other march'd againt Romulus; that which went againt Fidenae, got the Victory, and lew 2000 Romans; the other was worted by Romulus, with the los of 8000 Men. They afterwards fought near Fidenae, and all Men acknowledge the greatet Actions of the day were done by Romulus himelf, who hewed all manner of Skill as well as Courage, and eem'd to perform with trength and wiftnes more than humane. But what ome write, that of 14000 that fell that day, above half were lain by Romulus's own hand, is both very fabulous and altogether incredible: Such an Otentation do the Meenians make of Aritomenes, who, they ay, offer'd 300 Victims for as many Lacedaemonians he himelf lew. The Army being thus routed, Romulus uffering thoe that were left to make their ecape, drew up his Forces againt the City; they, having uffer'd uch great damages, did not venture to oppoe him, but humbly uing to him, contracted a League and Friendhip for an 100 years; but he nevertheles
diveted them of a great quantity of Lands, call'd Septimagium, which was the 7th. part of their Patrimony; as alo of everal alt-Springs upon the River, and took 50 Noblemen for Hotages. He made his Triumph for this on the Ides of October, leading, among the ret of his many Captives, the General of the Veientes, an ancient Man, but one who eem'd to have managed his Affairs imprudently, and unbecoming of his Age; whence even now in Sacrifices for Victories, they lead an old Man through the Market-place to the Capitol apparell'd in purple, with a Bulla or Child's-Toy tyed to it, and the Cryer cryes, Sardianians to be old; for the Thucans are aid to be a Colony of the Sardianians, and the Veientes are a City of Thucany.

This was the lat Battel Romulus ever fought; afterwards he, as mot, nay all Men, very few excepted, do, who are raied by great and miraculous good-haps of Fortune to Power and Greatnes: So, I ay, did he; for relying upon his own Romulus grows inolent. great Actions, and growing of an haughtier mind, he forook his popular Behaviour, and took upon him in exchange a trange Lordlines, which was odious and intolerable to the People. And firt, upon the Habit he choe to wear; for he dres'd in carlet with purple Robes over it, then
he gave Audience in a Chair of State, having always about him ome young Boys call'd Celer, wift.
Celeres, from their wiftnes in doing buines; there went before him others with Staves to make room, with everal Cords about them, preently to bind whom ever he commanded. Now the Latines formerly ued ligare, as now alligare, to bind, whence the Lictors were o call'd, and the Rods they carried were called Faces; but it is probable they were firt call'd Litores, afterwards by putting in a C, Lictores, for they are the ame the Graecians call < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Officers for the People; and the Graecians do till call the People in general, < in non-Latin alphabet > , and the common People, < in non-Latin alphabet > .

When after the death of his Grandfather Numitor in Alba, that Kingdom devolv'd upon Romulus, he put the Government into the hands of Magitrates, and elected yearly one to uperintend the Sabines. But that taught the Senators of Offends the Senate. Rome to eek after a free and Anti-monarchical State, wherein all might hare in the Rule and Government. For the Patricians, (as they call them,) were not now concern'd in State-Affairs, only had the Name and Title left them, convening in Council rather for fahion-ake than Advice, where they in ilence heard the King's Commands, and o departed, exceeding
the Commonalty only in this, that they heard firt what was done. Thee and the like were Matters of mall moment; but when he of his own accord parted among his Souldiers what Lands were acquired by War, and retored the Veientes their Hotages, the Senate neither conenting nor approving of it, then indeed he eem'd to put a great Affront upon them; whereupon, he uddenly diappearing a hort while after, the Senate fell under hrewd Supicions and Calumnies. He diappear'd on the Nones of July, as they now call the month, which Dies. was then Quintilis, leaving nothing of certainty to be related of his Death, only the time, as you hear: for there are now upon that day many Ceremonies perform'd in reemblance of that Misfortune. Neither is this uncertainty to be thought trange, eeing the manner of the Death of Scipio Africanus, who died at his own home after Supper, is neither much credited nor diprov'd; for, ome ay, he died eaily & uddenly; as it were of his own accord, being naturally a ickly Man; others, that he poyon'd himelf; others again, that his Enemies breaking in upon him in the night, tifled him. Scipio too when he was dead, lay open to be een of all, and indeed his Body gave ome upicion, and a reaonable dicovery of the Fact; but of Romulus,
when he vanih'd, was neither the leat part of his Body, or rag of his Cloaths to be een. So that ome fancied, the Senators having fallen upon him, cut his Body Several Opinions of his Death. into pieces, and each took a part away in his boom; others think, his diappearance was neither in the Temple of Vulcan, nor with the Senators only by; but that it happen'd, as he was haranguing the People without the City, near a Place call'd the
< in non-Latin alphabet >
Goats Marh, on the udden mot wonderful Diorders and Alterations beyond expreion roe in the Air, for the face of the Sun was darkned, and the day was turn'd into an unquiet and turbulent night, made up of terrible Thunderings, and boiterous Winds raiing Tempets from all Quarters, which cattered the Rabble and made them fly, but the Senators kept cloe together. The Tempet being over, and the light breaking out, when the People gather'd again, they miss'd and enquir'd for their King; but the Senators would not let them earch, or buie themelves about the Matter, but commanded them to honour and worhip Romulus, as one taken up to the Gods, and about to be to them, of a good Prince, now a propitious God. The Multitude hearing this, went away rejoycing and worhipping him, in hopes of good things from him; but there were ome who canvaing
the Matter more everely and rigorouly, accus'd and apers'd the Patricians, as Men that peruaded the People to believe ridiculous Tales, when they themelves were the Murderers of the King. Things being in this diorder, one, they ay, of the Patricians, of a noble Family, and Julius Proculus decides the Matter. mot honet Converation, and withal a mot faithful and familiar Friend of Romulus himelf, who came with him from Alba, Julius Proculus by Name, tepping into the Company, and taking a mot acred Oath, proteted before them all, that Romulus appear'd to, and met him traveling on the Road, comelier and fairer than ever, dres'd in hining and flaming Armour, and he being affrighted at the Apparition, aid, pon what Occaion or Reentments, O King, did you leave us here, liable to mot unjut and wicked Surmies, and the whole City detitute, in mot bitter Sorrow? And that he made Anwer: It pleas'd the Gods, O Proculus, we hould remain o long a time amongt Men as we did, and having built a City, the greatet in the World both in Empire and Glory, we hould again return to Heaven; but farewel, and tell the Romans, that by the exercie of Temperance and Fortitude, they hall far exceed all humane Power, and we will be to you the propitious God Quirinus. This eem'd very credible to the Romans, both upon the
Honety and Oath of him that poke it, and a certain divine Paion, like an Enthuiam, eized on all Men, for no body contradicted it, but laying aide all Jealouies and Detractions, they prayed to Quirinus, and aluted him God.

This is like ome of the Graecian Fables of Ariteas the Proconneian, and Cleomedes the Atypalaeian; for, they ay, Ariteas died in a Fuller's Work-houe, and, his Friends coming to him, his Body vanih'd; and that ome preently after coming a Journey, aid, they met him travelling towards Croton. And that Cleomedes, being an extraordinary trong and gygantic Man, and withal crazed and mad, committed many deperate Freaks: At lat in a certain School-houe, triking a Pillar that utain'd the Roof with his Fit, broke it in the middle, o the Houe fell and detroyed the Children in it; and being purued, he fled into a great Chet, and hutting to the Lid, held it o fat, that many Men with all their trength could not force it open; afterwards breaking the Chet to pieces, they found no Man in it alive or dead; at which being atonih'd, they ent to conult the Oracle at Delphi; to whom the Prophetes made this Anwer:

Of all the Heroes, Cleomede is lat. They ay too, the Body of Alomeno, as
he was carrying to her Grave, vanih'd, and a Stone was found lying on the Bier. And many uch Improbabilities do your fabulous Writers relate, deifying Creatures naturally mortal; tho' altogether to diown a divine Power, is an unholy and diingenuous thing; o again to mix Heaven and Earth, is as ridiculous; therefore we mut reject uch Vanities, being aur'd that, according to Pindar,
All humane Bodies yield to Deaths decree,
The Soul urvives to all eternity.
For that alone is deriv'd from the Gods, thence it comes, and thither it returns: not with the Body, but when it is mot free and eparated from it, and is altogether pure and clean, and diengag'd from the fleh; for the dry Soul (as Heraclitus phraes it) is bet, which flies out of the Body, as Lightning breaks from a Cloud; but that which is clogg'd and incumber'd with the Body, is like a gros and cloudy Vapour, hard to be kindled and mount on high. We mut not therefore, contrary to Nature, end the Bodies too of good Men to Heaven; but again we mut really believe that, according to a divine Nature and Jutice, their vertuous Souls are tranlated out of Men into Heroes; out of Heroes into demi-Gods; out of demi-Gods, (if they are, as by expiation, perfectly purg'd and anctified, and
disburden'd of all Paions attending Mortality) they are, not as in any humane Polity alter'd, but really and according to right Reaon chang'd and tranlated into Gods, receiving the greatet and mot bleed perfection.

Romulus his irname Quirinus, ome ay, ignifies as much as Mars or Warlike; others, Why Romulus was call'd Quirinus. that he was o call'd, becaue the Citizens were call'd Quirites; others, becaue the Ancients call'd a Dart or Spear Quiris, for the Statue of Juno placed on a Spear was call'd Quiritis, and the Dart in the King's Palace was call'd Mars, and thoe that behav'd themelves valiantly in War, were uually preented with a Dart, and that therefore Romulus, being a martial God, or a God of Darts, was call'd Quirinus; and there is a Temple built to his Honour on a Mount call'd from him Quirinalis.

The day he vanih'd on is call'd the Flight of the Rabble, or the
< in non-Latin alphabet > . Nones of the Goats, becaue they go then out of the City, and acrifice at the Goats-Marh, and as they go, they call out loudly upon the Names of ome of their Compatriots, as Marcellus and Caius, imitating how they then fled, and call'd upon one another in that Fright and Hurry. Some ay, this was not in imitation of a Flight, but of a quick and haty Onet, giving this account of
it: After the Gauls, who had taken Rome, were driven out by Camillus, and the City had not as yet recover'd her trength, many of the Latines, under the Command of Livius Pothumius, took this time to march againt her. The Army itting down before Rome, an Herald was ent, ignifying that the Latines were deirous to renew their former Alliance and Affinity, (that was now almot decayed) by contracting new Marriages between both Nations; if therefore they would end forth a good number of their Virgins and Widows, they hould ettle into a Peace and Friendhip, as they formerly did with the Sabines upon the like Conditions. The Romans hearing this, they both dreaded a War, yet thought a Surrender of their Women little better than a meer Captivity. Being in this doubt, a Servant-maid call'd Philotis, (or as ome ay, Teutola) advis'd them to do neither, but rather, by a Stratagem, both to avoid Fighting, and the giving up of uch Pledges. The Stratagem was this, that they hould end her elf, with a company of handom Wenches well dres'd, to the Enemy, intead of Free-born Virgins, and he would in the night light up a Torch, at which the Romans hould come arm'd and urprize them aleep. The Latines were thus deceiv'd, and accordingly Philotis et up a Torch in a wild
Fig-tree, skreening it behind with Curtains and Coverlets from the ight of the Enemy: But it was plain to the Romans: when they aw it, they ran furiouly together out of the Gates, hatening one another what they could, o falling in unexpectedly upon the Enemy, they defeated them. Upon that they made a Feat of Triumph, call'd the Nones of the Goats, becaue of the wild Fig-tree, call'd by the Romans, Caprificus, or the Goat-Fig; and they feat the Women without the City in Arbors made of Fig-tree boughs, and the Maids meet and run about playing; afterwards they fight in Sport, and throw Stones one at another, in memory they did then aid and ait the Roman Men in Fight. This many Authors do not admit for true: for the calling upon one anothers Names by day, and the going out to the Goats-Marh, as to Sea, eems to agree more to the former Relation, unles perhaps both the Actions, done at everal times, might have happen'd on the ame day of the Week. Now, they ay, it was in the 54th. year of his Age, and the 38th. How old he was when he died. of his Reign, that Romulus left the World.

div.head: The Comparion of Romulus and Theeus.
div.p:
THis is all I ever happen'd to hear of Romulus and Theeus, worthy of memory. Firt, Theeus eem'd, out of his own free-will, without any compulion, when he might have reign'd in ecurity at Trazene, in the enjoyment of no inglorious Empire, to have affected great Actions by himelf. The other to ecape preent Servitude, and a punihment that threatned him, (according to Plato,) grew valiant purely out of fear; and dreading the extreamet Inflictions, attempted great Enterprizes out of meer neceity. Again, His greatet Action was only the killing of one King of Alba; whereas the by-Adventures and Preludes of the other were the Conquets of Sciron, Scinnis, Procrutes and Corynetes; by reducing and killing of whom, he ridded Greece of very violent Oppreors, before any of them that were relieved, knew who did it; and he might then without any trouble as well have gone to Athens by Sea, conidering he himelf never was in the leat injured by thoe Robbers; whereas Romulus could not but be in Action whilt Amulius lived. A great tetimony of this is, that Theeus, for no wrong done himelf, but for the ake of others, did fall upon thee Villains; but Romulus and Remus, as long as they themelves uffer'd no ill by the Tyrant, permitted him to opprefs all others. And if it be a great thing to have been wounded in Battel by the Sabines, to have kill'd King Acron, and to have conquer'd many Enemies; we may oppoe to thee Actions, the Battel with the Centaurs, and the Feats done againt the Amazons. But what Theeus adventur'd, in offering himelf voluntarily with the other young Boys and Virgins, as part of the Tribute into Crete, either to be a
Prey to a Monter, or a Victim upon the Tomb of Androgeus, or, what is leat of all, to live vilely and dihonourably in lavery to inulting and cruel Men; a Man cannot expres what an Act of Boldnes, or Courage, or Jutice to the Publick, or of Honour and Bravery, that was. So that methinks the Philoophers did not define Love ill, to be the ervice of the Gods in aiting and preerving Youth; for the Love of Ariadne, above all, eems to be the proper work and deign of ome God, in order to preerve Theeus; and indeed we ought not to blame her for loving him, but rather wonder all Men and Women were not alike affected towards him; and if he alone were o, truly I dare pronounce her worthy of the Love of a God, who was her elf o great a Lover of Vertue and Goodnes, and the bravet Man.

But both thee naturally affecting Government, neither lived up to the true Character of a King, but flew off, and ran, one into Popularity, the other into Tyranny, falling both into the ame fault out of different Paions. For a Prince's chief end is to preerve his Empire, which is done no les by avoiding Indecencies, than by maintaining a decorum in all things: Who-ever is either too remis or too trict in this, is no more a King or a Prince, but either too popular a Man, or too lordly, and o becomes either odious or contemptible to his Subjects. This eems to be the fault of Eaines and good Nature, the other of Pride and Severity; but if we mut not in all repects impute Misfortunes to the Fates, but conider in them the difference of mens Manners and Paions, as the unreaonable and inconiderate effects of Wrath and Anger, a Man can neither excue one in his Behaviour to his Brother, nor the other to his Son. Tho' the Anger of Theeus is more excuable, becaue
it proceeded from a greater Caue, as being truck with the everer Lah. Romulus, having diagreed with his Brother, adviedly and deliberately upon the Concerns of the Publick, one would think, he could not of the udden have been put into o great paion; but Love, and Jealouie, and the Complaints of his Wife, (which few Men can avoid being provoked with) educed Theeus to commit that Outrage upon his Son. And what is more, Romulus in his Anger committed an Action of mot unfortunate Conequence; but that of Theeus ended only in words, ome evil-peaking, and a few old Peoples Cures, the ret of the Youth's miery eems to proceed from Fortune; o that o far a Man would give his Vote on Theeus's part. But the chiefet matter in the other is this, that his Performances proceeded from very mall beginnings; for both the Brothers being thought Servants, and the Sons of Swineherds, before they were Free-men themelves, they gave liberty to almot all the Latines, obtaining at once all the mot honourable Titles, as detroyers of their Countreys Enemies, preervers of their Friends and Kindred, Princes of the People, Founders, not removers of Cities; for uch an one was Theeus, who raied and compiled only one Houe out of many, demolihing many Cities bearing the Names of ancient Kings and Heroes. But Romulus did the ame afterwards, forcing his Enemies to deface and ruine their own Dwellings, and to ojourn with their Conquerors; not altering at firt or increaing a City that was before, but building one from the ground, acquiring likewie to himelf, Lands, a Countrey, a Kingdom, Wives, Children, and Relations. He kill'd or detroyed no body, but encouraged thoe that wanted Houes and Dwelling-places, if willing to be of a Society, and become Citizens. Robbers and Malefactors
he lew not, but he ubdued Nations, he overthrew Cities, he triumph'd over Kings and Princes; and as to Remus, it is doubtful by whoe Hand he was cut off, it is generally imputed to others. His Mother he apparently retriev'd from death, and placed his Grandfather, who was brought under bae and dihonourable Vaalage, in the ancient Throne of Aeneas, to whom he did voluntarily many good Offices, but never annoyed him, no not through ignorance it elf. But Theeus, in his forgetfulnes and inadvertency of the Command concerning the Flag, can carcely methinks by any Excues, or before the mot candid Judges, avoid the imputation of Parricide; which a certain Athenian perceiving it very hard to make an excue for, feigns that Aegaeus, at the arrival of the Ship, running hatily to a Tower to ee what News, lip'd and fell down, either for want of accidental help, or that no Servants attended him in that hate to the Sea-ide. And indeed thoe faults committed in the Rapes of Women, admit of no plauible excue in Theeus: Firt, In regard to the often repetition of the Crime; for he tole Ariadne, Antiope, Anaxo the Trazaenian, at lat Helena, when he was an old Man, and he not marriageable, being too young and tender, and he at an Age pat even lawful Wedlock. Then the Caue; for the Trazaenian, Lacedaemonian, and Amazonian Virgins, beide that they were not betrothed to him, were not worthier to raie Children by, than the Athenians, who were derived from Eretheus and Cecrops; but it is to be upected, thee things were done out of lut, and the atisfaction of the fleh. Romulus when he had taken near 800 Women, he choe not all, but only Herilia (as they ay) for himelf, the ret he divided among the Chief of the City; and afterwards, by the repect, and tendernes, and jutice
hewn towards them, he dicovered, that this Violence and Injury, was a mot commendable and politick Exploit to etablih a Society; by which he intermix'd and united both Nations, and made it the fountain of all after-Friendhip, and of Power with them. And that it was the Caue of Reverence, and Love, and Contancy in Matrimony, time can witnes; for in 230 years neither any Husband deerted his Wife, nor any Wife her Husband; but, as the mot curious among the Graecians can tell you the firt Parricide, o the Romans all well know, that Spurius Carvilius was the firt who put away his Wife, accuing her of Barrennes. The Circumtances of Matters do tetifie for o long a time; for upon thoe Marriages, the two Princes har'd in the Dominion, and both Nations fell under the ame Government. But from the Marriages of Theeus proceeded nothing of Friendhip or Correpondence for the advantage of Commerce, but Enmities and Wars, and the Slaughter of Citizens, and at lat the los of the City Aphidnae, where, only out of the compaion of the Enemy, whom they entreated and careed like Gods, they but jut mis'd uffering, what Troy did by Paris. Theeus his Mother was not only in danger, but uffered alo what Hecuba did, in being deerted and detitute of her Son; unles that of her Captivity be not a fiction, as I could wih both that and mot other things of him were. What is fabulouly related concerning both their Divinity, you will find a great difference in it; for Romulus was preerved by the pecial Favour of the Gods; but the Oracle given to Aegaeus, commanding him to abtain from all trange and foreign Women, eems to demontrate, that the Birth of Theeus was not agreeable to the Will of the Gods.

div.head: THE LIFE OF LYCURGUS.
div.byline: Tranlated from the Greek of Plutarch, By Knightly Chetwood, Fellow of King's College in Cambridge.
div.p:
THere is o much incertainty in the accounts which Hitorians have left us of Lycurgus, the Law giver of Sparta, that carcely any thing is aerted by one of them which is not call'd into quetion, or contradicted by the ret. Their entiments are quite different as to the Family he came of, the Voyages he undertook, the place, and manner of his death, but mot of all when they peak of the Laws
he made, and the Commonwealth which he founded. They cannot by any means be brought to an agreement as to the very Age in which this excellent peron liv'd: for ome of them ay that he flourihed in the time of Iphitus, and that they two jointly contrived the Ordinance for the ceation of Arms during the Solemnity of the Olympick Games. Of this opinion was Aritotle, and for confirmation of it he alledges an incription upon one of the copper Coits ued in thoe Sports, upon which the name of Lycurgus continued undefac'd to his time. But Eratothenes and Apollodorus, two learned Chronologers, computing the time by the ucceions of the Spartan Kings, pretend to demontrate that he was much more ancient than the very Intitution of the Olympick Games. Timaeus conjectures that there were two of this name, and in divere times, but that the one of them being much more famous than the other, men gave to him the glory of both their exploits: the elder of the two, according to him, was not long after Homer, and ome are o particular as to ay that he had een him too. But that he was of great antiquity may be gathered from a paage in Lib. de Laced. Rep. Xenophon, where he makes him contemporary with the Heraclidae: not but that the very lat Kings of Sparta were Heraclidae too; but he eems in
that place to peak of the firt, and more immediate ucceours of Hercules. But notwithtanding this confuion and obcurity of Writers who have gone before us in this Subject, we hall endeavour to compoe the Hitory of his This was the firt Life that Plutarch publih'd, and he eems to have a particular repect to this people, by writing a Book of their wie Sayings. Life, etting down thoe paages which are leat contradicted, and following thoe Authours which are mot worthy of credit.

The Poet Simonides will needs have it that Lycurgus was the Son of Prytanis, and not of Eunomus; but in this opinion he is ingular, for all the ret deduce the Genealogy of them both as follows:
Aritodemus,
Patrocles,
Sous,
Eurytion,
Prytanis,
Eunomus, who by his firt Wife had a Son nam'd Polydectes, and by his econd Wife, Diania, had this Lycurgus,
whoe Life is before us: but as Eutychidas ays, he was the ixth from Patrocles, and the eleventh from Hercules. Be this as it will, Sous certainly was the mot renown'd of all his Ancetours, under whoe conduct the Spartans ubdu'd Ilotos, and made Slaves of the Ilotes, and added to their Dominions, by Conquet, a good part of Arcadia. There goes a tory of this King Sous, that
being beieged by the Clitorians in a dry and tony place, o that he could come at no water, he was at lat contrained to agree with them upon thee hard terms, that he would retore to them all his Conquets, provided that Himelf A ubtile promie. and all his Men hould drink of a Spring not far ditant from his Camp: after the uual Oaths and Ratifications, he call'd his Souldiers together, and offered to him that would forbear drinking half his Kingdom for a reward: their thirt was o much tronger than their ambition, that not a man of them was able to forbear: in hort, when they had all drank their fill, at lat comes King Sous himelf to the Spring, and, having prinkled his face onely, without wallowing one drop, he marched off in the face of his Enemies, refuing to yield up his Conquets, becaue himelf, and all his men (according to the Articles) had not drank of their water.

Although he was jutly had in admiration as well for his wit and abtinence as for his warlike exploits, yet was not his Family irnamed from him but from his Son Eurytion, (of whom they were call'd Eurytionides:) the reaon of this was, that Eurytion took a coure never practis'd by his wie Predeceours, which was to flatter and cajole his own Subjects, by lackening the reigns of the Royal Authority. But
ee what followed! the people, intead of growing more tractable by it, made new encroachments upon him every day: inomuch that, partly by taking advantages of the too great eaines or neceities of the ucceeding Princes, partly by tiring out and vexing thoe which ued everity, they at lat brought the Government into contempt, and oon after the whole Kingdom into Anarchy and confuion. In this mierable etate things continu'd a long time, and amongt its other tragical effects, it caued the death of the Father of Lycurgus: for as the good King was endeavouring to quell a riot in which the parties were come to blows, he was among them mot barbarouly
< in non-Latin alphabet > , tab'd with a Cooks Knife. butchered; and left the title of King to his eldet Son Polydectes: but he too dying oon after, the right of Succeion (as every one thought) reted in Lycurgus; and reign he did, untill he had notice that the Queen, his Siter-in-law, was with Child: upon this he immediately declar'd that the Kingdom belong'd to her iue, provided it were Male, and that himelf would exercie the Regal Juridiction onely as his They call'd them
< in non-Latin alphabet > . Guardian and Regent during his minority: oon after an overture was made to him by the Queen, that he would make her elf micarry, or ome way detroy that he went with, upon condition that he would
marry her when he came to the Crown. Though he was extremely incens'd againt the Woman for this unnatural propoal, yet wiely mothering his reentments, and making hew of cloing with her, he dipatch'd the Meenger with a world of thanks, and expreions of joy, but withall diuaded her earnetly from procuring her elf to micarry, becaue that the violent means ued in uch caes would impair her health, if not endanger her life: withall auring her, that himelf would o order it, that the Child, as oon as born, hould be taken out of the way. By thee and uch like artifices, having drawn on the Woman to the time of her lying in, as oon as ever he heard that he was in labour, he ent ome of his Council to be by and oberve all that pat, with order, that if it were a Girle they hould deliver it to the Women, but if a Boy, that they hould bring it to him whereoever he were, and whatoever a-doing. It o fell out that as he was at Supper with his principal Magitrates, the Queen was brought to bed of a Boy, who was oon after preented to him as he was at the Table: he, taking him tenderly into his arms, aid to thoe about him, behold, my Lords of Sparta, here is a King born unto us; this aid, he laid him down upon the Chair of State, and nam'd
him Charilaus; that is, the Joy of the people: becaue they were o much tranported with joy both at the birth of the young Prince, and the contemplation of the noble Mind and Jutice of Lycurgus: and yet his good reign lated onely eight months. But Lycurgus was in nature a Prince, and there were more who obeyed him upon the account of his eminent Vertues, than becaue he was Regent to the King, and had the treaure and trength of the Nation in his hands. Yet could not all this enure him from envy, which made a puh at him (as Lycurgus envied. is uual) before he was well ettled in his high Trut; the Heads of this Faction were the Kindred and Creatures of the Queen-mother, who pretended not to have been dealt with utably to her quality; and her Brother Leonidas, in a warm debate which fell out betwixt him and Lycurgus, went o far as to tell him to his face, that he was very well aured that e'er long he hould ec him King; by this reflecting ininuation he endeavour'd to make the people jealous of Lycurgus, thus preparing the way for an accuation of him, as though he had made away with his Nephew, if he hould chance to fail, though by a natural death; words of the like import were deignedly cat abroad by the Queen-mother and her adherents.

Being exceedingly troubled at this, and not knowing what it might come to, he thought it his wiet coure to decline their envy by a voluntary exile, and o travel from place to place untill his Nephew came to marriageable years, and by having a Son had ecured the Succeion: etting Lycurgus his Travels. ail therefore with this reolution, he firt arrived at Crete, where having conidered their everal Forms of Government, and got an acquaintance with the principal men amongt them, ome of their Laws he very much approv'd of, and reolv'd to make ue of them in his own Country, and a good part of them he rejected as ueles. Amongt the perons there the mot renown'd for their ability and wiedom in State matters was one Thales, whom Lycurgus, by repeated importunities and aurances of Friendhip, at lat peruaded to go over to Lacedaemon. When he came thither, by his outward appearance and character, he eem'd no other than a Lyrick Poet, but in reality he perform'd the part of one of the ablet Law-givers in the world: the very Songs which he compos'd were pathetical exhortations to obedience and concord: The weetnes of the Meaures and the cadence of the Vere, uting with the Subject, both erious and delightfull, had o great an influence on their minds, that
they were inenibly oftned and civiliz'd: inomuch that at lat they renounced their private feuds and animoities, which had kept them o long at variance to their unpeakable diadvantage, and re-united themelves into a cheerfull and unanimous concurrence for the publick welfare: o that it may truly be aid that Thales prepared the way for Lycurgus, by removing the rubbih and clearing the ground-plot, that he might raie upon it the lating Fabrick of that glorious Commonwealth.

From Crete he ailed to Aia, with deign (as is aid) to examin the difference betwixt the Manners and Government of the Cretans (who were very wie and temperate) and thoe of the Ionians, a corrupt and effeminate people: as Phyicians, by the oppoition they find betwixt a healthfull and ickly body, are enabled to ditinguih the welling of a Dropie from a good and thriving habit, and a real health from that which but appears o. Here had he the firt ight of Homer's Works, which were Homer's Works brought to light by Lycurgus. preerved in all probability by the poterity of Cleobulus: and having oberv'd that the few looe expreions and actions of ill example which are to be found in his Poems, were very much out-weigh'd by thoe grave maxims of State and rules of Morality (which are frequently couch'd under
thoe very Fictions) he et himelf eagerly to trancribe and diget them into order, as thinking they would be of good ue in his own Country: and to his immortal honour be it aid, he was the firt who brought the Works of this mot admirable Poet into credit in Greece: for though ome fragments of them lay cattered before in a few private hands (who et a great value upon them,) yet were they never publihed together, nor generally admired, before the time of Lycurgus.

The Aegyptians ay that he took a Voyage into Aegypt, and that, being much taken This Story of the Aegyptians is confirm'd by ome Greek Hitorians. with their way of eparating the Souldiery from their Handy-crafts and Mechanicks, he reolv'd to imitate them at Lacedaemon: and this ditinction of their Profeions, as it prevented confuion, it encreaed their trength, and cauing regularity, added beauty to the State. But as for his Voyages into Spain, Africk, and the Indies, and his conferences there with the Gymnoophites, the whole relation (as far as I can find) rets on the ingle credit of Aritocrates, the Son of Hipparchus.

During the abence of Lycurgus, though he was cheaply parted with, he was dearly mis'd at Lacedaemon, and a great many Embaies were ent to pray his return, for Kings indeed we have (aid they) who wear
the marks and aume the titles of Royalty, but as for the inward qualities of their minds, they have nothing by which they are to be ditinguih'd from their Subjects: adding, that in him alone was the true foundation of Sovereignty to be een, a Nature made to Rule, and a Genius of that trength that it made him at the ame time lov'd and reverenced by the people. Though this eem'd a little to reflect, yet were not the Kings themelves avere from his return, for they look'd upon his preence as a bulwark for them againt the growing inolencies of the people.

Things being in this poture at his return, His return and the alterations he made. he apply'd himelf without los of time to a through Reformation, and reolv'd to change the whole face of the Commonwealth: for what could a few particular Laws and a partial alteration avail, when there was an univeral corruption of all orders and degrees of men in the State? He took therefore the coure wie Phyicians ue, when they have to doe with one who labours under a complication of Dieaes, they are not content to obviate one or two of them, but follow him with purges and letting bloud, untill they have quite drain'd him of the peccant humours, and exhauted the corrupt mas of his bloud; this done, they retore him by degrees, and precribe
a regimen of Diet quite contrary to the former: the Reader will eaily make the application. Having thus projected things, away he goes to Delphi to conult Apollo there, which having done, and offered his Sacrifice, he returned with that renowned Oracle, in which he is call'd Beloved of This Oracle is extant at length in Herodotus. God, and rather God than Man; that his Prayers were heard, that his Laws hould be the bet, and the Commonwealth which oberved them the mot famous in the world. Encouraged by thee things, he et himelf to bring over to his ide the leading men of Sparta, exhorting them to give him a helping hand in this great undertaking: he broke it firt to his particular friends, and then by degrees he gained others, at lat he animated them all together to put his deign in execution. When things were ripe for action he gave order to thirty of the principal men of Sparta to be ready arm'd at the Market-place by break of the day, to the end that he might trike a terrour into the oppoite party: Hermippus hath et down the names of twenty of the mot eminent of them; but the name of him whom Lycurgus mot confided in, and who was of mot ue to him, both in making his Laws and putting them in execution, was Arithmiadas. Things growing to a tumult, King Charilaus apprehending
that it was a Conpiracy againt his Peron, took Sanctuary in the Temple of Minerva the Protectres; being oon after undeceived, and put in heart again, and having taken an Oath of them that they had no treaonable deigns, he quitted his Refuge, and himelf alo entred into the confederacy with them: of o gentle and flexible a dipoition he was, and almot too good natur'd for a King: to which Archelaus his Partner in the Government alluded, when hearing him highly extoll'd for his goodnes, he aid, how can he be otherwie than a gracious Prince, for he is good even to the wort of men?

Amongt the many changes and alterations which Lycurgus made, the firt and of greatet importance was the etablihment of the Senate, which having a power equal to the Kings in matters of great conequence did (as Plato exprees it) with its phlegm allay and qualifie the hot complexion of a Monarchy, erv'd as a Rampart againt the inolence of the people, and always kept the Commonwealth in good temper. For the State which before had no firm Bais to tand upon, but lean'd one while towards an abolute Monarchy (when the Kings had the upper hand) and another while towards a pure Democracy (when the people had the better of it) found in this etablihment
of the Senate a counterpoie, which always kept things in a jut aequilibrium. For the Twenty Eight always adhered to the weaker ide, and put themelves like a weight into the lighter Scale, untill they had reduced the other to a Ballance. As for the determinate number of Twenty Eight, Aritotle is of opinion that it o fell out becaue two of the Aociates for want of courage fell off from the enterprie; but Sphaerus aures us that there were but twenty eight of the Confederates at firt: perhaps there is ome mytery in the number which conits of even multiply'd by four, and is the firt of perfect numbers after ix, being, as that is, equal to its ides. For my part, I cannot believe that Lycurgus had any uch niceties in his head, but pitch'd upon the number of Twenty Eight, that, the two Kings being reckoned amongt them, they might be Thirty in all. So eagerly et was Lycurgus upon this Etablihment invented by himelf, that he took a Journey to Delphi to credit it by the approbation of the Oracle, who gave him the famous Rhetra, or fundamental Statute, which runs thus. After
The Rhetra, or Oracle.
that you have built a Temple to Jupiter the Syllanian, and to Minerva the Syllanian, and after that you have divided the people into Tribes, you hall etablih a Council of thirty Senatours, in the number of which the two
Kings hall be compriz'd, and hall from time to time call the people to an Aembly betwixt Balyca and Cnacion, where the Senate hall propound things to the Commons, who hall not have power to debate upon their propoals, but onely to give or refue their aent, and it hall be in the power of the Senate to diolve the Aembly. Betwixt this Balyca and Cnacion (now called < in non-Latin alphabet > ) their Aemblies were held, for they had no pacious Council-houe richly hung and furnihed to receive them in: for Lycurgus was of opinion that uch theatrical Ornaments were o far from advantaging them in their Counels that they were rather an hinderance, by diverting their attention from the buines before them to gape upon the Statues and Pictures, and Roofs curiouly fretted, the uual embellihments of uch places amongt the other Graecians. The people then being thus aembled in the open air, it was not allow'd to any one of their order to give his advice, but onely either to ratifie or reject what hould be propounded to them by the King or Senate. But becaue it fell out afterwards that the people made gloes and explanations of Laws contrary to the intent of the Kings and Senate, and ometimes too by adding or raing out whole Sentences perverted the ene, King
Polydorus and Theopompus (to be even with them in their own kind) inerted into the Rhetra or grand Decretal the following Claue; That if the people hould go about to make alteration in the Decrees of the Senate, or to enlarge or limit the ene of them, that it hould be lawfull for the King and Senate to make void their reolutions and to diolve the Aembly. This buines was o dextrouly managed, that it pat among the people for as authentick as the ret of the Rhetra, as appears by thee Veres of Tyrtaeus,
If, Spartans, ye deire that heaven hould bles
Your New-born State with lating happines,
Hear what Apollo's Oracle commands:
Jove puts the Sceptre into Princes hands.
Let them command; let Senatours debate
The deep affairs, and interets of State:
Hear, ye, and give aent, and reverence pay,
And know, 'tis Subjects privilege—to obey.

Although Lycurgus had in this manner us'd all the qualifications poible in the Government of his Commonwealth, yet thoe who ucceeded him thought that the mallnes of the number of which the Senate conited made them omewhat imperious and preing, and therefore Plato no great friend to a Monarchy. (as Plato ays) they wanted a bridle, which bridle was the
power of the Ephori, etablih'd an hundred and thirty years after the death of Lycurgus. Elatus was the firt who had this dignity conferr'd upon him, in the reign of King Theopompus, whom when his Queen upbraided one day, that he would leave the regal power to his Children les than himelf had received it from his Ancetours, he told her that he was much mitaken, for he hould leave it o much greater than he found it, by how much it was more likely to lat. For indeed the Prerogative being thus kept within ome reaonable bounds, at once he freed himelf from the envy, and ecur'd himelf from the danger, to which an unlimited juridiction lies expoed. So that the Spartan Kings fared much better after it than their neighbours at Meene and Argos; who by crewing their Prerogative too high, crack'd it, and for want of yielding a little to the populacy, lot all.

Indeed, whooever hall take a propect of the Seditions and civil Wars which befell thee bordering Nations, (to whom they were as near related in bloud as ituation) will find good reaon to admire the profound wiedom and providence of Lycurgus; for thee three States in their firt rie were equal, or, if there were any odds they lay on the ide of the Meenians and Argives, who in the deciion of the Country were more
fortunate than the Spartans: yet was their flourih but of mall continuance, oon falling into confuion, partly by the tyrannical dipoition of their Kings, and partly by the ungovernablenes of the people: o that now their ervile and digracefull condition makes it appear to the whole world, that it is one of the greatet bleings which heaven can end down upon any Nation, to give them o wie a Law-giver who could et bounds to thoe two interering powers, and of uch jarring elements frame an orderly Commonwealth. But of this I hall ay more in its due place.

After the creation of the thirty Senatours his next task, and indeed the mot hazardous he ever undertook, was the making a new diviion of their Lands. For there was a very trange inequality amongt the inhabitants of Sparta, o that the City was urcharged with a multitude of beggarly and neceitous perons, whilt the Lands and Money were engroed by a few: therefore to the end that he might banih out of the State Luxury and Arrogance (the vices of the rich,) and Envy and Knavery, (the uual faults of the poor) and the ource of all michiefs, Want and Superfluity, he obtained of them to renounce their properties, and to conent to a new diviion of the Land: that they hould live all with the equality
and friendlines of co-heirs and Brothers: o that there being no other way left to mount to a degree of eminence above the ret than to become more valiant and more vertuous than they, ambition began to be a good ubject, and et men upon the ue of thoe means by which true honour is to be acquir'd.

Having got their conent to his propoals he immediately put them in execution: and having exactly urvey'd the whole Country of Laconia, he divided it into thirty thouand equal hares, and the Liberties of the City of Sparta into nine thouand, and thee he ditributed to the Inhabitants of the City, as he did the others to them who dwelt in the Country. Some Authours ay that he made but ix thouand lots for the Citizens of Sparta, and that King Polydore added three thouand more. Others ay that Polydore doubled the number Lycurgus had made, which (according to them) was but four thouand five hundred. A lot was o much as to yield one year with another about eventy Buhels of Grain, for the Mater of the Family, and twelve for his Wife, with a utable proportion of Oil and Wine. And this he thought ufficient to keep their bodies in good health and luty, and as for uperfluities he deign'd wholly to retrench them. It is reported
that as he returned from a Journey ome time after the diviion of the Lands, in harvet time, the ground being newly reap'd, oberving the Sheaves to be all equal, and the Shocks of the ame bignes, he milingly aid to thoe about him, methinks Lacedaemon is like the inheritance of a great many Brothers, which have newly made a diviion amongt themelves.

Not contented with this, he reolv'd to make a diviion of their Movables too, that there might be no odious ditinction or inequality left amongt them; but finding that it would be very dangerous to go about it openly, he bethought himelf of this tratagem. He commanded that all Gold and Silver Coin hould be cry'd down, and that onely a ort of Money made of Iron hould be current, whereof a great weight and quantity was but very little worth: o that to lay up twenty or thirty pounds there was requir'd a pretty large Chamber, and to remove it, nothing les than a yoke of Oxen. By this invention, it is carcely to be imagin'd, how many execrable Vices were banih'd Lacedaemon: for who would rob another of uch a curvy ort of Coin? who would injutly detein it? who would cheat and circumvent, be brib'd or turn Knight of the Pot to compas it? when that it was not eaie to be hid
when a man had it, nor brought a man any credit in the world by the poeion of it, nor could erve for any ue when you had cut it in pieces: for when it was red hot and jut tamp'd, they quench'd it in Vinegar, and by that means made it almot unmalleable by its hardnes.

In the next place he banih'd all Arts that were not abolutely neceary; but here he might almot have par'd his Proclamation: for they of themelves would have gone after the Gold and Silver, the money which remain'd being not o proper payment for curious Pieces: for being of Iron it was carcely portable, neither if they hould take o much pains as to export it, would it pas amongt the other Grecians, who were o far from valuing it that they thought it one of the mot ridiculous things in the world. Thus was foreign Traffick almot utterly cut off, for neither could the Lacedemonians buy any Merchandie of Strangers, neither did any Merchants think it worth the while to bring in their Goods to any part of Laconia. For the ame reaon, they were not petered with any pedantical Teachers of Rhetorick, with Gypies, Fortune-tellers, and Calculatours of Nativities; No pimping corrupters of youth brought their Ladies of compoition, or their Boys to be unnaturally abus'd there; no Gold-miths and Engravers,
no Jewellers and Perfumers were to be found amongt them, for there was no money: o that Luxury being depriv'd of that which fed and fomented it (being quite tarv'd out) was forc'd to quit their Country, and eek it elf one elewhere. For the rich had no preeminence here over the poor, and their riches and abundance, having no opportunity of appearing and boating of it elf in publick, were forced to remain ueles at home, a cotly prey to the rut and the moth. Their thoughts being thus taken off from things uperfluous, they became excellent Artits in thoe which were neceary: o that Bedteads, Chairs and Tables, and uch like taple Utenils in a Family, were admirably well made there: particularly their Cup was very much in fahion, and bought up by Souldiers, as Critias reports, for the colour and thicknes of the Cup hindred the muddines of the dirty water (which upon marches mut often be drunk) from being perceived: and the figure of it was uch that the mud ank to the bottom, or tuck to the ides, o that onely the puret part of the water came to the mouth of him that drank in it. And this skill of theirs, though in minute things, was mainly owing to their Law-giver, who took off their minds from the endles care of providing the
means and intruments of Luxury, to attend onely to thoe things which were of daily and indipenable ue.

The lat and mot materly troke of this excellent Philoopher, by which he truck at the very roots of Luxury, and exterminated utterly the deire of riches, was the Ordinance he made that they hould all eat in common, of the ame meat, and of uch kinds as were pecify'd in the Decree: by which it was exprely forbid to pamper themelves in private, to ue rich Couches, and magnificent Tables, abuing the labours of excellent Workmen, and delivering themelves up into the hands of their Butchers and Cooks, who us'd to cramme them in corners as they fatted up the Beats and the Poultery they fed on: by this way of life their manners were not onely corrupted but their bodies too were enfeebled, o that giving the rein to their enual appetites they tood in need of long leep and hot Bagnio's, and, in a word, of as much care and attendance as if they were continually ick. It was certainly an extraordinary thing to have brought about uch an enterprie as this, but a greater yet to have effected by the frugality of their publick Tables, that their riches hould be privileg'd from the hands of rapine, nay rather (as Theophratus oberves) hould be utterly degraded,
< in non-Latin alphabet > . loing their property, and almot their very nature, o that they no longer were the objects of envy. For the rich being oblig'd to partake of the ame fare with the poor, they could not make ue of, or enjoy their choice viands, nor o much as pleae their vain humours, by making a hew and vaunting of them to the world. So that the common Proverb that Plutus (the God of Riches) is blind, was no where o literally verify'd as in Sparta: for there he was kept continually blind, or rather like a dead Carcae, eneles, motionles, as when he lay wrapt up in the dark entrails of the earth. Nor could they take any refection in private before they came to the publick Halls, for every one had an eye upon them who did not eat and drink with a good tomach, and reproached them with the name of dainty and effeminate.

This lat Ordinance bore very hard upon the wealthier ort of men, o that being out of all patience they made an inurrection againt Lycurgus, and from ill words came to blows, o that at length he was forced to run out of the Aembly, and make to Sanctuary to ave his life: by good hap he got before all the ret, excepting one Alcander, (a young Gentleman otherwie not ill accomplih'd, but too haty and cholerick) who
came up o cloe to him, as that, whilt he turn'd himelf about to ee who was near him, he truck him upon the face, and beat out one of his eyes. The incomparable Philoopher was o far from being daunted and dicouraged by this accident, that he top'd hort, and hew'd his reverend face all in a gore bloud to his ingratefull Country-men: they were o trangely urpris'd and aham'd to ee it, that they immediately begg'd pardon, offer'd him any ort of reparation, and delivered Alcander into his hands to be punihed as he hould think fit. Lycurgus, having thank'd them for their care of his peron, dimis'd them all, excepting onely Alcander; taking him with him into his Houe he neither did nor aid any thing everely to him, but dimiing thoe whoe place it was, he ordered Alcander to wait upon him at Table: the young man, though not ued to ervile employments, without murmuring or repining did as he was commanded: being thus near him he had opportunity to oberve in him (beides the natural goodnes and mildnes of his temper) an extraordinary obriety in his diet, and a trength of complexion proceeding from it, which no labours and fatigues were able to urmount. He was o ravih'd with admiration of thee excellent qualities, that of an enemy he became one
of his mot zealous admirers, and told his Friends and Relations, that Lycurgus was not that moroe and ill-natur'd man whom they had formerly took him for, but of the weetet and mot Gentleman-like dipoition in the world. And thus did Lycurgus (for chatiement of his fault) make of a wild and diolute young man one of the dicreetet Citizens of Sparta.

In memory of this accident Lycurgus built a Temple to Minerva, irnamed Optilete, from a word which in the Dorick Dialect ignifies the preerver of the ight: for ome Authours, of which Diocorides is one (who wrote a Treatie of the Commonwealth of Sparta) ay that he was wounded indeed, but did not loe his eye with the blow: and this was the caue of the dedication of that Temple. Be this as it will, certain it is, that this miadventure was the caue that the Lacedemonians never bring any arms, no not o much as a taff into their publick Aemblies.

But to return to their publick repats, which had everal names in Greek: for the Candiots call'd them ' < in non-Latin alphabet > (becaue the men onely came to them:) The Lacedemonians call'd them < in non-Latin alphabet > (from a word which ignifies Parimony, becaue they were o many Schools of Sobriety) or < in non-Latin alphabet > , that is, Feats of Love, becaue that
by eating and drinking together they had opportunity of making Friends. To put in my own conjecture, perhaps they were imply call'd ' < in non-Latin alphabet > (Eating-houes) for uch the word is by the ubtraction of one letter. They met by companies of Fifteen, over or under, and each of them tood bound to bring in monthly a Buhel of Meal, eight Galons of Wine, five Pounds of Cheee, two Pounds and an half of Figs, for their deert, and a little Money to buy Fleh and Fih withall. Beides this, when any of them made Sacrifice to the Gods they always ent a dole to the Common-hall: and likewie when any one of them had been a Hunting, he ent thither a part of the Venion he had kill'd, and thee two were the onely allowable excues for upping at home. This cutom of eating together was oberv'd trictly for a great while afterwards: inomuch that Agis, King of Lacedaemon, having vanquih'd the Athenians, and ending for his Commons at his return home, becaue he deired to eat privately with his Queen, was refus'd by the Polemarchi: which refual, when he reented o much as to omit the Eucharitical Sacrifices which ued to be made for a War happily ended, they were o far from asking his pardon, that they et a fine upon his head, and obliged him to pay it.

They us'd to end their Children to thee Tables as to Schools of temperance and good husbandry: here they were intructed in State-affairs, not by mercenary Pedants, but, by experienced Statemen: here they learn'd the art of Converation, to droll without reflecting, and to make jets at the cot of no man's reputation: and withall to take a jet with the ame innocence and unconcernednes that they gave one. In this point of good breeding the Lacedemonians exceeded all the people of Greece: but if any man were out of humour, or was not of a nature to bear a jet, upon the leat hint given there was no more to be aid to him: it was cutomary alo for the eldet man in the company to tell each of them, as they came in, Look ye, Sir, not a word aid in company mut go out of this Door, and withall he pointed to it. When any one had a deire to be admitted into any of thee little Societies he was to go through this manner of probation: each man in the company took a little ball of oft bread (a cutom much like that of ballotting in other places) which they were to throw into a deep Bain, which a waiter carried round upon his head: thoe that lik'd the peron to be choen drop'd their Ball into the Bain without altering the figure; and thoe who diliked him pres'd
it betwixt their fingers, and made it flat: and this ignify'd as much as a negative voice; for if there were but one of thee flatted pieces in the Bain the Suiter was rejected: o curious they were in the choice of their company, and o tender of diguting any one member in it, by taking in a man unacceptable to him. Their principal Dih was a ort of black Broth, which was o much valued that the elderly ort fed onely upon that, leaving what fleh there was to the younger ort.

They ay that a certain King of Pontus,
The ame tory is told of Dionyius the Tyrant. Cic. Tuc. having heard much of this black Broth of theirs, ent for a Lacedemonian Cook on purpoe to make him ome: he had no ooner tated it but he found it was abominable: the Cook eeing him out of conceit with it, told him: Sir, to make this Broth relih you hould have bath'd your elf firt in the River of Eurotas.

Having eaten and drank thus moderately every man went to his home without lights; for the ue of them was utterly forbid, to the end that they might accutom themelves to march boldly in the dark. And uch was the order and fahion of their Meals.

Lycurgus would never reduce his Laws into writing, nay it is exprely forbid in the Rhetra; for he thought that the mot
material points, and uch as mot directly tended to the publick welfare, being imprinted on the hearts of their youth by a good education, and by a contant and habitual obervance of them, becoming a econd nature, would upply the place of a Law and Law-giver in them all the ret of their lives: and as for things of leer importance, as pecuniary contracts, and uch like, the forms of which ought to be chang'd as occaion requires, and in tract of time become inufficient for the ends they were intended for, he thought it the bet way to leave them to every man's dicretion, and to precribe no certain form at all: he left therefore no inviolable cutom in uch caes, willing that the manner and form of bargaining hould be altered according to the circumtances of time, and determinations of men of the oundet judgment. For he was peruaded that without good education the bet Laws in the world ignify'd nothing, and where that was they were in a manner uperfluous.

One branch then of the Rhetra was that their Laws hould not be written, another branch of it is particularly levell'd againt Luxury and expenivenes: for by it it was ordained, That the Ceilings of their Houes hould onely be wrought by the Ax, and their Gates and Doors mooth'd onely by
the Saw. And this was not without mytery: for if Epaminondas could ay with o good a grace, inviting ome Friends to his Table, Come, Gentlemen, be ecure, Treaon would never come to uch a poor Dinner as this; why might not this great Law-giver in all probability have thought that uch ill-favour'd Houes would never be capable of receiving Luxury and uperfluity? For a man mut have a more than ordinary hare of folly that would furnih uch Rooms with embroidered Beds, and Hangings of Arras, that would be erv'd in Plate upon a rough-hewn Table, and pretend to pomp and magnificence in a Houe which was almot too narrow for the neceities of life. And doubtles he had good reaon to think that they would proportion their Beds to their Houe, and their Coverlets to their Beds, and that the ret of their Goods and Furniture would be utable to them. It is reported that King Leotichidas, the firt of that name, was o little ued to the ight of carv'd Work, that, being entertain'd at Corinth in a tately Room, he was much urpris'd to ee the Timber and Ceiling o finely wrought, and asked his Hot, whether the Trees grew o in his Country?

A third Ordinance of this forementioned Rhetra was, That they hould not make War often, or long, with the ame Enemy,
let that they hould train and intruct them in the art of War by having often to doe with them: and by forcing them to defend themelves, at length teach them to be the aggreours: and for breaking this Law was Ageilaus much blamed a long time after, by making uch continual incurions into Boeotia, that at length he taught that people to make head againt the Lacedemonians: and therefore Antalcidas, eeing him wounded one day, aid to him, that he was very well paid for making the Thebans good Souldiers whether they would or no. And thee Laws were called the Rhetra, that is to ay, not inventions of Man's Wiedom, but Divine Sanctions and Revelations from Heaven.

In order to the good Education of their Youth (which, as I aid before, he thought the mot important and noblet Work of a Law-giver) he went o far back as to take into conideration their very Conception and Birth, by regulating their Marriages. For Aritotle wrongs the memory of this excellent Peron, by bearing us in hand, Pol. lib. 7. that, after he had try'd all manner of ways to reduce the Women to more modety and obriety, he was at lat forced to leave them as they were: becaue that in the abence of their Husbands, who pent the bet part of their lives in the Wars, their Wives
made themelves abolute Mitrees at home, and would be treated with as much repect as if they had been o many Queens. But by his good leave it is a mitake; for he took for that Sex too all the care that was poible: for an intance of it he ordered the Maidens to exercie themelves with Wretling, Running, throwing the Bar and cating the Dart, to the end that the Fruit they conceived might take deeper root, and grow trong, and pread it elf in trong and healthy Bodies; and withall that they might be the more able to undergo the pains of Child-bearing. And to the end he might take away their over-great tendernes, and that acquired womanihnes which vain cutom hath added to the natural, he ordered that they hould go naked as well as the young Men, and dance too in that condition at their olemn Feats and Sacrifices, inging certain Songs, whilt the young Men tood in a ring about them, eeing and hearing them: in thee Songs they now and then gave a atyrical glance upon thoe who had mi-behaved themelves in the Wars; and ometimes ang encomiums upon thoe who had done any gallant action, and by thee means enflamed the younger ort with an emulation of their glory. Thoe that were thus commended went away brave and well atisfy'd with themelves,
and thoe who were rally'd were as enibly touch'd with it as if they had been formally and everely reprimanded, and o much the more, becaue the Kings and whole Court aw and heard all that pas'd. Now though it may eem trange that Women hould appear thus naked in publick, yet may it be aid that true modety was oberv'd and wantonnes excluded; they were ufficiently clad in their native innocence and implicity, and wore the livery of the lovely original couple. The end of their exercie was to make themelves more active and vigorous, to the end that they might bear away the prize one from another, and at lat come to dipute it with the Men. From hence came that ene of honour and noblenes of pirit, of which we have an intance in Gorgo, the Wife of King Leonidas, who being told, in dicoure with ome foreign Ladies, that the Women of Lacedaemon were they onely of the world who had an Empire over the Men, he briskly reparty'd, that there was good reaon, for they were the onely Women who brought forth Men. Latly, thee publick proceions of the Maidens, and their appearing naked in their exercies and dancings, were provocations and baits to tir up and allure the young Men to Marriage: and that, not upon Geometrical reaons
(as Plato calls them) uch as Interet, and equality of Fortune and Birth, but from the weet contraint and unophiticated dictates of nature, from that myterious agreement and ympathy of minds which alone can make men happy in a married etate. Beides this, that he might promote Marriage more effectually, thoe who continued Batchelours were made infamous by Law; for they were excluded from the ight of thoe publick proceions in which the young Men and Maidens danc'd naked: nay, the Officers compell'd them to march naked themelves round the Market-place in the very depth of Winter, inging a certain Song to their own digrace, that they jutly uffer'd this punihment for diobeying the Laws. Moreover they were depriv'd of that repect and obervance which the younger ort were oblig'd to pay to their elders: and therefore no man found fault with what was aid to Dercyllidas, a great Captain, and one who had commanded Armies; who, as he came into the place of Aembly, a young man, intead of riing and making room for him, told him, Sir, you mut not expect that honour from me being young, which cannot be return'd to me by a Child of yours when I am old.

When they had a mind to marry, their Courthip was a ort of Rape upon the perons whom they had a fancy for, and thoe they choe not tender and The Romans allow'd them to marry at twelve years of age: he covertly blames them for it. half Children, but in the flower of their age and full ripe for a Husband: After this, She who manag'd the Wedding, comes, and haves cloe the Hair of the Bride, drees her up compleatly in Man's Clothes, leaves her upon a Mattres: this done, in comes the Bridegroom, in his every day Clothes, ober and compos'd, as having upp'd at his Ordinary, and teals in as privately as he can into the Room where the Bride lay, unties her Virgin Zone and takes her into his embraces; and o having tay'd ome time together, he returns as ecretly as he can to his Apartment with the ret of his Camerades, with whom he pends all the day, and good part of the night too, unles he teals a hort viit to his Bride, and that he did with a great deal of circumpection and fear of being dicover'd; nor was he wanting (as may be uppos'd) on her part, to ue her Womans wit in watching the mot favourable opportunities for their meeting, and making appointments when company was mot out of the way. In this manner they liv'd a long time, inomuch that they frequently had Children by their Wives before ever they aw their faces by day-light. Their
interview being thus difficult and rare erv'd not onely for continual exercie of their Temperance, and further'd very much the ends and intention of Marriage, but beides, thee hort Abences kept their paion till alive, which flaggs, and decays, and dyes at lat by too eaie Acces and long continuance with the beloved object: they always parted with regret, contriving when they hould come together again, and thought minutes hours till the next meeting: having thus et Modety as a Sentinel over the Marriage-bed, he next bethought himelf of a prevention of that wild and womanih paion, Jealouie. And this he A Remedy almot as bad as the Dieae, blam'd and derided by the other Graecians. thought the bet expedient, to allow men the freedom of imparting the ue of their Wives to thoe whom they hould think fit, that o they might have Children by them; and this he would needs make a very commendable piece of Liberality, and laugh'd at thoe who think the violation of their Bed uch an inupportable affront, that they revenge it by Murthers often, and ometimes by cruel Wars.
