Lycurgus thought a man not to be blam'd, who being tep'd in years and having a young Wife, hould recommend ome vertuous handome young man that he might have a Child by him who might inherit the good qualities of uch a Father, and this Child the good Man
loves as tenderly as if he was of his own begetting: on the other ide an honet man who had love for a married woman upon the account of her modety and the wellfavourdnes of her Children, might without formality beg of her Husband a nights lodging, that he might have a lip of o goodly a Tree which he might tranplant into his own Garden. And indeed, Lycurgus was of a peruaion that Children were not o much the propriety of their Parents as of the whole Commonwealth, and therefore he would not have 'em begot by the firt Comers, but by the bet Men that could be found: the Laws of other Nations eem'd to him very defective and incongruous, who were very olicitous for the breed of their Dogs and Hores, and ent a great way and were at no mall charges to get the bet Stallions; and yet kept their Wives under Lock and Key for fear of other men, whereas themelves were craz'd, old or infirm, and more fit to propagate Dieaes than their Species: if they had made the leat reflexion in the world they would have taken notice that the honour and dihonour of Children (who generally derive their good or ill qualities from thoe that beget 'em) doth chiefly redound to thoe who have the charge of their Education, and if they prove ill they firt feel the mart of it.
Such reaons may be alledg'd in favour of this Paradox of Lycurgus; but this is certain, that o long as thee Ordinances were oberv'd, the Women there were o far from that candalous Liberty which hath ince been objected to them, that they knew not what the name of Adultery meant. A proof of this we have in Geradas, a very ancient Spartan, who being ask'd by a tranger, what punihment their Law had appointed for Adulterers, he anwer'd, there are no Adulterers in our Country: but, replyed the tranger, uppoe there were one, and the crime prov'd againt him, how would you punih him? he anwer'd, that the Offender mut pay to the Plaintiff a Bull with a Neck o long as that he might drink of the River that ran at the foot of Taygetus over the top of the Mountain: the man being urpris'd at this aid, why, 'tis impoible to find uch a Bull; Geradas milingly reply'd, 'twas jut as poible to find an Adulterer in Sparta. And o much I had to ay of their Marriages.

Nor was it in the power of the Father to dipoe of the Child as he thought fit, but was oblig'd to carry it before the They kept their Court at a place called
< in non-Latin alphabet > . Tryers, (who were ome of the gravet men of the Tribe to which the Child belong'd) their buines it was carefully to view the Infant, and if they found it luty and wellfavour'd,
they gave order for its education, and allotted to it one of the nine thouand hares of Land above-mentioned for its maintenance; but if they found it deform'd, and of an ill complexion, they ordered it to be cat into a deep Thee places they call'd < in non-Latin alphabet > ; or Store-houes: an unnatural cutom. cavern in the earth, near the Mountain Taygetus, as thinking it neither for the good of the Child it elf, nor for the publick interet that it hould be brought up, ince nature had denied it the means of happines in its own particular by not giving it health, nor trength ufficient to make it erviceable to the publick: upon the ame account the Women did not bathe the new-born Children with Water, as is the cutom in all other Countries, but with Wine, to prove the temper and complexion of their Bodies; for a conceit they had, that weakly Children fall into fits of the Convulion, or immediately faint upon their being thus bath'd; on the contrary, thoe who were of a trong and vigorous habit, would acquire a greater degree of firmnes by it, and get a temper in proportion like Steel, in the quenching. Their Nures too were o carefull and experienc'd that, without uing Swadling-bands, their Children were all treight, well proportion'd and beautifull; and beides they us'd them to any ort of meat, and ometimes to bear the want of it, not to be afraid of the dark,
or to be alone, nor to be wayward, and peevih, and crying, as they are generally in other Countries, through the impertinent care and fondnes of thoe who look to them. Upon this account Spartan Nures were often bought up, or hir'd by people of other Countries: and it is reported that he who uckled Alcibiades was a Spartan: but if he was fortunate in his Nure he was not o in his School-mater: for his Guardian Pericles
in Alcib. priore. (as Plato tells us) choe a Slave for that Office call'd Zopyrus, nothing better than thoe that row'd in a Galley. Lycurgus was of another mind, he would not have Maters bought out of the Market, nor uch as hould ell their pains, nor would he have any thing mercenary in o important a charge.

Nor was it lawfull for the Father himelf to breed up the Children after his own fancy; but as oon as they were even years old they were to be enroll'd in certain Companies and Claes, where they all liv'd under the ame Orders and Dicipline, doing their exercies, and recreating themelves Their Exercies. together. Of thee, he who hew'd the mot conduct and courage, was made Captain; they had their eyes always upon him, obeyed his orders, and underwent patiently whatoever punihment he inflicted: o that the whole coure of their education
was one continued exercie of a ready and perfect obedience. The old men too were Spectatours of their performances, and oft-times hatch'd quarrels, and et them together by the ears, that by thoe early indications they might perfectly learn their natures, and know which would be valiant, which a coward when they hould come to more dangerous encounters: as for Learning, they gave them jut enough to erve their turn; their chief care was to make them good Subjects, to fit them to endure the fatigues of long and tedious marches, and never to return without victory from the field. To this end, as they grew in years their exercies were proportionably increas'd; their heads were hav'd, they were accutomed to go bare-foot, and for the mot part to play naked.

After they were twelve years old, they were no longer allow'd to wear double garments, Their Habit. one plain Coat erv'd them a whole year: and being but very eldom bath'd and trimm'd they were none of the neatet and cleanliet perons in the world. They lodg'd together in little Bands upon Beds made of the Ruhes which grew by the Banks of the River Eurotas, and becaue their points were harp they were to break them off with their Hands without a Knife: if it were a hard Winter they mingled ome
Thitle-down with their Ruhes, this kept them warm, and as well contented they were with it, as if it had been the bet Feather-bed in the world. By that time they were come to this age, there was not any of the more hopefull Lads who had not a lover to bear him company; The old men too had an eye upon them, coming often to the Schools to hear and ee them contend either in wit or trength with one another: and this they did as eriouly and with as much concern as if they were their Fathers, their Tutours, or their Magitrates; o that there carcely paed a moment without putting them in mind of their duty, nor was there any place o privileg'd but that they were punih'd if they had neglected it.

Beides all this, there was always one of the bet and honetet men in the City appointed to undertake the charge and governance of them: he again rang'd them into everal little Bands, and et over each of them for their Captain the dicreetet and mot metall'd of thoe they call'd Irenes, (which were uually twenty years old, and thoe who were about eighteen were call'd Mell-Irenes, as much as to ay, who would hortly be Men:) This young man therefore was their Captain when they fought, and their Mater at home, uing them for the offices of his Houe; ending the turdiet
of them to fetch Wood, and the weaker and les able to gather Salads and Herbs, Their Diet. and thee they mut either go without or teal them; and this they did by creeping into the Gardens, or conveying themelves very cunningly and cloely into the Eating-houes: and it concern'd them o to doe, for if they were taken in the fact they were whip'd without mercy; and that, not for want of honety but for want of wit, becaue they did not lay their deign well, and were not fine and cunning in their faculty. They tole too all other meat they could lay their Their Thievery. hands on, looking out harp and watching all opportunities, when people were aleep or more careles than uual. If they were caught they were not onely punih'd with whipping but hunger too, being reduc'd to their ordinary, which was but very lender, and o contriv'd on purpoe, that being pres'd by hunger they might cat about to help themelves by ome ubtile conveyance or adventurous action: and this was the principal deign of their hard fare: another there was not inconiderable, that they might grow the better in tallnes; for the vital pirits not being over-burthened and oppreed by too great a quantity of nourihment (which necearily dicharges it elf into thicknes and breadth) do by their natural lightnes and agility mount
upwards; and the ubtance of the Body not being gros or in two great a quantity, does more eaily follow the fahioning hand of Nature, whereas gros and over-fed Bodies are tubborn and untractable, and he can at bet make but a bungling piece of work of them. This we find by experience in Women which take Phyick whilt they are with Child; for though the Children be by that means made omething leaner and of a les ize, yet are they, for the mot part, lovely of apect, and extraordinary well hap'd; the remaining matter, after the eparation of the groer humours, being more upple and pliable and recipient of its form, which is always exact and perfect in its kind, when the matter is capable of it. But whether this be the true reaon or not, I leave it to be determin'd by the College of Phyicians.

To return from whence we have digreed; the Lacedemonian Children were o very cautious and fearfull of being dicovered, that a youth having toln a young Fox and hid it under his Coat, uffered it to tear out his very Bowels with its Teeth and Claws, and o dy'd upon the place, rather than he would dicover it: what is practis'd to this very day in Lacedaemon is enough to gain credit to this tory, for my elf have een everal of them endure whipping to
death at the foot of the Altar of Diana, irnamed Orthia. Barbarous Supertition.

The Iren, or under-mater, us'd to tay a little with them after Supper, and one of them he bid to ing a Song: to another he put forth a Quetion, which requir'd an advis'd and deliberate Anwer: for example, Who was the bet man in the City? What he thought of uch an action of uch a man? Uing them thus early to pas a right judgment upon perons and things, and to inform themelves of the abilities or defects of their Country-men: if they had not an Anwer ready, they were look'd upon as of a dull and careles dipoition, and to have little or no ene of Vertue and Honour: beides this, they were to give a good reaon for what they aid, and in as few words and as comprehenive as might be: he that failed of this, or anwered not to the purpoe (intead of a Ferule) had his Thumb bit by his Mater. It o fell out ometimes that the Iren did this in the preence of the old Men and Magitrates, that they might ee whether he punihed them jutly and in due meaure or not: and though he did amis they would not reprove him before his Scholars, (let it hould diminih their repect to him) but when they were gone he himelf was call'd to an account, and underwent a correction too, if he had run
far into either of the extremes of indulgence or everity.

It is a thing remarkable that their Lovers Their Lovers. and favourers had a hare in the young Lads honour or digrace: and there goes a tory, that one of them was fined by the Magitrates, becaue the Lad whom he lov'd cry'd out effeminately as he was fighting. (By the way o much in fahion was this ort of love among them, that the mot tay'd and vertuous Matrons would own publickly their paion to a modet and beautifull Virgin.) And though everal mens fancies met in one peron, yet did not this caue any trangenes or jealouie among them, but rather was the beginning of a very intimate friendhip, whilt they all jointly conpired to render the belov'd Boy the mot accomplih'd in the world.

They taught them alo a natural and Their hort Sayings. gracefull way of peaking, enlivened with a touch of inoffenive raillery, and comprehending a great deal of matter in few words. For Lycurgus, who ordered that a great piece of money (as is aforeaid) hould be but of an inconiderable value, on the contrary would allow no dicoure to be current, which did not contain in few words a great deal of uefull and weighty ene: o that Children there by a habit of long ilence and meditation had uch a preence
and quicknes of mind as to give very urpriing anwers, and oft-times peak Apothegms to the atonihment of the hearers; whereas the incontinence of the Tongue, like the other ort of incontinence, frutrates the ends of peaking, as that does of generation. From hence the pithines of the Laconian Speech; an intance of which we have in King Agis, who when a pert Athenian laugh'd at their hort Swords, and aid that the Jugglers and Mountebanks wallow'd them in the publick Shows and Theatres, anwered him, And yet our Enemies cannot endure the ight of them; and as their Swords were hort and harp, o were their Sayings: and truly in my judgment there is in this concie way of peech omething which I know better than I can expres, which flies level to the mark, and does more execution than a whole volee of words hot at rovers. Lycurgus himelf, who enjoined this manner of peaking, was one of the bet examples of it, as appears by his anwer to one who by all means would have a popular Government in Lacedaemon: Begin Friend, aid he, and make a trial in thy own Family. Another ask'd him why he allow'd of o mean and trivial Sacrifices to the Gods? he reply'd, That we may always have omething to offer to them. Being ask'd, What ort of Martial Exercies
or Combats he approv'd of, anwered, all orts, except that in which you The form of crying quarter among the Ancients. tretch out your hands. Many Sayings of the like force are to be found in the Letters which he occaionally wrote to his Country-men; as, being conulted how they might bet oppoe an invaion of their Enemies, return'd this anwer, By continuing poor, and not coveting to have one more than another. Being conulted again whether it were requiite to encloe the City with a Wall, ent them word, That City is well fortified which hath a Wall of Men intead of Brick. But as for thee Letters, whether they be counterfeit or not, I think it no eaie matter to determine, and therefore let every man think as he pleaes. But that they were indeed enemies to talkativenes thee following intances are an authentick and ufficient proof. King Leonidas told one who held him in dicoure upon ome uefull things and worthy his hearing but not in due time and place, Sir, you are impertinent for peaking in this place o much to the purpoe. King Charilaus, the Nephew of Lycurgus, being ask'd why his Uncle had made o few Laws, anwered, To men of few Words few Laws are ufficient. One blam'd Hecateus the Oratour becaue that being invited to a Feat he had not poke one word all Supper-time, Archidamus
anwered in his vindication, He who can peak well knows when to peak too.

I will now give an intance or two of their harp Reparties, which, as I aid before, had a ort of pleaantnes with them which made them to be the better excus'd. Damaratus being ask'd, in an He eems to allude to the Quetions which us'd to be put to the young Lads, as, Who is the bet man in Sparta? abuive manner by an importunate fellow, Who was the bet man in Lacedaemon? anwered him, He, Sir, that is the leat like you. Some, in company where Agis was, much extoll'd the exact Jutice of the Eleans, who ate as Judges at the Olympick Games; indeed, ays Agis, they are highly to be commended if they can doe Jutice once in the pace of five years. Theopompus anwered a tranger who brag'd that he was o much taken notice of for his love to the Lacedemonians, that his Country-men from thence call'd him a lover of the Lacedemonians.
< in non-Latin alphabet > , that it had been more for his honour if they had call'd him a lover of his own Country-men.
< in non-Latin alphabet > . And Plitonax, the Son of Pauanias, when an Oratour of Athens aid the Lacedemonians were an illiterate and ignorant people, told him, You ay true, Sir, for we onely of all the Graecians have learned none of your ill conditions. One ask'd Archidamus what number of fighting men there might be of the Spartans, he anwered, Enow, Sir, to drive out the wicked.

We may gues too at their manner of peaking by their very Jets. For they us'd not to throw them out at random, but the very wit of them was grounded upon ome coniderable ene. For intance, one being ask'd to go hear a Man who exactly counterfeited the voice of a Nightingale, anwered, Sir, I have heard the Nightingale it elf. Another having read this following incription upon a Tomb,
Extinguihing a cruel Tyranny
At Selinum thee brave Patriots did dy:
made this clinch upon it, that they well deerv'd to dye, for intead of extinguihing the Tyranny they hould have let it burn out. A Lad being offered ome Cocks of the Game o hardy that they would dye upon the place, aid that he car'd not for Cocks that would dye hardy, but for uch that would live and kill others. Another would by no means be carried home in a Chair, as he aw ome others were, becaue, aid he, I cannot conveniently rie in it to pay repect to my betters. In hort, their anwers were o ententious and pertinent that one aid well, that to be a Philoopher or a Lacedemonian ignified the ame thing. And though they were a very active people they exercied their Minds much more than their Bodies.

Nor were they les carefull to ing and compoe well than to expres themelves in proper terms and to peak to the point. And their very Songs had uch a life and pirit in them, that they enflam'd and ravih'd mens minds with a deire to doe great and good Actions; the tyle of them was plain and without affectation; the ubject always erious and moral; mot uually it Their Poetry. was in praie of uch men as had dy'd in the bed of honour for defence of their Country, or in deriion of thoe who would not venture their lives willingly in o good a caue: the former they declared happy, and almot Gods, and the latter they decrib'd as mot mierable and below the condition of men. In thee Veres too they talk'd high of what feats they would doe or had done, and vaunted of themelves as the bravet and mot valiant people in the world. The expreion was different and utable to their everal ages: for you mut undertand that they had three Choirs of them in their olemn Fetivals, the firt of the old Men, the econd of the young Men, and the lat of the Children: (to give a tate of them) the old Men began thus,
We have been (though now pent and old)
Hardy in Field, in Battel Bold.
The young men anwered them, inging,
We are o now: let who dares try,
We'll conquer, or in combat dye.
The Children came lat, and aid,
What ever ye can To the young men. doe or To the old men. tell,
We one day will you both excell.
Indeed if we will take the pains to conider their Compoitions, and the Airs on the Flute to which they were et when they march'd on to Battel, we hall find that Terpander and Pindar had reaon to ay that Muick was not incompatible with, but rather an help and incentive to, Valour. The firt ays thus of them.
Jutice goes in proceion through their Streets,
And Mars the Mues in weet conort meets.
And Pindar—
Blet Sparta! in whoe State we find
Things almot inconitent join'd:
In quiet times your Martial toils not ceae,
And Wars adorn'd with the oft arts of Peace.
Gray-headed Wiedom reigns in your Debates,
And well-bred Youth with equal Fire,
Handle their Arms, or touch their Lyre;
Ye Gods, the Muick of well ordered States!
So that thee two Poets decribe the Spartans as being no les muical than warlike, and the Spartan Poet himelf confirms it:
Our Sports prelude to War, and Muicks charms
Inpire deliberate Valour to our Arms.
And even before they engag'd in Battel the King did firt acrifice to the Mues (in all likelihood) Their going to Battel. to put them in mind of the manner of their education, and of the evere judgment that would be pas'd upon their actions, and thereby to animate them to the performance of ome gallant Exploit: ometimes too the Lacedemonians abated a little the everity of their manners in favour of their young men, uffering them to curle and perfume their Hair, and to have cotly Arms, and fine Clothes; and as well pleas'd they were to ee them marching out full of metal and pirit to an Engagement as the other Graecians were to ee their trim'd Hores neighing, and preing for the He alludes to the Olympick Games. coure. And therefore when they came to be wellgrown Lads they took a great deal of care of their Hair, to have it parted and trim'd, epecially againt a day of Battel, puruant to a aying of their Law-giver, that a large head of Hair et off a good Face to more advantage, and thoe that were ugly it made more ugly and dreadfull.

When they were in the Field their Exercies were generally more moderate, their Fare not o hard, nor o trict a hand held over them by their Officers, o that they were the onely people in the world to whom War gave repoe. When their Army was drawn up in Battel array, and the Enemy near, the King acrific'd a Goat, commanded the Souldiers to et their Garlands upon their heads, and the Pipers to play the Tune of the Hymn to Cator, and himelf advancing forwards began the Paean, which erv'd for a ignal to fall on. It was at once a delightfull and terrible ight to ee them march on to the Tune of their Flutes, without ever troubling their Order or confounding their Ranks, no diorder in their minds or change in their countenance, but on they went to the hazard of their lives as unconcernedly and cheerfully as if it had been to lead up a Dance, or to hear a conort of Muick. Men in this temper were not likely to be poeed with fear, or tranported with fury, but they proceeded with a deliberate Valour, full of hope and good aurance, as if ome Divinity had enibly aited them. The King had always about his peron ome one who had been crown'd in the Olympick Games: and upon this account a Lacedemonian refus'd a coniderable preent which was offered to
him upon condition that he would not come into the Lits, and having with much to doe thrown his Antagonit, ome of the Spectatours aid to him, And now, Sir Lacedemonian, what are you the better for your Victory? he anwered miling, O, a great deal, Sir, for I hall have the honour to fight by the ide of my Prince. After they had routed an Enemy they puru'd him till they were well aured of the Victory, and then they ounded a retreat, thinking it bae and unworthy of a Graecian people, to cut men in pieces who durt not look them in the face or lift up their hands againt them. This manner of dealing with their Enemies did not onely hew their magnanimity but had a politick end in it too; for knowing that they kill'd onely thoe who made reitance, and gave quarter to the ret, they generally thought it their bet way to conult their afety by flight. Hippias the Sophiter ays that Lycurgus himelf was a very valiant and experienced Commander. Philotephanus attributes to him the firt diviion of the Cavalry into
< in non-Latin alphabet > 12 in a ide the Captain and Lieutenant excepted. Troops of fifties in a quare Body: but Demetrius the Phalerian ays quite the contrary, and that he made all his Laws in a continued Peace. And indeed the ceation of Arms procured by his means and management, inclines me to think him a goodnatur'd
man, and one that lov'd quietnes and peace. Notwithtanding all this Hermippus tells us that he had no hand in the Ordinance, that Iphitus made it, and Lycurgus came onely as a Spectatour, and that by mere accident too. Being there he heard a voice of one behind him, blaming, and wondering at him that he did not encourage his Country-men to reort to o illutrious an Aembly; turning about and eeing no man, he concluded that it was a voice from Heaven, and thereupon immediately went to Iphitus, and was aitant to him in ordering the Ceremonies of that Feat, which by his means were better etablih'd, more famous and magnificent than before that time they were.

To return to the Lacedemonians. Their dicipline and order of life continued till after they were full grown men. No one was allowed to live after his own fancy; but the whole City reembled a great Camp in which every man had his hare of proviions, and buines et out, and look'd upon himelf not o much born to erve his own ends as the interet of his Country. Therefore if they were commanded nothing ele, they went to ee the Lads perform their Exercies, to teach them omething uefull, or to learn it themelves of thoe who knew better. And here I cannot
but declare my opinion, that one of the greatet bleings Lycurgus procur'd to his people was, the abundance of leiure, which proceeded from his forbidding to them the exercie of any mean and mechanical Trade; for it was but lot labour to wate themelves with anxiety and toil to heap together a great deal of money, which when they had got was but ueles lumber in their houe; for the Ilotes till'd their ground for them, and paid them yearly in kind the quantity above-mention'd, without any trouble of theirs. To this purpoe there goes a tory of a Lacedemonian who happened to be at Athens in Aies time in which a Citizen had been punih'd for idlenes, and came home much dicontented and comfortles: the Lacedemonian was much urpriz'd at it, and deired his Friend to hew him the man who was condemned for living like a Gentleman: o much beneath them they eteemed all mechanical employments, and the care of heaping up riches.

I need not tell you that upon the prohibition of Gold and Silver all Law-uits immediately ceas'd, for there was now no griping avarice, or poverty oppreed, but equality with abundance, and a quiet life with obriety. All their time (except when How they pent their time. they were in the Field) was taken up in
dancing, in feating, in their exercies, and hunting matches, or Thee were called
< in non-Latin alphabet >
places where good company us'd to meet. Thoe who were under thirty years of age were not allow'd to go into the Market-place, but had the necearies of their Family upply'd by the care of their Relations and Lovers: nor was it for the credit of elderly men to be een too often in the Market-place; it was eteem'd more honourable for them to frequent the Academies and places of converation, where they dicours'd agreeably, not of the price of Pepper, and interet of Money, but gravely pas'd their judgment on ome action worth conidering; extoll'd the good, and blam'd thoe who were otherwie, and that in a facetious way, o that the Feather of the Jet made the Arrow pierce the deeper, and left ome uefull remark or correction behind it. Nor was Lycurgus himelf o ullen and cynically grave but that now and then he would ruffle his gravity, and This is reported by Soilius. acrifice an hour to the little God of Laughter, to whom he dedicated a Statue in his Houe; to the end that by prinkling and eaoning their converations with mirth they might more willingly endure the trouble of their trict and hard life. To conclude this, he bred up his Citizens in uch ort, that they neither would, nor could live by themelves, but endeavour'd
to incorporate them all together, like warms of Bees in a cluter about their King; wholly deveting themelves of their own narrow interets, and forgetting themelves by the continual ectaie they were in to promote the publick interet and honour. What their Sentiments were will better appear by a few of their Sayings. Paedaretus not being admitted into the Lit of the three hundred who were choen to make good the pas at This exploit is excellently decrib'd by Herodotus lib. 7. The publick pirit of the Spartans. the Thermopyle, return'd home very joyfull and well pleas'd, aying, That it did his heart good to find that there were in Sparta three hundred better men than himelf. And Piitratidas being ent with ome others Ambaadour to the Lords Lieutenants of the King of Peria, being ask'd by them, Whether they came of their own accord, or were ent by the State? anwered, That if they obtain'd what they came for, they were commiion'd by the Publick, if not, they came of themelves. Argileonide asking ome trangers who came from Amphipolis, if her Son Braidas dy'd couragiouly, and as became a Spartan, they fell a-praiing him to a high degree, and aid, There is not uch another left in Sparta; She took them up hort, Hold, Gentlemen, Braidas indeed was a valiant man, but there are till in Sparta many more valiant than he.

The Senate (as I aid before) conited of them who were his chief aiders and aitants in the forming of the Government, and the vacancies he ordered to be upply'd out of the bet and mot deerving men who were full threecore years old; and we need not wonder if there was much triving and tickling for it: for what more glorious competition could there be amongt men than this, in which it was not As it was in the Olympick Games. diputed, who hould bear away the prize of wiftnes, or trength, but who was the wiet and mot vertuous man in the City, to whom hould be entruted for ever after (as the reward of his merits) the power and authority of the whole Commonwealth, and in whoe hands hould be depoited the honour, the lives and fortunes of all his Country-men? The manner of their Election The manner of their Elections. was as follows; The people being called together, ome perons deputed by the Senate, were lock'd up in a Room near the place of Election, which was o contriv'd that they could neither ee nor be een by the Competitours or people, but onely hear the noie of the Aembly without. (For they decided this, as mot other affairs of moment by the houts of the people.) This done, the Competitours were not brought in, and preented all together, but one after another, as by lot fell out, and through
the Aembly they pas'd in order without peaking a word. Thoe who were lock'd up, had writing Tables with them in which they et down the number of the houts and the greatnes of them, without knowing to which of the Candidates each of them were made. But he who was found to have the mot and loudet acclamations was declar'd Senatour duly elected. Upon this he had a Garland et upon his head, and went in proceion to all the Temples to give thanks to the Gods; a great number of young men followed him, making the treets to echo with his praies: The young Ladies too ung Veres in his honour, and a bleed man they call'd him who had led o vertuous a life. As he went round the City in this manner each of his Relations The Ancients never invited any one to dinner. invited him into his Houe to a handome Supper, aying, The City honours you with this Banquet: but he, intead of accepting their invitation, returned to the place where he formerly us'd to eat; and was erv'd as before, excepting that now he had a This was the manner of the Eatern Countries to expres their repect to any one, and from them probably the Graecians took it. double allowance. By that time Supper was ended, all the Women who were of kin to him were got about the Door, and he beckning to her whom he mot eteem'd preented to her the portion he had av'd, aying with-all, This was given me to day as a reward of my Vertue, I preent it to you, as an acknowledgment
of yours: upon this he was triumphantly waited upon home by the Women, as he was by the Men.

As touching Burials Lycurgus made very The manner of their Burials. wie Orders: for firt of all to cut off the upertition of Burying-places, he allow'd them to bury their dead within the City, and even round about their Temples, Other people generally buried them without their Walls, and long after took up the cutom of burning them. to the end that their youth might be ued to uch pectacles, and not be afraid to ee a dead body; and withall to rid them of the conceit that to touch a Corpe, or to tread upon a Grave would defile a man. In the next place he commanded them to bury in Woolen (which Cloth was to be red) and put nothing ele into the ground with them, except, if they pleas'd, a few To intimate that then they are in peace and at ret. Branches or Leaves of Olive. He would not allow of talkative Grave-tones, nor uffer o much as the names to be incrib'd, but onely of uch men who dy'd in the Wars, or Women which were profes'd of ome religious Order. The time too appointed for Mourning was very hort; for it lated but eleven days, and on the twelfth they were to doe acrifice to Proerpina, and leave off their Mourning: o that we may ee as he cut off all uperfluity, o in things neceary there was nothing o mall and trivial which had not ome profitable leon and intruction in it, and caus'd an
emulation of Vertue or hatred to Vice. All Lacedaemon was like a great Volume, every Leaf of which was fill'd with good rules, and great examples: which preenting themelves at all times and in all places to their thoughts, did inenibly aimilate the minds of the lookers on, and force them to imitate that always which they could not but meet with every where.

And this was the reaon why he forbid He forbids travelling into other Countries. them to travel into foreign Countries, viz. let they hould bring in foreign vices and vanities along with them: he thought it a mot eneles thing to take a journey into another Climate, to learn what Clothes they hould wear the next Winter; and to think themelves beieged and half undone if they were forc'd to drink the Liquours of their own Country; beides, this itch after novelty encreaing, makes men think of innovations in matters of more importance, and to deire new forms and fahions in the Government too. Withall he banihed all trangers from Lacedemon who could not give a very good reaon for their coming thither; not becaue he was afraid let they hould inform themelves of, and imitate his manner of Government, (as Thucydides would have it believed) but let they hould introduce omething contrary to good manners; for trange perons bring uually
trange dicoure along with them, that produces new thoughts and perwaions, and different opinions detroy the harmony of converation and civil ociety; and therefore as carefull he was to keep out all foreign cutoms as men uually are to keep out upected perons in the time of a reigning Petilence.

Hitherto, Therefore he approves their murthering their Infants. I for my part can ee no ign of injutice or want of equity in the Contitutions of this Commonwealth, and therefore I can by no means agree with thoe, who ay they are very well contriv'd to make men good Souldiers, but exceedingly defective in civil jutice and honety. But as for that ecret Ordinance (if
< in non-Latin alphabet >
it were one of Lycurgus's, as Aritotle ays it was) it is truly enough to put him and Plato too out of conceit both with the Law-giver and his Government. By this Ordinance thoe who had the care of the young men, dipatch'd privately ome of the ablet of them into the Country from time to time, arm'd onely with their Daggers, and taking a little neceary proviion with them, thee in the day-time hid themelves in the Thickets and Clifts, and there lay cloe, but in the night they iued out into the Highways and kill'd all the Ilotes they could light upon; ometimes they et upon them by day, as they were at work in the Fields,
and murthered them in cold bloud, as Thucydides ays in his Hitory of the Peloponneian War. The ame Authour tells us, that a good number of them being In token of Freedom granted. crowned by proclamation, and enfranchied for their good ervices, and led about to all the Temples in token of honour, diappeared all of a udden, being about the number of two thouand, and no man neither then nor ince could give an account how they came by their deaths. And Aritotle adds that the Ephori, o oon as they were entred into their Office, us'd to declare War againt them, that they might be maacred with a pretence of Law. It is confes'd on all hands, that the Spartans dealt with them very hardly; for it was a thing common to force them to drink to exces, and to lead them in that condition into their publick Halls, that their Children might ee what a contemptible and beatly ight a drunken man is: they made them to dance uncomely Dances, and ing ridiculous Songs, forbidding them exprely to meddle with any that were erious, for they would not have them prophaned by their mouths: upon this account when the Thebans made an Invaion into Laconia, and took a great number of the Ilotes prioners, they could by no means perwade them to ing the Odes of Lacedemonian Poets. Terpander, Alcman, or Spendon,
for (faid they) they are our Maters Songs we dare not ing them. So that it was truly oberved by one, that in Sparta he who was Free was mot o, and he that was a Slave there was the greatet Slave in the world. For my part I am of opinion that thee outrages and cruelties began to be exercis'd in Sparta long after the time of Lycurgus, namely oon after the great Earthquake, at which time the Ilotes made a general Inurrection, and, joyning with the Meenians, laid the whole Country wate, and brought the City to the greatet extremity it had ever been reduc'd to. For I cannot be perwaded that ever Lycurgus invented or put in force o wicked and barbarous an Act as The ecret Ordinance. this was, epecially when I look back upon the gentlenes of his dipoition, and his unprejudic'd jutice upon all other occaions; not to ay that it were a piece of high impiety to think hard of him, ince The Oracle above-mention'd. God himelf hath given o great a character of his Vertue.

To draw now towards the lat Scenes of his Life: when he perceiv'd that his Laws had taken deep root in the minds of his Country-men, that cutom had rendred them familiar and eaie, that his Commonwealth grew apace daily, and was now able to go alone, he had uch a calm joy and contentation of mind, as in Timaeo. Plato omewhere tells us
the Maker of the World had, when he had finih'd and et this great Machine a moving, and found every thing very good and exactly to anwer his great Idoea; o Lycurgus, taking an unpeakable pleaure in the contemplation of the greatnes and beauty of his Work, eeing every pring and particle of his new Etablihment in its due order and coure, at lat he conceived a vat thought to make it immortal too, and, as far as humane forecat could reach, to deliver it down unchangeable to poterity. To bring this to pas, he called an extraordinary Aembly of all the people, he told them that he now thought every thing reaonably well etablih'd, both for the good of the publick and for the happines of each particular, but that there was one thing till behind, and that of the greatet importance, which he thought not fit to impart untill he had conulted the Oracle; in the mean time his deire was that they would punctually oberve his Laws without any the leat alteration untill his return, and then he would doe as the God hould direct him. They all conented readily, and prayed him to haten his Voyage: but before he departed he adminitred an Oath to the two Kings, the Senate and Commons, that they would inviolably oberve his Ordinances during his abence. This done he et ail
for Delphos, and having acrific'd to Apollo, ask'd him, Whether he approv'd of the Laws he had etablih'd? the Oracle anwered, That his Laws were excellent, and that the people which oberv'd them hould live in happines and renown. Lycurgus took the Oracle in Writing, and ent it over to Sparta; having acrific'd the econd time to Apollo, and taking his leave of his Friends, and his Son, he reolv'd to dye in this Voyage, that the Spartans might never be releas'd from the Oath they had taken. He was now about that age, in which life was till tolerable, and yet a wie man would dye without regret; epecially when he conidered, That death comes then eaonably when life is at the bet He reolved therefore to make Lycurgus pines himelf to death an end of himelf by a total abtinence from meat, and even dying to et a copy of temperance to his Country-men; for he thought that a Stateman and good Patriot hould erve his Country with his lat breath, and that the end of their lives hould be no more idle and unprofitable than all that went before; epecially ince all men have a curioity to know the end of great Peronages, and believe mot firmly, and remember longet what they did or aid dying: and in this he had a double end, the one to ecure and crown his own happines, by a death utable to o honourable a life;
and the other, that it might be a eal and confirmation of his Laws, epecially ince that his Country-men had olemnly worn the obervation of them untill his return: nor was he deceived in his expectations, for the City of Lacedaemon continued the chief City of all Greece for the pace of five hundred years, mainly by their trict obervance of Lycurgus's Laws; in all which time there was no manner of alteration made during the reign of fourteen Kings, untill the time of Agis, the Son of Archidamus. For the new Creation of the Ephori (Tribunes too were etablih'd at Rome to maintain the privileges of the people, but in time they prov'd the ruine of the popular Government. who at firt were choen in favour of the people) were o far from diminihing, that they very much confirm'd the power of the Senate.

In the time of Agis Gold and Silver found a way into Sparta, and all thoe michiefs which attend the immoderate deire of riches. Lyander promoted much this diorder, for by bringing in rich Spoils from the Wars, although himelf was incorrupt, yet by this means he fill'd his Country with Avarice and Luxury, directly againt the Laws and Ordinances of Lycurgus; which o long as they were in force Sparta reembled ome holy Peronage or particular Philoopher (o unanimous they were and as it were acted by one Soul) rather than a great Commonwealth and Metropolis of
an Empire. And as the Poets feign of Hercules, that with his Lion's Skin and his Club, he went over the world, punihing the Wicked and extirpating Tyrants; o may it be aid of the Lacedemonians, that with a piece of The
< in non-Latin alphabet > . Parchment and a plain Frieze Coat, they gained the Sovereignty of Greece, and (which is more) their affections too; they depoed all uurp'd Powers, were the Commanders in War and the Arbitres of Peace, and Judges in civil differences or editions: and this they often did without o much as taking their Buckler in their hand, but barely by ending ome plain Man, without attendance, who went under the Character of the Lacedemonian Ambaadour; and they warmed about him at his coming like Bees about their King to receive his Orders; which, without aucy Remontrances and Provifo's, they immediately put in execution. Such a veneration they had for the equity and good conduct of this illutrious Commonwealth.

And therefore I cannot but wonder at thoe who ay, that the Spartans were good and obedient Subjects, but not skill'd in the art of governing; and for proof of it alledge a Saying of King Theopompus, who when one aid that Sparta held up o long becaue their Kings could command well, he reply'd,
nay, rather, becaue the people know o well how to obey. For indeed thoe who cannot command wiely are eldom or never well erv'd: on the other hand, a skilfull Leader is always readily followed. And as it is the part of a good Rider to train his Hore to turn, or top, or go on at his pleaure; o is it the greatet piece of
< in non-Latin alphabet > . King-craft to teach their Subjects obedience: wherefore the Lacedemonians o ordered matters, that people did not onely endure, but even deir'd to be their Subjects. For they did not ue to petition them for Ships, or Money, or a upply of armed Men, but onely for a Spartan Commander; and having obtain'd one, us'd him with honour and reverence; for o the Sicilians behav'd themelves to Gilippus, the Chalcidians to Braidas, and all the Colonies of the Graecians in Aia to Lyander, Ageilaus and Callicratidas: in hort they eteem'd and call'd them the Peace-makers, the Reformers, the Correctours of the licence both of Princes and People; and had their eyes always upon the City of Sparta as the perfect model of good Manners and wie Government. The ret eem'd as Scholars, they were the Maters of Greece; and to this Stratonicus pleaantly alluded, when in merriment he pretended to make a Law that the Athenians hould keep Proceions in the myteries of Ceres, the Eleans hould
dipoe of the Prizes at the Olympick Games (as being bet skill'd in matters of this nature) and that if either of them did amis the Lacedemonians hould be well beaten. Antithenes too, one of the Scholars of Socrates, aid well of the Thebans, who were become very proud for their ingle Victory at by the conduct of Epaminondas. Leuctres, That they look'd like Schoolboys who newly had beaten their Mater. Thee indeed were merry Sayings but yet may erve to tetifie the opinion men then had of the Spartans.

However it was not the deign of Lycurgus that his City hould govern a great many others; he thought rather that the happines of a Kingdom, as of a private man, conited chiefly in the exercie of Vertue, and mutual love of the Inhabitants; his principal aim was to make them nobly minded, content with their own, not apt to follow vain hopes, but moderate in all their He eems to reflect upon the Athenians, who ruin'd their State by triving rahly to enlarge it. enterpries; and by conequence able to maintain themelves and continue long in afety. And therefore all thoe who have written well of Politicks, as Plato, Diogenes, Zeno and everal others, have taken Lycurgus for their Model, as appears by their Writings: but thee great men left onely vain projects and words behind them, whereas Lycurgus, without writing any thing, left a flourihing Government, which
as it was never thought of before him, o can it carcely be imitated in following ages; o that he tands for an undeniable proof, that a perfect wie man was not o mere a notion and chymaera as ome men thought. He hath obliged the world not with one ingle Man, but with a whole Nation of Philoophers, and therefore deerves preference before all other Statits, becaue he put that in practice of which they onely had the idaea. None of the kindet Judges of thoe who went before him. Aritotle himelf was o convinc'd of his merit, that he acknowledges they did him les honour after his death than he deerv'd, although they built Temples, and offered Sacrifice to him as to a God.

It is reported that when his Bones were brought home to Sparta, they were truck with Lightning; an accident which befell no eminent peron but himelf and Euripides, who was buried at Arethua a City of Macedon: and this may erve for conolation to thoe who have an honour for that For Euripides was accued of Atheim. excellent Poet, That he had the ame fate with that holy man and favourite of the Gods. Some ay Lycurgus dy'd in the City of Cirrha, Apollythemis, Timaeus and Aritoxanes. others that he dy'd at Elis, and others at Crete, in a Town of which (call'd Pergamy) his Tomb was to be een cloe by the High-way ide. He left but one Son, nam'd Antiorus, who dy'd without
iue. His relations and Friends kept an annual Commemoration of him, and the days of the Feat were called Lycurgides. Aritocrates, the Son of Hipparchus ays that he dy'd in Crete, and that the Candiots, at his deire when they had burn'd his Body, cat the Ahes into the Sea; for fear let that if his Reliques hould be tranported to Lacedaemon, the people might pretend themelves releaed from their Oaths, and make innovations in the Government.
div.q: And thus much may uffice for the Life and Actions of Lycurgus.

div.head: THE LIFE OF NUMA POMPILIUS.
div.byline: Englih'd from the Greek, By Paul Rycaut, Eq
div.p:
THough many Noble Families of Rome
The Romans ambitious of Conanguinity to Numa. derive their Original from Numa Pompilius, yet there is great diverity amongt Hitorians concerning the time in which he reigned: a certain Writer called Clodius in a Book of his, entituled, The Chronology of pat times, averrs, that the ancient Regiters of Rome were lot when that City was acked by the Gauls, and that thoe which are now extant, are counterfeited to flatter and erve the humour of
great men, who are pleaed to have their pedigree derived from ome ancient and noble Lineage, though in reallity that Family hath no relation to them: and though it be commonly reported, that Numa was a Scholar, and a familiar acquaintance of Pythagoras; yet it is again contradicted by Various reports concerning him. thoe, who affirm, that he neither was acquainted with the Grecian Language, nor Learning; and that he was a peron of that natural Talent and abilities of Mind, as of himelf to attain unto Vertue, or ele that his inclinations were cultivated by ome foreign Intructour, whoe Rules and Doctrine were more excellent and ublime than thoe of Pythagoras. Some affirm alo, that Pythagoras was not a contemporary with Nama, but lived at leat five Ages after him; howoever it is probable, that ome other Pythagoras, a native of Sparta, who, in the third year of Numa's reign, which was about the ixteenth Olympiad, won a Prize at the Olympick Race, might be the peron, who, in his Travels through Italy, having gained an acquaintance and familiarity with Numa, might adminiter ome directions and rules to him for the contitution of his Kingdom; for which reaon, at the intigation of this Pythagoras, many of the Laconian Laws and Cutoms might probably be introduced amongt the Roman Intitutions.
Nor is it true, that Numa was decended of the Sabines, who declare themelves to be a Colony of the Lacedemonians, nor can we make any jut calculate from the periods of the Olympick Games, which though lately publihed by one Elias Hippia, yet carry not ufficient force of argument, and authority to render them authentick. Wherefore what we have collected of mot aured truth, concerning Numa, we hall deliver, taking our beginning from that place which is mot pertinent to our purpoe.

This commotion being appeaed, the City was greatly divided about the election A contet in Rome about chuing a King. of another King, for the minds of the ancient Romans and the new Inhabitants were not as yet grown into that perfect union and coalition of pirits, but that there were diverities of Factions amongt the Commonalty, and jealouies and emulations amongt the Senatours; for though all agreed that it was neceary to have a King, yet what Peron or of what Nation was the dipute. For thoe who had been builders of the City with Romulus, though they had already yielded a hare of their Lands and
dwellings to the Sabines, who were Aliens, yet could not be perwaded to reign into their hands the Regal Authority. On the other ide the Sabines alledged, that their King Tatius being deceaed, they had peaceably ubmitted to the obedience of Romulus, o that now their turn was come to have a King choen out of their own Nation; nor did they eteem themelves inferiour to the Romans, nor to have contributed les than they to the increae of Rome, which without their numbers and aociation could never have merited the name of a City.

Thus did both parties argue and dipute their caue; but let in the mean time Sedition and dicord hould occaion Anarchy and confuion in the Commonwealth; it was agreed and ordained, That the hundred and fifty Senatours hould interchangeably execute the Office of upreme Magitrate, and with all the formalities and rites of Regality offer the olemn Sacrifices, and dipatch judicial Caues for the pace of ix hours by day and ix by night; the which viciitude and equal ditribution of power would remove all emulation from amongt the Senatours, and envy from the people; when they could behold one elevated to the degree of a King, levelled in a few hours after, to the private condition of
a Subject: which Form of Government was termed by the Romans, Interregnum. Nor yet could this plauible and modet way of Rule ecape the cenure of the Vulgar, who termed it a deign of ome few, who, to abolih the Kingly Government, intended to get the power into their own hands: and therefore to circumvent this Their final determination. plot, they came at length to this concluion, that the party which did elect hould chooe one out of the body of the other; that if the Romans were Electours, they were to make choice of a Sabine; and if the Sabines elected, they were to chooe a Roman: this was eteemed the bet expedient to reconcile all parties and interets, for that the created Prince would be obliged to favour the one for their uffrages in his election, as he was the other on core of relation and conanguinity. In puruance of this agreement the Sabines remitted the choice to the ancient Romans, being more inclinable to receive a Sabine King elected by the Romans, than to ee a Roman exalted by the Sabines: conultations being accordingly held, Numa Pompilius, of the Sabine race, was elected; a peron o famous, and of that high reputation, that Numa choen King. though he were not actually reiding at Rome, yet no ooner was he nominated than accepted by the Sabines with applaue and
acclamation, equal to that freedom which the Romans hewed in his election.

The choice being declared and made publick, principal men of both parties, were appointed to compliment and intreat the Prince, that he would be pleaed to accept the adminitration of the Kingly Government. Now this Numa reided at a famous City of the Sabines called Cures, whence both the Romans and Sabines gave themelves the name of Quirites, as a comprehenive The Romans whence called Quirites. Numa's Stock and Education. name for both Aociates; Pomponius, an illutrious peron, was his Father, and he the younget of his four Sons, being by Divine Providence born on the eleventh of the Kalends of May, which was the day on which the Foundation of Rome was laid; he was endued with a Soul rarely tempered by Nature, and dipoed to Vertue, and excellently improved by Learning, Patience and the tudies of Philoophy; by which advantages of Art he regulated the diorderly motions of the Mind, and rendred Violence and Oppreion, which had once an honourable eteem amongt the barbarous Nations, to be vile and mean, making it appear, that there was no other Fortitude than that which ubdu'd the Affections, and reduc'd them to the terms and retraints of Reaon.

Thus whilt he banihed all luxury and oftnes from his own home, he gave a clear and manifet indication to all Citizens and trangers of his ound and impartial judgment, not delighting himelf in divertiements or profitable acquiitions, but in the worhip of the immortal Gods, and in the rational contemplation of their Divine Power and Nature; to all which renown and fame, he added this farther glory, that he took Tatia for his Wife, who was the Daughter He marries Tatia. of that Tatius, whom Romulus had made his Aociate in the Government; nor yet did the advantage of this Marriage well his vanity to uch a pitch as to deire to dwell with his Father-in-law at Rome; but rather to content himelf to inhabit with h • s Sabines, and cherih his own Father in his old Age: the like inclinations had alo Tatia, who preferred the private condition of her Husband before the honours and plendour he might have enjoyed in her Father's Court. This Tatia, as is reported, after he had lived for the pace of thirteen years with Numa in conjugal ociety, dyed; and then Numa, leaving the converation of the Town, betook himelf to a Country life, and in a olitary manner dwelt in the Groves and Fields conecrated to the Gods; where, Numa intimate with the Goddes Egeria. the common fame was, he gained uch acquaintance and familiarity with the Goddes
Egeria, that he lived in thoe retirements free from all diturbances and perturbations of mind, and being inpired with the ublime and elevated pleaure of a celetial marriage, he had arrived to a beatitude in this life, and to a clear notion of Divine Sciences.

There is no doubt, but that uch fancies as thee, have had their original from ancient Fables; uch as the Phrygians recount of Atis, the Bythinians of Herodotus, the Arcadians of Endymion, and a thouand other Demons which pat Ages recorded for Saints, that were beatified and beloved of the Gods; nor doth it eem trange, if God, who places not his affection on Hores or Birds, hould not didain to dwell with the vertuous, and entertain a piritual converation with wie and devout Souls: though it be altogether irrational to believe, that the Divine Eence of any God or Demon is capable of a enual or carnal love or paion for humane Beauty: And yet the wie Egyptians, did not conceive it an aburd fancy to imagin, that a Divine Eence might by a certain piritual impule apply it elf to the nature of a Woman, and lay the firt beginnings of generation, though on the other ide they concluded it impoible for the Male-kind to have any congres or mixture with a Goddes, not conidering
that there can be no real coition, but where there is a mutual communication of one to the other. The truth of the matter is this, thoe men are onely dear to the Gods, What perons acceptable to the Gods. who are vertuous, and thoe are beloved by them whoe actions are regulated by the rules of Divine Wiedom: and therefore it was no errour of thoe who feigned, that Phorbas, Hyacinthus and Admetus were beloved by Apollo; or that Hippolytus, the Sicyonian was o much in the favour of a certain God, that as often as he ailed from Sicyon to Cirrha, the God rejoyced and inpired the Pythian Prophetes with this heroick Vere,
Now doth Hippolytus return again,
And venture his dear life upon the Main.
It is reported alo that Pan became enamoured of Pindar for his Veres, and that a beatified Demon honoured Heiod and Archilochus after their deaths by the Mues; it is aid alo that Aeculapius ojourned with Sophocles in his life-time, of which many intances are extant to thee days; and that being dead, another Deity took care to perform his Funeral-rites: wherefore if any credit may be given to thee particular intances, why hould we judge it incongruous, that a like Spirit of the Gods hould
inpire Zaleucus, Minos, Zoroater, Lycurgus, Numa, and many others; or that the Gods hould conferr a meaner proportion of their favours on thoe who were Founders of Commonwealths, or buied in making Laws, and adminitration of the political affairs of Kingdoms? Nay it is mot reaonable to believe, that the Gods in their ober humour are aitent at the counels and erious debates of thee men to inpire and direct them; as they do alo Poets and Muicians, when in a more pleaant mood, they intend their own divertiement: but, as Bacchylis aid, thoughts are free, and the way is open to every man's entiment; yet in reallity it cannot be denied, but that uch men, as Lycurgus, Numa and others, who were to deal with the editious humours of Fanatick Citizens, and the uncontant dipoition of the multitude, might lawfully etablih their Precepts with the pretence of Divine Authority, and cheat them into uch Politicks as tend to their own happines. But to return to our purpoe.

Numa was about forty years of age when Numa's age when courted to be King. the Ambaadours came to make him offers of the Kingdom; the Speakers were Proculus and Veleus, the firt was an ancient Roman, and the other of the Tatian Faction, and zealous for the Sabine party. Their Speech
was hort, but pithy, uppoing, that when they came to tender a Kingdom there needed no long Oration or Arguments to perwade him to an acceptance: but contrary to their expectation they found that they were forc'd to ue many reaons and intreaties to allure him from his quiet and retir'd life, to accept the Government of a City, whoe Foundation was laid in War, and grown up in martial Exercies; wherefore, in preence of his Father and Martius his Kinman, he returned anwer in this manner; That ince every alteration of a man's life is dangerous to him, it were mere His Anwer to the Ambaadours. madnes for one that is commodious and eaie, and provided with all things neceary for a convenient upport, to eek or endeavour a change, though there were nothing more in it, than that he prefers a turbulent and an uncertain life before a quiet and a ecure condition. It is not difficult for a man to take his meaures concerning the tate of this Kingdom by the example of Romulus, who did not ecape a upicion, of having plotted againt the life of his Collegue Tatius; nor was the Senate free from the accuation, of having treaonably murthered their Prince Romulus. And yet Romulus had the advantage to be thought of Divine race, and to be conerved by a miraculous manner
in his infancy; how then can we who are prang from mortal eed, and intructed with principles and rudiments received from the men you know, be able to truggle with uch apparent difficulties? It is none of the leat of my commendations, that my humour renders me unfit to reign, being naturally addicted to tudies, and pleaed in the recees of a quiet life: I mut confes that I am zealous of Peace, and love it even with paion, and that the converation of men who aemble together to worhip God, and to maintain an amicable charity, is my chief buines and delight; and what time may be pared from this more neceary duty, I employ in cultivating my Lands and improving my Farms. But you Romans, whom Romulus perhaps may have left engaged in unavoidable Wars, require an active and brisk King, who may, cherih that warlike humour in the people which their late uccees have encouraged and excited to a warm ambition of enlarging their Dominions: and therefore uch a Prince as in this conjuncture hould come to inculcate Peace, and Jutice, and Religion into the minds of the people, would appear ridiculous and depicable to them who reolve on War and Violence, and require rather a martial Captain than a pacifick Moderatour.

The Romans perceiving by thee words, that he refued to accept the Kingdom, were the more intant and urgent with him, that he would not forake and deert them in this condition, by uffering them to relape into their former edition and civil dicord; which they mut unavoidably do, if he accepted not their proffer, there being no peron, on whom both parties could accord, but on himelf; and at length He is importun'd by his Father and Kinman to accept it. his Father, and Martius, taking him aide, perwaded him to accept this offer, which was important, and rather was conferred from Heaven than from Men. Though (aid they) you remain contented with your own Fortune, and court neither Riches nor Power, yet being endued with excellent Vertue, you may reaonably imagine, that uch a Talent of Jutice was not given by the Gods to be hidden or concealed; and that, ince the jut Government of a Kingdom is the greatet ervice a man can perform towards God, he ought therefore by no means to decline and refue Empire and Rule, which was the true phere and tation of wie and renowned men; and in which they had uch an acendant over mankind, as to influence their Souls with affections to Vertue, and to a religious worhip of the Gods, in the mot olemn and pompous
manner, it being natural to men to fahion and conform themelves by the example and actions of their Prince. Tatius, though a Foreigner, was yet acceptable, and in eteem of the Romans; and the memory of Romulus was o pretious to them, that after his deceae, they voted Divine Honours to be paid to him; and now who knows, but that this people being victorious, may be atiated with the War, and with the Trophies and Spoils they have acquired, and may gladly entertain a gentle and pacifick Prince, who being a lover of Jutice may reduce the City into a model and coure of Laws and judicial proceedings? And in cae at any time the affections of this people hould break forth into a furious and impetuous deire of War; were it not better then to have the reigns held by uch a moderating hand, as is able to divert the fury another way, and pend it elf on Foreigners? by which means thoe malignant humours which are the caues of civil dicord, will perpire and evaporate, and all the Sabines, and neighbouring people, be reconciled and joined in an ineperable union and alliance with the City.

To thee reaons and perwaions everal other aupicious Omens (as is reported)
did concurr; and when his own Citizens undertood what meage the Roman Ambaadours had brought him, they all addreed themelves to him, intantly intreating him to accept the offer; being aured that it was the onely means to appeae all civil dientions, and incorporate both people into one Body.

Numa yielding to thee perwaions and reaons, having firt performed Divine Service, proceeded to Rome; being met in his way by the Senate and People, who with an impatient deire came forth to receive him; the Women alo welcomed him with joyfull acclamations, and Sacrifices were offered for him in all the Temples, and o univeral was the joy, that they eem'd not to receive a King, but the addition of a new Kingdom. In this manner he decended into the Forum, where Spurius Vetius, whoe turn it was to be Governour at that hour, putting it to the Vote, Whether Numa hould be King; they all with one voice and conent cried out a Numa, a Numa. Then were His religious Policy. the Regalities and Robes of Authority brought to him, but he refued to be inveted with them, untill he had firt conulted and been confirmed by the Gods: o being accompanied by the Priets and Soothayers. Augurs he acended the Capitol, which at that time the Romans called the Tarpeian Rock.
Then the chief of the Augurs covered his head, and turned his face towards the South; and, tanding behind him, laid his right hand on the head of Numa, and prayed, cating his eyes every way, in expectation of ome aupicious ignal from the Gods. It is wonderfull to conider with what ilence and devotion the multitude, which was aembled in the Market-place, expected a happy event, which was oon determined by the appearance and flight of uch Birds as were accounted fortunate. Then Numa, apparelling himelf in his Royal Robes, decended from the Hill unto the people, by whom he was received, and congratulated with houts and acclamations, and eteemed by all for a holy and a devout Prince.

The firt thing he did at his entrance The firt alterations he made, what. into Government was to dimis the Band of three hundred men, which had been Romulus's Life-guard, called by them Celeres; for that the maintenance of uch a force would argue a diffidence of them that choe him, aying that he would not rule over that people of whom he conceived the leat ditrut. The next thing he did, was to add to the two Priets of Jupiter and Mars, a third in honour of Romulus, who was called Quirinalis. The Romans ancien •• y called their Priets Flamines, by corruption
of the word Pilamines, from a certain Cap which they wore called Pileus; for in thoe times Greek words were more mixed with the Latin than in this age: o alo that Royal Robe, which is called Laenas, Juba will have it from the Greek Chlaenas; and that the name of Camillus, which is given to the Boy that erves in the Temple of Jupiter, was taken from the ame which is given to Mercury, denoting his ervice and attendance on the Gods.

When Numa had by thee actions ininuated himelf into the favour and affection of the people, he began to dipoe the humour of the City, which as yet was obdurate and rendred hard as iron by War, to become more gentle and pliable by the applications of humanity and jutice. It was then if ever the critical motion of the City, and, as Plato properly tyles it, the time when it was in its highet fermentation. For this City in its original was the receptacle Rome a harbour for looe Perons. of all bold and daring pirits, where men of deperate Fortunes, joyning their hopes and force together, made frequent allies and incurions on their neighbours; the which, being properous, gave nourihment and increae to the City; and was then grown wrety and ettled in its fiercenes, as piles droven into the ground become more fixed and table by the impule and blows which
the Rammer layes upon them. Wherefore Numa, judging that it was the mater-piece of his Art to mollifie and bend the tubborn and inflexible pirits of this people, began to operate and practice upon them An awfull ene of Religion the chief expedient to reduce obdurate pirits. with the principles of Religion. He acrificed often, and ued upplications and religious Dances, in which mot commonly he officiated in peron, being ever attended with a grave and religious company; and then at other times he divertied their minds with pleaures and delightfull exercies, which he ever intermixed with their devotions, o as to cool their fiery martial pirits; and then to affect their fancies with a fear and reverence of God, he made them believe that trange Apparitions and Viions were een, and prophetick Voices heard, and all to eaon and poes their minds with a ene of Religion.

This method which Numa ued made it Numa why thought familiar with Pythagoras. believed that he was much converant with Pythagoras, and that he drew and copied his learning and wiedom from him; for that in his intitutions of a Commonwealth, he lays down Religion for the firt Foundation and ground of it. It is aid alo that he affected the exteriour garb and getures of Pythagoras, and to peronate him in all his motions. For as it is aid of Pythagoras, that he had taught an Eagle to come
at his lure, and toop at his call, and that as he paed over the heads of the people, aembled at the Olympick Games, he made him hew his golden Thigh, with many other rare arts and feats, which appeared miraculous; on which Timon Philaius wrote this ditick,
Pythagoras, that he might common fame acquire,
Did with his golden Vere mens minds inpire.
In like manner Numa affected the tory of a mountain Nymph to be in love with him, and that he entertained familiar converation with the Mues, from whom he received the greatet part of his Revelations; and having amongt them a particular devotion for the Lady which he named Tacita, he recommended the veneration of her to the Romans, which he did perhaps in imitation of the Pythagorean Silence. His opinion alo of Images is very agreeable to the Doctrine of Pythagoras; who taught, that the Firt Principle of Being, which is not capable to be affected with enual paions, is inviible, and incorrupt, and onely to be comprehended by abtracted peculations of the mind. And for this reaon he forbad the Romans to repreent God in
the form of Man or Beat, nor was there No Imagery in the religious worhip amongt the Romans for the firt 160 years. any painted or graven Image of a Deity admitted amongt them for the pace of the firt hundred and ixty years; all which time their Temples and Chapels were free and pure from Idols and Images, which eem'd too mean and beggarly repreentations of God, to whom no acces was allowable but by the mind raied and elated by divine contemplation. His Sacrifices alo had great imilitude with the Victims of Pythagoras, which were not celebrated with effuion of Bloud, but conited of the flour of Wheat, or Wine, and uch ort of blended Offerings. And to make appear the inclination that Numa had to Pythagoras by other intances; there is a certain Dramatick Poet, a very ancient Authour and a Scholar of Pythagoras, who, in a certain Book of his dedicated to Antenor, reports, that Pythagoras was made a Free-man of Rome; and that Numa gave to one of his four Sons the name of Mamercus, which was the name of one of the Sons of Pythagoras; from whence, as they ay, is prung that ancient Patrician Family of the Aemilians, for that the King uperadded the irname to him of Aemilius, to denote the oftnes of his words, and the fluency of his peech. I remember that when I was at Rome, I heard many ay, that when the Oracle directed two
Statues to be raied, one to the wiet, and another to the mot valiant man of Greece, they preently erected two of Bras, one repreenting Alcibiades, and the other Pythagoras.

But, to pas by thee matters, which are full of uncertainty, and not o important as to be worth our time to init long on; we hall proceed to things more pertinent, and hew, that the original contitution of Priets, which are called Pontifices, is acribed Numa firt contituted the Pontifices. unto Numa, and that he himelf, officiating in the firt and primary Order, took upon himelf the name of Pontifex, or High Priet; auming that title of Potens, or powerfull, as if thoe, whoe Office obliged them to an attendance on the Gods, were endued with a uper-eminent power and arbitrement above all others: ome will have this name to be given by way of uper-excellence, as to a ole Moderatour, in whoe power it is to ordain and appoint the times when Sacrifices and Divine Services are to be performed. But the mot common opinion is the mot aburd, which derives this word from Pons, which Latin ignifies a Bridge, aying, that anciently the mot olemn and holy Sacrifices were offered on Bridges, the care of which, both in maintaining and repairing, was the chief incumbence of the Priets, and that it was not
onely eteemed by the Romans to be unlawfull but an abominable impiety to demolih or diorder the Planks or Fabrick of a Bridge; becaue that by appointment of the Oracle, it was to be onely of Timber, and fatned with wooden Pins without Nails, or Cramps of Iron; and that the Stone Bridge was built many years after, when Aemylius was Quetor, and that the old Bridge of Wood was demolihed in the Reign of Ancus Martius, who was the Grand-on of Numa by his Daughter.

The Office of Pontifex, or Chief Priet, The Pontifical Office what. was to interpret the Divine Law and Propheies; and did not onely precribe rules for publick Ceremony, but regulated the Sacrifices of private perons, not uffering them in the heat of their devotion to exceed the more olemn Offerings, but directed in every thing with what Sacrifices the Gods were to be worhipped and appeaed. He was alo Guardian of the Vetal Virgins, the intitution of whom and of their perpetual The Intitution of the Vetals. Fire, was attributed to Numa, who perhaps fancied the nature of pure and uncorrupted Flames to be agreeable to chate and unpolluted Bodies, or that Fire which conumes but produces nothing, alludes bet to the terile condition of Virgins. This Vetal Fire was ordained after the example of that in Greece, and particularly at Delphos
and Athens, onely with this difference, that here it was conerved by Virgins but there by Widows, who were pat the years and deires of Marriage; and in cae by any accident it hould happen, that this Fire became extinct, as the holy Lamp was at Athens, under the tyranny of Arition, and at Delphos, when that Temple was burnt by the Medes, and at Rome, in the time of the War with Mithridates, and of their own civil dientions, when not onely the Fire was extinguihed but the Altar demolihed: and then afterwads to kindle this Fire again it was eteemed an impiety to light it from the common parks or flame, but from the pure and unpolluted rays of the Sun; the which they performed by an Intrument framed of three equal angles, which being placed in oppoition to the Sun, collects the rays into one centre, and o attenuates the air, that it immediately gives fire to any combutible matter from the intene reflexion and reverberation of the Sun beams. Some are of opinion that thee Vetals had no other care or buines than the conervation of this Fire; but others conceive, that they were keepers of thoe Divine Secrets, which are concealed and hidden to all others but themelves; of which we have made mention in the life of Camillus, o far as the revelations of uch myteries
are conitent with due repect to Religion. Gegania and Verenia, as is reported, were the names of the two firt Virgins which were conecrated and ordained by Numa; next Canuleia and Tarpeia ucceeded them; to which Servius afterwards added two more, the which number of four hath continued to this our age.

The Statutes precribed by Numa for the The Laws appointed for the Vetal Virgins. Vetals were thee. That they hould vow to keep a leae of their Virginity, or remain in a chate or unpotted condition, for the pace of thirty years; the firt ten whereof they were like Novitiates, obliged to learn the Ceremonies, and practie themelves in the Rules of their Religion; then they took the degree of Prietes, and for other ten years exercied the Sacerdotal Function; and the remaining ten they employed in teaching and intructing others. Thus the whole term being compleated, it was lawfull for them to marry, and leaving then the acred Order, they were at liberty to chooe uch a condition of life as did mot indulge, and was gratefull to their own humour: but this permiion few (as they ay) made ue of; becaue it was oberved, that their change of life was never accompanied with contentment, being ever after ad and melancholy; for which reaon they confined themelves untill old age and the hour of
death to the trict and decent rules of a ingle life.

But this evere condition was recompened Their Privileges. by other privileges and prerogatives; as that they had power to make a Tetament in the life-time of their Father, that they had a free adminitration of their own affairs without Guardian or Tutor, which was the privilege of women who were the Mothers of three Children: when they went abroad they had the Faces carried before them; and if perchance in their walks abroad it were their fortune to encounter a Malefactour leading to execution, they had the privilege to free him from death; upon oath made, that the occaion was accidental and not deigned or of et purpoe. Whooever preed upon the Chair on which they were carried was guilty of a capital crime, and immediately punihed with death. If thee Vetals committed any faults they were punihable by the High Priet onely, who, as the nature of the offence required, whipped them naked in a dark place, and under the caution of a Veil or Curtain; but he that had been defiled, or permitted her elf to be defloured, was buried alive near the Gate which is called Collina; where a little mount of Earth is raied, called in Latin Agger; under it is a narrow Room, to which a decent
is made by Stairs: here they prepare a Bed, and light up a Lamp, and provide a mall quantity of Victuals, uch as Bread, Water in a Bottle, Milk and Oil; that o that Body, which had been conecrated and devoted to the mot divine and myterious ervice, might not be aid to perih by a death o detetable as that of Famine. The party thus condemned, is carried to execution through the Market-place in a Litter, wherein he is covered and bound with Cords, o that the voice of her cries and laments cannot be heard; all people with ilence go out of the way as he paes, and uch as follow accompany the Bier with olemn and tacite orrow; and indeed uch is the adnes which the City puts on on this occaion, that there is no pectacle of grief which appears of more common and general concernment than this.
