When they come to the place of Execution, the Officers looe the Cords, and then the High Priet, lifting his hands to Heaven, murmures ome certain prayers to himelf, then the Prioner being till covered is brought forth, and led down by the teps unto her Houe of darknes; which being done, the Priets retire, and the Stairs being drawn up, the Earth is preed and crouded in untill the Vault is filled. And this was the punihment of thoe who broke their Vow
of Virginity. It is aid alo that Numa built the Temple of Veta, which was intended for a conervatory of the Holy Fire, in an orbicular form, to repreent perhaps the Frame of the Univere, in the centre of which the Pythagoreans place the element of Fire, and give it the name of Veta and Unity: and yet they do not hold that the Earth is immovable, or that it is ituated in the middle region of the Globe; but keeps a circular motion about the eat of Fire: nor do they account the Earth amongt the chief or primary Elements; following the opinion of Plato, who, they ay, in his mature and philoophical age, held that the Earth had a lateral poition, for that the middle or centre was reerved for ome more noble and refined Body.

There was yet a farther ue of the High Priet, and that was to order the Proceion at funeral Rites, according to the method precribed by Numa, who taught, that there was no uncleannes in the contact of dead Corpes, but a part of the ervice owing to the ubterranean Gods: amongt which they worhipped the Goddes Libitina as the chief of thoe who preided over the Ceremonies performed at Burials; whether they meant hereby Perephone, or (as ome of the learned Romans will have it) Venus, for they, not without good reaon, attributed
the beginning and end of Man's lie to the ame original caue and virtue of a Deity.

Numa alo precribed Rules for regulating the days of Mourning, according to certain The regulation of Funeral Rites and Ceremonies. times and ages. As for example, a Child of three years, and o upwards to ten, was to be mourned for, for o many months as it was years old; and the longet time of mourning for any peron whatoever was not to exceed the term of ten months: which alo was the time appointed unto Widows to lament the los of their deceaed Husbands; before which they could not without great indecency pas unto econd Marriages; but in cae their incontinence was uch as could not admit o long an abtinence from the Marriage-bed, they were then to acrifice a Cow with Calf for expiation of their fault.

Numa alo was Founder of everal other Orders of Priets; two of which are worthy to be here mentioned, namely the Salii and the Feciales, which, with other intances, are clear proofs of the great devotion and anctity of this Peron. Thee Feciales, Feciales, an Order of Priets, whence o tyled. whoe name in my opinion is derived from their Office, were the Arbitratours to whom all Controveries were referred relating to War and Peace; for it was not allowable to take up Arms untill they had
declared all hopes and expedients rejected which tended to an accommodation; by the word Peace, we mean a determination of matters in dipute by Law, and not by Violence or Force. The Romans commonly dipatched the Feciales, who were properly Heralds, to thoe who had offered them injury, requiring atisfaction; and in cae they made not retitution or jut returns, they then called the Gods to witnes againt them and their Country, and o denounced War: the ene of the Feciales in this cae was of abolute neceity, for without their conent it was neither lawfull for the Roman King, nor yet for the people to take up Arms; and from them the General took his rules concerning the jutice of his caue, which being adjudged, and the War determined; the next buines was to deliberate of the manner and ways to manage and carry it on. It is believed, that the laughter and detruction which the Gauls made of the Romans, was a jut judgment on the City for neglect of this religious proceeding: for that when a foreign Nation beieged the Cluinians, Fabius Ambutus was dipatched to their Camp with Propoitions of Peace; but they returning a rude and peremptory Anwer thereunto, Fabius imagined that his Treaty was at an end, and that he had fully complied with the
duty of his Embaie; and therefore rahly engaging in a War, challenged the toutet and bravet of the enemy to a ingle Combat. It was the fortune of Fabius to kill his adverary and to take his poils, which when the Gauls undertood, they ent a Herald to Rome to complain againt Fabius, who, before a War was publihed, had, againt the Law of Nations, made a breach of the Peace. The matter being debated in the Senate, the Feciales were of opinion, that Fabius ought to be conigned into the hands of the Gauls; but he, being pre-advied of this judgment, fled to the people, by whoe protection and favour he was ecured: on this occaion, the Gauls marched with their Army to Rome, where, having taken the Capitol, they acked the City. The particulars of all which are at large related in the Hitory of Camillus.

Now the original of the Salii is this: In the eighth year of the reign of Numa, that terrible Petilence, which was pread over all Italy, did likewie mierably infet the City of Rome; at which the Citizens being greatly affrighted, and depairing of health, were again comforted by the report of a brazen Target, which (they ay) fell from Heaven into the hands of Numa, and of which they relate trange effects, operated by the virtue of this miraculous Buckler;
and that Numa having had conference with the Nymph Egeria, and ome of the Mues, he was aured, that that Target was ent from Heaven for the cure and afety of the City; and that, becaue on the conervation thereof the common health and benefit depended, he was ordered by them to make eleven others, o like in all dimenions and form to the original; that in cae there hould be a deign to teal it away, the true might not be ditinguihed or known from thoe which were counterfeited; by which means there would be more difficulty to defeat the counels of Fate, or invert the order of divine Predetination: He farther declared, that he was commanded to conecrate that place and the Fields about it to the Mues, where he had often entertained a free intercoure and communication with them; and that the Fountain which watered that Field hould be made acred and hallowed for the ue of the Vetal Virgins, who were to wah and cleane the penetralia of their Sanctuary with thoe Holy Waters. The truth hereof was peedily verified by a miraculous ceation of the Petilence; whereupon Numa immediately delivered this Target to the bet Artits to have others made in a jut likenes in all particulars thereunto; but none was able to arrive unto a perfect
imilitude in all unditinguihable repects, untill at length one Veturius Mamurius, an excellent Mater, happily hit upon it, and made one o to repreent the other in all repects, that Numa himelf was at a tand, and could not ditinguih the true from that which was counterfeited. The keeping of which Targets was committed to the charge of certain Priets, which are called Salii; who did The Intitution and Office of the Salii. not receive their name, as ome imagine, from one Salius, a certain Dancing-mater, who was born at Samothrace, or at Mantinea, who taught the way of dancing in Arms; but rather from that Dance which the Salii themelves ue, when in the month of March they carry the acred Targets through the City; at which proceion they are habited in a hort Caock, girt with a broad Belt clap'd with bras Buckles; on their heads they wore a copper Helmet, and ever and anon ounded on the Targets with hort Cemyters: in this manner they proceeded with a nimble motion, and jut meaures of their Feet, and with uch handome and various turns, as demontrated great trength and agility of body. Thee Targets were called Ancylia from the fahion of them; for they were not made in a round or orbicular form but oval and with certain folds or pleats cloing one over the other, they fitted the Elbow by their
cubical Figure, and thence were called Ancylia, from < in non-Latin alphabet > , which ignified a crooked hape, or from the cubit, which is from the Writ to the Elbow, and called in Greek < in non-Latin alphabet > , on which they carry thee Ancylia. Juba, who much affected the Greek Tongue, draws many of his derivations from thence, and would have it from < in non-Latin alphabet > , which ignifies as much as ent from above, or from < in non-Latin alphabet > , which is the cure or medicine of Dieaes, or from < in non-Latin alphabet > , which is a deliverance from great drines, or from < in non-Latin alphabet > , which is an ecape from great evils; whence it is that the Athenians called Cator and Pollux
< in non-Latin alphabet > ; all which may erve to employ the curioity of thoe who have a fancy to Greek derivations. All the reward which Mamurius received for this his Art, was to be mentioned and commemorated in the Veres which the Salii ang, as they danced in their Arms through the City; though ome will have it that they did not ay Veturius Mamurius, but Vetus Memoria, which is Ancient Remembrance.

After Numa had in this manner intituted A memorable intance of Devotion in Numa his building a Palace adjoining to Veta's Temple. thee everal Orders of Priets, he erected a Royal Palace near the Temple of Veta, called to this day Regium; where he pent the mot part of his time, in precribing Rules for Divine Service, intructing
the Priets, and with zeal and devotion attending in peron on the Offices of Religion. He built another Houe upon the Mount Quirinalis; which place they hew to this day. In all publick Proceions and olemn Prayers, Tiptaves or Huhers were ent before to give notice to the people that they hould forbear their work, and attend to the Divine Solemnity: for they ay that the Pythagoreans did not hold it ufficient reverence towards the Gods to worhip them in a negligent manner, as when the religious Proceions did obviouly occur, but obliged their Scholars to go out from their Houes and with prepared hearts attend to Divine Supplications: o Numa in like manner Indifference and Ditraction of buines great hindrances to Devotion. decreed, that his Citizens hould neither ee nor hear Divine matters in a perfunctory manner, and with wandring thoughts, but laying aide all ditractions of mind, and cares of the world hould apply and elevate their meditations to Religion; and the ways and treets hould be clear of noie or laments, or other incumbrances which might obtruct or diturb the olemnity and eriounes of devotion. Something of this cutom remains at Rome to this day; for when the Conul begins to acrifice or officiate; they call out to the People, Hoc age, or attend to the work in hand, and is as much as with us, Let us Pray, whereby
the Auditours then preent were admonihed to compoe and recollect their thoughts for prayer: And as Pythagoras had certain Precepts and Sayings, uch as thee: Thou halt not make a Peck Meaure thy eat to it on. Thou halt not tir the Fire with a Sword. When thou goet forwards, look not behind thee. When thou acrificet to the celetial Gods, let it be with an odd number, and when to the terretrial let it be with even. So likewie Numa delivered other Sentences of an obcure and abtrue meaning; uch as thee: Thou halt not acrifice to the Gods an offering of Wine proceeding from a Vine which was never pruned. No acrifices hall be performed without Meal. e a circular motion in adoration of the Gods, and it down when you have worhipped. The two firt Precepts eem to denote, that Probable conjectures of the ignificancy of the everal Potures in Divine Worhip. urbanity and a natural complaiance with the world is a part of Religion; and as to the turning which the Worhippers are to ue in divine adoration, it is to repreent the orbicular motion of the world. But in my opinion, the meaning rather is, that he who comes to worhip, enters the Temple with his face towards the Eat; where, being come up as high as the Chancel, he turns towards the Wet, and then back again to the Eat, perfecting the whole office of his prayers to that God who is Maker
of the Univere: unles perhaps this change of poture may allude to the Egyptian Wheels, which were Hieroglyphicks of the intability of humane fortune, and that where God hould fix and etablih our lot and condition, we hould there ret contented, and repoe our elves with intire reignation to the Divine pleaure. They ay alo, that the itting quiet and in a repoed poture after worhip did denote a conceion, or grant of the petitions they made, and was an aurance of everlating felicity in the future life: and that this till and edentary ceation from work was the full top or period of buines already performed; from whence now deigning to begin others, they were to preent themelves before the Gods, to obtain their bleings, and ucces on that which was to follow. And this form of Ceremony did very well ute with the preceding Doctrine, which taught that men ought not to approach the Gods in a tranitory way, and with ditracted minds, but, laying aide all worldly cares and wandring fancies, hould then onely pray when their thoughts are poeed with Divine Meditation. By uch Dicipline as this, recommended by the contant practice and example of the Legilatour, the City did o inenibly pas into a religious temper and frame of devotion, and
tood in that awe and reverence of the vertue of Numa, that they received and believed with an undoubted aurance, whatoever he delivered, though never o fabulous, his authority being ufficient to make the greatet aburdities and impoibilities to pas for matters and points of Faith.

There goes a tory, That he once invited a great number of Citizens to an entertainment; Several fabulous relations of Numa's intimate familiarity with the Gods. at which the Dihes in which the Meat was erved were very homely and plain, and the Commons hort, and the Meat ill dreed: the Guets being ate, he began to tell them, that the Goddes which was his familiar Spirit, and always converant with him, was then at that time preent, when on a udden the Room was furnihed with all orts of pretious Pots and Dihes, and the mean Fare converted into a mot magnificent Feat, adorned with all orts of the mot delicious Viands. But the Dialogue which is reported to have paed between him and Jupiter, urpaes all the fabulous Legends that were ever invented. They ay, that before Mount Aventine was inhabited or incloed within the Walls of the City, that two Demi-gods, which were Picus and Faunus, did uually frequent the Fountains and cloe hades of that place; which ome will have to be two Satyrs of the Titanian race; who being expert in the
faculty of Phyick, and dexterous in legerdemain and magical pells, like the Dactyli of Mount Ida, made a Journey through all the parts of Italy. Numa contriving one day to urprie thee Demi-gods, mingled the Waters of the Fountain of which they did uually drink with Wine and Honey, which o pleaed thee liquorih Deities, that he eaily ennared and took them; but then they changed themelves into many various forms and hapes, intending, under horrid and unknown tranmutations, to make their ecape: but, finding themelves entrapped in inextricable toils, and in no poibility to get free, revealed unto him many ecrets and future events; and particularly a charm againt. Thunder and Lightning, which they compoed of Onions, and Hair, and the Bones of a Fih: but ome deny, and ay, that thee Demi-gods did not dicover the ecret of this charm to Numa; but that they, by the force of their Magick Art and Spells, had contrained Jove himelf to decend from Heaven to atisfie the demands of Numa, and that he then, in an angry manner anwering his enquiries, told him, that if he would charm the Thunder and Lightning, he mut doe it with Heads: How, aid Numa, with the Heads of Onions? No, reply'd Jupiter, of Men. But Numa, willing to divert the cruelty of this
Receipt, turned it another way, aying, Your meaning is, the Hairs of Mens Heads; No, reply'd Jupiter, of living Men: then Numa, being intructed by the Goddes Egeria, eemed to mitake, and ay, How! with the Bones of the Fih Maena? which, being the three ingredients that compoe the charm, o operated on Jupiter, that he returned again to Heaven pacified and wellpleaed. This place was ever afterwards called Elicium, or Ilicium, from the Greek word < in non-Latin alphabet > , which ignifies propitious or mercifull; and in this manner this Magick Spell was effected.

Such was the upertitious humour of that Age, which the example of the Prince The people of Rome generally inclin'd to upertition in Numa's reign. had wrought in the Minds of the Vulgar, that nothing was o aburd and ridiculous in Religion which gain'd not belief; and Numa himelf was aid to have been poeed with uch a confidence and fiducial trut in the Gods, that when it was told him, that the Enemy was near at hand, he milingly anwered, That he feared them not, let them come at their peril, for he was then acrificing to the Gods. It was he alo that built the Temples of Faith, and Terminus; and taught the Romans uch repect to Faith, that it was the greatet Oath, and the mot obligatory that they could wear; and to the God Terminus they offer unto this
day the bloud of Beats, both in publick and private Sacrifices, upon the borders and tone marks of their Land: though anciently thoe Sacrifices were olemnized without bloud, it being the Precept and Doctrine of Numa to offer nothing to the God Terminus, but what was pure and free of bloudy cruelty; for that he, whoe incumbence it was to fix boundaries, was thereby contituted an Arbiter of Peace and Jutice, punihing thoe who removed their neighbours Landmark, or invaded his right. It is very clear, that it was this King who firt precribed bounds to the juridiction of Rome; for Romulus would have betrayed his own caue, and plainly dicovered how much he had encroached on his neighbours Lands, had he ever et limits to his own; which as they are fences and curbs againt arbitrary invaions, to thoe who oberve them, o they erve for evidences to arie in judgment againt thoe, who break over and violate the borders with which they are circumcribed. The truth is, the portion of Lands which the Romans poeed at the beginning, was very narrow, untill Romulus by War enlarged them; and which Numa afterwards divided amongt the indigent Commonalty, that he might ward them againt violent neceity, which always puts men upon injurious deigns and
hifts, and that by placing them in Farms, he might accutom them to a deire of property, Numa a friend and advancer of Husbandry. and a regular way of living; for as there is nothing that o reconciles the minds of men to Peace, as Husbandry and a Country lie; o it makes them abhorr all violence, and gives them courage and reolution to defend their owed Lands and Patures from the encroachment of their neighbours. Wherefore Numa, that he might take and amue the hearts of his Citizens with Agriculture or Husbandry, which is an employment that rather begets civility and a peaceable temper than great opulency and riches, he divided all the Lands into everal parcels, to which he gave the name of Pagus or Borough, and over every one of them he ordained a Chief or Arbitrator in judicial caues; and taking a delight ometimes to urvey his Colonies in peron, he made judgment of every man's inclinations and manners, by his indutry, and the improvements he had made, of which being witnes himelf, he preferred thoe to honours and authority who had merited mot; and on the contrary reproached the luggihnes of uch, who had given themelves over to a careles and a negligent life. But above all, which was a principal He firt divided the Citizens into ditinct Companies. point of his Politicks, he divided the people into everal Companies: for as the
City did conit, or rather was ditinguihed (as we have aid) by two orts of Tribes; from whence dangerous Factions, Tumults and Seditions did arie; he contrived to cat them into divers mall moulds and models: for as hard and dienting Bodies are not eaily incorporated, o long as they remain in their gros bulk, but being beaten into a powder, or melted into mall Atoms, are often cemented and conolidated into one; o this people, being eparated and ditinguihed into mall diviions, were afterwards with les difficulty united into one Body: wherefore ditinguihing the whole City by their everal Arts and Profeions; he formed the Companies of Muicians, Goldmiths, Maons, Dyers, Taylors, Skinners, Braiers and Potters; and all other Handy-crafts men he compoed and reduced into a ingle Company, appointing unto every one their repective Halls, Courts and other privileges belonging to their Societies, which they held by the Charters received from this Prince. In this manner all factious ditinctions began to ceae in the City; there being no peron farther eteemed under the notion of a Sabine, a Roman or a Tatian, but all were comprehended under the general denomination of a Citizen of Romulus; whereby all other terms growing out of ue and fahion, the
national animoities reconciled of themelves, and all diolved into the common tye and relation of a Roman Citizen.

He is alo much to be commended for the repeal, or rather amendment of that Law, which gives power to Fathers to ell their Children; for he exempted uch as were married from that ubjection, conditionally that they had matched themelves with the liking and conent of their Parents: for it eemed a very hard and unjut thing, that a woman, who had given her elf in marriage to a man whom he judged free, hould afterwards find her elf betrayed and cat away upon a Husband that was a Servant.

He attempted alo to draw a Scheme of The regulation of the year intituted by Numa. the Heavens, and thereunto conform a Kalendar and Ephemerides of the Year, which though it was not perfect, yet it was not altogether without ome learned conjectures, and uch as reduced the account of the Year to ome tolerable regulation: for during the Reign of Romulus, their Months had no certain or equal term; for ome of them contained 20 Days, others 35, others more; the which errour proceeded from want of a true knowledge of the different motions of the Sun and Moon; onely they kept to this account, that the whole coure of the Year contained 360 Days. Numa alo farther
oberving, that there was eleven Days difference between the Lunary and the Solary Year: for that the Moon compleated her Anniverary coure in 354 Days, and the Sun in 365; to remedy which inequality, he doubled the eleven Days, and after every two Year added an intertitial to follow the Month of February, which the Romans called the Month of Mercidinus; but this account hath ince that time received a better amendment. He alo altered the order of the Months; for March, which was reckoned the firt, he put into the third place; and January, which was the eleventh, he made the firt; and February, which was the twelfth and lat, to be the econd. Some will have it, that it was Numa alo which added the two Months of January and February: for in the beginning, when men Various, aburd and unskilfull computations of the year. were ignorant and barbarous, they compoed a Year of ten Months: the Arcadians in Greece had onely four, in Arcanania they accounted by ix; and the Egyptians had at firt but one Month, which afterwards they divided into four, according to the eaons of the Year: which Country of Egypt, though it eem new to us, is yet inhabited by an ancient people; for if we may believe their Chronicles (unles they account Months for Years) their Genealogies are deduced from great Antiquity.
And that the Romans at firt comprehended the whole Year within ten, and not twelve Months, plainly appears by the name of December, which ignifies the tenth Month, and is the lat in order: and that March was the firt is likewie evident, for that the fifth Month after it was called Quintilis, and the ixth Sextilis, and o the ret; o that if January and February had in this account preceded March, Quintilis had been put in the eventh place, and o called September. It is alo very probable, that this firt Month was dedicated by Romulus to Mars; the econd to Venus, called April, from the Greek word Aphrodites; which the Women olemnize in honour of that Goddes, adorning their heads on the Kalends, or firt days of it, with Myrtle Garlands. But others will not allow of the derivation of this word from Aphrodites, but rather deduce it from the word Aperio, which in Latin ignifies, to open, becaue that this Month is in the high Spring, when all Buds and Flowers open and dicloe themelves: the next is called May, from Maia the Mother of Mercury, to whom this Month was made acred: then June follows, o called from Juventus, or youthfulnes of the Year, which is then warm, and gay, and in its juvenile eaon. To the other Months alo they gave denominations
according to their order, o the fifth was called Quintilis, Sextilis the ixth, and o the ret September, October, November and December: Afterwards Caear, when he had overcome Pompey, changed the name of the Month Quintilis to that of Julius, which we call July; as alo that of Sextilis was changed into Augutus, which was a irname to the Succeour of Caear. Domitian alo in imitation hereof gave the two other following Months the names of Germanicus and Domitianus, but, he being lain, they recovered their ancient denominations of September and October; but the two lat have ever reerved their names without any alteration. The Months which were added, and tranpoed in their order by Numa was February, which deduces its name from Februo, ignifying a purification by Sacrifice; for then they offered Plants, and celebrated the Feat of Lupercalia, in which many Ceremonies agree with the Solemnities ued at the Lutrations or cleaning days: but January was o called from Janus, and a precedency of order given to it by Numa before March, which was dedicated to the God Mars; intimating in my opinion thereby, that the Arts and civil tudies of Peace are to be preferred before warlike or martial employments. For this Janus, whether he were a Daemon, or Demigod,
or a King, was certainly a great Polititian and lover of Arts and Sciences, whereby he transformed the incult natures of men into a gentle and civil dipoition; for which reaon they figure him with two Faces, beholding at the ame time both tates and contitutions of humane kind. His Temple at Rome hath two Gates, which they call the Gates of Mars; becaue they tand open in the time of War, and hut in the times of Peace, of which latter there was very eldom an example; for when the Roman Empire was enlarged and extended to its utmot bounds, it was o encompaed with barbarous Nations and Enemies, that it was eldom or never at peace: onely in the time of Augutus Caear, after he had overcome Anthony, that Temple was hut; as likewie not many years before, when Marcus Atilius and Titus Manlius were Conuls; but then it continued not o long, before that Wars breaking out, the Gates of Janus were again opened: but during The Gates of Janus's Temple never open in Numa's reign. the Reign of Numa, which continued for the pace of forty three years, thoe Gates were ever hut, there being a profound quiet without the noie or clattering of Arms: for not onely the people of Rome were animated with a pirit of peace, which they enjoyed under the jut proceedings of a pacifick Prince; but even the neighbouring
Cities, as if they had been inpired with the ame inclinations, breathed nothing but a alubrious and gentle air of mutual friendhip, and amicable correpondence; and being ravihed with the delights Happy reults of Peace. which Jutice and Peace produce, every one apply'd himelf to the management of his Lands and Farm, to the education of his Children, and worhip of the Gods: Fetival days, and Sports, and Banquets were the common divertiements; and Families entertained and treated their acquaintance and friends in uch a free and open manner, that all Italy ecurely convered with each other without fears, or jealouies, or deigns, being all poeed with that Divine Spirit of Love and Charity, which flowed from Numa as from a Fountain of Wiedom and Equity: o that the Hyperbolies, which the Poets of thoe days ued, and the flights which are allowable in Vere, were flat and not able to reach with their highet expreions the happines of thoe days;
When Spears, and Swords, and direfull Arms of War
Were laid aide, and rutied in their places;
No Trumpet ounds alarm'd the publick peace,
But all ecurely lept—
For during the whole Reign of Numa, there was neither War, nor Sedition, nor Plots deigned againt the State, nor did any Faction prevail, or the ambition and emulation of great Men attempt upon the Government: for indeed men o reverenced his Vertue, and tood in uch awe of his Peron, which, they believed, was guarded by a particular care of Divine Providence, that they depaired of all ucces in their initer intentions: and then that happy Fortune, which always attends the life of men who are pure and innocent, betowed a general eteem and good reputation on him; and verified that aying of Plato, which ome Ages after he delivered in relation to the happines of a well formed Commonwealth: For, aith he, where the Royal Power, by God's Grace, meets with a mind and pirit addicted to Philoophy, there Vice is ubdued and made inferiour to Vertue: no man is really bleed but he that is wie; and happy are his Auditours, who can hear and receive thoe words which flow from his mouth: there is no need of compulion or menaces to ubject the multitude, for that A vertuous example mot conpicuous and enticing in a Prince. lutre of vertue which hines bright in the good example of a Governour, invites and inclines them to wiedom, and inenibly leads them to an innocent and happy life, which being conducted by friendhip and
concord, and upported on each ide with temperance and jutice, is of long and lating continuance; and worthy is that Prince of all rule and dominion, who makes it his buines to lead his Subjects into uch a tate of felicity. This was the care of Numa, and to this end did all his actions tend.

As to his Children and Wives, there is a diverity of reports by everal Authours: ome will have it that he never had any other Wife than Tatia, nor more Children than one Daughter called Pompilia: others will have it that he left four Sons; namely, Pompo, Pinus, Calpus and Mamercus, every one of which had iue, and from them decended the noble and illutrious Families of Pomponi, Pinari, Calpurni and Mamerci, to which for ditinction ake was added the irname of Royal. But there is a third ort of Writers, which ay that thee pedigrees are but a piece of flattery ued by the Heralds, who, to incurr favour with thee great Families, deduced their Genealogies from this ancient Lineage; and that Pompilia was not the Daughter of Tatia, but born of Lucretia, to whom he was married after he came to his Kingdom: howoever all of them agree in opinion, that he was married to the Son of that Martius who perwaded him to accept the Government,
and accompanied him to Rome, where, as a ignal of honour, he was choen into the Senate; and after the death of Numa, tanding in competition with Tullus Hotilius for the Kingdom, and being diappointed of the Election, in high dicontent killed himelf: howoever his Son Martius, who had married Pompilia, reiding at Rome, was the Father of Ancus Martius, who ucceeded Tullus Hotilius in the Kingdom, and was but five years of age, when Numa died.

Numa lived omething above eighty years, and then (as Pio writes) was not taken out Numa's Death and honourable Interment. of the world by a udden or acute Dieae, but by a chronical Ditemper, by which he lingred long, and at lat expired. At his Funerals all the glories of his Life were conummate; for the kind people, and his friendly companions, met to honour and grace the rites of his Interment with Garlands and contributions from the publick: the Senatours carried the Bier on which his Corps was laid, and the Priets followed and accompanied the olemn proceion; the remainder of this dolefull pomp was compoed of Women and Children, who lamented with uch tears and ighs, as if they had bewailed the death or los of a dearet relation taken away in the flower of his age, and not of an old and out-worn King.
It is aid that his Body, by his particular command, was not burnt, but that he ordered two tone Coffins to be made, in one of which he appointed his Body to be laid, and the other to be a repoitory for his acred Books and Writings, and both of them to be buried under the Hill Janiculum; thereby imitating the Legilatours of Greece, who, having wrote their Laws in Tables, which they called Cirbas, did o long inculcate the contents of them, whilt they lived, into the minds and hearts of their Priets, till their undertandings became living Libraries of thoe acred Volumes; it being eteemed a profanation of uch myteries To commit to writing Divine Precepts held a profanation by the Grecian Law-givers. to commit their ecrets unto dead letters. For this very reaon, they ay, the Pythagoreans forbad that their Precepts or Concluions hould be committed to paper, but rather conerved in the living memories of thoe who were worthy to receive their Doctrines: and if perchance any of their abtrue notions or perplexed cares, uch as were their poitions in Geometry, were made known, or revealed to an impure peron, unworthy to receive uch myteries, they preently imagined that the Gods threatned punihment for uch profanation; which was not to be expiated but by Sword and Petilence, or other judgments of the Gods. Wherefore having thee everal intances
concurring to render the Lives of Numa and Pythagoras agreeable, we may eaily pardon thoe who make a comparion between their temperament of Soul and manners of living, believing that there was an intimate familiarity and converation between them.

Valerius Antias writes that the Books which were buried in the aforeaid Chets or Coffins of Stone were twelve Volumes of holy Writ, and twelve others in Greek containing the Wiedom and Philoophy of the Grecians: and that about four hundred years afterwards, when P. Cornelius and M. Bebius were Conuls, there happening a great inundation of Water, which with a violent torrent carrying away the Chets of Stone, overturned them and diplaced their Covers, o that being opened, one of them appeared empty without the Skeleton or Reliques of any humane Body; in the other were the Books before-mentioned, till remaining entire, and not much worn out with time: which when the Pretor Petilius had read and perued, he made Oath in the Senate, that in his opinion, it was not fit for thoe Books to be divulged, or made publick to the people; whereupon the Edition of them was uppreed, and all the Volumes by command carried to the Market place, and there burnt.

Such is the fortune of good men, that their Vertue urvives their Bodies, and that the envy and emulation which evil men conceive againt them is oon extinguihed; but their reputation and glory is immortal, and hines with more plendour after their death, than in the time when they were living and converant in the world: and as to Numa, the actions of the ucceeding Kings erved as o many Foils to et off the brightnes of his majetick Vertues: for after him there were five Kings; the lat of which was made an exile, being depoed from his Crown: of the other four, three were by treaon aainated and murthered; the other, who was Tullus Hotilius that immediately ucceeded Numa, whilt he derided his vertues, and epecially his devotion and religious worhip, reproached his memory, as a cowardly and mean pirited Prince; and, diverting the minds of the people from their peaceable and honet coure of life to wars and depredations, was himelf urprized by an acute and tormenting Dieae; which caued him to change his mind and Even Atheits in • ime of adve • ity implore the Deity. call upon the Gods; but it was accompanied with uch upertition and vain imaginations, as was much differing from the true Piety and Religion of Numa: and, becaue he infected others with the contagion of his errours, the Gods, as is aid,
were angry, and revenged their own dihonour by a Thunder-bolt which troke him dead.

div.head: THE COMPARISON OF NMA with LYCRGS.
div.p:
HAving thus finihed the Lives of Lycurgus and Numa; we hall now (though the work be difficult) compare their Actions in that manner together, o as eaily to dicern wherein they differed, and wherein they agreed. It is apparent that they were very agreeable in the actions of their lives, their Moderation, their Religion, their civil Arts and political Government were alike; and both ininuated a belief in the people, that they derived their Laws and Contitutions from the Gods: yet in their peculiar manner of managing thee excellencies, there were many circumtances which made a diverity: For firt, Numa accepted the
Kingdom being offered, but Lycurgus reigned The different qualities of Lycurgus and Numa. it; the one from a private peron and a tranger was created King, the other from the condition and publick character of a Prince decended to the tate of a private peron. It was glorious to poes a Throne in Righteounes and Judgment; and great bravery on the other ide to prefer Jutice before a Kingdom: the ame vertue which made the one appear worthy of Regal power, exalted the other to a degree of o much eminence, that it eemed a condecention in him to toop unto a Crown: latly, as Muicians tune their Harps according to their Note; o the one let down the high flown pirits of the people at Rome to a lower Key, as the other crewed them up at Sparta to a higher Note, which were fallen flat by diolutenes and riot. For it was not o much the buines and care of Lycurgus to reaon his Citizens into peace, or to perwade them to put off their Armour, or ungird their Swords; as it was to moderate their love to Gold or Silver, or the profuenes of their Tables, or to abate their extravagancies in rich Clothes and Furniture: nor was it neceary to preach unto them, that, laying aide their Arms, they hould oberve the Fetivals, and acrifice to the Gods; but rather, that, moderating the affluence of their Tables and
exces of diet, they hould become temperate and abtemious, and employ their time in laborious and martial exercies: o that the one moulded his Citizens into what humour he pleaed, by a gentle and oft way of argument; the other with danger and hazard of his peron, carce worked upon the affections of a diolute people. It is certain, that Numa was naturally endued with a more gentle and obliging way, which mollified the harh dipoition of his people, and made them tractable and lovers of jutice: but Lycurgus was more rigid and (ince we mut mention it) we cannot excue his everity againt the Ilotes, or term it other than a cruel action; and in the um of all conclude, that Numa was far the more moderate and plauible Legilatour; granting even to Servants a licence to it at meat with their Maters at the Feat of Saturn, that o they alo might have ome tate and relih of the weetnes of liberty. Some will have it that this cutom Numa's indulgence to Slaves variouly interpreted. was introduced by Numa on this jut reaon, that becaue the Servants were intrumental in cultivating the grounds and gathering the Fruits which the Earth produced, there hould be a time appointed when they might enjoy the fruits of their labours, in a more free and delightfull manner: Others will have it to be in remembrance of
that age of Saturn, when there was no ditinction between the Lord and the Servant; but all lived as Kindred and Relations in a parity and condition of equality. In hort, it eems that both aimed at the ame deign and intent, which was to compoe and incline their people to modety and frugality; but as to their other vertues, the one availed himelf mot on Fortitude, and the other on Jutice: unles we will attribute their different ways to the different temperaments of their people; for Numa did not out of cowardie or fear affect Peace, but becaue he would not be guilty of thoe injuries which are the neceary conequences of War: nor did Lycurgus, out of a principle of violence and fury, promote and excite a pirit of War in his people, but rather encouraged the art of War, and inclined their minds, which were oft and enervated by Luxury, to martial Exercies; that o they might be the better prepared to repell injuries, and reit the invaions of their enemies: in this manner both having occaion to operate on their Citizens, and make a change and alteration in their humours and manners, the one cut off the uperfluities and excees, whilt the other upplied the defects of that which was wanting.

The frame of Numa's Politicks did mot ute with the contitution of a Commonwealth,
and more repected the humour of a popular Government; for having ranged his people into everal Companies, uch as Goldmiths, Muicians, Shoo-makers, and other Handicraft Trades, he cherihed Numa tudious of Trade, Lycurgus of martial Dicipline. them and gave them privileges by their Charters: but the Government of Lycurgus was more Aritocratical, conferring the greatet authority on the Nobility, and leaving the profeion of mechanical Arts, and Trades, to be the employment onely of Strangers, and of the low and baer Commonalty. The Citizens he allowed onely to manage the Spear and Buckler; becaue that being the Miniters and Servants of Mars, they had no great need of knowledge or literature more than to oberve the words of command, and obey their Leaders, intending by their dicipline of War to enable them to defend themelves and offend their enemy: for to men that were really made Free and become Gentlemen all trade and traffick was forbidden; and the gainfull and pecuniary Arts, and the care of Proviions, and preparing Suppers and Banquets, made the buines onely of Servants, or of the Ilotes. But Numa made none of thee ditinctions, onely he took care that men grew not rich by Spoils or Prizes taken in the War, all other profits and acquiitions being allowable by the Law,
and not dihonourable in the eteem of the world: nor did he endeavour to level mens Etates, or reduce them to an equality, but gave every man a liberty to amas wealth, and grow as rich as he was able; but took no care to provide againt poverty, which, by the additions of poor people, which flocked to the City, increaed daily. In the beginning of all, he ought to have uppreed or dicountenanced covetounes, whilt there was no great diparity in the etates of men, and whilt the balance was equal; and, after the example of Lycurgus, have obviated thoe many and great michiefs which proceeded from avarice, as the fountain and original of them all: and yet Lycurgus is not to be blamed for etablihing the Agrarian Law, which was a dividing of Lands amongt the people, nor was Numa to be reproved for not admitting uch Law or Cutom in his juridiction: becaue equality was the Bais and foundation of his Commonwealth, but the cae of Numa was far different; for the diviion of Lands having been formerly admitted and made, the taking them away or altering mens properties in them, could not have been performed without the troubles and dangers which follow uch innovations.

Now as to Marriages, and the regular way of increaing the world, they both
agreed on uch political Contitutions as Their different Laws and Contitutions in Marriage, chiefly deign'd to prevent Jealouie. hould clear the mind of Husbands from all torment of jealouie, and yet their Cutoms and Laws herein were diverly qualified. For when a Roman thought himelf to have a ufficient proviion of Children, in cae his neighbour who had none, hould come and deire him to accommodate him with his Wife, that he alo might have the benefit of iue from his fruitfull Woman; he had a lawfull power to lend her to him who deired her, either for a certain time, or ele to looe the bonds of Marriage, and conign her into the hands of her Paramour for ever. But the Laconian had another rule, for it was allowable for him to afford the ue of his Wife to any other that deired to have Children by her, and yet till to keep her in his Houe, and retain the bond and conditions of Marriage in the ame force and vertue as before: nay many Husbands (as we have aid) would often invite men of handome Features and comely Bodies to their Houes, in hopes of Children of the like hapes and beauty, which they adopted and acknowledged for their own. What difference was there then between thee everal cutoms? unles it be this, That the free ue which the Laconians indulged of their Women was a remedy againt the humour of jealouie, which often affects
men with uch torment of mind, that their days conume in orrow and diquiet: the other of the Romans conerved ome repect for the modety of Women, and the acrednes of Marriage, not enduring a community of Wives in the ame Houe, nor a transferring of the right of them to another, unles the matrimonial Knot were firt diolved. Moreover the Contitutions of Numa as to Virgins were more evere, precribing rules to keep them modet, and free from all upicions of unchatity: but the Orders of Lycurgus were in that point more diolute, giving more liberty to Maids and ingle Women; which afforded to the Poets ubject for their raillery, as Ibycus who gave them the Epithet of < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Wenches that held up their Petticoats as far as their Thighs, and < in non-Latin alphabet > , or rampant Girles, that run mad for a Man, o Euripides aith,
Where wanton Girles with roring Boys,
Fill all their Fathers Houe with noie;
Clothes looely flowing with a lit between,
For what we hide, they would have een.
For the Habit which Maidens wore came but to their Knees, and was open on both ides, o that as they walked their Thighs appeared bare; according to thee Veres of Sophocles
Hermione tuck'd up her Smock on high,
Not being aham'd to hew her brawny Thigh.
This manner of Habit gave the Women An undecent practice of the Women of Laconia. uch confidence, that they hen-peck'd their Husbands; and not onely bore the greatet way at home, but alo had the privilege of Votes in publick Aemblies: but the Matrons under the Government of Numa were ruled with better decorum; for though the Husbands were very indulgent to their Sabine Wives, endeavouring to compenate for their Rape, in the Reign of Romulus, by extraordinary kindnes, howoever their liberty was retrained within ome terms of modety, which taught them obriety and ilence, and to abtain from Wine and freedom of dicoure, and long viits, unles in company or preence of their Husbands: So that when at a certain time a Woman had the confidence to plead her own caue at the Bar in a place of Judicature; it eemed o trange and montrous a thing, that the Senate ent to enquire of the Oracle, what uch a prodigy in nature did portend: and indeed the vertue of modet Women is bet illutrated by comparing them with the michievous examples of thoe that were lewd and impudent: For as the Greek Hitorians record in their Annals the names
of thoe who firt unheathed the Sword of Civil War, or murthered their Brothers, or were Parricides and killed their Fathers; o the Roman Writers report, that Spurius Divorce not in ue amongt the ancient Romans. Carvilius was the firt who divorced his Wife; being a cae that never before happened in the pace of 230 years from the Foundation of the City: and that one Thalea, the Wife of Pinarius, was the firt that had any quarrel or debate with her Mother-in-law, Gegania, in the Reign of Tarquinius Superbus: o excellent were the Laws and Contitutions of the conjugal Rites of that City, that uch peccadillio's as thee were recounted for flagitious crimes, and the leat failures in them at firt were reputed infamous, and fit to be branded and marked with hame in the Hitory of thoe times. Now the Laws which Lycurgus ordained, either in relation to Virgins or married Women, were different: for he eteeming procreation of Children to be the principal end of Marriage, would fix no et term of age, when Men or Women hould be eteemed capable of giving their conents to each other in Marriage; for he thought that nature being the principal guide in that matter hould not be retrained with violence, which produces hatred and fear; but rather being gently indulged, when youth, and love, and kindnes move; the
coition might be more atisfactory, and conequently the Children become more robut, trong and healthfull.

But the Romans deigning in the firt place to deliver the Bodies of their Daughters pure and undefiled into the embraces and poeion of the Husband, made it lawfull for Fathers to marry their Daughters at twelve years of age, or under: which firt way of Lycurgus eems more agreeable to the deires of Nature, which onely repects the procreation of Children; but the other is better adapted to make a conjugal life comfortable, and calculated for the rules of moral living. Howoever thoe general rules which Lycurgus precribed for education of Children, for their meetings together and viits, as alo thoe regulations he made in their Feats, or Compotations, Exercies and Sports, do argue, that Numa was in ome manner inferiour to him in the art and mytery of giving Laws: For as to The prudent methods of Lycurgus's Contitutions. education, Lycurgus was of opinion, That Parents were rather obliged to follow the inclinations and genius of their Children, than to adhere to any fixt or formal rule of Dicipline: as for example, if a Father deigning to make his Son a Husbandman, or a Carpenter, a Braier, or a Muician; will he not firt conult his genius or inclinations, before he oblige him to a Profeion
whereunto he hath no delight, and for which he hath no Talent or capacity? For as paengers who embark together on the ame Ship, though they have divere deigns, and apply themelves to different interets, yet when Storms arie, whereby the whole Cargaon is endangered, they forake the thoughts of their private concernments, that they may unite their hands and heads for the common conervation; in like manner, the Legilatours or Law-makers, whoe buines is the publick good, are not required to give or precribe tanding rules for every particular action or private affair, but uch onely as repect the common ue and benefit.

And ince we may blame the common ort of Legilatours, who, either for want of power or knowledge, take fale meaures in the Maxims they lay down for fundamental Laws: how much rather may we except againt the conduct of Numa, who for the reputation of his wiedom onely being called and invited by the general conent of a new and unettled people to be their King, did not in the firt place provide and contitute rules for the education of Children and the dicipline of Youth; for want of which men become editious and turbulent, and live not quiet in their Families or parihes; but when they are inured from their Cradles
to good Principles, and intructed from their Infancy in the rules of Morality, they receive uch impreions of Vertue as make them enible of that benefit and eae which peace and mutual agreement brings to a Commonwealth. This with many others, was one of the Politicks of Lycurgus, and was of great ue in the confirmation and etablihment of his Laws. An intance we have in the practice of Swearing and making Oaths a part of Religion, which had An Oath held acred by the Lacedemonians. proved very inignificant, unles that by good dicipline a principle had been at firt intilled of the acrednes of uch a Function; and this was the caue that the Lacedemonians, having ucked in thee principles with their milk, were poeed with a mot reverend eteem of all his Intitutions; o that the main points and fundamentals of his Law, continued for above 500 years in force with trict obervance, and without any violation. But Numa, whoe whole deign and aim was peace, and to conerve his people in uch a ene of Religion and Divine worhip as might conduce to the preent tranquillity, did never make proviions for a future condition, or for the time of War: and therefore no ooner did he expire his lat breath, than peace vanihed with it, and immediately after his deceae the Gates of Janus Temple
flew wide open; and as if War had been long pent up within thoe Walls, it ruh'd forth like a mighty Storm infeting all Italy with bloud and laughter: and thus that excellent Fabrick, and compoition of Equity and Jutice was diolved, for want of early principles, intilled by good education Remines in bringing up of youth prejudicial to the Roman State. into youth, which are the foundation to upport it, and the neceary cement which unites all together, in a fixed and immutable habit. What then (may ome ay) hath Rome been prejudiced by her Wars? I anwer that this quetion, which men make, who take their meaures from the advance of Riches and Power exalted with Luxury, rather than from that Innocence and moderation of Mind, which is always accompanied with tranquillity and peace, is not to be reolved by a udden anwer, but by a long and philoophical dicoure. Howoever it makes much for Lycurgus, that o oon as the Romans deerted the Doctrine and Dicipline of Numa, their Empire grew and their power encreaed: whenas on the contrary, o oon as the Lacedemonians fell from the Intitutions of Lycurgus, the Fabrick of their Government diolved with their Laws, and, the Grecian Empire being lot, they alo were reduced to the utmot point of deolation and ruine. And yet there is omething peculiarly ignal and
almot Divine in the circumtances of Numa, for he was an Alien, and yet courted againt his own inclinations to accept a Kingdom; the frame of which though he entirely altered, yet he performed it without force or coaction, and with uch lenity that nothing was acted but with the aent and concurrence of the people. Lycurgus on the other ide favoured the Nobility, and made them the Lords and Rulers over the Commons; and yet that Government was well tempered alo, and duly poied by Wiedom and Jutice.

div.head: THE LIFE OF SOLON.
div.byline: Tranlated from the Greek, By Thomas Creech, of Wadh. Coll. Oxon.
div.p:
DYdymus the Grammarian, in his anwer to Aclepiades concerning Solon's Tables, mentions a paage of one Philocles, who delivers that Solon's Father's Solon of a noble Family. name was Euphorion, contrary to the opinion of all thoe who have written concerning him: for they generally agree that he was the Son of Exetides, a man of moderate wealth and power in the City; but of a noble Stock, being decended from Codrus:
his Mother, as Heraclides Ponticus affirms, was Couin to Piitratus his Mother, and thoe two at firt were great Friends, partly becaue they were a kin, and partly becaue Piitratus was a handome Lov'd Piitratus. gracefull man, and they ay Solon lov'd him: and that is the reaon, I uppoe, that when afterwards they differ'd about the Government, their enmity never produc'd any hot and violent paion, they remembred their old kindnees, and that kept the flame of their love and dear affection till alive: For that Solon was Amorous, Solon lov'd Boys. and unable toutly to reit the force of Beauty, we may conjecture by his Poems; and by a Law he forbad Slaves to perfume themelves, or love Boys, making that an honourable action, and onely fit for Gentlemen, and as it were inviting the Worthy to the practice, when he commanded the Unworthy to forbear. Piitratus likewie is reported to have lov'd one Charmus, and to have conecrated his Statue in the Academy, where thoe light their Torches that win the acred < in non-Latin alphabet > : Solon, as Ermippus writes, when his Father had ruin'd his Etate in doing benefits and kindnees to other men, though he had Friends enough that were willing to contribute to his relief, yet he was aham'd to be beholding to others, ince he was decended
from a Family who were accutomed to doe kindnees rather than receive them. He therefore apply'd himelf to Merchandie; Solon turns Merchant. though others aure us that Solon travel'd rather to get Learning and Experience than to raie an Etate: 'tis certain that he was a lover of Wiedom, for when he was old he would ay, I grow old till learning many things. But he was no admirer of Riches, eteeming thoe equally wealthy
Who ees vat heaps of Gold at his command,
Fine Hores, and a fair Etate in Land;
And Him, to whom indulgent Fate betow'd
Sufficient wealth to buy him Clothes and Food:
But if to this a Wife, and pratling Boys,
And youth, and grace, He hath the height of Joys.
And in another place,
I would be rich, and yet to raie my pure
Not cheat, for wealth o got the Gods will cure.
Now 'tis no hame for a prudent man and a good Citizen not to be olicitous about uperfluities, or to look after competent necearies. In his time (according to Heiod) a Trade was not dihonourable, nor did it
debae the quality of the profeours; but Merchandie was a worthy Calling, which brought home the good things which the barbarous Nations enjoy'd, was the occaion of friendhip with their Kings, and mother of Experience. Some Merchants have built great Cities, as the Founder of Mailia, that man o much eteem'd by the Gauls that live about the Rhone: ome alo report that Thales and Hyppocrates the Mathematician traded; and that Plato defray'd the charges of his Travels by elling Oil in Aegypt. Now Solon's oftnes and profuenes, his dicoure of pleaures in his Poems, too looe for a Philoopher, were occaion'd by his trading life; for having uffer'd a thouand dangers, 'twas fit they hould be recompenc'd with pleaure and enjoyments: but that he accounted himelf rather poor than rich is evident from thee lines;

q.l: Some wicked men are rich, ome good are poor;
I would not change my Vertue for their tore:
For that's a ure poeion, firm as Fate;
Whilt wealth now flies to this man, now to that.

div.p:
At firt he us'd his Poetry onely in trifles, Solon a Poet. in vain humours, and to pas away his idle hours: but afterwards his Numbers contein'd
moral Sentences, and many tranactions of the Commonwealth, which he did not write for the bare ake of the Hitory; but to apologize for his own actions, and ometimes to correct, chatie and tir up the Athenians to noble performances. Some report that he deign'd to put his Laws into a Poem, and began it thus,

l.hi: We humbly beg a bleing on our Laws

q.l: From mighty Jove, and honour and applaue.

div.p:
Of moral Philoophy, as mot of the then Learned onely Politicks. wie men, he chiefly eteemed Politicks; in Phyicks he was very rude and illiterate, as appears by this,
Soft Snow and Hail fall from a frozen Cloud;
From glaring Lightning Thunder roars aloud?
The Winds make the Seas rough, they vex the Main;
But when they ceae to blow, 'tis mooth and plain.
And indeed 'tis probable, that at that time Thales onely had rais'd wiedom above practice into peculation; and the other ix were call'd wie from their prudence in Politick concerns. Fame delivers that they had an
enterview at Delphos, and another at Corinth, The meeting of the wie Men. by the procurement of Periander, who made proviion for their entertainment: but their reputation was chiefly raied Of the Tripod ent to the wie Men. by ending the Tripod to them all, and their modet refual, and complaiant yielding to one another: For (as the tory goes) ome of the Coans fihing with a Net, ome trangers, Mileians, bought the draught at a venture; the Net brought up a golden Tripod, which (they ay) Helen at her return from Troy, upon the remembrance of an old prophecy, threw in there. Now the trangers at firt conteting with the Fihers about the Tripod, and the Cities epouing the quarrel o far as to engage themelves in a War; Apollo decided the Controverie, by commanding to preent it to the wiet Man: and firt it was ent to Miletum to Thales, the Coans freely preenting him with that for which they fought all the Mileians, but Thales declaring Bias the wier peron, it was ent to him; from him to another; and o going round them all, it came to Thales a econd time; and at lat, being carried from Miletum to Thebes, it was there dedicated to Apollo Imenius. Theophratus writes, that it was firt preented to Bias at Priene; and next to Thales at Miletum; and o through all it returned to Bias, and was afterwards ent to Delphos.
This is a general report, onely ome intead of a Tripod ay this preent was a Cup ent by Croeus; others a piece of Plate that one Buthocles had left. 'Tis reported that Anacharis Anacharis and Solon acquainted. and Solon, and Solon and Thales were familiarly acquainted, and ome have deliver'd parts of their dicoure: For (they ay) Anacharis coming to Athens, knock'd at Solon's Door, and told him, That he being a tranger was come to be his Guet, and contract a Friendhip with him: and Solon replying, 'Tis better to eek Friends at home, Anacharis return'd, Then you that are at home take me as a Guet and as a Friend: Solon omewhat urpried at the brisknes of that Repartee, receiv'd him kindly, and kept him ome time with him, whilt he was managing the Commonwealth, and contriving his Laws; which when Anacharis undertood, he laught at him, for imagining the Citizens unruly deires and affections could be retrain'd by thee Laws, which were like Spider's Webs, and would catch, 'tis true, the weak and poor, but Anacharis's aying of Laws. are eaily broken by the mighty and rich. To this Solon return'd, Men keep their promies when neither ide can get any thing by the breaking of them; and he would o fit his Laws to the Citizens, that all hould undertand 'twas more eligible to be jut and obey, than act contrary to the command.
But the event rather agreed with the conjecture of Anacharis, than Solon's hope. Anacharis, being one time at the Aembly, aid, he wondred much that in Anacharis aying of the Grecian Aemblies.
Greece the Wie men hould propoe caues, and Fools determine.

When Solon came to Thales at Miletum, Solon and Thales acquainted. he wondred that Thales took no care to get him a Wife and Children. To this Thales made no anwer for the preent, but a few days after dealt with a tranger to pretend that he came from Athens ten days ago; and Solon enquiring what news there, the man, according to his intructions, reply'd, None, but concerning a young man's Funeral which the whole City celebrated; for he was (as the tory went) the Son of an honourable Man, and the mot vertuous of his Citizens; who was not then at home, but had been travelling a long time. Solon reply'd what a mierable man is he! but what was his name? I have heard it, ays the Man, but have now forgotten it, onely there was a great talk of his Wiedom and his Jutice. Thus Solon was drawn Thales concerning Marriage. on by every anwer, and his fears heightned, till at lat, being extremely concern'd, he mention'd his own name, and ask't the tranger if that young man was not call'd Solon's Son; and the tranger aenting, he began to beat his head, and to doe and peak
all thoe things which uually come from men in o great a paion: But Thales held him, and with a mile aid, Thee things, Solon, keep me from Marriage and getting Children, which are too great for your courage and your contancy to upport; however be not concern'd at the report, for 'tis a Fiction. This Ermippus delivers from Pataecus, who boated that he had Aeop's Soul. But 'tis We hould eek conveniencies though we mut once loe them. weak and aburd not to eek conveniencies for fear of looing them, for upon the ame account, we hould neither love Wealth, Glory, nor Wiedom, ince we may fear to be depriv'd of all thee: nay, even Vertue it elf, than which there is no greater, nor more deirable poeion, is often lot by Sicknes or Enchantments: Now Thales, though unmarried, could not be free from olicitude, unles he likewie took no care of his Friends, his Kinmen, or his Country; nay (as Hitory delivers) he adopted Cubithus his Siter's Son. For the Soul, having a principle of kindnes in it elf, and being born to love, as well as perceive, think or remember, inclines, and fixes upon ome tranger, when he hath none of her own to embrace. And as when an Etate wants a lawfull Heir, trangers or Batards endeavour to win the kind poeour, and when they have once gotten his affection, his care and tendernes encreaeth with
his love; inomuch that ome men that are rigid againt the Marriage-bed, and light the fruit of it, when their Servant's or Harlot's Boy is ick or dies, are almot kill'd with grief, and mierably lament. Some have very meanly, and below the dignity of a Man mourn'd for the los of a Dog, or Hore; others upon the death of vertuous Children, have not been concern'd, nor guilty of a mean action; but pas'd the ret of their lives like men, and according to the principles of reaon. For 'tis not benevolence, but weaknes that prompts a Man to continual grief, and makes thoe fear whom Reaon hath not arm'd againt Fortune, inomuch that they cannot enjoy the thing that they deire, the fear of loing it till vexing, and bringing contant racks and torments to their minds. Now we mut not provide againt the los of Wealth, by Poverty; or of Friends, by refuing all acquaintance; or of Children, by getting none, but by Morality and Reaon: But of this too much.

Now when the Athenians were tired with a tedious and difficult War, that they managed againt the Megarenians for the Iland Salamis; and made a Law that it hould be death for any man, by writing or peaking, to aert that the City ought to endeavour to recover it: Solon, vext at the
digrace, and perceiving thouands of the youth wih'd for ome body to begin, but did not dare to tir firt for fear of the Law; he counterfeited a ditraction, and Solon counterfeits himelf mad. by his own Family it was pread abroad the City that he was mad: he ecretly compos'd an Elegy, and, getting it by heart that it might eem extempore, he ran out into the Market-place with a Cap upon his Head, and, the people gathering about him, got up upon the tanding of the Cryer, and ang that Elegy which begins thus,
From Salamis that glorious Ile I come
And bring you news, and noble Veres home.
That Poem is call'd Salamis, it contains an hundred Veres, and elegantly written: now whilt he ang, his Friends commended it, and epecially Piitratus, who exhorted the Citizens to obey his directions; inomuch that they recall'd the Law, and renew'd the War under Solon's conduct. The common report is, that with Piitratus he ail'd to Coliada, and finding the Women, according to the cutom of the Country there, acrificing to Ceres, he ent a truty Friend to Salamis, who hould pretend Solon retakes Salamis. himelf a Renegade, and advie them, if they deired to eize the chief Athenian Women, to make all ail to Colias: the Megarenians
preently man'd a Ship, and Solon eeing it put off from the Iland, commanded the Women to be gone, and ome beardles youths dres'd in their Garments, their Shoes and Mitres, and privately arm'd with Daggers, to dance and wanton near the hore, till the Enemies had landed, and the Ship was in their power. Things being thus ordered, the Megarenians were allur'd with the appearance, and, coming near, leap'd eager upon their prey, o that not one of them ecaped, and the Athenians preently et Sail for the Iland, and took it. Others deliver that it was not taken this way, but that he firt received this Oracle from Delphos,
Thoe Heroes that in fair Aopia ret,
All buried with their Faces to the Wet
Appeae, go offer what hall pleae them bet.
And that Solon ailing by night to the Iland, acrific'd to the Heroes Periphemus and Cichris, and then taking 500 Athenians Voluntiers, (a Law having pas'd that thoe that took the Iland hould be chiefet in the Government) with a number of Fiher Boats, and one great Ship, he anchored in a Bay of Salamis that looks towards Euboea: and the Megarenians that were then in the Iland being alarm'd by an uncertain report,
in great diorder betook themelves to their Arms; and ent a Ship to dicover the Enemies. This Ship Solon took, and ecuring the Megarenians, man'd it with Athenians, and gave them orders to ail to the Iland with as much privacy as poible; and he with the other Souldiers march'd againt the Megarenians by Land. Now whilt they were fighting, thoe from the Ship took the City, and this relation is confirm'd by the following olemnity; for an Athenian Ship at firt ail'd ilently to the Iland, then, with noie and a great hout, one leaps out arm'd, and with a trong cry runs to the Promontory Sciradium, to meet thoe that approach upon the Land; and jut by there tands a Temple, which Solon dedicated to Mars; for he beat the Megarenians, and as many as were not kill'd in the Battel he ent away upon Articles: but the Megarenians till contending, and both ides having received coniderable loes, they choe the Spartans for Arbitrators: Now many affirm that Homers authority did Solon a coniderable kindnes, and that he having inerted a line into the Catalogue of Ships, read thee Veres when the matter was to be determined.

q.l: Twelve Ships from Salamis tout Ajax brought,

l.hi: And rank't his Men where the Athenians fought.

div.p:
The Athenians account this but an idle tory, and report, that Solon made it appear to the Judges, that Philaeus and Euryaces, the Sons of Ajax, being made free of Athens, gave them the Iland; and that one of them dwelt at Buron in Attica, the other at Melite; and that the Tribe of the Phileides, from which Piitratus was decended, receiv'd its name from this Philaeus. A further argument againt the Megarenians is taken from the dead Bodies, which are not buried after their fahion, but according to the Athenian: for the Megarenians turn the Carcae to the Eat, the Athenians to the Wet (but Hereas the Megarenian denies this, and affirms that they likewie turn the Body to the Wet) and that the Athenians have a Sepulchre for every Body, but the Megarenians put two or three into one: and farther they report, that ome of Apollo's Oracles, where he calls Salamis Ionia, made much for Solon. This matter was determined by five Spartans, Critolaides, Amompharetus, Hypechidas, Anaxilas and Cleomenes. For this Solon grew fam'd, and powerfull; but his advice to Solon's Religion. revenge the God at Delphos, to ait him, and not uffer the Cirrheans to profane the Oracle, got him mot repute among the Grecians: for upon his perwaion, the Amphyctiones undertook the War, as amongt
others, Aritotle affirms in his Treatie of the Victors at the Pythian Games, where he makes Solon the Authour of this Counel: Solon was not General in that Expedition, as Ermippus delivers out of Evanthes the Samian, for Aechines the Oratour ays no uch thing, and in the Commentary of the Delphian affairs Alcmaeon, not Solon is declared Leader.

The Athenians now free from the Cylonian The Athenians quarrel about the Government. edition, and the execrable banih'd, fell into their old quarrels about the Government; there being as many different parties, as there were diviions in the City; The Higher quarter favoured Democracy, the Lower Oligarchy, and thoe that liv'd toward the Sea, tood for a mixt ort of Government, and o hindred either of the
other parties from prevailing: At the ame time alo the Poor quarrelling with the Rich about the inequality of Etates, the City eem'd in a deperate condition and to be freed from its diturbances and ettled by a Tyranny alone: for all the People were indebted to the Rich; and either they manur'd their Grounds, paying them ix parts of the encreae, and were therefore call'd Hectemorii and Thetes: or ele they engaged their Body for the debt, and might be eized by their Creditours; o ome of them were made Slaves at home, others old to trangers; ome (for no Law forbad it) were forc'd to ell their Children, or run their Country to avoid the cruelty of their Creditours; but the mot and toutet of the People roe, and exhorted one another to tand to it to chue a Leader, to detroy the avage exactours, divide the Land, and change the Government. Then the wiet of the Athenians perceiving Solon had leat practied thoe exactions; that he had not ided with the Rich, and was not indebted with the Poor, pret him to ait the Commonwealth and compoe the differences: Though Phanias the Lesbian affirms that Solon quiets the Sedition.
Solon, to ave his Country, put a trick upon both parties, and privately promied the Poor a diviion of the Lands, and the Rich ecurity for their Debts: Solon was unwilling
to meddle at firt, being afraid of the pride of one party and the greedines of the other; but he was choen Archon with Philombrotus, and impower'd to be an Arbitrator and ettle Laws; the Rich conenting becaue he was wealthy, the Poor becaue he was honet: There is a aying of his before the Election, that Equality never breeds War, and this pleas'd both parties, the Wealthy and the Poor; the one expecting this Equality in Dignity and Power, the other in Riches and Etate. Thus there being great hopes on both ides, the chief men pret Solon to take the Government into his own hands, and when he was once ettled manage the buines roundly and according to his pleaure: and many of the Commons, perceiving it would be a difficult change to be effected by Law and Reaon, were willing to have one wie and jut man et over the Affairs: and ome ay that Solon had this Oracle from Apollo
Sit in the midt, if you the Ship will guide,
And thouands hall ait to tem the Tide:
But chiefly his Familiars chid him for diaffecting Solon refues to be a Monarch. Monarchy onely for its name, as if the vertue of the Ruler could not make it a lawfull Form: That this Euboea had experimented who choe Tunondas, and Mytilene
who took Pittacus for their Prince: yet this could not hake Solon's reolution, but (as they ay) he reply'd to his Friends, 'Tis true a Tyranny is a very fair pot, but it hath no way to go out at: and in a Copy of Veres to Phocus he writes,
That I have par'd my Country, kept my Fame,
Nor tain'd my Glory with a Tyrant's name,
That when I could detroy I choe to ave,
I cannot bluh, I think my Actions brave:
From which 'tis manifet that he was a man of great reputation before he gave his Laws. The everal jeers that were put upon him for refuing the Power, he delivers in thee words:
Sure Solon was a oft, a hallow fool,
Who when the Power was offer'd would not rule;
The Fih were in his Net, that Many caught,
Yet he, mean Soul, refus'd to take the draught:
For ele to have enjoy'd but one day's reign
He would have uffer'd the everet pain:
To have obtain'd uch power in uch a place
He would have lot himelf, and damn'd his Race.
Thus he makes the Many and the Racals peak of him. Yet though he refus'd the Government he was not too remis in the
Affairs, he did not appear mean and crouching Solon's good behaviour. to the powerfull; nor made his Laws to pleaure thoe that choe him; for where 'twas well before he apply'd no remedy, nor altered any thing, for fear let unettling, and bringing the Commonwealth into a confuion, he hould be too weak to new model and raie it to a tolerable condition; but what he thought he could effect by perwaion upon the pliable, and by force upon the tubborn, that he did; joyning (as he himelf peaks) force and jutice; and therefore when he was afterwards ask'd if he had left the Athenians the bet Laws that could be given, he reply'd, I have etablihed the bet They could receive. The way which the Athenians ue to take off from the badnes of the thing, by giving it a good and innocent appellation, as for a Whore a Mitres; for Taxes Rates; for Garrions Guards; for Prions Houes of Cutody; eem'd at firt to be Solon's contrivance, who nam'd this taking off the Peoples Debts Seiacthia, a throwing off a Burthen: for the firt thing which he ettled Solon frees the People from their Debts. was that what Debts remain'd hould be forgiven, and no man for the future hould engage his Body for a um of Money: Though ome (as Androtion) affirm that the Debts were not taken off; but the ue onely leened, which o pleas'd the People,
that they nam'd that kindnes Seiacthia, together with the enlarging their Meaures, and encreaing the value of their Money; for he made a Pound which before contain'd but eventy three Drachms, to contain an hundred, o that though the number of pieces in the payment was equal, the value was les; which prov'd a coniderable benefit to thoe that were to dicharge great Debts, and no los to the Creditours: But mot agree that 'twas the taking off the Debts that was call'd Seiacthia, which is confirm'd by ome places in his Poem, where he glories that he had remov'd the Tyes from their Etates, that heretofore they were Slaves now Free, that ome which were eiz'd for their Debts he had brought back from other Countries, where by the length of their exile they had forgotten their Mother Tongue, and ome he had et at liberty which were in cruel lavery at home. When he was deigning this, a very unlucky thing hapned; for when he had reolv'd to take off the Debts, and was thinking on a good way and fit beginning for the action, he told ome of his Friends, Conon, Clinias and Hipponicus, in whom he had a great deal of confidence, that he would not meddle with the Lands, but onely free the People from their Debts; they uing the advantage, took up vat ums
of Money and purchaed ome large Farms, and when the Law was enacted they kept the Poeions, and would not return the Money; which brought Solon into a great upicion and dilike, as if he himelf had not been abus'd, but was concern'd in the contrivance: but he preently top'd this upicion by releaing his Debtours of five Talents (for he had lent o much) according to the Law: others, as Goluzelus the Rhodian, ay fifteen, but his Friends were ever afterward called Chreocopidoe. In this he pleas'd neither Party, for the Rich were angry for their Money, and the Poor that the Land was not divided, and (as Lycurgus ordered in his Commonwealth) all levell'd to one degree. He 'tis true being the Eleventh from Hercules, and having reign'd many years in Lacedaemon had gotten a The difference between Solon and Lycurgus. great reputation, power and Friends which he could ue in modelling his State; and applying force more than perwaion inomuch that he lot his eye in the cuffle, brought about the mot effectual means to preerve and unite a State by not permitting any to be Poor or Rich in his Commonwealth. But Solon could not rie to that by his Polity, yet he acted to the height of his power, having nothing but the good will and good opinion of his Citizens to rely on: And that he offended mot that look'd for another
poture of Affairs, he declares in thee words:
Once they ador'd me, but they now depie,
And quint upon me with their envious eyes!
But in a little time being enible of the Solon entruted with all the power. profit, they laid by their grudges, made a publick Sacrifice, calling it Seiacthia, and choe Solon to new model and make Laws for the Commonwealth: They gave him power over all their Magitracies, their Aemblies, Courts, Senates; that he hould appoint the Number, Times of meeting, and what Etate they mut have that could be capable of thee: and diolve or continue any of the preent Contitutions according to his pleaure. Firt then he repeal'd all He repeals Draco's Laws.
Draco's Laws, except thoe concerning Murther, becaue they were too evere, and their punihments too great; for Death was appointed for almot all offences, inomuch that thoe that were convicted of Idlenes Draco's Laws. were to dye, and thoe that tole a Cabbage, or an Apple to uffer as the Villains that committed Sacrilege or Murther: And therefore Demades is famous for aying that
