Draco's Laws were not writ with Ink but Bloud: and he himelf being once ask'd, Why he made Death the punihment of mot offences? reply'd, Small ones deerve that, and I have no higher for the greater Crimes. Next, Solon being willing to continue Solon's model of his Commonwealth. the Magitracy in the hands of the rich Men, and yet receive the People into the other part of the Government, he took an account of the Citizens Etates, and thoe that were worth five hundred Meaures of Wet and Dry he plac'd in the firt rank, calling them Pentacoiomedimnoi; thoe that could keep an Hore, or were worth three hundred Meaures, were nam'd Hippada telountes, and made the econd Clas; the Zeugitae that had two hundred Meaures were in the third; and all the others were call'd Thetes, who were not admitted to any Office, but could come to the Aembly, and give their Voices: which at firt eem'd nothing, but afterwards appear'd a coniderable privilege; for mot of the Controveries came to their hearing, becaue in all matters that were under the cognizance of the other Magitrates there lay an appeal to that Aembly. Beide 'tis aid that he was obcure and ambiguous in the wording of his Laws, on purpoe to encreae the honour of his Courts; for ince their differences could not be adjuted by the
Letter; they were to bring all their Caues to the Judges, who were as Maters, and interpreters of the Laws: and of this Equality he himelf makes mention in this manner;
What power was fit I did on all betow,
Not rais'd the Poor too high, nor pret too low:
The Rich that rul'd, and every Office bore
Confin'd by Laws they could not pres the Poor:
Both parties I ecur'd from lawles might,
So none prevail'd upon another's right:
And for the greater ecurity of the weak Commons, he gave all liberty to enter an Action againt another for an injury; o Solon's Laws about Injuries. that if one was beaten, maim'd or uffer'd any violence, any man that would, and was able, might proecute the injurious: intending by this to accutom the Citizens like members of the ame Body, to reent and be enible of one anothers injuries, and there is a aying of his agreeable to this Law, for being ask'd what City was bet modell'd? That, ays he, where thoe that are not injur'd equally proecute the unjut with thoe that are: when he had contituted the Areopagus of the yearly Magitrates, He intitutes the Areopagus. of which he himelf, being Archon, was a member; till oberving that the People, now free from their Debts, grew
proud and imperious; he ettled another Court of four hundred, a hundred out of The Court of 400. each of the four Tribes, which were to inpect all matters before they were to be propounded to the People; and to take care that nothing but what had been diligently examin'd, hould be brought before the general Aembly: The upper Council he made inpectours and keepers of the Laws, uppoing that the Commonwealth held by thee two Councils, as by firm Anchors, would be les liable to be tot by tumults, and the People be more at quiet: Thus mot deliver that Solon intituted the Areopagus, which eems to be confirm'd, becaue Draco makes no mention of the Areopagites, but in all capital Caues applies himelf to the Ephetae: Yet Solon's thirteenth Table contains the eighth Law, et down in thee words: Whoever before Solon's Archonhip were digrac'd let them be retor'd, except thoe that being condemn'd by the Areopagites, Ephetae, or the Kings for Murther, or deigns againt the Government, had fled their Country when this Law was made: and thee words eem to hew that the Areopagus was before Solon's Laws, for who could be condemn'd by that Council before his time, if he was the firt that intituted the Court? unles, which is probable, there is ome defect and
obcurity in this Table, and it hould run thus, Thoe that are convicted of uch offences as belong to the cognizance of the Areopagites, Ephetae, or the Prytanes, when this Law was made, hould remain till in digrace whilt others are retor'd: and this was his meaning. Amongt his other The Law againt Neuters in a Tumult. Laws, that is very peculiar, and urpriing, which makes all thoe infamous who tand Neuters in a Sedition; for it eems, he would not have any one inenible and regardles of the Publick, and, ecuring his private affairs, glory that he had no feeling of the ditempers of his Country: but preently joyn with the good party and thoe that had the right upon their ide, ait, and venture with them, rather than hift out of harms way and watch who would get the better. But that eems an aburd The Law about Hierees. and foolih Law, which permits an Hieres, if her lawfull Husband prove impotent, to lye with his nearet Kinman: yet ome ay, this Law was well contriv'd againt thoe, who, concious of their own inability, yet, for the ake of the portion, would match with Hierees, and make ue of Law to put a violence upon Nature; for now ince he can lye with whom he pleae, they mut either abtain from uch Marriages or continue them with digrace, and uffer for their covetounes and deign'd
affront: beides 'tis well done to confine her to her Husband's nearet Kinman, that the Children may be of the ame Family; and agreeable to this is the Law that the Bride and Bridegroom hall be hut into a Chamber, and eat a Quince together, and that her Husband is oblig'd to go in to uch an Heires thrice a Month, for though he gets no Children, yet 'tis an honour and due affection which an Husband ought to pay to a vertuous chate Wife; it takes off all petty differences, and will not permit their little quarrels to proceed to a rupture.

In all other Marriages he forbad Dowries Concerning other Marriages. to be given, the Wife was to have three uits of Clothes, a little inconiderable Houhold-tuff, and that was all: for he would not have Marriages contracted for gain, or an Etate, but for pure Love, kind Affection, and to get Children. Dionyius, when his Mother advis'd him to marry one of his Citizens, Indeed, ays he, by my Tyranny I have broken my Country's Laws, but cannot put a violence upon thoe of Nature by an uneaonable Marriage. Such diorder is never to be uffer'd in a Commonwealth, nor uch uneaonable and unperforming Marriages, which neither attain their due end, nor fruit: but any provident Governour or Law-giver might ay to an old Man that takes a young Wife,
what is poken to Philoctetes in the Tragedy; Poor Wretch, in what a fit condition art thou to be married! and if he finds a young Man with a rich old Woman, like a Partridge growing fat upon the duty, remove him to a Virgin that needs a Husband; and of this enough.

Another commendable Law of Solon's is Not to peak evil of the Dead. that which forbids men to peak evil of the Dead; for 'tis pious to think them acred, and jut not to meddle with thoe that are gone, and politick to prevent the perpetuity of dicord: He likewie forbad them to peak evil of the Living in the Temple, before the Tribunal, in the Court, or at the Games; or ele to pay three Drachmas to the private peron, and two to the publick; for never to be able to rule paion hews a weak nature, and ill-breeding: and always to moderate it, is very hard, and to ome impoible: Now the matter of Laws mut be poible if the maker deigns to punih few in order to their amendment, and not many to no purpoe.

He is likewie much commended for his Concerning Wills. Law concerning Wills, for before none could be made; but all the wealth and Etate of the deceaed belonged to his Family: but he permitted them, if they had no Children, to betow it on whom they pleaed; eteeming Friendhip a tronger Tye
than Kindred, and Affection than Neceity; and thus made every man's Etate in the dipoal of the poeour: yet he allow'd not all orts of Legacies, but thoe onely which were not extorted by the phrenzy of a Dieae, charms, imprionment, force, or the perwaions of his Wife; with good reaon thinking it all one between deceit and neceity, flattery or compulion, ince both are equally powerfull to perwade a man from Reaon.

He regulated the Walks, Feats, and Laws concerning Women. Mourning of the Women; and took away every thing that was either unbecoming or immodet: when they walk'd abroad no more than three Coats were allow'd them; a half penny-worth of meat and drink, nor a Basket above a cubit high; and at night they were not to tir but in a Chariot; with a Torch before them. The Mourners Concerning Mourning. tearing themelves to raie pity, and their lamentations at Strangers Funerals he forbad. To offer an Ox at the Grave was not permitted; nor to bury above three Garments with the Body, or viit the Tombs of any beides their own Family, unles at the very Funeral; mot of which are likewie forbidden by our Laws, but this is farther added in ours, that thoe that are convicted of extravagance in their Mournings, are to be punihed as oft and effeminate
by the Cenors of the Women.

He oberving the City was fill'd with Solon intituteth Trades. perons that flock'd from all parts into Attica, for ecurity of living, and that mot of the Country was barren and unfruitfull; and the Traders at Sea imported nothing to thoe that could give them no exchange: he brought his Citizens to Trade; and made a Law, that no Son hould be oblig'd to relieve his Father, who had not bred him up to any Calling. 'Tis true, Lycurgus
The difference between Lycurgus and Solon. having a City free from all Strangers, and enough, or (according to Euripides) ufficient for twice o many; and abundance of Labourers about Sparta, who hould not be kept idle, but be broken with continual toil and work, he did well to take off his Citizens from Trades laborious and mechanical, and keep them to their Arms, and teach them onely the Art of War. But Solon fitting his Laws according to the tate of Things, and not ordering Things according to his Laws, and finding the ground carce rich enough to maintain the Farmers, and altogether unable to feed the lazy multitude; he brought Trades into credit, and ordered the Areopagites to examine how every man got his living, and chatie the idle: But that Law was more Law about the Sons of Harlots. rigid which (as Heraclides Ponticus delivers) declar'd the Sons of Harlots not oblig'd
to relieve their Fathers, for he that will not marry doth not take a Woman for Children, but for pleaure, and thus hath his jut reward, having no pretence to upbraid his Children, to whom he hath made their very Birth a candal and reproach. But in hort, many of Solon's Laws Solon's Laws about Women. about Women are aburd; for he permitted any one to kill an Adulterer that found him in the Act; if any one forc'd a free Woman, an hundred Drachma's was the Fine; if he entic'd her, twenty; except thoe that traded for a price, I mean common Whores; for they go openly to thoe that hire them. He made it unlawfull to ell a Daughter, or a Siter, unles, being yet unmarried, he was found wanton with a Man. Now 'tis irrational to punih the ame Crime ometimes very everely and without remore, and ometimes very lightly and as 'twere in port, with a trivial Fine, unles there being little Money then in Athens, that carcity made thoe Mulcts the more grievous punihment. The value of Sacrifices mut be one Sheep, and a Drachma for a Buhel. The Victor in the Ithmian The carcity of Money. Games was to have for reward an hundred Drachma's. The Conquerour in the Olyman five hundred. He that caught a Dog Wolf, five Drachma's, he that kill'd a Bitch, one: the former um (as Demetrius Phalereus
aerts) was the value of an Ox, the latter of a Sheep: but thoe prices which in his ixteenth Table he ets on the choice Sacrifices were certainly far greater, for ele they are very little in comparion of the preent. The Athenians, their Fields Whence the Athenian Tribes call'd. being better for Pature than Corn, were from the beginning great enemies to Wolves; and ome affirm their Tribes did not take their names from the Sons of Javan, but from the different orts of Occupation that they followed; the Souldiers were call'd Hoplitae, the Craft-men Ergatae; and of the remaining two, the Farmers, Georgi, and the Shepherds and Graiers Aigicorae. Beides, ince the Country hath but few Solon's Law about Wells. Rivers, Lakes, or large Springs, and many us'd Wells which they had dug; there was a Law made that where there was a publick Well within a Hippicon (that is four Furlongs) all hould draw at that; but when it was farther off they might provide a private Well: and if they had dug ten fathom deep and could find no Water they had liberty to fetch ten Gallons a day from their neighbours: for he thought it prudent to make proviion againt want but not encourage lazines. Beides, he hew'd his Laws concerning Planting and other things. skill in the orders about planting, for any one that would plant another Tree, was not to et it within five foot of his neighbour's
Field; but if a Fig or an Olive, not within nine: for their Roots pread farther, nor can they be planted near all orts of Trees without damage, for they draw away the nourihment, and hurt ome by their venomous effluviums. He that would dig a Pit or a Ditch, was to dig it at as far a ditance from his neighbour's Ground as it was deep: and he that would raie tocks of Bees, was not to raie them within three hundred feet of thoe which another had already rais'd: He permitted onely Oil to be exported, and thoe that did export any other Fruit, the Archon was olemnly to cure; or ele pay himelf an hundred Drachma's: and this Law was written in his firt Table, and therefore let none think thoe liars that affirm, the exportation of Figs was heretofore unlawfull; and the Informer againt the Delinquents call'd a Sycophant. Beides he made a Law concerning Laws about hurtfull Beats. hurts and injuries from Beats, in which he commands the Mater of any Dog that bit a Man, to hang him in a Chain of four Cubits; and this was a good device for mens ecurity. The Law concerning Law about naturalizing Strangers. naturalizing Strangers is evere, for he permitted onely thoe to be made Free of Athens, who were in perpetual exile from their own Country, or came with their whole Family to trade there: and this he
did, not to dicourage Strangers, but rather invite them, by making them ecure of the privileges of that Government: and beides he thought they would prove the more faithfull Citizens, who had been forc'd from their own Country, or voluntarily forook it.

But the Law concerning publick Entertainments was peculiarly Solon's, for if any Law about publick Feats. man came often, or if he that was invited refus'd, they were punihed; for he concluded that one was greedy, the other a contemner of the publick: All his Laws he etablihed for an hundred years, and writ them in wooden Tables nam'd Axonas, which might be turn'd round in oblong caes; ome of their relicks may be now een in the common Hall at Athens. Thee (as Aritotle affirms) are called Cyrbes, and Cratinus the Comedian, omewhere peaking of Draco and Solon, ays, in thoe Cyrbes they now parch Peae. But ome ay thoe are properly Cyrbes, which contain the Laws concerning Sacrifices and the Rites of Religion: and all the others Axones. The Senate all jointly wore to confirm the Laws, and every one of the Themothetae vow'd at the Cros in the Market-place, that if he brake any of the Statutes, he would dedicate a golden Statue, as big as himelf, at Delphos. Now oberving the irregularity Solon regulates the Months. of the Months, and that the Moon did not
always rie and et with the Sun; but often in the ame day overtake and go before him, he ordered the day hould be nam'd < in non-Latin alphabet > , the Old and New; attributing that part of it which was before the conjunction to the Old Moon, and the ret to the New. He being the firt it eems that undertood that Vere of Homer,
< in non-Latin alphabet > . The following day he call'd the New Moon, after the twentieth he added no day, but counting backward, according to the decreaing Phaes of the Moon he reckon'd up to thirty.

Now when thee Laws were enacted, Solon leaves Athens. and ome came to Solon every day, either to commend or dipraie them, and advie, if poible, to leave out, or put in omething: and many were curious, and deired him to explain, and tell the meaning of uch and uch a paage, and he knowing that not to doe it was diobliging, and to doe it would get him ill will; and deirous to bring himelf out of all traits, and take off all reaons of upicion from thoe that ought them: for 'tis a hard thing (as he himelf ays) in great affairs to pleae every body: he pretended himelf Mater of a Ship, and having obtain'd leave for ten years abence, he departed: for he hoped by that time his Laws would be cutomary
and familiar: his firt Voyage was for Aegypt, Solon in Aegypt. and he liv'd (as he himelf ays)
Near Nilus mouth, by fair Canopus hore.
He pent ome time in tudy with Penophis of Hierapolis and Sonchis the Saite, the mot famous of all the Priets; from whom (as Plato ays) getting ome knowledge of the Atlantick Iland, he put it into a Poem, and endeavoured to bring it into credit among the Grecians: from thence he ail'd to Cyprus, where he was made Solon in Cyprus. much on by Philocyprus one of the Kings there, who had a mall City built by Demophoon Theeus's Son, near the River Clarius, in a trong place, 'tis true, but barren and uneaie of acces. Solon perwaded him, ince there lay a fair plain below, to remove, and build a more pleaant and greater City: And he there preent took care to get inhabitants, and fitted it both for defence and convenience of living: inomuch that many Subjects flock'd to Philocyprus, and the other Kings imitated the deign; and therefore to honour Solon, he call'd the City Solos, which was formerly nam'd Apeia: and Solon himelf in his Elegies peaking to Philocyprus, mentions this Foundation in thee words;

l.hi: Long may you live, and fill the Solian Throne,
Succeeded till by Children of your own:
And whilt from your bles'd Ile I gently ail,

q.l: Let Venus end a kind and properous Gale:

l.hi: Let her enlarge the bounds of your Command,
And raie your Town, and end me afe to Land.

div.p:
That Solon hould dicoure with Croeus, Solon with Croeus. ome think not agreeable with Chronology; but I cannot reject o credible a relation, and o well atteted, and (what is more) o agreeable to Solon's temper, o worthy his wiedom and greatnes of mind, becaue forooth it doth not agree with ome Chronological Canons, which thouands have endeavoured to regulate, and yet to this day could never bring the differing opinions to any agreement. And therefore they ay Solon coming to Croeus at his requet, was in the ame condition, as an inland Man when firt he goes to ee the Sea; for as he fanies every River he meets with to be the Ocean, o Solon, as he pas'd through the Court, and aw a great many Nobles richly dres'd, and proudly attended with a multitude of Guards and Footboys, thought every one had been the King, till he was brought to Croeus, who was deck'd with all the ornaments of Jewels, Purple and Embroidery; all that could make him fine, and admired, that he might appear the mot glorious and gaudy pectacle. Now when Solon came before him, and eem'd not at all urpris'd, nor
gave Croeus thoe complements he expected; but hew'd himelf to all dicerning eyes, to be a Man that depied uch gaudy vanities; he commanded them to hew him all his Wealth, though he did not deire to ee it, and all his warlike preparations: now when he return'd from viewing all this, Croeus ask'd him if ever he had een an happier Man than he was? and when Solon anwered he knew one Tellus a Citizen of his, and told him that this Tellus was an honet man, had good Children, a competent Etate, and dy'd bravely for his Country; Croeus took him for an ill bred fellow, and a fool, for not meauring happines by the abundance of Gold and Silver; and preferring the life and death of a private and mean Man, before o much power and uch an Empire: he ask'd him again if beides Tellus, he knew any other Man more happy? and Solon replying yes, Cleobis and Bito, who were Brothers, were very loving and extreme dutifull to their Mother; for when the Oxen went but low, they put themelves into the Waggon, and drew their Mother to Juno's Temple, who was extremely pleas'd with their action, and call'd happy by her neighbours; and then acrificing, and feating, they never roe again, but died without pains or convulions immediately after they had gotten
o great credit and reputation. What, ays Croeus angry, and dot not thou reckon us amongt the happy men? and Solon, unwilling either to flatter, or exaperate him more, reply'd; The Gods, O King, in other things have given the Greeks nothing great and excellent, o our wiedom is bold, and mean, and low, not noble and Kingly; and this oberving the numerous misfortunes that attend all conditions, forbids us to grow inolent upon our preent enjoyments, or to admire any man's happines that may change, for what variety will happen is unknown; but to whom God hath continued happines unto the end, that Man we call happy; but his happines that is yet alive, is like the glory and crown of a Wretler that is till within the ring, unteady, and uncertain: after this he was dimis'd, having griev'd, but not intructed Croeus. But Aeop, he that writ the Fables, Solon's dicoure with Aeop. (being then at Sardis, upon Croeus his invitation, and very much eteem'd) was concern'd that Solon was o meanly treated, and gave him this advice: Solon, let your viits to Kings be as eldom, or as pleaant as you can: and Solon reply'd, No faith, but let them be as eldom, or as profitable as you can. Then indeed Croeus depis'd Solon, but when he was overcome by Cyrus, had lot his City, was taken alive,
condemn'd to be burnt, and laid bound upon the Pile before all the Perians and Cyrus himelf; he cry'd out as loud as poibly he could three times, O Solon, and Cyrus urpris'd, and ending ome to enquire, what Man, or God this Solon was, that he onely invok'd in this unavoidable misfortune? Croeus told him the whole tory, aying he was one of the wie men of Greece, whom I ent for, not to be intructed, or to learn any thing that I wanted, but that he hould ee, and be a witnes of my happines: the los of which is now a greater evil, than the enjoyment was a good; for when I had them they were goods onely in Opinion, but now the los of them hath brought upon me intolerable and real evils; and that man conjecturing thee preent calamities would happen, bad me look to the end of my life, and not rely and grow proud upon uncertainties. When this was told Cyrus, who was a wier man than Croeus, and eeing in the preent example that Solon's aying was confirm'd: he not onely freed Croeus from punihment, but honour'd him as long as he lived; and Solon had the glory by the ame aying to intruct one King, and ave another.

When Solon was gone, the Citizens began to quarrel; Lycurgus headed the lower quarter, Megacles the Son of Alcmaeon thoe that
liv'd towards the Sea, and Piitratus the upper quarter, in which were the meanet people (the Thetes) and greatet enemies to the rich: inomuch that though the City yet us'd their Laws, yet all look'd for, and deir'd a change of Government, hoping the change would be better for them, and put them above the contrary Faction. Affairs tanding thus, Solon return'd and Solon returns to Athens. was reverenced by all and honoured: but his old age would not permit him to be as active, and peak in the publick, as formerly; but privately dicouring with the heads of the Factions, he endeavoured to compoe the differences: Piitratus till appearing the mot tractable; for he was a weet and taking man in his dicoure, a friend to the poor, and very little given to enmity or paion, and what his nature had not given, cutom and imitation taught; therefore he was truted more than the others, being accounted a prudent moderate Man, one that lov'd equality, and would be an enemy to him that trove againt the preent ettlement, rather than undermine it himelf; for which his fair carriage he deceiv'd the people. But Solon preently dicovered him, and found out his deign, yet did not hate him upon this, but endeavoured to humble him, and bring him off from his ambition, and often told him, and
others, that if any one would take away his apiring thoughts, and deire of Empire, none would make a more vertuous Man, or a more excellent Citizen. Thepis at this Tragedies begun. time beginning to act Tragedies, and the thing, becaue 'twas new, taking very much with the multitude; for 'twas not yet a matter of trife and contention; Solon, being by nature a lover of learning, and now in his old age living idle, porting and cheering himelf with Muick and a glas of Wine, went to ee Thepis himelf (as the ancient cutom was) act; and after the Play was done, he dicours'd him, and ask'd him if he was not aham'd to tell o many lies before uch a company; and Thepis replying, 'Tis no harm to ay or doe o in jet and merriment; Solon vehemently triking his taff againt the ground, Ay, ays he, if we honour and commend uch Merriment as this, we hall find it will creep into our erious affairs. Now when Piitratus, having Piitratus gets the Government. wounded himelf, was brought into the Market-place in a Chariot, and tirred up the People, as if he had been thus dealt with for his affection to the Government, and a great many were enraged, and cry'd out: Solon, coming cloe to him, aid, Piitratus, you do not imitate lyes well; for you cut your elf to bring your Citizens into a tumult, but he to deceive his
enemies: Then preently the People would defend Piitratus, and gathered into an Aembly; where one Ariton making a motion that they hould allow Piitratus fifty Club-men for a Guard to his peron, Solon oppos'd it, and talk'd a great deal uch as he hath left us in his Poems, You doat upon his words and taking phrae. And again,
True, each Man ingle is a crafty Soul,
But all together ye make one giddy Fool:
But oberving the poor men an-end to gratifie Piitratus, and tumultuous; and the rich fearfull, and getting out of harms way, he departed; aying he was wier than ome, and touter than others: wier than thoe that did not undertand the deign, touter than thoe that, though they undertood it, were afraid to oppoe the Tyranny. Now the People having pat the Law, were not exact with Piitratus about the number of his Club-men, but took no notice of it, though he lited and kept as many as he would, till he eiz'd the Catle: when that was done, and the City in an uproar, Megacles with all of his Family treight fled: but Solon, though he was now very old,
and had none to back him; yet came into the Market-place, and made a peech to his Citizens, ometimes blaming their inadvertency and meannes of pirit, ometimes paionately exhorting them, not thus tamely to loe their Liberty; and likewie then poke that memorable aying, that before 'twas an eaier task to have top'd the riing Tyranny, but now the greater and more glorious action to detroy it, when it was begun already, and had gathered trength. But all being afraid to ide with him, he return'd home, and taking his Arms he brought them out, and laid them in the Porch before his Door, with thee words: To the utmot of my power I have triven for my Country and my Laws, and then he buied himelf no more: His Friends adviing him to fly, he refus'd, but writ a Poem, and thus rattled the Athenians,
If now you mart, blame not the heavenly powers,
For they are good, the fault is onely ours;
We gave him all our Forts, we took the Chain,
And now he makes us Slaves, yet we complain.
And many telling him that the Tyrant would have his Head for this, and asking to what he truted that he ventur'd to peak o boldly, he reply'd, my old Age. But Piitratus, having gotten the command, o honoured Solon, obliged and kindly entertained him, that Solon gave him his advice, and approv'd many of his actions: for he kept many of Solon's Laws, oberved them himelf, and compelled his Friends to obey. And he himelf, though then in power, being accus'd of Murther before the Areopagus, came quietly to clear himelf, but his accuer let fall the Indictment. And he added other Laws, one of which is, that the maim'd in the Wars hould be maintain'd at the publick charge; this Heraclides Ponticus delivers, and that Piitratus followed Solon's example in this, who had before determin'd it in the cae of one Therippus that was maim'd: and Theophratus aerts, that 'twas Piitratus, not Solon that made that Law againt Lazines, which was the reaon that the Country was better manur'd, and the City not o clogg'd with Inhabitants. Now Solon having begun The Atlantick Ilands. a great Work in Vere, the relation or Fable of the Atlantick Ilands, which he had learn'd from the wie Men in Sais, and was convenient for the Athenians to know, grew weary of it; not (as Plato
ays) by reaon of his multitude of buines, but his age, and being dicourag'd at the greatnes of the task; for thee Veres tetifie that he had leiure enough, Now I grow old, yet till I learn, And again,
I mind a Song, a Mis and glas of Wine;
Thee are mot mens delights, and thee are mine:
But Plato willing to improve the tory of the Ilands, as if 'twere a fair Etate that wanted an Heir, and decended to him; makes them tately Entrances, noble Encloures, large Courts, uch as no Eay, no Fable, no Fiction ever had before; but beginning it late, he ended his Life before his Work; and o the Readers trouble for the unfinih'd part is the greater, as the atisfaction he takes in that which is compleat is extraordinary: for as the City of Athens left onely the Temple of Jupiter Olympius, unfinih'd, o Plato, amongt all his excellent Works, left this onely Piece about the Atlantick Ilands imperfect: Solon liv'd after Piitratus eiz'd the Government (as Heraclides Ponticus aerts) a long time;
but Phanias the Epheian ays, not full two Solon's Death. years; for Piitratus began his Tyranny when Comias was Archon; and Phanias ays Solon dy'd under Hegetratus, who ucceeded Comias. Now the tory that his Ahes were catter'd about the Iland Salamis, is too abur'd to be believ'd, or be any thing but a mere Fable; and yet 'tis written by many coniderable men; and Aritotle the Philoopher.

div.head: THE LIFE OF P. VAL. POPLICOLA.
div.byline: Englihed from the Greek, By Mr. Dodwell.
div.p:
NOW Solon making uch a Figure, to him we compare Poplicola, which later Title the Roman people entail'd upon his merit, as a noble acces to his former name Publius Valerius. He decended from Valerius, a man amongt Valerius's extraction, whence. our ancetours, reputed the principal reconciler of the differences betwixt Roman and Sabine, and one that with the greatet ucces perwaded their Kings to aent thereunto,
and from a tate of hotility compos'd them into a friendly union. To this man Publius Valerius owing his Birth (as they write) whilt Rome remain'd under its Kingly Government, obtain'd a name as great from his eloquence as his riches; the one courteouly employing in a liberal ditribution to the poor, the other generouly in the ervice of jutice, as thereby auring, hould the Government fall into a Republick, he would become a chief tate in the Community. It happen'd afterwards, that the unjut and illegal apiring of Tarquinius
The uurpation of Tarquinius Superbus. Superbus to the Crown, with his making it intead of Kingly rule the intrument of inolence and tyranny; mov'd the people into an hatred and regret of his reign, inomuch that from the death of Lucretia (he
< in non-Latin alphabet >
acrificing her own life to the vengeance of his violence) they took an occaion of revolt. And L. Brutus fitting things for a change, aided with the conduct of Valerius depos'd the Kings. And whilt the people inclin'd towards the electing one Leader intead of their King, Valerius acquiec'd in this, that to rule was rather Brutus's due as the Authour of the Democracy. But the name of Monarchy growing odious to the people, and to live under a divided power carrying a complacency in the propect, they choe two to the managery
thereof; which put Valerius in hopes that with Brutus he might be elected Conul, but was diappointed; for intead of Valerius, Valerius diappointed of the Conulhip. notwithtanding the endeavours of Brutus, Tarquinius Collatinus was choen, the Husband of Lucretia, a man no ways more vertuous than Valerius. But the Nobles, dreading the return of their Kings, who till us'd all endeavours abroad and olicitations at home, were reolv'd upon a Chieftain of an intene hatred to them, and no ways indulging to their interet.

Now Valerius was troubled, that his ervice for his Country hould be upected to be miemployed, becaue he utained no private injury from the inolence of the Tyrants, withdrew himelf from the Senate, His private retirement. and practice of the Bar, quitting all publick concerns: which gave an occaion of dicoure and fear too; let, through malice reconcil'd to the King's ide, he hould prove the ruine of the State tottering as yet under the uncertainties of a change. But Brutus being jealous of ome others, determin'd to give the Tet to the Senate upon the Altars: upon the day appointed Valerius came with cheerfulnes into the Forum, and was the firt man that proteted neither to contribute to, or promote Tarquin's deigns, but rigorouly to maintain his liberty, which gave great atisfaction to the Senate
and aurance to the Conuls, his actions oon after hewing the incerity of his Oath. For Ambaadours came from Tarquin, with Letters affecting a populacy, and full of ininuating
< in non-Latin alphabet >
expreions, whereby they thought to wheedle the people, auring them, the King had cat off all inolence, and made moderation the onely meaure of his deires. To this Embay the Conuls thought fit to give publick audience: but Valerius oppos'd
< in non-Latin alphabet >
it, and would not permit, that to the poorer ort, who entertain'd the fear of a War with more reluctancy than Tyranny, any occaion hould be offer'd, or any temptations to new deigns. Afterwards other Ambaadours arriv'd, who declar'd their King would recede from his Crown, and lay down his Arms onely capitulating for a retitution to himelf, to his Friends and Allies of their Moneys and Etates to upport their banihment. Now everal inclining Brutus's publick zeal. to this motion, and Collatinus favouring the requet, Brutus, a peron of a fierce and paionate nature, ruh'd into the Forum,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
there proclaiming his fellow-Conul to be a Traitour, in granting Subidies to Tyranny and Ammunition for a War, when 'twere cruelty to relieve the neceities of their flight. This caus'd an Aembly of the Citizens, amongt whom the firt that pake was Gaius Minutius, a private man, who
advis'd Brutus, and peruaded the Romans to take care that thoe Goods remaining in their hands, might be employ'd againt the Tyrants rather, than being remitted to the Tyrants, be return'd againt themelves: Yet however 'twas the Romans opinion, that whilt they enjoy'd the liberty they had fought for, not to reject Articles of Peace for the akes of their Goods, but to throw them out after them. This regard of the Goods was the leat part of Tarquin's deign, yet the demand ounded the humours of the people, and became a preparatory A Conpiracy ecretly contriv'd by Tarquin's Agents. to a Conpiracy; which the Ambaadours endeavour'd through the delay of their return, under pretence of elling ome of the Goods and reerving others to be ent away, till uch time as they corrupted two of the eminentet Families in Rome, three Senatours of the Aquilian, and two of the Vitellian Family, all of them by the Mother's ide being Nephews to Collatinus; beides Brutus had a peculiar alliance to the Vitellians from his marriage with their Siter, by whom he had everal Children; whereof two the Vitellians, whom nearnes of bloud and education had endear'd each to other, decoy'd into an aociation of their Treaon, auring them withall, hould they interes themelves in Tarquin's Family, and the Kings Party, they
would be freed from the dotage and auterity of their Father (whoe irreconcilement to offenders they term'd auterity, and his dotage was a pretext and plea to the Tyrants for his ecurity, which occaioned the continuance of that irname.) When upon thee inducements the Youths came to dicoure the Aquilians, all thought it convenient to oblige themelves in a olemn and dreadfull Oath, with the ceremony of drinking
< in non-Latin alphabet >
A horrid confirmation of Treaon.
the bloud of a murther'd man, and touching his entrails. To which deign they reorted to the habitation of the Aquilians, where was an Houe allotted for this tranaction, (as happen'd) darkome and deolate; for the dometick Vindicius made no appearance, but there abconded himelf, not out of deign or any intelligence of the affair, but accidentally being within, and eeing with how much hate and concern they came in, was afraid to be dicover'd, but plac'd himelf behind a Chet, o as he
< in non-Latin alphabet >
might oberve their actions and over-hear their debates. The reult was to kill the Conuls, and they wrote Letters to Tarquin advertiing the ame, and entruted them in the hands of the Ambaadours lodging then at the Aquilians, and were preent at the Conult.

Upon their departure thence Vindicius crept out of his obcurity, but not undertanding
how to manage the buines, was at a tand; for to arraign the Sons before the Father Brutus, or the Nephews to the Uncle Collatinus eem'd equally (as 'twas indeed) a cene of horrour; yet knew no private Roman, to whom he could entrut ecrets
< in non-Latin alphabet >
of uch importance, and yet could not uffer to be buried in ilence, what his concience engag'd him to reveal; and therefore Valerius made acquainted with the Conpiracy. addres'd himelf to Valerius, the generoity of the man and civility inviting thereto, being a peron to whom the needy had eaie acces, and never hut his Gates againt the petitions or the indigences of a low etate: but when Vindicius had made a total dicovery to him, his Brother Marcus and his own Wife being preent at the relation, Valerius was truck with amazement, and by no means would dimis the Dicoverer, but confin'd him to his own His prudent managery thereof. Houe, and plac'd his Wife as a guard to the Gatesending his Brother in the interim to beet the King's Palace, and to eize, if poible, their Letters, and ecure the dometicks; whilt he, with his contant attendance of Clients and Friends, and a great retinue of Servants, repair'd to the Houe of the Aquilians, who were abent from home, and, forcing an entrance through the Gates, happen'd upon the Letters then lying in the Lodgings of the Ambaadours;
whilt things were in this motion, the Aquilians made an haty return, and mutering themelves about the Gate, endeavour'd a recovery of the Letters: The other Party made a reitance, who cating their Gowns about their Necks, and uing violence one to the other, at length hurried them with great difficulty through the Streets into the Forum. The like engagement happen'd about the King's Palace, where Marcus eiz'd ome other Letters, deign'd to be convey'd away in the Goods, and laying hands on what Servants his indutry could find, drag'd them alo into the Forum. When the Conuls had quieted the tumult, Vindicius was brought out by the orders of Valerius, and the Accuation read, the Letters were opened, to which the Traitours could make no Plea. Mot tood mute and dejected as enible of the Villany, yet ome, to ingratiate themelves with Brutus, mention'd Banihment, and the tears of Collatinus, attended with Valerius's ilence, gave ome hopes of mercy: But Brutus calling his two Sons by their names, Cant thou The impartial proceeding of Brutus. (aid he) O Titus, nor thou Valerius make no defence againt the Indictment; the quetion being thrice propos'd, and no return made to Brutus, he turn'd himelf to the Lictors, and cry'd, What remains is His evere Sentence. your duty. The Lictors preently eiz'd the
Youths, and tripping them of their Garments, bound their hands behind them, and tore their Bodies with courges, which eem'd too tragical a Scene to be gaz'd upon; yet 'tis obervable, Brutus made it the object of his choice, and would not uffer the leat glance of pity to often and mooth his wonted rigour and auterity, but reolutely made his eyes attend the execution, even whilt the Lictors extending them on the ground, with an Ax cut off their Heads; then he departed, committing the ret to the judgment of his Collegue. This was an action equally as capable of commendation as reproof, for either the greatnes of his vertue rais'd him above the impreions of orrow, or the extravagancy of his miery took away all ene of it: but neither eem'd common or the reult of his humanity, but either proceeded from a divine efficacy or a brutih tupidity, yet 'tis more
< in non-Latin alphabet >
reaonable we award it to his honour, let through the weaknes of the Judge his vertue hould hazard a direpute, for in the Romans opinion Brutus labour'd more to reduce and ettle the Government, than Romulus to found the City.

Upon Brutus's departure out of the Forum, a conternation, horrour and ilence for ome time poes'd all, that reflected on what was done: beides, the eaines and
forbearance of Collatinus gave confidence to the Aquilians to requet ome time to anwer their Charge, and that Vindicius their Servant hould be remitted into their hands, and no longer harbour'd amongt their Accuers. The Conul eem'd inclin'd to their motion, and thereupon diolv'd the Aembly; but Valerius would not uffer Vindicius to depart, who was encircled with the Rabble, nor the people to withdraw without cenuring the Traitours; at length laid violent hands upon the Aquilii, and calling Brutus to his aitence, exclaim'd againt the unreaonable proceedings of Collatinus, to impoe upon his Collegue the neceity of taking away the lives of his own
< in non-Latin alphabet >
Sons, and yet have thoughts of gratifying ome Women with the lives of Traitours and enemies to their Country. Collatinus at this dipleas'd, and commanding Vindicius to be taken away, the Lictors dipers'd the Rabble, and eiz'd their Man, and beat off whooever endeavour'd a recue. But Valerius's Friends withtood the eiure, and the people cry'd out for Brutus, who returning, and ilence being made, aur'd them he had hew'd himelf a evere animadverter upon his own Sons, and therefore left the ret to the uffrages of the free Citizens, allowing every man to peak his pleaure, and gain the people over to his
peruaion. But there was no need of Oratory, for it being referr'd to the Vote, they were return'd condemn'd by all the uffrages, and were accordingly beheaded.

When Collatinus aw his alliance to the Collatinus reigns his Conulhip. Kings had render'd him upicious, and his name had made him odious to the people, who abominated the name of Tarquin, and perceiving himelf as an offence to every one, relinquih'd his Charge and departed the City. The Court being call'd, in his Valerius declared Conul. room Valerius honourably obtain'd the Conulhip as a jut reward of his good will; of which he thought Vindicius deerv'd a hare, whom he made Denizon of Rome, and gave him the privilege of voting in what Tribe oever he was pleas'd to be enroll'd: (which liberty in voting, Appius a long time after, out of a popular deign, granted to other Libertines) and from this Vindicius, a perfect Manumiion, is call'd to this day Vindicta. This done,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
the Goods of the Kings are expos'd to plunder, and the Palace to ruine; The pleaant
< in non-Latin alphabet >
Campus Martius, which Tarquin enjoy'd, was devoted to the ervice of that God; but happening to be harvet eaon, and the Sheaves yet lodging on the ground, they thought it not reaonable to commit them to the Flail, or unanctifie them with any ue, and therefore carrying them to the
River ide, and Trees withall, that were cut down, they cat all into the Water, and dedicated a luggih and fruitles Soil to the The dedication of the Campus Martius. Deity. Now thee thrown in one upon another, and cloing together, the tream did not bear them far, but being carry'd down together and inking to the bottom, there gain'd a ettlement, and finding no farther a conveyance, but there top'd and interwoven one with another, the tream work'd the mas into a firmnes, and wah'd down mudd, which ettling there, became an acceion of matter as well as cement to the rubbih; inomuch that the violence of the Waves could not remove it, but forc'd all things to it, and then with a gentle preure clos'd it together, which by reaon of their bulk and olidity gaining new ubidies, and the neighbouring pace receiving what the tream brought down, at lat grew into an Iland, call'd Inula Sacra, lying by the City, adorn'd with the Temples of the Gods and conecrated Walks, call'd in the Latin Tongue inter duos pontes. Though
< in non-Latin alphabet >
ome ay, this happened not at the dedication of Tarquin's Field, but in after times, when Tarquinia, a Vetal Prietes, gave the adjacent Field to the publick, and for that obtain'd great honours, as amongt the ret, that of all Women her tetimony alone hould find credit and acceptance, and had
the liberty to marry, but refus'd it, and thus ome write it happened.

But Tarquin, depairing of a return to his Kingdom by the Conpiracy, found a kind reception amongt the Tucans, who with a great Army lead him out into the Field; the Conuls headed the Romans againt them, and made their rendezvoue in the holy places, the one call'd the Arian Grove, the other the Aeuvian Meadow: when they came to charge, Aruns, the Son of Tarquin,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
The ingle engagement of Aruns with Brutus. and Brutus, the Roman Conul, not incidentally encountring each other, but out of a malicious rage (the one to avenge Tyranny and enmity to his Country, the other his Banihment) et Spurs to their Hores, and engaging with fury intead of reaon, grew unmindfull of their own ecurity, and o fell together in the combat. This o dreadfull an onet hardly enur'd a more favourable end; but both Armies doing and receiving equal damage were diverted by a Storm. Now Valerius was much concern'd, not knowing the ucces of the day; and eeing his men as well difmayed at the ight of their own dead, as reviv'd at the los of the enemy, o undicernible alike had the greatnes of the laughter made the appearance, that each ide upon a review of their remains adjudg'd
< in non-Latin alphabet >
to themelves rather a defeat, than from the
etimate each made of his enemy, a Victory. The night being come, (and uch as one may preume mut follow uch a Battel) and the Armies laid to ret, they write the Grove hook and murmured a Voice, aying,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
that the Tucans lot one man more than the Romans, which was eteem'd as an Oracle, and the Romans preently entertain'd it with houts and expreions of joy: whilt the Tucans through fear and amazement deerted their Tents, and were much dipers'd; The Romans falling upon the remains, The Tucans vanquihed by the Romans. which amounted to nigh five thouand, took them prioners, and plunder'd the Camp: when they numbred the dead, they found on the Tucans ide eleven thouand and three hundred, exceeding their own los but by one man. This Fight happen'd upon the lat of February, and Valerius triumph'd upon the Conquet, being the firt Conul that adorn'd it with a Chariot, which fight as it appear'd magnificent, o 'twas receiv'd with a veneration free from envy, or (what ome ugget) an offence to the Spectatours, neither did it avour of emulation or ambition, when 'twas deriv'd to after ages. The people applauded likewie the honours he did to his Collegue, in etting forth his Obequies with a Funeral Oration, which o pleas'd the Romans, and found o good a reception, that it became
cutomary for the bet men to celebrate the Funerals of great men with Speeches in their commendation, and their antiquity is affirm'd to be greater than that of Greece, unles according to the Oratour Anaximenes's account we acknowledge Solon to be Authour.

Yet ome part of Valerius's behaviour Valerius why dieteemed by the people. gave an offence and digut to the people, becaue after Brutus, whom they eteem'd as Patriot of their Liberty had not preum'd to Lord it without a Collegue, but till aum'd one and then another to him in his Commiion; but Valerius (aid they) carrying all things by his power, eem'd not a Succeour to Brutus, having no deference to the Conulhip, but an aim to Tarquin's Tyranny; and notwithtanding his verbal Harangues to Brutus's memory, yet when he was attended with all the Rods and Axes, and came from an Houe as tately as that he demolih'd of the Kings, thoe actions hew'd him an imitatour of Tarquin; beides his dwelling Houe call'd Velia was more magnificent, which hanging over the
< in non-Latin alphabet >
Forum, overlook'd all tranactions there, the acces to it was hard, and the return from it difficult, but to ee him come down, was a tately propect, and equall'd the majety of a King. But Valerius hew'd, how much it imported men in power and great
Offices to give admittance to truth before flattery; for upon his Friends remontrances, that he dipleas'd the people, contended not, neither reented it, but that very night ending for Carpenters pulled down Valerius demoliheth his tately Houe. his Houe and levell'd it with the ground; o that in the morning the people flocking thither aw the ruines, they lov'd and admir'd the generoity of the man, and deplor'd the Conul's los, who wanting an
< in non-Latin alphabet >
Houe, was forc'd to eek a foreign habitation; and wih'd a repair of o much beauty and magnificence, as to one, to whom malice had unjutly procur'd the ruine. His Friends receiv'd him, till the place the people gave him was furnih'd with an Houe, though les tately than his own, where now tands the Temple call'd Vicus Publicus.

He reolv'd to render the Government as well as himelf, intead of terrible, familiar and pleaant to the people, and parted the Axes from the Rods, and always upon his entrance into the Aembly, with an humble ubmiion vail'd them to the people, as retoring thereby the excellency of a Commonwealth,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
and this the Conuls oberve to this day. But the humility of the man, which the people thought real, was but a device, to abate their envy by this moderation, for as much as he detracted from his liberty, o
much he advanc'd in his power, the people till ubmitting with atisfaction, which they expres'd by calling him Poplicola, i. e. a popular man, which name had the
< in non-Latin alphabet >
preheminence of the ret, and therefore in the equel of this Hitory we hall ue no other. He gave free leave to any to ue for the Conulhip, but before the admittance of a Collegue, mitruting futurity, let the emulation or the ignorance of him hould cros his deigns, by his own authority enacted The Ordinances and Laws of Poplicola. ome good and noble Contitutions. Firt he upply'd the vacancies of the Senatours, which either Tarquin long before put to death, or the War lately out off; thoe that were regitred, they write amounted to one hundred threecore and four: afterwards he made everal Laws, which added much to the people's liberty, as one granting offenders the liberty of appealing to the people from the cenure of the Conuls; a econd, that made it death to uurp the magitracy without the peoples conent; a third for the relief of poor Citizens, which taking off their taxes encourag'd their labours; another againt diobedience to the Conuls, which was no les popular than the ret, and rather to the benefit of the Commonalty, than to the advantage of the Nobles, for it impos'd upon diloyalty the penalty of ten Oxen and two Sheep,
the price of a Sheep was ten Oboli, of an Ox an hundred. For the ue of Money was Money not much in ue amongt the Romans. then infrequent amongt the Romans, their wealth coniting in a plenty of Cattel, o that afterwards their Etates were call'd Peculia from Pecus, i. e. Cattel, and had
< in non-Latin alphabet >
upon their ancient Money engrav'd an Ox, a Sheep, or an Hog; and hence irnam'd their Sons Suilli, Bubulci, or Caprarii, (they calling Caprae, Goats, and Porci, Hoggs.) Thee Laws hewed the evennes and the popularity of the giver, yet amidt this moderation he intituted one exceive punihment, for he made it lawfull without accuation to take away any man's life that apir'd to a Tyranny, and acquitted the executioner, if he produc'd evidences of the crime; for though 'twas not probable, whoe deigns were o great, to ecape all notice, yet becaue 'twas poible his power might prevent judgment, which the uurpation it elf would then take off, gave a licence to any to prevent the urper. He was honour'd likewie for the Law touching the
< in non-Latin alphabet >
Treaury, and becaue neceity engag'd the Citizens out of their Etates to contribute to the maintenance of Wars, and he being unwilling himelf to be concern'd in the care of it, or to permit his Friends, or indeed that the publick Money hould be entruted into private hands, allotted the
Temple of Saturn for the Treaury (in which to this day they repoite the Tribute-money) and granted the people the liberty of chuing two young men as Quetors, i. e. Treaurers, and the firt were P. Veturius and Minucius Marcus, there being
< in non-Latin alphabet > P. Veturius and Minucius Marcus firt Quetors in Rome. a great Sum collected, for they aes'd one hundred and thirty thouand, excuing Orphans and Widows from the payment. Affairs tanding in this poture he admitted Lucretius, the Father of Lucretia, as his Collegue, and gave him the precedence in the Government by reigning up the Faces,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
i. e. Rods to him as due to his years, which humble obervance to age was deriv'd to poterity. But within a few days Lucretius dy'd, and Marcus Horatius ucceeded in that honour, and continu'd the remaining part of the year.

Now whilt Tarquin was making preparations in Tucany for a econd War againt the Romans, 'tis aid a portentous accident fell out. When Tarquin was King, and having not compleated the buildings of the Capitol, he deigning, whether from a Divine impule or his own pleaure, to erect an earthen Chariot upon the top, entruted the workmanhip to Tucans of the City Veies, but oon after was oblig'd to retire from his Kingdom. The Work thus model'd the Tucans et in a Furnace, but the
Clay hew'd not thoe paive qualities which uually attend its nature, to ubide and be condens'd upon the exhalations of the moiture, but roe up and well'd to that bulk, that being conolidated and firm, notwithtanding the removal of the head and breaking down the walls of the Furnace, it could not be taken out without much difficulty. The wie men look'd upon this as a Divine prognotick of ucces and power to thoe that hould enjoy it, and the Tucans reolv'd not to deliver it to the Romans who demanded it: but anwer'd that it rather belong'd to Tarquin, than to thoe that forc'd him into exile. A few days after there happen'd an Hore-race with the uual hews and olemnities, the Chariotier with his Crown on his head oftly driving his victorious Chariot out of the ring, the Hores, upon no apparent occaion affrighted, but either out of a Divine intigation or an accidental, hurried away their driver full peed to Rome, neither did his holding them in prevail, or his gentle oothings, but
< in non-Latin alphabet >
with violence was forc'd along, till coming to the Capitol, was there thrown by the Gate call'd Ratumena. This occurrence rais'd wonder and fear in the Veians, who upon this permitted a delivery of the Chariot.

Now Tarquin, the Son of Demaratus, warring with the Sabines, avow'd the building of the Capitol, which Tarquinius Superbus, Grandon to the avower, began, yet could not dedicate it, becaue he lot his Kingdom before 'twas finih'd; when 'twas compleated and adjuted with all its ornaments, Poplicola had a great ambition Poplicola ambitious of dedicating the Capitol. to the dedication, but the Nobility envy'd him that honour, as well as thoe his prudence in making Laws and conduct in Wars entitled him to: and preuming he merited not the addition of this, they importun'd Horatius to ue for the dedication; and whilt Poplicola was engag'd to lead the Army into the Field, voted it to Horatius, and accordingly conducted him to the Capitol, auring themelves, that were Poplicola preent, they hould not have prevail'd. Yet ome write, Poplicola was by lot detin'd againt his will to the Army, the other to the dedication; and what happen'd in the performance, eems to intimate ome ground for this conjecture: for upon the Ides of September, which happens about the full Moon of the Month Metagitnion, the
< in non-Latin alphabet >
people flocking to the Capitol, and ilence enjoyn'd, Horatius after the performance of other Ceremonies holding the Doors, according to cutom pronounc'd the words of dedication; then Marcus the Brother of Poplicola,
who had tood for ome time at the Door, oberving his opportunity, cry'd, "O Conul, thy Son lies dead in the Camp, which made great impreions upon the Auditory, yet in no wie dicompos'd Horatius, receiving onely this reply, Then cat Horatius's undaunted reply to Marcus. the dead out whither you pleae, for I hall not admit of orrow; and o puru'd his dedication; this news was not true, but Marcus thought the lye might avert him from his performance. This argued him a man of an admirable contancy, whether he preently aw through the cheat, or believ'd it as true, hewing no dicompoure in his paions. The ame ucces attended the dedication of the Second Temple: the firt is aid to be built by Tarquin, and dedicated by Horatius, which was burnt down in the civil Wars. The Second Sylla built, and dying before the dedication, bequeath'd that honour to Catulus; but when this was demolih'd in the Vitellian Sedition, Vepaian with omewhat like ucces began a Third, and aw it finih'd, but liv'd not to ee its ruines, which accompany'd his death; yet urviving the dedication of his Work, eem'd more fortunate than Sylla, who dy'd before his, though immediately after his death 'twas conum'd by Fire. A Fourth was built by Domitian, and dedicated. 'Tis aid Tarquin expended forty thouand
pound of Silver in the very Foundations; but the greatet treaure of any private The magnificent tructure of the Capitol. man in Rome would not dicharge the guilding of this Temple in our days, it amounting to above twelve thouand Talents: the Pillars were cut out of Pentelick
< in non-Latin alphabet >
Marble, having length utable to their thicknes, and thee we aw at Athens; but when they were cut a-new at Rome and embellih'd, they gain'd not o much beauty, as they lot in proportion, being render'd too
< in non-Latin alphabet >
taper and lender. Now whooever hould admire the excellency of the Capitol, and afterwards urvey a Gallery in Domitian's Palace, or an Hall, Bath, or the Apartments of his Concubines, what Epicarmus wrote of a profue man
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
Thou art not gen'rous, thy bounty's vice within,
Thy gifts thou lavih't, and glory't in the in.
he might readily apply it to Domitian, Thou art neither pious or noble, onely pleaing thy elf in the itch of Building, and a deire like Midas of converting all into Gold and pretious Stones: and thus much for this matter.

Tarquin, after the great Battel wherein he lot his Son in an engagement with Brutus, fled to Cluius, and ought aid from Clara Porenna, then the mot powerfull Prince Porenna epoues Tarquin's quarrel. of Italy, and a peron of ingular candour and generoity, who aur'd him his aitence, immediately ending his commands to Rome that they hould receive Tarquin as their King; and upon the Romans refual proclaim'd War, and having ignified the time and place where he intended his afault, approach'd with a great Army. Now Poplicola in his abence was choen Conul a econd time, and Titus Lucretius his Collegue; but returning to Rome with intentions of appearing more generous than Porenna, built the City Sigliuria when Porenna layt encamp'd in the neighbourhood; and walling it at great expence, there plac'd a Colony of even hundred men, as being little concern'd at the War: but Porenna making a harp aault, oblig'd the defendants to retire to Rome, who had almot in their entrance admitted the enemy into the City, had not Poplicola by allying out at the Gate prevented them, and joining Battel by Tiber ide, oppos'd the enemy, that pres'd on with their multitude; but at lat inking under his honourable wounds, was carried out of the Fight. The ame fortune fell upon Lucretius, o that the Romans
being dimay'd retreated into the City for their ecurity, and Rome was in great hazard of being taken, the enemy making good their puruit to the wooden Bridge, where Cocles Horatius, econded by two The noble atchievement of Cocles Horatius. of the eminentet men in Rome, Hermenius and Lucretius, made head againt them. (This name he obtain'd from the los of one of his Eyes in the Wars; or as others write, from the depreure of his Noe, which cauing a eeming coalition of
< in non-Latin alphabet >
his eye-brows, made both eyes appear but as one, and hence they intending to call him Cyclops, by a cadency of the Tongue, uually
< in non-Latin alphabet >
call'd him Cocles. This Cocles kept the Bridge, and repuls'd the enemy, till his own party broke it down behind, and then in his Armour cat himelf into the River, and wam to the hither ide, being wounded upon his Hip with a Tucan Spear. Poplicola admiring his courage invited the Romans every one to gratifie him with a preent of as much proviions as he pent in a day, and afterwards gave him as much Land as he could encircle with a Plough in one day; beides erected a brazen Statue to his honour in the Temple of Vulcan, as a requital for the lamenes he contracted from his wound. But Poenna laying cloe iege to the City, and a Petilence raging amongt the Romans, beides a new Army
of the Tucans making incurions into the Country; Poplicola a third time choen Conul deign'd without allying out to make
< in non-Latin alphabet >
his defence, however privately tealing out upon the Tucans, put them to flight, and lew five thouand. Now the Hitory of The hazardous attempt of Mutius. Mutius is variouly deliver'd, but this relation hall follow the common reception; he was a peron endow'd with every vertue, but mot eminent in warfare, and reolving to kill Porenna, attir'd himelf in Tucan Habit, and uing the Language came to the Camp, and approaching the eat where the King ate amongt his Nobles, but not of a certainty knowing the King, and yet fearfull to enquire, drew out his Sword, and tab'd him, that amongt all made the likeliet appearance of being a King: Mutius was taken in the act, and whilt under examination, a Pan of Fire was brought to the King, who intended to acrifice; Mutius thrut his right hand into the flame, and whilt it burnt, beheld Porenna with a tedfat and undaunted countenance; Porenna admiring the man, dimis'd him, and return'd his Sword, reaching it from his Seat: Mutius receiv'd it in his left hand, which occaion'd the name of Scaevola, i. e. lefthanded; and aid, I have overcome the terrours of Porenna, yet am vanquih'd by his generoity, and gratitude obliges
me to dicover, what no punihment could extort; and aur'd him then, that three hundred Romans, all of the ame reolution, lurk'd about his Camp onely waiting for an opportunity, and that he by lot detin'd to the enterprie, was not troubled, he micarry'd in the ucces, becaue he was o good a man, and deerv'd rather to be a Friend to the Romans than an Enemy. To this Porenna gave credit, and thereupon expres'd an inclination to a Truce, not, I preume, o much out of fear of the hundred Romans, as an admiration of the Roman courage. All other Writers call this man Mutius Scaevola, yet Athenodorus Sandon in a Book wrote to Octavia Caear's Siter, avers he was alo call'd Opigonus. Poplicola not o much eteeming Porenna's enmity dangerous to Rome as his friendhip and alliance erviceable, was induc'd to refer the Controverie betwixt him and Tarquin to his Arbitration, and everal times engag'd to prove Tarquin the wort of men, and jutly depriv'd of his Kingdom: but Tarquin proudly reply'd, he would admit no Judge, much les Porenna, that had revolted from his Confederacy: Porenna reenting this Porenna makes peace with the Romans. anwer, and mitruting the equity of his caue, together with the olicitations of his Son Aruns, who was earnet for the Roman interet, made a Peace on thee conditions,
that they hould reign the Field, they had taken from the Tucans, and retore all Prioners, and receive their Fugitives: To confirm the Peace the Romans gave as Hotages ten of the Nobility's Sons, and as many Daughters, amongt which was Valeria the Daughter of Poplicola.

Upon thee aurances Porenna ceas'd from all acts of hotility, and the Virgins went down to the River to bathe, at that part where the crookednes of the Bank embracing the waters rendred it pleaant and erene; and eeing no guard or any coming or going over, were encouraged to wim over, notwithtanding the depth and the violence of the tream. Some affirm that one of them, by name Cloelia, paing over on Hore-back, peruaded the ret to follow; but upon their afe arrival coming to Poplicola, he neither admir'd or approv'd their return, but was concern'd, let he hould appear les faithfull than Porenna, and this boldnes in the Virgins hould argue treachery in the Romans; o that apprehending
< in non-Latin alphabet >
them, he ent them back to Porenna. But Tarquin's men having intelligence thereof, laid a trong ambucade on the other ide for thoe that conducted them; who skirmihing together, Valeria, the Daughter of Poplicola, ruh'd through the enemy and led, and with the aitence
of three of her retinue made good her ecape; whilt the ret were dangerouly hedg'd in by the Souldiers. Aruns Porenna's Son upon advertency thereof, haten'd to their recue, and putting the enemy to flight, deliver'd the Romans. When Porenna Porenna's generoity to the Daughter of Poplicola. aw the Virgins return'd, and demanding, who was the authour and abettour of the deign, and undertanding Cloelia to be the peron, look'd upon her with a countenance equally cheerfull and compaionate, and commanding one of his Hores to be brought umptuouly adorn'd, made her the preent. This as an evidence they produce, who affirm that onely Cloelia pas'd the River on Horeback; thoe who deny it, eteem'd it onely as the honour the Tucan did to her courage, whoe Effigies on Horeback tands in the Via Sacra as it leads to the Palatium, which ome ay is the Statue of Cloelia, others of Valeria. Porenna thus reconcil'd to the Romans, oblig'd them with a freh intance of his generoity, and commanded his Souldiers to depart the Camp onely with their Arms, and leaving their Tents wealthy and furnih'd with proviions, he aigned them to the Romans. Whence it became cutomary upon publick ale of Goods, to cry Porenna's firt, thereby to eternize the memory of his kindnes; and erected his brazen Image by the Senate-houe,
plain but of antique fahion. Afterwards the Sabines making incurions upon the Romans, M. Valerius, Brother to Poplicola, was made Conul, and with him Pothumius Tubertus. Marcus through the Marcus victorius over the Sabines. management of affairs by the conduct and authority of Poplicola obtain'd two great Victories, in the latter of which, he lew thirteen thouand Sabines without the los of one Roman, and was honour'd with an Houe built in the Palatium at the publick charge, as an acceion to his triumphs; and whereas the Doors of others Houes open'd inward into the Houes, they made this to open outward into the Street, as intimating by this privilege, that he was always ready for the publick ervice. The ame fahion in their Doors the Greeks (they ay) had of old, which appears from their Comedies, wherein thoe that are going out make a noie at the Door within, to give notice to thoe that pas by or tand near the Door, that the opening the Door into the Street might occaion no urprial.

The year after Poplicola was made Conul the fourth time, when a confederacy of the Sabines and Latins threatned a War, beides a upertitious fear o'er-run the City, ariing from the Womens micarriages
< in non-Latin alphabet >
of mutilous births, and no conception waiting its due time: Poplicola upon the Sibyll's
intructions acrificing to Pluto, and retoring certain Games dedicated to Apollo, rendred the City cheerfull, with the aurances he had in the Gods, and then prepar'd againt the menaces of men. Now there was one Appius Clauus amongt the Sabines, a Appius Clauus deerts the Sabine caue. man of a great Etate and trength of Body, but mot eminent for the excellency of his Vertue, and the depth of his Reaon, yet could not (what is uually the fate of great men) ecape the envy of others, which was much occaioned from his detracting the War, and eeming to promote the Roman interet, as deigning to bring them under their Yoke; and knowing how welcome thee reports would be receiv'd by the gaping multitude, and how offenive they would be to the Army and the abettours of the War, was afraid to tand a Trial; but having a coniderable aitance of Friends and Allies, rais'd a tumult amongt the Sabines, which delay'd the War. Neither was Poplicola wanting, not onely to undertand the grounds of the Sedition, but to promote and encreae it, and accordingly dipatch'd Emiaries with thee intructions
< in non-Latin alphabet >
to Clauus, That Poplicola was aur'd of his goodnes and jutice, and thought it even in bad men unworthy, epecially in him though injur'd to eek revenge upon his Citizens; yet if he pleas'd for his own
ecurity to leave his enemies and come to Rome, he hould be receiv'd both in publick and private, with that honour his vertue deerv'd, or their grandeur requir'd. Appius eriouly weighing thoe things, which neceity propos'd as advantageous, and adviing
< in non-Latin alphabet >
with his Friends, and they inviting others to the ame peruaion, came to Rome with five thouand Families with their Wives and Children, being a people of a quiet and edate temper: Poplicola advertis'd of their approach, receiv'd them with all the kind offices of a Friend, and enfranchis'd them into the Community, alloting to every one two Acres of Land by the River of Aniene, but to Clauus twenty five Clauus choen Senator. Acres, and admitted him into the Senate, and made him an aociate in the Government, which he o prudently manag'd, that it haten'd his preferment, and o improv'd his greatnes, that his poterity the Claudii became inferiour to no Family in Rome.

The departure of thee men rendred things quiet amongt the Sabines, yet the chief of the Community would not uffer them to ettle into a peace, but reented that
< in non-Latin alphabet >
Clauus, what his preence could not atchieve, by turning Renegade hould obtruct their revenge upon the Romans for all their injuries; and coming with a great Army, ate down before Fidenae, and plac'd
an ambucade of two thouand men near Rome, in the obcure and hollow places, with a deign that ome few Horemen, as oon as day, hould make incurions, commanding them upon their approach to the Town, o to retreat, as to draw the enemy into the ambuh; but Poplicola oon advertis'd of thee deigns by the Renegado's, dipos'd his Forces to their repective charges, and Pothumius Balbus his Son-in-law coming with three thouand men in the evening was order'd to take the Hills, under which the ambuh lay, there to oberve their motions; and the Collegue Lucretius, attended with a Body of light and luty men, was commanded with his Hore to aail the van-curriers of the Sabines; whilt he with another Army encompas'd the enemy, and, accidentally a thick mit falling, Pothumius early in the morning with houts from the Hills aail'd the ambucade: Lucretius charg'd the light Hore, and Poplicola beieg'd the Tents: o that things aur'd a defeat and ruine to the Sabines; The Sabines totally vanquih'd. and thoe that made no reitence the Romans kill'd in their flight, all their hopes expiring in their own detruction; for each Army of the Sabines preuming afety in the other, both ceas'd to fight or keep their ground; the one quitting the Camp to retire to the Ambucade, the Ambucade flying
to the Camp, met thoe in as great need of aitence, to whom they fled in hopes of a ecurity; but the nearnes of the City Fidenae became a preervation to everal of the Sabines, epecially to thoe that upon the acking deerted the Camp, but thoe that could not recover the City, either perih'd in the Field, or were taken prioners. This Victory the Romans (though uually acribing uch ucces to ome God) attributed to the conduct of one Captain, and 'twas oberv'd to be heard amongt the Souldiers, that Poplicola had deliver'd their enemies lame and blind, onely not in chains,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
to be dipatch'd by the Sword: beides from the Spoil and Prioners a great wealth accru'd to the Romans. But Poplicola having ended his Triumph, and bequeathing the City to the prudence of the ucceeding Conuls, oon died, Poplicola dies. whoe life was led with the goodnes and vertue mortality would admit: The people as not having gratify'd his deerts, when alive, but as in gratitude till oblig'd, decreed him a publick Interrement, every one contributing his Quadrans towards the
< in non-Latin alphabet >
charge; beides the Women by a general conent in private mourned a whole year with a incere veneration to his memory; he was buried by the peoples deire in the Street call'd Velia, where his poterity had the honour of burial, but now none of the
Family are there interred, but the Body is carried thither, and one places a burning Torch under it, and then immediately takes it away, as an attetation of the deceaed's privilege, and his receding from his honour, and then the Body is remov'd.

div.head: THE COMPARISON OF POPLICOLA with SOLON.
div.p:
NOW there appears omewhat ingular in this parallel, and what has not occur'd in any other of the Lives; as the one to be the imitatour of the other, and the other a witnes of his vertue; o that upon the urvey of Solon's Sentence to Croeus applauding Tellus's happines, it eems more applicable to Poplicola; for Tellus, whoe vertuous life and dying well had gain'd him the name of the happiet man, yet was never celebrated in Solon's Poems for a good
man, or that his Children or his Government deerv'd his memorial: but Poplicola, as his life was the mot eminent amongt the Romans, as well for the greatnes of his vertue as his power, o at his death was accounted amongt the greatet Families, and even in our days the Poplicolae, Mealae, Poplicola's poterity of long continuance. and Valerii for ix hundred years acknowledge him as the fountain of their honour. Beides, Tellus though keeping his order and fighting like a valiant Captain, yet was lain by his enemies; but Poplicola (what was more honourable) lew his enemies, and aw his Country victorious through his conduct; and his honours and triumphs procur'd him (what was Solon's ambition) an happy end; and what as a reproof to Mimnermus touching the continuance of Man's life he exclaimed,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
A ilent unlamented death I hate,
Let ighs of Friends and tears attend my Fate.
atteted his happines; his death did not onely draw tears from his Friends and acquaintance, but became the object of an univeral wih and orrow through the whole City, for the very Women deplor'd
this los as of a Son, Brother, or univeral Father. Solon aid,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
An Etate I love, but not unjutly got, let vengeance hould purue the unjutice: But Poplicola's riches were not onely the product of his jutice, but his ditributions of them to the poor were the dicretion of his charity, o that if Solon was reputed the wiet man, we mut allow Poplicola to be the happiet, for what Solon wih'd Poplicola in reality what Solon wih'd to be. for as the greatet and mot perfect good, that Poplicola in its proper ue enjoy'd to his death: o that Poplicola became as well an honour to Solon, as Solon to him, in tranmitting the exactet method of modelling a Commonwealth, and tripping the Conulhip of its pride, made it eaie and pleaant to the people; he tranplanted everal Laws into Rome, as his impowering the people to elect their Officers, and allowing Offenders the liberty of appealing to the People, as Solon did to the Judges. Poplicola did not indeed create a new Senate, as Solon did, but augmented the old with almot a double number. He erected the Office of Quetors; let the Conul, if
good, hould not have leiure otherwie to attend greater matters; or if bad, hould have any temptation to unjutice, having the Government and Treaury in his hands. The averion to tyranny was greater in Poplicola,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
for whooever endeavour'd an uurpation, his punihment by Solon's Law commenc'd onely upon conviction: but Poplicola made it death before a trial. And though Solon jutly gloried, that when things without the leat averion of the Citizens were preented to his Sovereignty, he refus'd the offer; yet Poplicola merited not les, who finding a tyrannical Government, made it more popular by not uing the Authority he might. But we mut allow, that Solon knew it before Poplicola: for;
< in non-Latin alphabet > ,
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
An even hand will an even tate maintain,
Holding not too looe, nor yet too trait a rein.
But the remiion of debts was more peculiar
< in non-Latin alphabet >
to Solon, which much trengthened the Citizens liberty; for the Law intending a level little avail'd, if the debts of the poor prevented that equality; and where they
eem'd chiefly to exercie their liberty, as in debates, elections and adminitrations of
< in non-Latin alphabet >
their Offices, they were overrul'd by the rich, yielding themelves to their dipoal. But 'tis more extraordinary, that rebellion attending uually this remiion of debts, yet he apply'd this as a deperate remedy, and eaonably allay'd their heats by his vertue and eteem, which was above the infamy or detraction, that could arie from this act. The beginning of his Government was more glorious, for he was himelf an original, and followed no example, and without the aid of an Allie did great things by his own conduct: yet the death of Poplicola was more happy and admired; for Solon aw the diolution of his own Commonwealth; but Poplicola preerv'd his inviolable till the Civil Wars. Solon leaving his Laws engraven in Wood, but detitute of a defender, departed Athens; whilt Poplicola remaining in his magitracy etablih'd the Government: and though Solon was enible of Piitratus's ambition, yet was not able to uppres it, but unk under the new etablih'd Tyranny; whereas Poplicola utterly ubverted and diolved a potent Monarchy, trongly ettled by long continuance; being nothing inferiour to Solon in vertue and dipoition, and withall favourably aited with power and fortune
to accomplih his vertuous deigns: and as for martial exploits, Daimachus Plataeenis does not o much as attribute the Wars againt the Megarenes to Solon, as is before intimated: But Poplicola in great encounters, Poplicola in many repects preferable to Solon. both as a private Souldier and Commander, obtain'd the victory.
