As to the managery of publick affairs, Solon in a mimical way, and by a counterfeit hew of madnes olicited the enterprie of Salamis; whereas Poplicola in the very beginning, nothing daunted at the greatet enterpries, oppos'd Tarquin, detected the Conpiracy; and being principally concern'd both in preventing the ecape, and afterwards punihing the Traitours; he not onely excluded the Tyrants from the City, but frutrated likewie all their expectations from thence: who, as in matters of conflict, tumult or oppoition he behaved himelf with courage and reolution; o in peaceable debates where perwaion and condecenion were requiite he was more to be commended; Porenna a terrible and invincible Enemy by his means being reconciled and made a Friend. Some may perhaps object, that Solon recovered Salamis for the Athenians, which they had lot; whereas Poplicola receded from part of what the Romans were preently poes'd of: but judgment is to be made of actions according to
the times in which they were perform'd: The conduct of a wie Politician is ever uted to the preent poture of affairs, who often by forgoing a part aves the whole, and by yielding in a mall matter ecures a greater; as Poplicola who by retoring what the Romans had lately uurped, aved their undoubted patrimony, and moreover procured the Stores of the enemy for them, who were very much traitned to ecure their City: For permitting the deciion of the Controverie to his Adverary, he not onely got the victory, but what likewie he would willingly have given to have overcome; Porenna putting an end to the War, and leaving them all the proviion of his Camp, through a perwaion of the vertue and gallant dipoition of the Romans, which the Conul had impres'd upon him.

div.head: THE LIFE OF THEMIS TOCLES THE ATHENIAN.
div.byline: Tranlated out of the Greek, By Edward Brown, M. D.
div.p:
THE obcure Family of Themitocles gave ome beginning to his honour, and made his glory hine the brighter. His Father Neocles was none of the mot plendid of Athens, but of the Diviion of Phrear, and of the Line of Leontes; and by his Mother's ide, as it is reported, he was illegitimate
I am not of the noble Grecian race,
I'm poor Abrotanon and born in Thrace:
Yet 'mong the Greeks my fame hall never ceae,
For them I brought forth great Themitocles.
Yet Phanias writes that the Mother of Themitocles was not of Thracia but of Caria, and that her name was not Abrotanon but Euterpe: and Neanthes adds further that he was of the City of Halicarnaus in Caria: upon which conideration, when the Strangers, and thoe that were but of the half bloud, or had but one Parent an Athenian, were to perform their exercie at Cynoarges (a wratling place without the Gates dedicated to Hercules, who was alo under ome illegitimacy, and was not one of the great immortal Gods, but had a mortal Woman for his Mother) Themitocles Themitocles's policy to ennoble his Birth. peruaded divers of the young Noblemen to accompany him, to anoint and exercie themelves together at Cynoarges; in doing which, he eemed with ome ingenuity to take away the ditinction between the truly Noble and the Stranger, and between thoe of the whole and thoe of the half bloud of Athens. However it is certain that he was related to the Houe of Licomedes, for Simonides reports that he rebuilt the Chapel of Phlyes belonging to that Family,
and beautified it with Pictures and other Ornaments, after it had been burnt by the Perians.

It is confes'd by all that from his youth he was of an impetuous nature, full of pirit, apprehenive, and of a good undertanding, ever reolving to undertaking great actions and manage publick affairs. The vacations and times of recreations from his tudies, he pent not in play or in idlenes, as other youths, but would be always inventing or putting in order ome Oration or Declamation, the ubject of which was generally the excuing or accuing his companions; o that his Mater would often ay to him, Boy, thou cant never be any thing mean or indifferent, but mut at ome time or other prove either a mot heroick glorious bleing, or a mot detructive plague and ruine to thy Country. He received very lowly and negligently uch intructions as were given him to improve his manners and behaviour, or to make him skilfull in any pleaure, or to teach him a gentile or gracefull deportment; but whatever was delivered to him to improve him in prudence, or in the management of publick affairs, he would apprehend it immediately, and undertand it beyond one of his years, for in uch things he confided in his own natural parts: and therefore afterwards in
dicoures of Humanity, the liberal Sciences, and gentile Education, being derided by thoe who thought themelves well skilled therein, he was forced to defend himelf omewhat arrogantly, aying, I undertand not how to touch a Lute or play upon a Harp, but if a mall, mean, obcure City were committed to my charge, I know well how to make it coniderable, great and glorious. Yet notwithtanding this, Steimbrotus ays, that Themitocles was a hearer of Anaxagoras, and that he tudied natural Philoophy under Melius; but he mut needs err in the time, for Melius was Commander of the Samians, when Pericles made War againt Samos, but Themitocles was much elder than Pericles, whereas Anaxagoras was very converant with him. They are therefore rather to be credited, who report, that Themitocles was an earnet follower of Mneiphilas, the Phrearian, who was neither Oratour nor natural Philoopher, but a Profeour of that which was then called Wiedom, or a prudence exercied in ordering publick concerns, and an accurate undertanding and judgment in affairs of State; which profeion being begun by Solon was preerved ucceively as a Sect of Philoophy; but thoe who came afterwards, and mixed it with pleadings and diputes in Law, and transferred the practical
part of it to a mere art of peaking, and an exercie of words and terms, were generally call'd Sophiters. However Themitocles, when he entred upon affairs of State, applied himelf to Mneiphilas.

In the firt motions of his youth he was not regular nor well poied, drawing the lines of his affairs according to his own natural fancy, without reaon or intruction; and made great alterations in his deigns on the one hand and on the other; and very often determined for the wort, as he afterwards confeed, aying, Ragged Colts make the bet Hores, when it comes to pas that they are well taught and managed. But thoe who upon this account do erroneouly raie reports of his being diinherited by his Father, and that his Mother died for grief of her Son's lewdnes, do certainly mot falely calumniate him; and there are divers who relate to the contrary, how that to deterr him from dealing in the publick, and to let him ee how the vulgar behave themelves towards their Leaders when they have at lat no further ue of them, his Father hewed him the old Galleys as they lay neglected and foraken upon the Seahore without any care taken of them: yet it is evident, that early, even in his younger years, Themitocles did mot violently and with great eagernes apply himelf to
undertand how to govern and to win glory and honour, in which being earnet to be the firt, from the very beginning he by this rahnes preently created to himelf the hatred of the mot powerfull and chiefet in the City, but more epecially of Aritides Aritides oppoes Themitocles. the Son of Lyimachus, who always oppoed him; and yet all this great enmity between them eem'd to have but a light beginning, for they both were in love with the fair Steilaus of Teios, as Ariton the Philoopher relates: and from that time they perpetually contended with their Parties and Factions in the Commonwealth, not but that the diagreeablenes of their lives and manners may eem to have encreaed the difference; for Aritides was of a mild nature, good and fair conditioned, and governing all things for the bet with jutice and ecurity, not for glory, or the favour of the people, he was often forced to oppoe Themitocles, and to tand up againt the encreae of his authority who tirred up the people to many attempts and brought in great innovations; for it is aid that Themitocles was o tranported with the thoughts of glory, and o inflamed with the deire of performing great actions, that although he were but young when the Battel of Marathon was fought againt the Perians, and the warlike conduct of their General
Miltiades was every where noied about, he was taken notice of to be thoughtfull, and to go meditating many things alone by himelf, to pas the nights without leep and to refue his accutomed meetings and recreations, and to thoe who wondred at this change in his manner of living, and demanded the reaon of it, he gave this anwer, that the Trophies of Miltiades would not let him leep; and when others were of opinion that the Battel of Marathon would put an end to the War, Themitocles thought that it was but the beginning of far greater Conflicts, for which he prepared himelf continually, for the good of all Greece, and exercied the City as one foreeeing at a great ditance what was likely to come to pas. And firt of all, the Athenians being accutomed to ditribute the revenue proceeding Themitocles advies that the revenue of the Silver Mine at Laurion hould be employed in building Ships. from the Silver Mine at Laurion; he was the onely man that durt propoe to the people, that this ditribution hould ceae, and that with the Money Ships hould be built to make War againt the Aeginetes, who were the mot flourihing people in all Greece, and by the number of their Ships held the Sovereignty of the Sea: and to this Themitocles did eaily peruade them, not by tirring them up againt Xerxes or the Perians, who were at a great ditance, and their coming was very uncertain, and at
that time not much to be feared; but by eaonably making ue of the emulation, hatred and anger of the Athenians againt the Aeginetes, he induced them to thee preparations. So that with this Money an hundred Ships were built, with which they afterwards fought againt Xerxes; and in He caues the City to be built towards the Sea. a hort time he caued them to decend, and drew the City toward the Sea, with this advantage, that thoe who on Land were not a fit match for their neighbours, with their Ships might be able to free themelves from the Perians, and become rulers of Greece. So that, as Plato ays, intead of making them a tanding Militia, and tout Souldiers that would not give way in fight, he turned them into Mariners and Sea-men toed about the Sea, and gave occaion for this reproach againt him, that he took away from the Athenians the Spear and the Shield, and bound them to the Bank and the Oar. Thee things he performed getting the better of Miltiades, who oppoed him, as Steimbrotus relates: but whether or no he hereby injured the purity and exact rule of Government, let thoe who are more judicious determine. But that the deliverance of Greece came at that time from the Sea, and that thoe Galleys etablihed the City of Athens again after it was detroyed, to omit others, Xerxes himelf is a ufficient
witnes, who though his Land Forces were till entire, after he had been worted at Sea, fled away; and thought himelf no ways able to encounter them. And it eems to me, that he left Mardonius behind him, not out of any hopes he could have to bring them into ubjection, but to hinder the Greeks from puruing him.

Themitocles is aid to be very intent upon heaping up riches, that he might be the more liberal; (for loving to acrifice often, and to be plendid in his entertainment of Strangers, he tood in need of a plentifull revenue) yet he is accued by others to be parimonious and ordid to that degree, that he would ell the proviion which was preented him. He deired Philides, who was a breeder of Hores, to give him a Colt, and when he refued it, he threatned him that in a hort time he would turn his Houe into a Hore of Wood, like the Trojan Hore, intimating thereby that he would tir up trife and contets between him and thoe of his own Family and Relations.

He went beyond all men in ambition and deire of honour, and when he was but young and not known in the world, he deired Epicles of Hermiona who had a very good hand at the Lute, and was much eteemed by the Athenians, to come and practie at his Houe, being ambitious and
coveting to be popular, and deirous that many hould enquire after him and frequent his company. When he came to the Olympian Games, and was o plendid in his Equipage and Entertainments, in his rich Tents and Furniture, that he trove to out-doe Cimon, he dipleaed the Greeks, who thought that uch magnificence might be allow'd of in one who was a young Gentleman of a great Family; but a great piece of inolence in him to carry himelf thus high who was an uptart and of no coniderable Fortune. He et out a Tragedy at his own expene, and wan the Prize with his Tragedians, in thoe times when they purued thoe Sports with great eagernes and ambition, and et up a Table of his Victory with this incription; Themitocles the He affects popularity. Phrearian was at the charge of it, Phrynicus made it, Adymantus had the chief Part. He was well beloved by the common people, and he would alute every particular Citizen by his own name, and always hew himelf a jut Judge of Controveries between private men; and he aid to Simonides, a Poet of Chios, who deired omething of him, when he was Commander of the Army, that was not reaonable, Simonides, you would be no good Poet if you hould go contrary to the due Meaures and Rules of Poetry, nor hould I
be a good Magitrate, if for favour or affection I hould go contrary to the Law. And at another time laughing at Simonides he told him, that he was a man of little judgment to peak againt the Corinthians who were inhabitants of a great and beautiull City, and to have his own Picture drawn o often, having uch an ill Face.

When he came to be great and had won He caues Aritides to be banih'd. the favour of the people, he tirred up a party againt Aritides that expelled him, and banihed him out of the City by their publick Votes. When the King of Peria was coming down into Greece, and the Athenians were in conultation who hould be their General, and many withdrew themelves of their own accord, being terrified with the greatnes of the danger; there was one Epicydes an Oratour, Son to Euphemides, a Man who was powerfull in peech and of an eloquent Tongue, but of a faint Heart and a narrow Soul, a mere lave to Riches; this Man was deirous of the Command, and was look'd upon to be in a fair way to carry it by the number of Votes; but Themitocles fearing that, if the Government hould fall into uch a man's hands, all would be lot, he bought out Epicydes; and for a good um of Money caued him to deit from his pretenions.

When the King of Peria ent Meengers into Greece, with a Greek Interpreter, to demand Water and Earth as an acknowledgment of their ubjection and obedience to him, Themitocles by the conent of the people eis'd upon the Interpreter and put him to death, for preuming to publih the Orders and Decrees of the King of Peria in the Grecian Language; and for this he was highly honoured by the Greeks, as alo for what he did to Arthmius of Zelea, who for bringing Gold from the King of Peria to corrupt the Grecians, was by an Order from Themitocles degraded from all honour, and regitred in the Book of infamy, he, and his Children, and his Poterity: but that which mot of all redounded to his honour, was that he put an end to all the Civil Wars of Greece, compos'd their differences, and peruaded them to lay aide all enmity during the War with the Perians; and in this great Work Chileus the Arcadian was very aiting to him.

Having taken upon himelf the Command of the Athenian Forces, he immediately endeavoured to peruade the Citizens to leave the City, and to embark themelves upon their Galleys, and to meet with the Perians at a great ditance from Greece: but many being againt this, he led a great He leads an Army into Thealy. Army joined with the Lacedemonians into
Tempe; that in o narrow a Valley, bounded on each ide with high Rocks, he might the more eaily defend the Thealians, who had not as yet declar'd for the King: but when they return'd without performing any thing, and that it was known that not onely the Thealians, but all as far as Baeotia had yielded to Xerxes; then the Athenians more willingly hearkned to the advice of Themitocles to fight by Sea, and ent him with a Fleet to guard the Straits of Artemiium.

When the Grecian Fleets were joined, the Greeks would have the Lacedemonians to command, and Eurybiades to be their Admiral; but the Athenians, who urpaed all the ret in number of Veels, would not condecend to come after any other, till Themitocles, perceiving the danger of this contet, yielded the command to Eurybiades, and got the Athenians to ubmit, extenuating the los, by peruading them, that if in this War they behaved themelves like men, the Grecians for the future of their own accord would retore to them the chief command: and by this moderation of his it is evident, that he was the great Authour of the afety of Greece; and carried on the Athenians to that height of glory, that they urpaed their enemies in valour, and their friends and confederates in kindnes and civility.

As oon as the Perian Armada arrived The great Perian Fleet comes in ight. at Aphetae, Eurybiades was atonihed to ee uch a vat number of Veels before him, and being informed that two hundred more ail'd about behind the Iland of Sciathus, he immediately determined to retire further into Greece, and to ail back into ome part of Peloponneus, where their Land Army and their Fleet might join, for he looked upon the Perian Forces to be altogether invincible by Sea. But the Eubeans, fearing that the Greeks would forake them, and leave them to the mercy of the enemy, they ent Pelagon to dicoure privately with Themitocles, and with him a good um of Money, which he accepted, and gave it to Eurybiades, as Herodotus reports. In this affair none oppoed him o much as Architeles Captain of a Galley called the Powerfull; who having not money to upply his Sea-men made hate to et ail, but Themitocles o incened the Athenians againt him, that they et upon him and left him not o much as his Supper; at which Architeles was much urpris'd, and took it very ill, but Themitocles immediately ent him in a Chet a ervice of all proviions, and at the bottom of it a Talent of Silver, deiring him to up for the preent, and to provide for his Sea-men and Souldiers for the future, if not, he would report it amongt
the Athenians, that he had received money from the enemy, thus Phanias the Lesbian relates it.

Though the Fights between the Grecians and the Perians in the Straits of Euboea were not o great in the whole as to make a final deciion or determination of the War; yet the experience which the Greeks learnt hereby was of great advantage: for thus they effectually undertood, that neither the number of Ships, their riches and ornaments, nor their boating houts, nor barbarous Songs of Victory, were any ways terrible to men that dare fight, and were reolved to come hand to hand with their enemies, thee things they were to depie, and to come up cloe and grapple with their foes. This the Poet Pindarus took notice of, and hath not ill expreed it, peaking of the Fight at Artemiium.
To glorious Liberty Athens did this day,
By bold attempts a deep foundation lay.
For boldnes is the beginning of victory. Artemiium is above the City of Etioea upon Artemiium. the coat of Euboea which lies open to the North, but over againt it is Olizon, and a Country which formerly was under Philoctetes, where there is a mall Temple of Diana of the Eat, and Trees about it,
which are encompaed again with Pillars of white Stone; and if you rub them with your hand they end forth both the mell and colour of Saffron: in one of the Pillars thee Veres are engraved,
Within thee Seas, the brave Athenians hew
Their matchles valour, when they overthrew
The numerous Nations that from Aia pring,
And the great Navy of the Perian King:
And trophies won by uch a glorious fate
To bright Diana here did conecrate.
There is a place till to be een upon this Shoar, where in the middle of a great heap of Sand, they take out from the bottom a dark powder like Ahes, or omething that hath paed the Fire; and here they think the Shipwrecks and Bodies of the dead were burnt. But on the other ide, as oon as news came from Thermopylae to Artemiium informing them that King Leonidas was lain, and that Xerxes had made himelf mater of all the paages by Land, they returned back into Greece, the Athenians having the command of the Rere, the place of honour and danger, as thoe who by their former actions had tetified both their skill and courage in War.

As Themitocles ail'd along the coat he took notice of the Harbours and fit places
for the enemies Ships to retire into, and engraved He tempts the Ionians to forake the Perians. large Letters in uch Stones as he found there by chance, as alo in others which he et up on purpoe near to the landing places, or where they were to water; in thee incriptions he required the Ionians to forake the Medes, if it were poible, and come over to the Greeks, who were their ancient Founders and Progenitours, and were now hazarding all for their liberties, but if this could not be done, then to be a hindrance and diturbance to the Perians in all their Fights. He hoped that thee writings would prevail with the Ionians to revolt or raie ome great diorders, by cauing them to be much upected by the Perians.

Now though Xerxes had already paed through Doris, and invaded the Country of Phocis, and had burnt and detroyed the Cities of the Phocians, yet the Greeks ent them no relief; and though the Athenians earnetly deired them to oppoe the Perians in Boeotia, before they could come into Attica, as they themelves had given aitence to the Greeks by Sea at Artemiium, yet the Grecians gave no ear to their requet, being wholly intent upon Peloponneus, and reolved to gather all their Forces together within the Ithmus, and to build a Wall from Sea to Sea in that trait neck of
Land, which parts the Saronick Bay from the Gulf of Corinth; o that the Athenians were enraged to ee themelves thus betrayed, and at the ame time afflicted and dejected at their being foraken by the Greeks: to fight alone againt uch a numerous Army was to no purpoe, and this onely expedient was left them for the preent, to leave their City, and betake themelves to their Ships; which the people were very unwilling to hearken to, imagining that it would ignifie little to regard their own afety, or to deire victory, when they had once foraken the Temples of their Gods, and expoed the Tombs and Monuments of their Ancetours to the fury of their Enemies. Themitocles being at a los, and not able to draw the people over to his opinion by any humane reaon, he et his machines on work, as in a Play, and brought in his Divine Revelations, wonderfull Signs, Prodigies, Oracles, and mytical anwers of the Gods. The Dragon of Minerva kept in the inward part of the Temple near to her Statue erved him for a Prodigy, for Themitocles having gained the Priets, they gave it out to the people, that the Dragon refued to eat, that the offerings which were et before it were found untouched, that at lat it diappeared, that the Goddes had left the City, and taken her flight before them
towards the Sea. He often repeated to them the Oracle which bad them trut to Walls of Wood, hewing them that Walls of Wood could ignifie nothing ele but Ships, and that the Iland of Salamine was not to be termed mierable or unhappy, but Apollo had given it the name of Divine, for that it hould be one day very fortunate to the Greeks: at length his opinion prevail'd, and he obtain'd a Decree, that the City hould be recommended to the protection of Minerva the Tutelary Goddes of the Athenians, that they who were of age to bear Arms hould embark, and that all poible care hould be taken to ave the Children, the Women, and the Slaves. This The Athenians end away their Families to Troezena. Decree being confirmed, mot of the Athenians removed their Parents, Wives and Children to Troezena, where they were received very courteouly, and the Troezenians made an Order of Council, that they hould be maintained at the publick charge, ditributing daily two oboli to every one, gave leave to the Children to gather Fruit where they pleaed, and paid the Schoolmaters who intructed them. This Order was made when Nicagoras was Regiter.

There was no publick treaure at that time in Athens: but the Senate of Areo¯pagus (as Aritotle ays,) ditributed to every one that was lited eight Drachms; which
was a great help to the etting out of the Fleet, but Clidemus acribes this to a tratageme of Themitocles; who when the Athenians went down to the Haven of Piraea, aid, that the hield wherein the Head of Medua was engraven was taken away from the Statue of Minerva, and he being employed to earch for it, and ranacking in all places, found among their Goods great ums of Money, which he brought back for the ue of the publick, and with this the Soldiers and Sea-men were well provided for their Voyage.

When the whole City of Athens were going The Athenians embark. on Board it afforded a pectacle worthy of pity and admiration: for who would not have commierated thoe who were to leave their Country, and at the ame time admired their courage and reolution, to ee them end away their Fathers and Children before them, and not be moved with the cries and tears, and lat embracings of their ancient Parents and nearet Relations, when they paed over into the Iland! but that which moved compaion mot of all was, that many old men by reaon of their great age were left behind; and even the tame dometick Animals moved ome pity, running about the Town, clocking, mewing, houling, as deirous to be carried along with their Maters that had nourihed them:
among which it is reported that Xantippus the Father of Pericles had a Dog that would not endure to tay behind; but leaped into the Sea, and wam along by the Galley's ide, till he came to the Iland of Salamine, where he fainted away and died, and that part of the Iland in which he was buried is till called the Dog's Grave.

Among the great actions of Themitocles, Themitocles recalls Aritides from banihment. the return of Aritides was not the leat; for before the War he was oppreed by a Faction tirred up by Themitocles, and uffered Banihment, but now perceiving that the people regretted the abence of this great Man; and fearing that he might go over to the Perians to revenge himelf, and thereby ruine the affairs of Greece; Themitocles propoed a Decree, that thoe who were banihed for a time, might return again to give what aitence they could to the Grecians, both by their counel and valour, with the ret of the Athenians.

Eurybiades by reaon of the greatnes of Sparta was Admiral of the Grecian Fleet, but yet was faint-hearted in time of danger, and willing to weigh Anchor and et Sail for the Gulf of Corinth, near which the Land Army lay encamped, but Themitocles violently oppoed him, upon which happened many remarkable paages, and when Eurybiades to blame his impatience told
him, that at the Olympian Games they that rie up before the ret are lahed, Themitocles replied, and they that are left behind are never crowned, Eurybiades lifting up his Staff as if he were going to trike, Themitocles minding nothing but the interet of Greece, cryed, Strike if you will, but hear what I ay: Eurybiades wondring much at his moderation, deired him to peak, and Themitocles hereby brought him to a better undertanding of his affairs, but one who tood by him told him that it did not become thoe who had neither City nor Houe, nor any thing left to looe, to perwade others to relinquih their habitations and forake their Countries; to which Themitocles gave this reply, We have indeed left our Houes and our Walls, bae Fellow, not thinking it fit to become Slaves for the ake of thoe things that have no Life nor Soul, and yet our City is the greatet of all Greece, as coniting of two hundred Galleys which are here to defend you if you pleae; but if you run away and betray us as you did once before, the Greeks hall oon perceive that the Athenians will poes as fair a Country and as large and free a City as that already lot. Thee expreions of Themitocles made Eurybiades upect, that if he retreated, the Athenians would fall off from him. When one of Eretria began to oppoe him,
he aid, Have you any thing to ay of War, that are like an
< in non-Latin alphabet > , Loligo, Calamar pecado, Calamaro, a Sleeve, Calamary, or Ink-Fih. Ink-Fih? you have a Sword but no Heart. Some ay that while Themitocles was dicouring of thee things upon the Deck, there was an Owl een flying to the right hand of the Fleet, which came and ate upon the top of the Mat, this happy It cats out a yellow Ink. Omen o far dipoed the Greeks to follow his advice, that they preently prepared It is an exanguious cartilaginous Fih, having no bloud, it is thought to have no Heart; and it is aid to have a Sword, becaue it hath a Cartilage in it, which exactly reembles the Blade of a Rapier. to fight; yet when the enemies Fleet was arrived at the Haven of Phaleris upon the Coat of Attica, and with the number of their Ships had hadowed all the Shore, and when they aw the King himelf in peron come down with his Land Army to the Sea ide, with thoe multitudes, and all his Forces united; then the good Counel of Themitocles oon vanihed, and the Peloponneians cat their eyes again towards the Ithmus, and took it very ill if any one pake againt their returning home, and reolving to depart that night, the Pilots had order what coure to teer.

Themitocles being highly concerned that the Grecians hould retire, and looe the advantage of the narrow Seas and trait Paages, and lip home every one to his own The tratageme of Themitocles to force the Greeks to fight. City, conidered with himelf, and contrived that tratageme, that was carried on by Sicinus. This Sicinus was a Perian Captive,
but a great lover of Themitocles, and Tutour to his Children: upon this occaion Themitocles ent him privately to Xerxes, commanding him to tell the King that the Admiral of the Athenians having epoued his interet, had ent early to inform him, that the Greeks were ready to make their ecape, and that he counelled him to hinder their flight, to et upon them while they were in this confuion and at a ditance from their Land Army; and hereby he might detroy all their Forces by Sea. Xerxes was very joyfull at this meage, and received it as from one who wihed all things properous to him; and therefore immediately iued out intructions to the Commanders of his Ships, that they hould preently et out two hundred Sail, to encompas all the Ilands, and encloe all the Straits and Paages, that none of the Greeks might ecape; and to follow with the ret of their Fleet at better leiure. This being done, Aritides the Son of Lyimachus was the firt man that perceived it, and went to Themitocles into his Cabbin; not out of any peculiar Friendhip, for he had been formerly banihed by his means, as hath been related, but to inform him how they were encompaed by their enemies. Themitocles knowing the generoity of Aritides, and being much taken with his Viit
at that time, imparted to him all that he had tranacted by Sicinus, and intreated him that having great authority among the Greeks, he would now make ue of it in joyning with him to induce them to tay, and fight their enemies in thoe narrow Seas. Aritides applauded Themitocles, and went to the other Commanders and Captains of the Galleys, and encouraged them to engage; yet they did not perfectly aent to him, till a Galley of Tenedos which revolted from the Perians, whereof Panaetius was Commander, came into their Fleet, and confirmed the news that all the Straits and Paages were beet, and then their rage and fury as well as their neceity provoked them all to fight.

As oon as it was day Xerxes placed Xerxes places himelf conveniently to ee the Sea-fight. himelf on high to view his Fleet, and how it was et in order. Phanodemus ays he ate upon a Promontory above the Temple of Hercules, where the Coat of Attica is eparated from the Iland by a narrow Chanel; but Acetodorus writes, that it was in the confines of Megara, upon thoe Hills which are called the Horns, where he ate in a Chariot of Gold, with many Secretaries about him to decribe all that was done in the Fight.

When Themitocles was about to acrifice upon the Admiral Galley, there were three
very beautifull Captives brought to him, well dreed and gloriouly adorned with rich Vets and Gold, aid to be the Children of Autarctus and Sandauce Siter to Xerxes; as oon as the Prophet Euphrantides aw them, and oberved that at the ame time the Fire blazed out from the Offerings and cat forth a more than ordinary bright Flame, and that one neezed to the right, which portended ome fortunate event, he took Themitocles by the hand, and ordered that the three Children hould be conecrated and purified for Sacrifice, and offered up as a Vow for Victory to Bacchus the Devourer, for hereby the Greeks hould not onely ave themelves, but alo obtain Victory. Themitocles was much diturbed at this trange and terrible Prophecy, but the common Three Children acrificed before the Fight. people who in the mot difficult conflicts and greatet exigencies hope for relief by aburd and extravagant means, rather than by any reaonable way, calling upon Bacchus with one voice, led the Captives to the Altar, and compelled him to perform the Sacrifice, as the Prophet had commanded. This is reported by Phanias the Lesbian a great Philoopher and Hitorian. As to the number of the enemies Ships, the Poet Aechylus writes in a Tragedy called the Perians, That to his own knowledge Xerxes had a thouand Ships, of which two
hundred and even were extraordinary good Sailers. The Athenians had a hundred and eighty; in every Ship eighteen men fought upon the Deck, four of which were Archers and the ret well armed.

As Themitocles had poeed the mot advantageous place, o with no les conideration he choe the bet time of fighting; for he would not et the Stemms of his Galleys againt the Perians, nor begin the Fight till the time of day was come, when there contantly ries a blutring wind from without the Bay, which brings in with it a great Sea, and makes rough Water in the Chanel; this was no inconvenience to the Grecian Ships, which were low built and trong, but o far hurtfull to the Perians, which had high Sterns and lofty Decks, were heavy, and could not eaily tack, nor feel the Rudder, that it overet them, or laid their ides bare to the Grecians, who fiercely aaulted them, trictly obeying the orders of Themitocles, who well undertood what was mot for their advantage: and when Ariamenes Admiral to Xerxes, a good Ariamenes Admiral to Xerxes. man, and by far the bravet and worthiet of the King's Brothers, made towards Themitocles, and having a great Ship, threw Darts, and hot forth Arrows, as from the Walls of a Catle; Amenias the Decelian, and Soicles the Pedian, who ailed in the
ame Veel bore in and attacked him, and both Ships meeting Stemme to Stemme and triking together, their harp Stemmes armed with Bras, pierced through one anothers Ships, o that they were fatned together; when Ariamenes attempting to board them, Amenias and Soicles ran at him with their Pikes and thrut him into the Sea, his Body as it floated amongt other Shipwrecks was known by Artemiia and carried to Xerxes. It is reported that A Flame in the Air and trange Sounds and Voices heard during the Fight. in the middle of the Fight a great Flame hined bright in the Air above the City of Eleuis, and that Sounds and Voices were heard through all the plain of Thriaia as far as the Sea, ounding like a number of men that were going to celebrate the Myteries of Bacchus, and that a mit eemed to rie from the place from whence this ound came, and paing forward fell upon the Galleys. Others affirmed that they aw Apparitions and Spirits in the hape of armed Men which reached out their hands from the Iland of Aegina towards the Grecian Galleys and were like the Aeacides, whoe aitence they had implored in their prayers before the Fight. The firt man that took a Ship was Lycomedes the Athenian, Captain of a Galley, who cut down the enigns of honour, and dedicated them to Apollo crowned with Laurel. And as the Perians
fought in a narrow Arm of the Sea, and could bring but part of their Fleet to fight, they fell foul of one another, and the Greeks hereby equalled them in trength, fought with them till the evening, forced them The Greeks overcome the Medes. back, and obtained o clear and celebrated a Victory, as Simonides oberves, that neither Greek nor any other Nation, ever by Sea performed uch glorious ervice.

After this Sea-fight Xerxes being inraged Xerxes attempts to top up the Sea. at his ill fortune, attempted by cating great heaps of Earth and Stones into the Sea, to top up the Chanel and to make a Dam, upon which he might lead his Land Forces over into the Iland of Salamine.

Themitocles being deirous to know the opinion of Aritides, told him, that he intended to et Sail for the Hellepont, to break the Bridge of Ships, whereby he might hinder the retreat of Xerxes, and keep Aia within Europe; but Aritides being troubled at his deign, gave this reply, We have hitherto fought with an enemy who hath regarded little ele but his pleaure and luxury, but if we hut him up within Greece, and drive him to neceity, he that is Lord of uch great Forces, will no longer it quietly with an Umbrella of or Canopy of State. Gold over his Head, looking upon the Fight for his pleaure, but in uch a trait will attempt all things; he will be reolute and
appear himelf in peron upon all occaions, he will oon correct his errours, and upply what he has formerly omitted through remines; and will be better advied in all things. Therefore it is no ways our interet to take away the Bridge that is already made, but rather to build another if it were poible, that he might make his retreat with the more expedition. To which Themitocles anwered, if this be requiite, we mut immediately ue all diligence, art and indutry, to rid our elves of him as oon as may be: and to this purpoe he found out among the Captives one of the King of Peria's Eunuchs named Arnaces; whom he ent to the King, to inform him, that the Greeks being now victorious by Sea, had decreed to ail to the Hellepont, where the Ships were fatned together, and detroy the Bridge; but that Themitocles being paionately concerned for the King, revealed this to him, that he might haten towards the Aiatick Seas, and pas over into his own Dominions: and in the the mean he would caue delays, and hinder the Confederates from puruing him. Xerxes no ooner heard this, but being very much terrified, retreated out of Greece Xerxes retreats. with all peed. The prudent conduct of Themitocles and Aritides, and the advantageous management of this affair, was afterwards
more fully undertood at the Battel of Plataea; where Mardonius with a very mall portion of the Forces of Xerxes put the Greeks in danger of loing all.

Herodotus writes that of all the Cities of The Aegine
•• s perform good ervice.
Greece Aegina performed the bet ervice in the War; in which alo all men yielded to Themitocles, though ome, out of envy, did it unwillingly; and when they returned to the entrance of Peloponneus, where the Souldiers delivered their Suffrages by laying a Stone upon the Altar, to determine who was mot worthy, every one gave the firt Vote for himelf and the econd for Themitocles. The Lacedemonians carried him with them to Sparta; where giving the rewards of Valour to Eurybiades, and of Wiedom and Conduct to Themitocles, they crowned him with Olive, gave him precedency, preented him with the richet Coach in the City and ent three hundred young men to accompany him to the confines of their Country: and at the next Olympian Games, when Themitocles entred the place where thoe Exercies were performed, the Spectatours took no further notice of thoe who trove for Matery, but pent the whole day in looking upon him, hewing him to the Strangers, admiring The mitocles highly applauded. him, and applauding him by clapping their hands, and all other expreions of joy;
which o delighted him, that he confeed to his Friends, that he then reaped the fruit of all his labours for the Greeks; he was in his own nature a great lover of honour, as is evident from thoe things which are recorded of him. When he was choen Admiral by the Athenians, he ended no buines fully, publick, nor private, but deferred all till the day they were to et ail, that dipatching much buines together, and having to doe with all orts of men, he might appear great and able to perform all things. Viewing the dead Bodies cat up by the Sea, he perceived Collars and Chains of Gold about them, yet paed on, onely hewing them to a Friend that followed him, aying, Take you thee things, for you are not Themitocles. He aid to Antiphates a young Nobleman who had formerly behaved himelf haughtily towards him, but now in his glory obequiouly waited upon him; young man, we are in the right, and now we doe both as we hould doe. He aid that the Athenians did not honour him, or admire him, but when they were in danger they heltred themelves under him, as they do in tormy foul weather under a Plane-tree; and when they have fair weather again they pull off its Leaves and Fruit, and cut down its fairet Branches. A Seriphian telling him that
he had not obtained this honour by himelf but by the greatnes and plendour of his City, he replied, You peak truth, for I hould never have been eteemed if I had been of Seriphus: nor would you have come to any thing though you had been of Athens. A Commander of the Army who thought he had performed coniderable ervice for the Athenians, boating and comparing his actions with thoe of Themitocles, he told him that the day after the Fetival reproached the Fetival, that upon her day thoe who were laborious and indutrious refrehed themelves, but upon the Fetival the luggard and luxurious enjoyed all things, to which the Fetival replyed, it is true, yet if I had not been before you, you had not been at all; o if Themitocles had not been before you where had you been now? Laughing at his own Son, who was omewhat too bold through the indulgence and fondnes of his Mother, he told him that he had the mot power of any one in Greece; for the Athenians command the ret of Greece, I command the Athenians, your Mother commands me, and you command your Mother. Loving to be ingular in all things, when he had Land to ell, he ordered the Cryer to give notice that there were good neighbours near it. Of two who made love to his Daughter
he preferred the Vertuous before the Rich, aying, he deired a Man without Riches rather than Riches without a Man, with many uch expreions.

After thee things he began to build and He builds the Walls of Athens. wall the City of Athens, having with Money corrupted the Lacedemonian Ephori, and perwaded them not to be againt it, as Theopompus reports; but as mot relate it, by over-reaching and deceiving them, for being choen by the Governours of Athens he went to Sparta where the Lacedemonians accuing him for rebuilding the Walls of the City of Athens, and Poliarchus being ent on purpoe from Aegina to plead againt him, he denied the fact, bidding them to end to Athens to ee whether it were o or no: by which delay he got time for the building of the Wall, and ordering the Athenians to eize upon thoe who were ent, and keep them as Hotages for him; when the Lacedemonians knew the truth, they did him no hurt, but hiding their anger for the preent, ent him away.

After this, conidering the great advantage He fortifies the Haven of Piraea. of good Ports, he fortified the Haven of Piraea, and joyned the whole City to the Sea, ordering the publick affairs contrary to the judgment of the old Kings of Athens; who endeavouring to withdraw their Subjects from the Sea and ailing about,
and to accutom them to live by planting and tilling the Earth, publihed the Dicoure between Minerva and Neptune, and how they contended for the patronage of the Athenians, when Minerva by hewing to the Judges an Olive Tree, was declared to be their tutelary Goddes; but Themitocles did not onely joyn the Haven of Piraea to the City, as the Poet Aritophanes oberves, but he joyned the City to the Haven, and the Land to the Sea, which encreaed the power of the People againt the Nobility; the Authority coming into the hands of Watermen, Mariners and Maters of Ships: and ordered that the Pulpit built in the Market-place for publick Orations, hould be placed towards the Sea, which the thirty Tyrants afterwards turned towards the Land; uppoing that great power by Sea would give life and encouragement to a popular Government; but that Labourers and Husbandmen would be les offended at the greatnes of the Nobility: but Themitocles had a higher opinion of Sea forces.

After the departure of Xerxes, when the Grecian Fleet was arrived at Pagaa, where they wintered, Themitocles, in a publick Oration to the people of Athens, telling them that he had a deign to perform omething that would be very beneficial and advantageous
to the Athenians, but that it was of uch a nature, that it could not be made publick or communicated to the people in general: The Athenians ordered him to impart it to Aritides onely; and if he approv'd of it to put it in practice, and when He propoes to burn the Grecian Fleet in the Haven of Pagaa. Themitocles had dicovered to him that his deign was to burn the Grecian Fleet in the Haven of Pagaa; Aritides coming out to the people, gave this report of the tratageme contrived by Themitocles, that there was nothing more advantageous, nor could any thing conduce more to the properity and grandeur of Athens than this, but withall that it would be the mot unjut action in the world, at which the Athenians commanded Themitocles to deit from his intention, and to think no further of it.

When the Lacedemonians propoed at the general Council of the Amphictyonians that the Repreentatives of thoe Cities which were not in the League, nor had fought together againt the Perians, hould be excluded out of that Aembly; Themitocles fearing that the Thealians with thoe of Thebes, Argos and others, being thrown out of the Council, the Lacedemonians would become wholly maters of the Votes, and act what they pleaed; he applied himelf to the Deputies of the Cities, and prevailed with the Members then itting to
alter their opinions in this point, remontrating to them that there were but one and thirty Cities which did partake of the War, and that mot of thee alo were very mall, and how intolerable it would be, if the ret of Greece hould be excluded; and that the General Council hould come to be ruled by two or three great Cities. By this he chiefly incurred the high dipleaure and hatred of the Lacedemonians, who afterwards promoted Cimon to all honours, and placed him as an emulatour and adverary to Themitocles in all affairs of State.

He was alo burthenome to the Confederates, ailing about the Ilands and collecting money from them. Herodotus ays, that requiring money of thoe of the Iland of Andros, he told them, that he had brought with him two Goddees, Peruaion and Force; and they anwered him that they had alo two great Goddees which prohibited them from giving him any money; Poverty and Impoibility. Timocreon the Rhodian Poet reprehends him omewhat bitterly for being wrought upon by money to let thoe who were banihed return, and for betraying one who was his Guet and Friend. The Veres are thee
You may the honour of Pauanias raie,
Leutychides, or ele Xantippus praie,
Of Aritides I'll diplay the fame
The bet man e'er from mighty Athens came.
The fale dark deeds of bae Themitocles
Can never the divine Latona pleae:
His Friend and Guet Timocreon, for gain,
A prioner here he baely doth detain.
To get three Talents ome he does recall,
Banihes, murthers others, laughs at all.
While with his Bags well fill'd he may carroue,
And in the Ithmus keep a publick Houe.
Yet there doth uch cold entertainment give
His Guets oft wih him not an hour to live.
But after the entence and banihment of Themitocles Timocreon reviles him more exceively and more reproachfully, in a Poem which begins thus,
Mues, convey the Echo of my Vere,
And what I write continually reheare,
'Tis requiite that this you hould dipere,
All over Greece, and through the nivere.
It is reported that when it was put to the quetion whether Timocreon hould be banihed for iding with the Perians, Themitocles gave his Vote againt him, and when Themitocles was accued for treating with the Medes, Timocreon made thee upon him.
Timocreon now is not the onely man
Hath worn allegiance to the Perian.
Others are faulty, nay the greatet fail,
He's not the onely Fox without a Tail.
And when the Citizens of Athens began to hearken willingly to thoe who traduced and reproached him, he was forced to put them in mind of the great ervices he had performed, and asked thoe who were offended with him, whether they were weary with receiving benefits often from the ame peron, whereby he rendred himelf more odious: but he more highly incened He builds a Temple and dedicates it to Diana. the people, and accumulated their hatred towards him, when laying the Foundation of the Temple of Diana, he named it Aritoboule or Diana of the bet Counel; intimating thereby, that he had given the bet counel not onely to the Athenians but to all Greece. He built this Temple near to his own Houe, in a place called Melita, where now the Hangmen carry out the Bodies of uch as are executed, and throw the Halters and Clothes of thoe that are trangled or otherwie put to death. There is to this day a Statue of Themitocles in the Temple of Diana of the bet Counel, which repreents him to be a peron not onely of a noble Mind, but alo of a mot
heroical apect. At length the Athenians banihed him, making ue of the Exotracim The Exotracim. to depres his great worth, eminence and authority, as they ordinarily did to all thoe whom they thought too powerfull, or in a capacity to oppres them; or by their greatnes were become diproportionable to that equality which was thought requiite in a popular Government. For the Exotracim was intituted not o much to punih the Offender, as to mitigate and pacifie the fury of the envious, who delighted to depres thoe who were trancendent in eminence and glory, and by fixing this digrace upon them, they exhaled part of the venomous rancour of their minds.

Themitocles being banihed from Athens, while he tayed at Argos the Tryal of Pauanias happened, which gave uch advantage to his enemies, that Leobotes of Agraula Son of Alcmaeon indited him of Treaon; the Spartans joyning with him in the accuation.

When Pauanias went about this treaonable deign, he concealed it at firt from Themitocles, though he were his intimate Friend, but when he aw him expelled out of the Commonwealth, and how impatiently he took his banihment, he ventured to communicate it to him, and deired his aitence, hewing him the King of Peria's
Letters, and exaperating him againt the Greeks, as a cured and ungratefull people. However Themitocles immediately rejected the propoals of Pauanias, and wholly refued to be a party in the enterprie, though he never revealed thoe dicoures nor dicovered the Conpiracy to any man, either expecting that it would be dicovered by other means, or hoping that Pauanias would deit from his intentions, eeing that he attempted without due conideration things that were aburd, dangerous, and that could not be put in practice.

After that Pauanias was put to death, Letters and Writings being found concerning this matter which rendred Themitocles upected, the Lacedemonians were clamorous againt him, and the envious Athenians accued him, when being abent from Athens, he made his defene by Letters, epecially againt the chief accuations, and wrote to the Athenians in anwer to the malicious detractions of his enemies, urging that he who was always ambitious to govern, was never born to erve, and hould be very unwilling to become a Slave, would never ell himelf and his Country to the Perians the mortal enemies of the Greeks.

Notwithtanding this the people being perwaded by his accuers, ent Officers to take him and bring him away to be tried
before the great Council of the Greeks; but having timely notice of it, he paed He flies into the Iland of Corfu. over into the Iland of Corcyra, the chief City of the Iland having received great obligations from him, for being made Judge of a difference between them and the Corinthians, he determined the Controverie, ordering the Corinthians to lay down twenty Talents, and that the Town and Iland of Leucas hould be equally inhabited by a Colony ent from both Cities. From thence he fled into Epirus, and the Athenians and Lacedemonians till puruing him, he plunged himelf into uch intricate difficulties, that he had mall hopes ever to ecape; for he fled for refuge to Admetus King of the He flies to Admetus King of the Moloians. Moloians, who having formerly made a requet to the Athenians, Themitocles being then in the height of his Authority, had ued him didainfully and thrown durt upon him; which o enraged the King, that if he could have then laid hold of him, he would have ufficiently revenged himelf; yet in this misfortune, Themitocles fearing the freh hatred of his Neighbours and fellow Citizens, more than the former dipleaure of the King, threw himelf at his mercy, and became an humble uppliant to Admetus after a peculiar manner, different from the cutom of all other Countries. For holding the young Prince (who was
then a Child) in his Armes, he protrated himelf before the King's Houhold Gods; this being the mot acred and onely manner of upplication among the Moloians, which was not to be refued, and ome ay that Queen Phthia informed Themitocles of this way of petitioning, and placed her young Son near to him before the Figures of their dometical Deities: others ay that King Admetus, that he might be under a religious obligation not to deliver him up to thoe who perecuted him, helped him to act that part, and intructed him in this olemn Rite. At that time Epicrates of Acharnia privately conveyed his Wife and Children out of Athens, and ent them hither, for which afterwards Cimon condemned him, and put him to death, as Steimbrotus reports, yet either forgetting this, or making Themitocles to be little mindfull of it, he ays he ailed into Sicily, and deired in marriage the Daughter of Hieron Tyrant of Sicily, promiing to bring the Greeks under his power; and Hieron refuing him, he departed from thence into Aia: but this is not probable; For Theophratus writes in his Hitory of Kings, that when Hieron ent race Hores to the Olympian Games, and erected a royal Tent richly furnihed, Themitocles made an Oration to the Greeks inciting them to pull down the Tyrant's
Tent, and not to uffer his Hores to run. Thucydides ays that paing over Land to the Aegaean Sea, he took Ship at Pidna in He takes Ship at Pidna. the Bay of Therme not being known to any one in the Ship, till being terrified to ee the Veel driven by the Winds near to Naxus, which was then beieged by the Athenians, he made himelf known to the Mater and Pilot; and ometimes entreating them, at other times threatning them that if they went on hore he would accue them, and induce the Athenians to believe, that they did not take him in out of ignorance, but that he had corrupted them with money from the beginning, he compelled them to bear off, and tand out to Sea, and ail forward towards the Coat of Aia.

A great part of his etate was privately conveyed away by his Friends, and ent after him by Sea into Aia, beides which there was dicovered and conficated to the value of fourcore Talents; as Theophratus writes. Theopompus ays an hundred; whereas Themitocles was never worth three Talents, before he was concerned in the publick.

When he arrived at Cuma, and undertood that all along the Coat there were many laid wait for him, and particularly Ergoteles and Pythodorus (for the Game was worth the hunting after by uch as purued
gain every where, the King of Peria having offered by publick proclamation two hundred Talents to him that hould take him) he fled to Aeges a mall City of the Aeolians, where no one knew him but onely his Hot Nicogenes, who was the richet man in Aeolia, and well known in the Court of Peria. While Themitocles lay hid for ome days in his Houe, one night after a Sacrifice and a good Supper, Olbius Schoolmater to Nicogenes's Children fell frantick and inpired, and cried out in Vere,
This night intructs in mytick dreams and charms,
How t'ue thy parts and ever conquering Armes.
After this Themitocles dream'd that a Dragon Themitocles's Dream. coyled it elf up upon his Belly, and creeping up to his Neck, as oon as it touched his Face was turned into an Eagle; which pread its Wings over him, and took him up, and flew away with him into Countries far remote, where a golden Sceptre appeared to him, upon which he reted himelf ecurely, freed from all fear and trouble: and oon after Nicogenes made ue of this invention to end him away.

The barbarous Nations, and amongt them the Perians epecially, are naturally jealous, clownih and moroe towards their Women, not onely to their Wives, but alo to their Slaves and Concubines, which they keep o trictly that never any one ees them abroad, even at their Meals they are hut up within Doors; and when they take a journey, they are carried in cloe Coaches, or put under a little Tent or Covering hut cloe on all ides, and et upon a Waggon; uch a travelling Carriage being prepared for Themitocles, they overwhelmed him, and hid him in it, and carried him on his journey; and told thoe whom they met or dicoured with upon the Road, that they carried a young Grecian Lady out of Ionia to a Noble-man at Court.

Thucydides and Charon of Lampachus report that Xerxes being dead, Themitocles dicoured with his Son: but Ephorus, Deinon, Clitarchus, Heraclides and many others write, that he came to Xerxes, and though the chronological Tables do better agree with the relation of Thucydides, yet they are not exactly compiled with that undeniable certainty, that they hould be thought to be built upon unhaken and immovable Foundations.

When Themitocles was come to the critical Comes to Artabanus. point, he applyed himelf firt to Artabanus
Commander of a thouand men, telling him, that he was a Grecian and deired to peak with the King about important affairs, concerning which the King was extremely olicitous; Artabanus anwered him, Stranger, the Laws of men are different, and ome eteem one thing honourable and ome another, but it is honourable for all men to oberve and commend the Laws of their own Country; it is allowable for you Grecians to admire liberty and equality, but amongt our many excellent Laws, we account this the mot glorious, to honour the King, and to worhip him, as the Image of that great Deity that preerves and protects the Univere; and if you can accutom your elf to our Laws, and fall down before the King and worhip him, you may both ee him and peak to him; but if your mind be otherwie, you mut make ue of others to intercede for you; for it is not the national cutom here for the King to give audience to any one that doth not fall down before him: Themitocles hearing this, replied, Artabanus, I that come hither to encreae the power and glory of the King, will not onely ubmit my elf to his Laws, ince it hath pleaed God to raie the Perian Empire to this greatnes; but will alo caue many more to be worhippers and adorers of the King,
Let not this therefore be an impediment, why I hould not communicate to his Majety what I have to impart, Artabanus asking him who mut we tell him that you are? for you eem to be no ordinary peron, Themitocles anwered, no man mut be informed of this before the King himelf. Thus Phanias relates it; to which Eratothenes in his Treatie of Riches, adds, that by the means of a Woman of Eretria who was kept by Artabanus, he was brought acquainted with him, and obtained this favour from him.

When he was introduced to the King and He is brought before Xerxes. had paid his due reverence to him, he tood ilent, till Xerxes commanding the Interpreter to ask him who he was? he replied, I am Themitocles the Athenian, banihed and perecuted by the Greeks, I flie to thee for refuge mighty Monarch; the evils that I have done to the Perians are eaily to be forgiven, in conideration of the many atchievements accomplihed for them, when I hindred the Grecians from puruing the Medes after the fatal Battels of Salamis and Plataea, when having freed my Country and placed the Greeks in afety, my ambition led me on to greater enterpries; in which being uccesfull, I gratified the far extended Perian Empire, and performed ervices acceptable to the greatet Prince on
earth; ince which all things having conpired to augment my preent calamities, utable to uch a condition, I come hither, hoping to receive mercy from a gracious reconciled Sovereign, who hath laid aide his anger, and is no longer mindfull of former evils; humbly imploring you, that taking the Greeks for witnees of the ervices I have done for Peria, you will make ue of this occaion to hew the world the noblenes of your vertue, rather than to fulfill your wrath, or atisfie your indignation, hereby you will preerve an humble uppliant; if otherwie, you detroy a ervant of the Perians, and a publick enemy of the Greeks. Beides this, he related the manner of the Viion, which he aw at Nicogenes's Houe, and what was directed him by the Oracle of Dodona, where Jupiter commanded him to go to him that had a name like his, by which he undertood, that he was ent from Jupiter to Xerxes, eeing that they had both the name of mighty Kings; and he knew no other great acred powers but Jupiter, and the Perian Emperour.

The King heard him attentively, and though he admired his undertanding and courage, gave him no anwer at that time, but when he was with his intimate Friends, he rejoyced in his great good fortune, and
eteemed himelf very happy in this, and prayed to his God Arimanius, that all his enemies might be ever of the ame mind with the Greeks, to provoke, abue and expell the bravet men amongt them. Then he acrificed to the Gods, and preently fell to drinking, and was o well pleaed that in the night in the middle of his leep, he cried out for joy three times, I have Themitocles the Athenian.

In the morning, Xerxes calling together the chief of his Court, had Themitocles brought before him, who expected no good would come of it, epecially when he aw the Guards were fiercely et againt him as oon as they knew his name, and gave him ill language; and as he came forward towards the King, who was et down and the ret kept ilence, paing by Roxanes a Commander of a thouand men, he heard him igh and whiper oftly to him without tirring out of his place, You ubtile Greek Serpent, the Kings good Genius hath brought thee hither; yet when he came into the preence, and fell down, the King aluted him, and pake to him kindly, telling him, he was now indebted to him two hundred Talents; for it was jut and reaonable, that he hould receive the reward which was propoed to whooever hould bring Themitocles; and promiing much more, and
encouraging him, he commanded him to peak freely what he would concerning the affairs of Greece, Themitocles replied, that a man's Dicoure was like to a rich Perian Carpet variouly wrought and figured, the beautifull Images and proper Figures of which are bet repreented when they are clearly and fairly opened; but when they are contracted and folded up, they are obcured and lot, and therefore he deired He learns the Perian Language. time to learn the language perfectly, in which he was to expres his mind, and unfold his ecret ervices. The King being pleaed with the comparion, and bidding him take what time he would, he deired a year, in which time having learnt the Perian Language ufficiently he pake with the King by himelf without the help of an Interpreter: and thoe who were at a ditance thought that he dicoured onely about the affairs of Greece; but there happening at the ame time great alterations at Court, and removals of the King's Favourites, he drew upon himelf the envy of the great ones; who imagined, that he who had this great liberty might take the boldnes to peak many things concerning them: for the favours hewn to other Strangers were nothing in comparion of the honours conferred on him; the King inviting him to partake of his own patimes and recreations
both at home and abroad, carrying him with him a-hunting; and made him his intimate o far, that he permitted him not onely to come into the preence of the Queen Mother, but alo to wait upon her often, and convere familiarly with her. And beides this, he heard the Dicoures of the Magicians, by the King's epecial command; and was intructed in the ecret Philoophy and Magick of the Perians.

When Demaratus the Lacedemonian, being ordered by the King to ask whatoever he pleaed, and it hould immediately be granted him, deired the Royal Diademe, and that being lifted up on high he might make his publick entrance, and be carried in tate through the City of Sardis with the Imperial Crown of Peria upon his head, after the manner of Kings; Mithropautes Nephew to Xerxes, taking him by the hand told him, that he had no Brains for the Royal Diademe to cover; and if Jupiter hould give him his Lightning and Thunder, he would be ne'er the more Jupiter for that; the King alo repuled him with corn and anger, reolving never to be reconciled to him, but to be inexorable to all upplications on his behalf; yet Themitocles pacified him, and prevailed with him to forgive him: and it is reported that the ucceeding Kings in whoe Reigns there
was a greater communication between the Greeks and Perians than formerly, when they invited any coniderable Grecian into their ervice, to encourage him they would ignifie to him by Letters, that he hould be as great with them as Themitocles was with Xerxes. They relate alo how Themitocles when he was in great properity, and courted by many, eeing himelf plendidly erved at his Table, he turned to his Children and aid, Children, we had been undone if we had not been undone. Mot Writers ay, that he had three Cities given him Magneia, Myus and Lampacus, to maintain him in Bread, Meat and Wine. Neanthes of Cyzicus and Phanias add two more, the City of Percotes to provide him with Clothes, and Palaecepis with Bedding and Furniture for his Houe.

As he went down towards the Sea ide to provide againt the attempts and practices of the Greeks, a Perian whoe name was Epixyes Governour of the upper Phrygia laid wait to kill him; having for that purpoe provided a long time before a crew of Piidian murtherers, who were to et upon him when he came to reide in a City that is called Lyons-head: but Themitocles The Mother of the Gods appears to him. leeping in the middle of the day, the Mother of the Gods appeared to him in a Dream, and aid unto him; Themitocles,
never come at the Lyon's-head, for fear you fall into the Lyon's Jaws, for this advice I expect that your Daughter Mneiptolema hould be my ervant. Themitocles was much atonihed, and when he had poured forth his prayers, and made his vows to the Goddes, he left the great Road, and taking a compas about, went another way, changing his intended tation to avoid that place, and at night took up his ret in the Fields; but one of the Sumpter-hores which carried part of the Furniture for his Tent, having fallen that day into a River, his Servants pread out the Tapetry which was wet, and hanged it up to drie it: in the mean time the Piidians made towards them with their Swords drawn, and not dicerning exactly by the Moon what it was that was tretched out to be dried, they thought it was the Tent of Themitocles, and that they hould find him reting himelf within it; but when they came nigh, and lifted up the Hangings, thoe who watched there fell upon them and took them. Themitocles having ecaped this great danger, was in admiration of the goodnes of the Goddes that appeared to him; and in memory of it he built a Temple in the City of Magneia, which he dedicated to Cybele Dindymene Mother of the Gods, wherein he conecrated and devoted
his Daughter Mneiptolema unto her ervice.

When he came to Sardis he viited the Temples of the Gods, and oberving at his leiure their Buildings, Ornaments, and the number of their Offerings, he aw in the Temple of the Mother of the Gods the Statue of a Virgin in Bras two Cubits high, called the Water-bringer, or he that brought the Water back again into its right Chanel. Themitocles had caued this to be made and et up when he was Surveyor of the Aquaeducts at Athens, out of the Fines and Forfeitures of thoe, whom he had dicovered to have taken away the Water, or to have turned it out of its due coure, by other Pipes fitted for their private ue: and whether he had ome regret to ee this fair Image in Captivity, and the Statue of a Grecian Virgin kept Prioner in Aia; or whether he was deirous to let the Athenians ee in what great credit he was with the King, and what authority he had in all the Perian affairs; he entred into dicoure with the Governour of Lydia, to peruade him to end this Statue back to Athens, which o enraged the Perian Officer, that he told him, he would write the King word of it: Themitocles being affrighted hereat, got acces to his Wives and Concubines, whom he gained with money, and by their means mitigated the fury of the Governour; and
afterwards carried himelf more reervedly and circumpectly, fearing the envy of the Perians; and gave over travelling about Aia, and lived quietly in his own Houe in Magneia, where for a long time he paed his days in great ecurity, as Theopompus writes, being courted by all, and preented with rich Gifts, and honoured equally with the greatet perons in the Perian Empire; the King at that time not minding his concerns with Greece, being inceantly buied about the affairs of the upper Provinces.

But when Aegypt revolted, being aited by the Athenians, and the Grecian Galleys roved about as far as Cyprus and Cilicia, and Cimon had made himelf mater of the Seas, the King turned his thoughts, and bending his mind chiefly to reit the Grecians and to hinder their increaing power againt him, raied Forces, ent out Commanders, and dipatched M • engers to Themitocles at Magneia, to put him in mind of his promie, and to incene him and irritate him againt the Greeks; yet this did not increae his hatred nor exaperate him againt the Athenians, neither was he any ways elevated with the thoughts of the honour and powerfull command he was to have in this War; but either imagining that this undertaking could not properouly be carried
on, nor the King eaily compas his deigns, the Greeks having at that time great Commanders, and amongt them Cimon wonderfully uccesfull in the affairs of Greece; or chiefly being ahamed to ully the glory of his former great actions, and of his many Victories and Trophies; he determined to put a concluion to his days utable to his former great deeds, and to make an end agreeable to the whole coure of his life: he acrificed to the Gods, and invited his Friends, and having kindly entertained them, and haked hands with them, he drank Bulls Bloud, as the general report goes; but ome ay he took poion which He drinks Bulls Bloud. dipatched him in a hort time and ended his days in the City of Magneia, having lived ixty five years, mot of which he had pent in the State and in the Wars, in governing of Countries and commanding of Armies. The King being informed of the caue and manner of his death, admired him more than ever, and continued to hew kindnes to his Friends and Relations.

Themitocles left three Sons by Archippa Daughter to Lyander of Alopece; Archeptolis, Polyeuctus and Cleophantus. Plato the Philoopher mentions the latter as a mot excellent Horeman; but relates nothing ele of him worthy of memory: of his eldet Sons Neocles and Diocles, Neocles
died when he was young by the bite of a Hore, and Diocles was adopted by his Grandfather Lyander to be his Heir. He had many Daughters, of which Mneiptolema, whom he had by a econd Marriage, was Wife to Archeptolis, her Brother-in-law by another Mother; Italia was married to Panthedes of the Iland of Scio; Sybaris to Nicomedes the Athenian. After the death of Themitocles, his Nephew Phraicles et ail for Magneia, and married his Daughter Nicomachia, receiving her from the hands of her Brothers; and brought up her Siter Aia the younget of all the Children.

The Magneians poes the plendid Sepulchre His Tomb at Magneia. of Themitocles placed in the middle of their great Piazza, and it is not worth the taking notice of what Andocides writes to his Friends, concerning the Reliques of Themitocles; how the Athenians robbed his Tomb, and threw his Ahes into the Air; for he feigns this to exaperate the Nobility againt the people; and there is no man living but knows that Phraicles is mitaken in his Hitory, where he brings in Neocles and Demopolis for the Sons of Themitocles to incite or move compaion, as if he were writing of a Tragedy: yet Diodorus the Comographer writes in his Book of Sepulchres, but by conjecture rather
than of his certain knowledge, that near to the Haven of Piraea, where the Land runs out like an Elbow from the Promontory of Alcimus, and when you have doubled the Cape and paed inward where the Sea is always calm, there is a vat Foundation, and upon this the Tomb of Themitocles in the hape of an Altar; and Plato the Comedian eems to confirm this in thee Veres,
Thy Tomb is fairly placed on the Strand,
Where Merchants from all parts may pas or land;
Where Ships from every quarter come in ight,
And may engage in many a bloudy Fight:
So that thy Ahes placed on the Shore,
Both Sea and Land may honour and adore.

Divers honours alo and privileges were granted to the Kindred of Themitocles at Magneia, which were oberved down to our times; and another Themitocles of Athens enjoyed them, with whom I had a particular acquaintance and Friendhip in the Houe of Ammonius the Philoopher.

div.head: THE LIFE OF F. CAMILLUS.
div.byline: Englihed from the Greek, By Mich. Payne, Trin. Coll. Cant. Soc.
div.p:
AMong the many remarkable things that are related of Furius Camillus, this above all eems mot ingular and trange, that he who for the mot part was in the highet commands, and had performed the greatet Actions, was five times choen Dictatour, triumphed four times, and was tyled a Second Founder of Rome, yet never was o much as once Conul. The reaon whereof was the tate and temper of the
then Commonwealth; for the People being at diention with the Senate tifly refued to return Conuls, but in their tead elected other Magitrates called Military Tribunes, who though they acted every thing with full Conular Power and Authority, yet their Government was les grievous to the People, by reaon they were more in number: for to have the management of affairs entruted in the hands of ix perons rather than two, was ome eae and atisfaction to thoe who could not endure the Dominion of a few. This was the condition of the times when Camillus flourihed in the height of his actions and glory, and although the Government in the mean time had often proceeded to Conular Elections, yet he could never perwade himelf to be Conul, againt the good-will and inclination of the People. In all other his adminitrations which were many and various, he o behaved himelf, that when he was alone in Authority, his power was exercied as in common, but the honour of all actions redounded intirely to himelf, even when in joint Commiion with others; the reaon of the former was his moderation, commanding without pride or inolence; of the latter, his great judgment and wiedom, wherein without quetion he excelled all others. And whereas the Houe of the
Furii was not at that time of any coniderable quality, he was the firt that raied himelf to honour, erving under Pothumius Tubertus, Dictatour, in the great Battel againt the Aeques and Volces; for riding out from the ret of the Army, and in the charge receiving a wound in his Thigh, he for all that gave not over the fight, but plucking out the Dart that tuck cloe in the wound, and engaging with the bravet of the enemy, he put them to flight, for which action, among other rewards betowed on him, he was created Cenor, an Camillus made Cenor. Office in thoe days of great eteem and authority. During his Cenorhip one very good act of his is recorded, that whereas the Wars had made many Widows, he obliged uch as had no Wives, ome by fair perwaion, others by threatning to et Fines on their heads, to take them in marriage. Another neceary one, in cauing Orphans to be rated, who before were exempted from Taxes, the frequent and chargeable Wars requiring more than ordinary expences to maintain them. But that which pinched them mot was the Siege of Veii
The Siege of Veii. (ome call them Venetani.) This was the head City of Tucany, not inferiour to Rome, either in number of Arms or multitude of Souldiers, inomuch that preuming on her wealth and magnificence, and priding her
elf in the variety of pleaures he enjoyed, he had fought many a fair Battel with the Romans, contending for Glory and Empire. But now they had quitted their former ambition having been weakned and brought low in many notable encounters, o that having fortified themelves with high and trong Walls, and furnihed the City with all orts of Weapons offenive and defenive, as likewie with Corn and all manner of Proviions, they cheerfully endured the Siege, which though tedious to them, was no les troubleome and vexatious to the beiegers. For the Romans having never been accutomed to lie long abroad in the heat of Summer, and contantly to winter at home, they were then firt compelled by the Tribunes, to build Forts and Garrions in the Enemies Country, and raiing trong Works about their Camp to joyn Winter and Summer together. And now the eventh year of the War drawing to an end, the Commanders began to be upected as too low and remis in driving on the Siege, infomuch that they were dicharged and others choen for the War, among whom was Camillus then econd time Tribune. But at preent he had no hand in the Siege, his lot being to make War upon the Falices and Capenates, who taking advantage of the Romans being buied on all hands,
had much poiled their Country, and through all the Tucan War given them ore diverions, but were now reduced by Camillus, and with great loes hut up within their Walls.

And now in the very heat of the War an The trange accident of the Alban Lake. accident happened to the Alban Lake no les wonderfull than the mot incredible things that are reported, and by reaon no viible caue could be aigned, or any natural beginning whereto to acribe it, it became matter of great amazement. It was the beginning of Autumn, and the Summer before had neither been very rainy, nor in appearance over troubled with Southern winds, and of the many Lakes, Brooks and Springs of all orts wherein Italy abounds, ome were wholly dried up, others drew very little Water with them. But all the Rivers, as they contantly ued in Summer, ran in a very low and hollow Chanel.
