But the Alban Lake that is fed by no other waters but its own, being compaed about with fruitfull Mountains, without any caue, unles it were Divine, began viibly to rie and well, increaing to the feet of the Mountains, and by degrees reaching to the very tops of them, and all this without any violent toing, or agitation of its Waves. At firt it was the wonder of Shepherds and Herdmen, but when the Earth which like
a great Dam held up the Lake from falling into the lower grounds, through the quantity and weight of Water was broken down; and that in a violent tream it ran through the plow'd Fields and Plantations, to dicharge it elf in the Sea; it did not onely trike terrour in the Romans, but was thought by all the inhabitants of Italy to portend ome extraordinary events. But the greatet talk of it was in the Camp that beieged Veii, when once this accident of the Lake came to be known among them, and as in long Sieges it is uual for parties of both ides to meet and convere with one another; it happened that a Roman had A ubtile fetch of a Roman Souldier. gained much confidence and familiarity with one of the beieged, a man well vered in ancient learning, and had the reputation of more than ordinary skill in divination. The Roman oberving him to be overjoy'd at the tory of the Lake, and to mock at the Siege, told him that this was not the onely prodigy that of late had happened to the Romans, but that others more wonderfull than this had befallen them, which he was willing to communicate to him, that he might the better provide for his private affairs in thee publick ditempers. The man greedily embraced the motion, expecting to hear ome wonderfull ecrets, but when by little and little he had drill'd him
on in dicoure, and inenibly drawn him a good way from the Gates of the City, he natched him up by the middle, being tronger than he, and by the aitence of others that came running from the Camp, eized and delivered him to the Commanders. The man reduced to this neceity, and knowing that detiny is not to be avoided, dicover'd to them the ecret counels of his Country. That it was not poible the City hould be taken, untill the Alban Lake, which now broke forth and had found out new paages, was drawn back from that coure, and o diverted, that it could not mingle with the Sea. The Senate Ambaadours ent to Delphos. having heard and deliberated of the matter, decreed to end to Delphos to ask counel of that God; the Meengers were perons of the greatet quality, Cous Licinius, Valerius Potitus and Fabius Ambutus; who having made their voiage by Sea, and conulted the God, returned with other anwers, particularly that there had been a neglect of ome of their Country Rites relating to the Latine Feats. As for the Alban Water, the Oracle commanded, that if it was poible, they hould draw it from the Sea, and hut it up in its ancient bounds; but if that was not to be done, then they hould bring it down into Ditches and Trenches into the lower grounds, and o dry it
up; which meage being delivered, the Priets performed what related to the Sacrifices, and the People went to work, and turned the Water.

And now the Senate in the tenth year of the War taking away all other Commands created Camillus Dictatour, who choe Cornelius Scipio for his General of Hore; and in the firt place he made Vows unto the Gods, that if they would grant a happy concluion of that War, he would celebrate to their Honour the great Sports, and dedicate a Temple to the Goddes whom the Romans call Matuta the Mother, but from the Ceremonies which are ued, one would verily think he was Leucothea, for leading a Servant-maid into the ecret part of the Temple they there buffet her, and then drive her out again; and they embrace their Brothers Children, more than their own; and in the matter of Sacrifices ue the ame ceremonies as to Bacchus his Nures, and what is cutomary in the ad cae of Ino in remembrance of the Concubine. Camillus having made thee Vows, marched into the Country of the Falices, and in a great Battel overthrew them and the Capenates their Confederates; afterwards he turned to the Siege of Veii, and finding that to take it by aault The continuation of the Siege of Veii. would prove a difficult and hazardous attempt,
he cut Mines under ground, the Earth about the City being eay to break up, and allowing as much depth as would carry on the Works without being dicovered by the Enemy. This deign going on in a hopefull way, he without, gave aaults to the Enemy to divert them about the Walls, whilt they that worked underground in the Mines were inenibly, without being perceived, got within the Catle, under the Temple of Juno, which was the greatet and mot celebrated in all the City. It is reported that the Prince of the Tucans was at that very time at his Devotions, and that the Priet after he had looked into the Entrails of the Beat, hould cry out with a loud voice, That the Gods would give the victory to thoe that hould finih thoe Sacrifices: and that the Romans who were in the mines hearing the words, immediately pull'd down the Floor, and acending with noie and clahing of Weapons, frighted away the Enemy, and natching up the Entrails carried them to Camillus. But this may look like a Fable. The City being taken by torm, and the Souldiers buied in pillaging and gathering an infinite quantity of Riches and Spoil, Camillus from the high Tower viewing what was done, at firt wept for pity; and when they that were by, congratulated his good ucces,
he lift up his hands to Heaven, and broke out into this Prayer. O mot mighty Jupiter, and ye Gods that are Judges of good and evil actions, Ye know that not without jut caue, but contrained by neceity we have been forced to revenge our elves on the City of our unrighteous and implacable Enemies. But if in the viciitude of things, there be any calamity due, to countervail this great felicity, I beg that it may be diverted from the City and Army of the Romans, and with as little hurt as may be, fall upon my own Head. Having aid thee words, and jut turning about (as the cutom of the Romans is to turn to the right when they worhip or pray) he fell flat to the ground, to the atonihment of all that were preent. But recovering himelf preently from the fall, he told them, that it had ucceeded to his wih, a mall michance in recompence of the greatet good fortune.

Having acked the City, he reolved according as he had vowed to carry Juno's Image unto Rome; and the Workmen being ready for that purpoe, he acrificed to the Goddes, and made his upplications, that he would be pleaed to accept of their devotion toward her, and graciouly vouchafe to accept of a place among the Gods that precided at Rome: They ay, that the
Statue anwered in a low voice, that he was ready and willing to go. Livy writes that in praying, Camillus touched the Goddes, and invited her, and that ome of the tanders by cryed out, that he was willing. They who tickle mot for this Miracle, and endeavour to defend it, have the wonderfull fortune of that City on their ides, which from a mall and contemptible beginning attained to that greatnes and power which it could never have done, without thoe many and great manifetations of God upon all occaions appearing for it. Beides, they produce other Wonders of the like nature, as the often weating of Statues, and that they have ometimes been heard to groan, as likewie the turning aide of ome, and nodding and approving of others, as many of the Ancients have reported; and we our elves could relate divers wonderfull things which we have heard from men of our own time, which are not lightly to be rejected: but to give too eay credit to uch things, or wholly to disbelieve them, is equally dangerous, by reaon of humane infirmity, which hath no bounds or command of it elf, but is ometimes carried to upertition and dotage, otherwhile to the contempt and neglect of all Religion. But moderation is the bet, and to doe nothing too much. But Camillus,
whether puffed up with the greatnes Camillus's deportment upon the acking of Veii ditatfull to the Romans. of the action to have won a City that was competitour with Rome, and had held out a ten years iege, or exalted with the flattery of thoe that were about him, aumed to himelf more than became a civil and legal Magitrate. Among other things was the pride and haughtines of his Triumph, driving through Rome in a Charriot drawn with four White Hores, no General either before or ince having done the like; for the Romans eteem that carriage to be acred and peculiar onely to the King and Father of the Gods. This alienated the hearts of the Citizens from him who were not accutomed to uch pomp and bravery.

The econd pique they had againt him, was his oppoing the Law by which the City was to be divided; for the Tribunes of the People preferred a Law, that the People and Senate hould be divided into two parts, one of which hould remain at home, the other as the lot hould give it remove to the new-taken City. By which means they hould not onely have much more Room, but by the advantage of two great and fair Cities be better able to maintain their Territories, and the ret of their plentifull Fortunes. The People therefore who were now grown rich and numerous, greedily embraced it, and in great crouds, began
to tumult in the publick Courts, demanding to have it put to the Vote. But the Senate and ablet Citizens judging the Proceedings of the Tribunes to tend rather to the detruction than diviion of Rome, yet unable to bear up againt it themelves, flew to Camillus for aitence, who fearing to come to the open encounter, yet by continual flinging in new occaions to buy and employ their heads, made a hift to tave off the Law. For thee things he was direliht by the People. But the greatet and mot apparent caue of their hatred againt him, aroe from the tenths of the Spoil, the multitude having herein, if not o jut, yet a plauible pretence againt him. For it eems, as he went to the iege of Veii, he had vowed to Apollo, that if he took the City, he would dedicate to him the tenth of the Spoil. The City being taken Camillus unmindfull of his Vow. and acked, whether he was loth to trouble the Souldiers at that time, or that through multitude of buines he had forgotten his Vow; he uffered them to enjoy that part of the Spoils alo. Some time afterwards, when his Authority was laid down, he brought the matter before the Senate, and the Priets at the ame time reported out of the Sacrifices, that the anger of the Gods was portended, and that they were not to be appeaed without expiation and offerings.
The Senate decreed the obligation to be in force.

But eeing it was difficult for every one to produce the ame very things they had taken to be divided anew, they ordained that every one upon oath hould bring into the Publick the tenth part of his gains. This eemed very evere and grievous to the Souldiers, who ceaed not to murmur, that poor men, and uch as had endured o much labour and travail in the War, hould be forced, out of what they had gained and pent, to bring in o great a proportion; Camillus being aaulted by their clamour and tumults, for want of a better excue, betook himelf to the meanet of defences, by confeing he had forgotten his Vow; but they complained that he that then vowed the tenth of the Enemy, now levied it out of the tenths of the Citizens. Nevertheles, every one having brought in his due proportion, it was decreed that out of it a Bowl of may Gold hould be made and ent unto Delphos. But there was great The free contribution of the Roman Ladies to pacify Apollo. carcity of Gold in the City, and when the Magitrates were conidering where to get it, the Roman Ladies meeting together and conulting among themelves, out of the golden Ornaments they wore, contributed as much as went to the making the Offering; which in weight came to eight Talents
of Gold. The Senate, to give them the honour they had deerved, ordained that funeral Orations hould be ued at the obequies of Women, as well as Men, it having never before been a cutom that any Woman after death was publickly praied. Chuing out therefore three of the chief of the Nobility for Ambaadours, they ent them in a fair Veel, well man'd, and umptuouly adorned. It was winter, and the Sea was calm, however, it is remarkable, that being brought almot to the very brink of detruction, beyond all expectation, they ecaped the danger. For hard by the Iles of Aeolus, the Winds lacking, the Gallies of the Liparians came upon them, taking them for Pirates. But when they held up their hands in upplicant manner, the Liparians forbore violence, onely fatned their Ship and towed her into the Harbour, where they expoed to ale their Goods and Perons, adjudging them to be lawfull prize. But by the vertue and interet of one man Timeithius by name, who was Governour of that place, and ued his utmot peruaion, they were with much adoe dimied. Beides, he himelf joined ome of his own Veels with them, to accompany them in their voyage, and ait them at the dedication: for which he received honours at Rome according as he had
deerved. And now the Tribunes of the People War againt the Falices. again reuming the Law about the diviion of the City, the War againt the Falices luckily broke out, giving liberty to the Nobility to chue what Magitrates they pleaed, who thereupon choe Camillus military Tribune, with five other Aociates; Affairs then requiring a Commander of authority and reputation, and one well experienc'd in War; when the People had ratified the Election, Camillus marched with his Forces into the Territories of the Falices, and beieged Falerii a well-fenced City and plentifully tored with all necearies of War: And although he perceived it would be no mall work to take it, nor little time pent about it, yet he was willing to exercie the Citizens, and keep them doing abroad, that they might have no leaure, idleing at home, to follow the Tribunes into faction and edition. Which remedy the Romans contantly ued, like good Phyicians, to dipere abroad thoe violent Humours that diturb the Commonwealth. The Falerians, truting in the trength of their City, which was well fortified on all ides, made o little account of the Siege, that beide thoe that garded the Walls, the ret as in times of peace walked the Streets in their common Habits. The Boys went to School, and were led by their Mater to
play and exercie about the Town-walls; For the Falerians, like the Grecians, ued one publick School, to the end, their Children being brought up together, might betimes learn to convere and be familiar with one another.

This School-mater deigning to betray The treachery of the Falerian Schoolmater. the Falerians by their Children, led them out every day under the Town-wall, at firt but a little way, and when they had exercied brought them home again. Afterwards by degrees he drew them farther and farther, till at lat by practice he had made them bold and fearles, as if no danger was about them; at lat, having got them all together, he brought them to the Out-guard of the Romans and delivered them up, demanding to be led to Camillus. Where being come, and tanding in the middle, he aid, That he was the Mater and Teacher of thoe Children, but preferring his favour before all other obligations, he was come to deliver up his Charge to him, and in that the whole City. When Camillus had heard him out, he was truck with the horrour of o treacherous an Act, and turning to the Standers by, he aid, What a ad thing is War, which is begun and ended with much unjutice and violence! But to good men there are certain Laws even in War it elf, and victory is not o greedily to
be hunted after as not to refue the aitence of wicked and unrighteous actions; for it becomes a great General to rely on his own vertue, and not the deceit and treachery of others. Which aid, he commanded His deerved Punihment. his Officers to tear off his Cloaths, and bind his Hands behind him, and give the Boys Rods and Scourges, to punih the Traytour, and drive him back to the City. By this time the Falerii had undertood the treachery of the School-mater; and the City, as in uch a general Calamity it mut needs be, was full of lamentations and crys, the honourable Men and Women running in ditraction about the Walls and Gates, when behold the Boys came whipping their Mater on, naked and bound, calling Camillus, their Saviour, their God, their Father; Inomuch, that it truck not onely into the Parents, but the ret of the Citizens that aw what was done, uch an admiration and love of Camillus his Jutice, that immediately running into Counel, they ent Ambaadours to him, to reign whatever they had to his dipoal. Camillus ent them to Rome, where being brought into the Senate, they poke to this purpoe, That the Romans preferring Jutice before Victory, had taught them rather to embrace ubmiion than liberty; that they could not confes themelves to be o much inferiour in
trength, as they mut acknowledge them to be uperiour in vertue. The Senate remitted the whole matter to Camillus, to judge and order as he thought fit. Who taking a um of Money of the Falerians, and making a Peace with the whole Nation of the Falices, returned home: But the Souldiers, who expected to have had the Pillage of the City, when they came to Rome emptyhanded, railed againt Camillus among their Fellow-citizens, as a hater of the People, and one that maliciouly oppoed the interet of the Poor. Afterwards, when the Tribunes of the People again propoed the Law for dividing the City, Camillus of all others mot openly appear'd againt it, paring no pains, but inveying with all boldnes againt the Promoters of it; o that forcing and contraining the multitude, they dimied the Law, though contrary to their inclinations. But againt Camillus they had an implacable hatred. Inomuch, Camillus labours under two ad diaters. that though a great misfortune befell him in his Family (one of his Sons dying of a dieae) yet the commieration of his cae could not in the leat make them abate of their malice. And indeed he took this los with immoderate orrow, being a man naturally of a mild and tender dipoition; even that day, when the accuation was preferred againt him, he kept houe, and
was hut up a cloe Mourner with the Women. His Accuer was Lucius Apuleius. The Crime, Fraud in the Tucan Spoils; and accordingly it was given out, that there were found with him certain bras Gates part of thoe Spoils. The People were exaperated againt him, and it was plain they would take hold of the leat pretence and occaion to condemn him. Wherefore gathering together his Friends and fellow Souldiers, and uch as had bore command with him, a coniderable number in all, he beought them that they would not uffer him to be unjutly cruht under fale accuations, and left the mock and corn of his Enemies. His Friends having advied and conulted among themelves made anwer, that as to the Sentence they did not ee how they could help him, but that they would contribute to whatoever fine hould be et upon him: Not able to endure o great an indignity, he reolved in his anger, to leave the City, and go into Exile. Wherefore having taken leave of his Wife, His voluntary banihment, and his Son, he went ilently to the Gate of the City, where making a tand, and turning himelf about, he tretched out his Hands to the Capitol, and prayed to the Gods, That if without any fault of his own, but merely through the malice and violence of the people, he was driven out into banihment,
that the Romans might quickly have caue to repent of it; and that all mankind might viibly perceive, that they needed his aitence, and longed for his return. Thus, like Achilles, having left his imprecations on the Citizens, he went into banihment; o that neither appearing, or making defence, he was condemned in the um of fifteen thouand Aes, which reduced to Silver makes a thouand five hundred Drachma's; for an Ae was a little piece of Money, ten of which in Bras made a Penny. There is not a Roman but does believe that and its concomitant calamities. immediately upon the Prayers of Camillus, a udden Judgment followed at the heels, and that he received a ufficient revenge for the injutice done unto him; which though we cannot think was pleaant, but rather grievous and bitter to him, yet it was very remarkable, and noied over the whole World: For uch vengeance fell upon the City of Rome, and uch dimal times ucceeded, as drew along with them all manner of dangers and deaths, accompanied with digrace and infamy: Whether or no it fell out by chance or fortune, or it be the office of ome God not to ee injured Vertue go unrevenged. The firt token that eemed to threaten ome michief to enue, was the death of the Cenor in the Month of July, for the Romans have a religious reverence
for the office of a Cenor, and eteem it a acred thing. The econd was, That jut before Camillus went into exile, Marcus Cedicius, a peron of no great quality or of the rank of Senatours, but eteemed a ober and creditable man, reported to the Military Tribunes a thing worthy their conideration. That going along the Night before in that Street which is called the new Way, and being called by ome body in a huge voice, he turned about but could ee no body, but heard a voice bigger than a Man's, which aid thee words, Go, Marcus Cedicius, and early in the morning tell the Military Tribunes, that uddenly they are to expect the Gauls. But the Tribunes made a mock and port with the tory, and a little after Camillus his buines fell out.

The Gauls are decended originally of the Celtae, and are reported by reaon of The Gauls, their original and progres. their vat numbers to have left their Country not able to utain them all, and to have gon in earch of other places to inhabit. And being many thouands of them young Men and able to bear Arms, and carrying with them a greater number of Women and young Children, ome of them paing the Riphaean Mountains, fell upon the Northern Ocean, and poeed the uttermot bounds of Europe; others eating
themelves between the Pyrenaean Mountain and the Alpes, for a long time lived near to the Sennones and Celtorii. But afterwards tating of the Wine which was then firt brought them out of Italy, they were all o much taken with the Liquor, and tranported with the unuual delight, that natching up their Arms, and taking their Parents along with them, they marched directly to the Alpes to find out that Country which yielded uch Fruit, eteeming all others barren and unpleaant. He that firt brought Wine among them, and was the chief intigatour to draw them into Italy, is aid to be one Arron a Tucan, a man of Arron intrumental in bringing the Gauls into Italy. noble extraction, by nature not evil, but happened to be in thee untoward circumtances: he was Guardian to an Orphan, one of the richet of that Country, and much admired for his beauty, his name Lucumo; From his Childhood he had been bred up with Arron in his Family, and now grown up, he left not the Houe, pretending to take great delight in his converation, thus for a great while together he ecretly enjoyed Arron's Wife, corrupting and being corrupted by her. But when they were both o far gone on in their paions, that they could neither refrain their lut or conceal it, the young Man eied the Woman and openly carried her away. The Husband going to
Law, and overpower'd in multitude of Friends and Money, left his own Country, and hearing of the tate of the Gauls, went to them, and was Conductour of that Expedition into Italy. At firt coming they preently poeed themelves of all that Country which anciently the Tucans inhabited, reaching from the Alpes to both the Seas, as the names themelves witnes; for the North Sea Adria is o called from the Tucan City Adria, and that which lies on the other ide to the South is called the Tucan Sea. All the Country is well planted with Trees, has pleaant and rich Pature, and well watered with Rivers. It had eighteen fair and tately Cities, excellently eated for indutry and Trade, and plentifully provided for all pleaures and delights. The Gauls cating out the Tucans eated themelves in them: but thee things were done long before.

But the Gauls at this time were beieging Cluium a Tucan City. The Cluians ent to the Romans for uccour, deiring them to interpoe with the Barbarians by their Letters and Ambaadours. There were ent three of the Family of the Fabii perons of the greatet quality, and mot honourable in the City. The Gauls received them courteouly in repect to the name of Rome, and giving over the aault which
was then making upon the Walls came to conference with them, where the Ambaadours asking what injury they had received of the Cluians that they thus invaded their City, Brennus King of the Gauls miling made anwer, The Cluians doe us injury, Brennus's atyrical reply to the Roman Ambaadours at the Siege of Cluium. in that not able to till a mall parcel of ground, they mut needs poes a great Territory, and will not communicate any part to us, who are trangers, many in number and poor. In the ame nature, O Romans, formerly the Albanes, Fidenates and Ardeates, and now lately the Veiens and Capenates and many of the Falices and Volces did you injury; upon whom ye make War if they do not yield you part of what they poes, ye make Slaves of them, ye wate and poil their Country and ruin their Cities, neither in o doing are ye cruel or unjut, but follow that mot ancient of all Laws, which gives the things of the feeble to the trong, beginning from God and ending in the Beats, for all thee by nature eek, the tronger to have advantage over the weaker: Leave off therefore to pity the Cluians whom we beiege, let ye teach the Gauls to be good and compaionate to thoe that are oppreed by you. By this anwer the Romans perceived that Brennus was not to be treated with, o they went into Cluium and encouraged and tirr'd up the inhabitants to make a ally
with them upon the Barbarians, which they did either to try the trength of the Cluians, or to hew their own. The ally being made, and the fight growing hot about the Walls, one of the Fabii, Quintus Ambutus, being well mounted, and etting Spurs to his Hore, made full againt a Gaul, a man of huge bulk and tature, whom he aw was rode out a great ditance from the ret. At the firt he was not perceived through the harpnes of the encounter, and the glittering of his Armour that hindred the ight of him; but when he had overthrown the Gaul, and was going to gather the Spoils, Brennus knew him, and invoking the Gods Brennus by what incens'd to make War with Rome. to be witnees, that contrary to the known and common Law of Nations, which is holily oberved by all mankind, that he who came an Ambaadour hould act hotility againt him, he drew off his men, and bidding the Cluians farewell, led his Army directly to Rome. But not willing it hould look as if they took advantage of that injury, and were ready to embrace any light occaion and pretence of quarrel, he ent a Herald to demand the man in punihment, and in the mean time marched leaurely on. The Senate being met at Rome, among many others that poke againt the Fabii, the Priets called Feciales were the mot violent proecutours, who laying Religion before
the Senate, advied them that they would lay the whole guilt and expiation of the fact upon him that committed it, and o acquit the ret. Thee Feciales Numa Pompilius, the mildet and jutet of Kings, contituted the Conervatours of Peace, and the Judges and Determiners of all Caues by which War may jutifiably be made. The Senate referring the whole matter to the People, and the Priets there as well as in the Senate pleading againt Fabius, the multitude did o little regard their authority that in corn and contempt of it they choe Fabius and the ret of his Brethren Fabius choen Tribune in the expedition againt the Gauls.
Military Tribunes. The Gauls hearing this, in great rage would no longer delay their march, but hatned on with all the peed they could make. The places through which they marched, terrified with their numbers and uch dreadfull preparations of War, and conidering the violence and fiercenes of their natures, began to give their Countries for lot, not doubting but their Cities would quickly follow; but contrary to expectation they did no injury as they paed, or drove any thing from the Fields, and when they went by any City they cried out, That they were going to Rome; that the Romans onely were their Enemies, and that they took all others for their Friends. Thus whilt the Barbarians
were hatening with all peed, the Military Tribunes brought the Romans into the Field to be ready to engage them, being not inferiour to the Gauls in number (for they were no les than forty thouand Foot) but mot of them raw Souldiers and uch as had never handled a Weapon before; beides Neglect of religious duties, and multiplicity of Officers extremely prejudicial to the Roman affairs. they had neglected to conult the Gods, as they ought and ued to do upon all difficulties, epecially War, but ran on without taying for Priet or Sacrifice. No les did the multitude of Commanders ditract and confound their proceedings; for before upon les occaions they choe a ingle peron called Dictatour, being enible of what great importance it is in times of danger, to have the Souldiers united under one General, who had abolute and unaccountable power in his hands. Add to all that the remembrance of Camillus his cae was no mall hinderance to their affairs, it being grown a dangerous thing to command without humouring and courting the Souldiers. In this condition they left the City, and encamped by the River Allia about eleven miles from Rome, and not far from the place where it falleth into the Tyber, where the Gauls coming upon them, and they hamefully engaging without Order or Dicipline, were mierably defeated. The left Wing was immediately driven into the River and
there utterly detroyed: the Right had les damage, by declining the hock, and from the low grounds getting to the tops of Hills, from whence many of them afterwards drop'd into the City; the ret as many as ecaped (the Enemy being weary of the laughter) tole by night to Veii giving Rome for gone, and all that was in it for lot. This Battel was fought about the Summer Soltice, the Moon being at full, the very ame day in which formerly happened that ad misfortune to the Fabii, when three hundred of that name and Family were at one time cut off by the Tucans. But from this econd los and defeat, the day got the name of Allienis, from the River Allia, and till retaineth it. But concerning Remarkable occurrences relating to the obervation of particular days. unlucky days whether we hould eteem any uch or no, or whether Heraclitus did well in upbraiding Heiod for ditinguihing them into fortunate and unfortunate, as one ignorant that the nature of every day is the ame, I have dicoured in another place; but upon occaion of this preent ubject I think it will not be amis, to annex a few examples relating to this matter. On the fifth of June the Boeotians happened to get two ignal Victories, the one about Leuctra, the other at Geratus, about three hundred years before, when they overcame Lattamyas and the Thealians,
and aerted the liberty of Greece. Again on the ixth of Augut the Perians were worted by the Grecians, at Marathon, on the third at Plataeae as alo at Mycale; on the twenty fifth at Arbeli. The Athenians about the full Moon in Augut got a Sea Victory about Naxus under the Conduct of Chabrias; about the twentieth at Salamin, as we have hewn in our Book of Days. April was very unfortunate to the Barbarians, for in that Month Alexander overcame Darius his General at Granicum; and the Carthaginians on the twenty eventh were beaten by Timoleon about Sicily, on which ame Day and Month Troy eems to have been taken, as Ephorus, Callithenes, Damates and Phylarchus have related. On the other hand the Month July was not very lucky to the Grecians; for on the eventh day of the ame they were defeated by Antipater, at the Battel in Cranon, and utterly ruin'd; and before that in Chaeronea they were defeated by Philip, and on the very ame Day, ame Month and ame Year, they that went with Archidamus into Italy were there cut off by the Barbarians. The Carthaginians alo oberve the twenty eventh of the ame Month, as bringing with it the mot and greatet of their loes. I am not ignorant that about the Feat of Myteries Thebes was detroyed by Alexander;
and after that upon the ame twentieth of Augut, on which day they celebrate the Myteries of Bacchus, the Athenians received a Garrion of the Macedonians; on the elf ame day the Romans lot their Camp under Scipio, by the Cimbrians, and under the conduct of Lucullus overcame the Armenians and Tigranes. King Attalus and Pompey died both on their birth days. I could reckon up everal that have had variety of fortune on the ame day. This day called Allienis is one of the unfortunate ones to the Romans, and for its ake other two in every Month, Fear and Supertition as the cutom of it is more and more encreaing. But I have dicoured this more accurately in my Book of Roman Caues.

And now after the Battel, had the Gauls The Gauls imprudent managers of their Victory. immediately purued thoe that fled, there had been no remedy but Rome mut have wholly been ruined, and all thoe who remained in it utterly detroyed, uch was the terrour that thoe who ecaped the Battel had truck into the City at their return, and o great afterwards was the ditraction and confuion. But the Gauls not imagining their Victory to be o coniderable, and overtaken with the preent joy, fell to feating and dividing the Spoil, by which means, they gave leiure to thoe who were
for leaving the City, to make their ecape, and to thoe that remained to provide and prepare for their coming. For they who reolved to tay at Rome, quitting the ret of the City, betook themelves to the Capitol, which they fortified with trong Rampiers and Mounds, and all ort of Slings and Darts, in order to hold out a Siege. But their firt and principal care was of their Holy Things, mot of which they conveyed into the Capitol. But as for the conecrated The holy Fire preerv'd by the Vetals. Fire, the Vetal Virgins took it up and fled away with it, as likewie with other Holy Relicks. Some write that they preerved nothing but that ever-living Fire which Numa had ordained to be worhipped as the Principle of all things; for Fire is the mot active thing in nature, and all generation is motion or at leat with motion, all other parts of matter without warmth lie luggih and dead, and crave the influence of heat as their Soul, which when it comes upon them they preently fall to doing or uffering omething: wherefore Numa, a Why intituted by Numa. man very curious in uch things, and for his wiedom thought to convere with the Mues, did conecrate Fire, and ordained it to be kept ever burning, in reemblance of that eternal Power which preerveth and acteth all things. Others ay that that Fire was the ame they burned before the Sacrifices,
and was no other than what the Greeks call Purifying Fire, but that there were other things hid in the mot ecret part of the Temple, which were kept from the view of all except thoe Virgins which they call Vetals. The mot common opinion was that the Image of Pallas, brought into Italy by Aeneas, was laid up there; others ay that the Samothracian Gods lay there, telling a tory, How that Dardanus carried them to Troy, and when he had built that City, dedicated them there; that after Troy was taken, Aeneas tole them away and kept them till his coming into Italy. But they who pretend to undertand more of thee things, affirm, that there are two Barrels, not of any great ize, one of which tands open and has nothing in it, the other full and ealed up. But that neither of them is to be een but by the mot Holy Virgins: others think that they who ay this are deceived, becaue the Virgins put mot of their holy things into two Barrels, and hid them under ground in the Temple of Quirinus, and that from hence that place to this day bears the irname of Barrels. However it be, taking the choicet and mot venerable things they had, they fled away with them haping their coure along the River ide, where Lucius Albinus, a imple Citizen of
Rome, who among others was making his ecape, overtook them, having his Wife, Children and Goods in a Cart, who eeing the Virgins lugging along in their armes the Holy Relicks of the Gods in a helples and weary condition, he caued his Wife and Children to decend, and taking out his Goods, put the Virgins in the Cart, that they might make their ecape to ome of the Grecian Cities. This extraordinary devotion of Albinus, and repect to the Gods in uch an exigence of time, and extremity of his own affairs is o remarkable, as deerves not to be paed over in ilence. But the Priets that belonged to other Gods, and the mot ancient of the Senatours, uch as had run through many Conulhips and Triumphs, could not endure to think of leaving the City; but putting on their holy Vetures and Robes of State, and Fabius the High Priet performing the Office, they made their Prayers to the Gods, and devoting themelves as it were for their Country, ate themelves down in Ivory Chairs in the Market-place, and in that poture expected the uttermot of what hould follow. On the third day after the Battel, Brennus appeared with his Army at the City, and finding the Gates to tand wide open, and no Guards upon the Walls, he firt began to upect it was ome deign or tratageme,
never dreaming that the Romans were in o low and foraken a condition. But when he found it to be o indeed, he Brennus enters Rome. entered at the Colline Gate, and took Rome in the three hundred and ixtieth year or a little more after it was built, if it be likely that an exact account of thoe times has been preerved, when there is o much confuion and dipute in things of a later date. The report of the City's being taken preently flew into Greece, though in different and uncertain rumours, for Heraclides of Pontus who lived not long after thee times, in his Book of the Soul, relates that a certain report came from the Wet, that an Army proceeding from the Hyperboreans, had taken a Greek City called Rome, eated omewhere upon the great Ocean. But I do not wonder that uch a fabulous and bumbat Authour as Heraclides hould foit into the truth of the tory uch high-flown words as Hyperborean and Ocean. Aritotle the Philoopher appears to have heard an exact account of the taking of the City by the Gauls, but he calls him that recovered it Lucius, but Camillus his irname was not Lucius but Marcus, but this is poken by way of conjecture. Brennus having taken poeion of the City, et a trong Guard about the Capitol, and going himelf to view the City, when he came into the
Market-place, he was truck with an amazement at the ight of o many men itting in that order and ilence, oberving that they neither roe at his coming, or o much as changed colour or countenance, but without fear or concern leaned upon their Staves, and in that fullen majety ate looking one upon the other. The Gauls for a great while tood wondring at the object, being urpried with the trangenes of it, not daring o much as to approach or touch them, taking them for an Aembly of the Gods. But when one, bolder than the ret, drew near to M. Papirius, and putting forth his hand, gently touched his Chin, and troked his long Beard, Papirius with his Staff truck him on the Head and broke it, The Roman Senatours barbarouly murthered by the Gauls. at which the Barbarian enraged, drew out his Sword and lew him; this was the introduction to the laughter, for the ret of his fellows following his example, et upon them all and killed them, and continuing their rage dipatched all that came in their way; in this fury they went on to the acking and pillaging the Houes, for many days together lugging and carrying away. Afterwards they burnt them down to the ground, and demolih'd them, being incened at thoe who kept the Capitol, becaue they would not yield to ummons, or hearken to a urrender, but on the contrary
from their Walls and Rampiers galled the Beiegers with their Slings and Darts. This provoked them to detroy the whole City, and put to the Sword all that came to their hands young and old, Men, Women and Children. And now the Siege of the Capitol having lated a good while, the Gauls began to be in want of Proviion, wherefore dividing their Forces, part of them tay'd with the King at the Siege, the ret went to forage the Country, detroying the Towns and Villages where they came; but not all together in a Body, but in different Squadrons and Parties, and to uch a confidence had ucces raied them, that they carelely rambled about without the leat fear or apprehenion of danger. But the greatet and bet ordered Body of their Forces went to the City of Ardea where Camillus then ojourned, having ever ince his leaving Rome equetred himelf from all buines, and taken to a private life: but now he began Camillus tudious of upporting the declining tate of his Country. to roue up himelf and cat about, not how to avoid or ecape the Enemy, but to find out an opportunity how to be revenged of them. And perceiving that the Ardeans wanted not men, but rather heart and courage, through the unskilfull management of their Officers. At firt he began to deal with the young men, flinging out words among them, That they ought not to acribe
the misfortune of the Romans to the courage of their Enemy, or attribute the loes they utained by rah counel, to the conduct of thoe who brought nothing with them to conquer, but were onely an evidence of the power of Fortune; That it was a brave thing even with danger to repell a foreign and barbarous War, whoe end in conquering was like Fire to lay wate and detroy. But if they would be courageous and reolute he was ready to put an opportunity in their hands to gain a Victory without hazard at all. When he found the young men embraced the thing, he went to the chief Officers and Governours of the City, and having perwaded them alo, he mutered all that could bear Arms, and drew them up within the Walls, that they might not be perceived by the Enemy who was near; who having coured the Country, and returned heavy laden with booty, lay encamped in the Plains in a careles and negligent poture, o that the night coming upon them who had been diordered with Wine, there was a great ilence through all the Camp. Which when Camillus undertood by his Spies, he drew out the Ardeans, and in the dead of the night paing in ilence thoe grounds that lay between, he made himelf mater of their Works, and His Victory over the Gauls at Ardea. then commanding his Trumpets to ound, and his Men to hout and hollow, he truck
uch terrour into them, that even they who took the alarum could hardly recover their Senes: Some were o overcharged with Wine, that all the noie of the Aaylants could not awaken them: A few, whom fear made ober, getting into ome order, for a while reited; and o died with their Weapons in their hands. But the greatet part of them, buried in Wine and Sleep, were urprized without their Arms and dipatched: But as many of them, as by the advantage of the night, got out of the Camp, were the next day found cattered abroad and wandring in the Fields, and were pick't up by the Hore that purued them. The fame of this Action preently flew through the neighbouring Cities, and tirred up the Youth of all Parts to come and join themelves with him. But none were o much concerned as thoe Romans who ecaped in the Battel of Allia, and were now at Veii thus lamenting with themelves; O heavens, what a Commander has Providence bereaved Rome of, to honour Ardea with his Actions! And that City, which brought forth and nured o great a man, is lot and gone; and we detitute of a Leader, and living within trange Walls it idle, and ee Italy ruin'd before our eyes. Come, let us end to the Ardeans to have back our General, or ele, with Weapons in our
hands, let us go thither to him; for he is no longer a baniht man, nor we Citizens, having no Country, but what is in the poeion of the Enemy. They all agreed upon the matter, and ent to Camillus, to deire him to take the Command; but he anwered, that he would not, untill they that were in the Capitol, hould legally chue him; for he eteemed them, as long as they were in being, to be his Country: that if they hould command him, he would readily obey; but againt their conents, he would intermeddle with nothing. When this anwer was returned, they admired the modety and temper of Camillus, but they could not tell how to find a Meenger to carry thee things to the Capitol; and what was more; it eemed altogether impoible for any one to get to them, whilt the Enemy was in full poeion of the City. But among the young men, there was one Pontius Cominius, of indifferent birth, Cominius's hazardous attempt. but ambitious of honour; this man proffered himelf to run the hazard, but he took no Letters with him to thoe in the Capitol, let that being intercepted, the Enemy might learn the intentions of Camillus. But putting on a poor garment, and carrying Corks under it; the greatet part of the way he boldly travelled by day, and came to the City when it was dark: The Bridge
he could not pas, by reaon it was guarded by the Barbarians; o that taking his Cloaths, which were neither many nor heavy, and binding them about his head, he laid his body upon the Corks, and wimming on them, got over to the City. And avoiding thoe Quarters where he perceived the Enemy was awake, which he gueed at by the lights and noie; he went to the Carmentale Gate, where there was greatet ilence, and where the hill of the Capitol is teepet, and ries with craggy and broken tones. By this way he got up, though with much difficulty, by reaon of the abruptnes of the paage, and preented himelf to the Guards, aluting them, and telling them his name; he was taken in, and carried to the Commanders. And a Senate being immediately called, he related to them in order the victory of Camillus, which they had not heard of before, and told them the proceedings of the Souldiers, adviing them to confirm the Command to Camillus, as in whoe conduct alone, the whole Army abroad relied. Having heard and conulted of the matter, the Senate declared Camillus Dictatour, and Camillus voted Dictatour. ent back Pontius the ame way that he came; who, with the ame ucces that he came, got through the Enemy, without being dicovered and delivered to the
Romans, the Election of the Senate, who received it with great acclamations of joy; and Camillus coming to them, found twenty thouand of them ready in arms; with which forces, and thoe Confederates he brought along with him, which were more in number; he prepared to et upon the Enemy.

But at Rome ome of the Barbarians paing by chance that way by which Pontius by night had got into the Capitol, pied in everal places the print of his feet and hands, as he caught and clammered, and the Mos that grew to the Rock tore off and broken, and reported it to the King, who coming in peron and viewing it, for the preent aid nothing. the Trial, not willing to acquit him of the crime, proved by manifet circumtances, and yet unable to execute the Law, that noble action of his being always in their eyes by reaon of the place. fled, he drove furiouly to oppoe the puruers; inomuch that thoe who were got within the Camp preently turned back and followed him, and thoe that came flying from without, made head again and gathered about him, exhorting one another not to forake their General. who were forward and ambitious to command. Wherefore when the revolt of the Tuculanes was reported, they gave Camillus the charge of reducing them, chuing one of his five Collegues to go with him. And now when every one of them put in earnetly for the place, contrary to the expectation of all, he pat by the ret and choe Lucius Furius, the very ame man, who againt the judgment of Camillus, by rahly hazarding a Battel, had brought things to a dangerous and almot deperate condition; willing, as it hould eem, to hide and diemble that micarriage, and divert the hame.
