Which Arts, though
they could not drive out of Camillus the certain opinion he had of their Treaon, yet wrought in him a certain compaion for their repentance, o that he commanded them to go to the Senate and attone their anger, and himelf became interceour in their behalf, inomuch that their City was acquitted of all offences, and admitted into the freedom and privileges of Rome. Thee were the mot memorable actions of his ixth Tribunehip.

After thee things, Licinnius Stolo raied A dangerous Faction at Rome headed by Licinnius Stolo. a great Sedition in the City, by which the people fell to diention with the Senate, earnetly contending that of two Conuls one hould be choen out of the Commons, and not both out of the Nobility. Tribunes of the people were choen, but the Multitude violently oppoed the election of Conuls; things through this diention running into greater diorder, Camillus was the fourth time created Dictatour by the Senate, ore againt the will of the People; neither was he himelf very forward to accept it, as being unwilling to oppoe his authority againt thoe, who in many and great conflicts, had repoed ingular trut and confidence in him, and with whom he had done more things in military Affairs, than ever he had tranacted with the Nobility in civil: that now he was pitch'd upon
out of envy, that prevailing he might uppres the people; or failing, be uppret himelf. However, to provide as good a remedy as he could for the preent; knowing the day on which the Tribunes of the people intended to prefer the Law, at the ame time he proclaimed a general muter, and called the people from the Market-place into the Field, threatning to et heavy fines upon uch as hould not readily obey. On the other ide, the Tribunes of the people oppoed themelves to his threats, olemnly proteting to fine him in 50000 Drachmas of Silver, if he perited to hinder the people in giving their uffrages for the Law. Wherefore, either that he feared another banihment or condemnation, as not agreeable to his age, and misbecoming thoe great actions he had performed, or finding himelf not able to tem the current of the Multitude, which ran with a trong Camillus under bad circumtances reigns the Dictatourhip. and irreitible force, for the preent he betook himelf to his Houe, and afterwards for ome days together pretending indipoition of body, laid down his Dictatourhip, and the Senate created another Dictatour; who chuing Stolo, leader of this Sedition, to be General of hore, uffered that Law to take place, which was mot grievous to the Nobility, namely, that no peron whatoever hould poes above 500 Acres of Land.
Stolo exceedingly triumphed in the conquet he had gained, till not long after, he was found himelf to poes more than he allowed unto others, and o uffered the penalties of his own Law. And now the contention about election of Conuls coming on (which of all other dientions was the harpet, and from its firt beginning had adminitred mot matter of diviion between the Senate and the People) certain The econd invaion of the Gauls. intelligence arrives, that the Gauls again proceeding from the Adriatick Sea, marched directly towards Rome, and upon the very heels of the report manifet acts of hotility are related; that the Country through which they marched was all wated, and uch as by flight could not make their ecape to Rome, were dipered and cattered among the Mountains. The terrour of this War quieted the Sedition, o that the Nobility conferring with the Commons, and both joyning Councils, unanimouly choe Camillus the fifth time Dictatour. Who, though very ancient, as not wanting much of fourcore years, yet conidering the danger and neceity of his Country, did not as before pretend icknes or other excue, but readily undertook the charge, and lited his Soldiers. And knowing that the force of the Barbarians lay chiefly in their Swords with which they laid about them
in a rude and unskilfull manner hacking and hewing the Head and Shoulders; he Camillus's extraordinary proviions for the War. caued iron Murrions to be made for mot of his Men, moothing and polihing the outide, that the Enemies Swords lighting upon them might either lide off, or be broken; and round about their Shields he drew a little rim of bras, the wood it elf being not ufficient to bear off the blows. Beides, he taught his Soldiers in cloe engaging, to ue long Javelins or punchion Staves, which holding under their Enemies Swords would receive the force and violence of them. When the Gauls drew nigh about the River Anien, dragging a heavy Camp after them, and loaden with infinite Spoil, Camillus drew forth his Forces, and planted himelf upon a Hill of eay acent, and which had many hollow places in it, to the end that the greatet part of his Army might lie concealed, and thoe few which appeared might be thought through fear to have betaken themelves to thoe upper grounds. And the more to encreae this opinion in them, he uffered them without any diturbance to poil and pillage even to his very Trenches, keeping himelf quiet within his Works, which were well fortified on all ides: At lat, perceiving that part of the Enemy were cattered about the Country a-forraging,
and having advice that thoe that were in the Camp did nothing day and night but drink and revell, in the night-time he drew forth his lightet-armed men and ent them before, to oberve and watch the Enemy, and to be ready to hinder them from drawing into order, and to vex and dicompoe them when they hould firt iue out of their Trenches; and early in the morning he brought down his main Body, and et them in battel-array in the lower grounds, being a numerous and courageous Army; whereas the Barbarians had taken them for an inconiderable and fearfull party. The firt thing that abated the pride and courage of the The Gauls upon two accounts diheartned. Gauls, was, that they were to fight when they leat expected it, and that their Enemies had the honour of being aggreours. In the next place, the light-armed men falling upon them before they could get into their uual order, or range themelves in their proper quadrons, did o force and pres upon them, that they were obliged to fight confuedly and at random without any dicipline at all. But at lat, when Camillus brought on his heavy-armed Legions, the Barbarians with their Swords drawn went vigorouly to engage them; but the Romans oppoing with their Javelins, and receiving the force of their blows on that part of their Shield which was well guarded
with teel, they turned the edge of their Weapons, being made of a oft and ill-tempered metal, inomuch that their Swords immediately bent in their hands, and tood crooked to the Hilts; as for their Bucklers, they were pierced through and through, and grown o heavy with the Javelins that tuck upon them, that forced to quit their own Weapons, they endeavoured to make advantage of thoe of their Enemies; o that gathering up the Javelins in their hands, they began to return them upon the Romans. But the Romans perceiving They are vanquihed by the Romans. them naked and unarm'd, preently betook themelves to their Swords, which they o well ued, that in a little time great laughter was made in the foremot ranks, and the ret of them fled, dipering themelves all over the Champain Country; for as for the Hills and upper Grounds, Camillus had poeed himelf beforehand of them, and they knew it would not be difficult for the Enemy to take their Camp, eeing through confidence of victory they had left it unguarded. They ay this Fight was thirteen years after the acking of Rome, and that from henceforward the Romans took courage, and laid aide thoe dimal apprehenions they had conceived of the Barbarians; thinking now that their firt defeat, was rather the effect of icknes, and the
trange concurrence of evil chances than the teddy courage or true force of their Enemy. And indeed this fear had been formerly o great, that they made a Law, That Priets hould be excued from war-like ervice, unles in an invaion from the Gauls. This was the lat military Action that ever Camillus performed; for as for the City of the Velitrani, it was but a by acceion to this victory, it being urrendred unto him without any reitance. But the greatet contention in civil Affairs, and the hardet to be managed againt the People, was till remaining; for they returning home full of victory and ucces, violently inited, contrary to the ancient cutom, to have one of the Conuls choen out of their own body. The Senate trongly oppoed it, and would not uffer Camillus to lay down his Dictatourhip, thinking that under the helter of his great name and authority they hould be better able to contend for the power of the Nobility. When Camillus
The Tribunes their rude deportment toward Camillus. was itting upon the Tribunal, dipatching publick affairs, an Officer ent by the Tribunes of the people commanded him to rie and follow him, laying his hand upon him as ready to eie and carry him away; upon which uch a noie and tumult followed in the Aembly, the like was never heard of before; ome that were about Camillus,
thruting the people from the Bench, and the multitude below calling out to pull him down: Being at a los what to doe in this exigent of affairs, yet he laid not down his authority, but taking the Senatours along with him, he went to the Senate-houe; but before he entred, he beought the Gods that they would bring thee Troubles to a happy concluion, olemnly vowing, when the Tumult was ended, to build a Temple to Concord. A great contet ariing in the Senate, by reaon of contrary opinions, at lat the mot moderate and agreeable to the people prevailed, which yielded, that of two Conuls, one of them hould be choen of the Commonalty. When the Dictatour had proclaimed this determination of the Senate to the People, they were immediately (as it could not otherwie be) pleaed and reconcil'd with the Senate; and for Camillus, they accompanied him home, with all the expreions and acclamations of joy; and the next day being aembled together, they voted a Temple of Concord to be built according to The Temple of Concord why and when firt erected.
Camillus his Vow, facing the Aembly and Market-place; and to thoe Feats which are called Latines, they added one day more, making them four Fetivals in all; and for the preent they ordained that the whole people of Rome hould acrifice with
Garlands on their heads. In the election of Conuls held by Camillus, M. Aemilius was choen of the Nobility, and Lucius Sextius the firt of the Commonalty; and this was the lat of all Camillus's actions. In the year following a petilential icknes infected Rome, which beides an infinite number of the common ort, wept away mot of the Magitrates, among whom was Camillus. Whoe death cannot be called immature, if we conider his great Age, or greater Actions; yet was he more lamented than all the ret put together that then died of that ditemper.

div.head: THE LIFE OF PERICLES.
div.byline: Tranlated from the Greek, By Adam Littleton, D. D.
div.p:
CAear on a time eeing belike ome A moral Introduction. Strangers at Rome, who were people of Quality, carrying up and down with them in their Armes and Booms young Puppy-dogs and Monkeys, and hugging and making much of them, took occaion to ask, whether the Women in their Country were not ued to bear Children; by that Prince-like reprimand gravely reflecting upon uch perons, who pend
and lavih that affection and kindnes, which Nature hath implanted in us, upon brute Beats, which is due and owing to humane Creatures, thoe of our own kind. Now inamuch as even the Whelps and Cubs of Dogs and Apes have a kind of inclination to learning and knowledge, and love to look about them and to take notice of things, the Soul of Man hath by Nature a higher principle of Reaon, o as to find fault with thoe who make ill ue of that inclination and deire upon idle dicoures and ights that deerve no regard, while in the mean time they carelely pas by good and profitable things of that ort.

For indeed as to the outward Sene, that The advantage of the ndertanding above Sene. being paive in receiving the impreion of thoe objects that come in its way and trike upon it, it is peradventure neceary for it (the Sene) to entertain and take notice of every thing that appears to it, be it what it will, uefull or unuefull: but every man, if he will make ue of his ndertanding, hath a natural power to turn himelf upon all occaions, and to change and hift with the greatet eae to what hall eem to himelf mot fit. So that a man ought to purue and make after the bet and choicet of every thing, that he may not onely imploy his contemplation, but may alo be nourihed and improved by it. For as that Colour
is mot gratefull and agreeable to the Eye, whoe lively frehnes together with its pleaure and delightfulnes revives and cherihes the ight; o a man ought to apply his mind and reaoning to uch objects and notices, as with delight are apt to call it forth and allure it to its own proper good and peculiar advantage.

Now thee objects and notices are to be The Hitory of vertuous actions raieth an emulation to doe the like. met with in thoe works and performances which proceed from Vertue, which do alo infue and beget in the minds of readers, whilt they convere with the bare tories and narratives of them, a kind of emulation and forward cheerfulnes, which may lead them along and draw them on to an imitation. Foramuch as in other things of another nature there doth not immediately follow upon the admiration and liking of the thing done any trong deire of doing the like. Nay many times on the very Which doth not happen in things of Art or Skill. contrary when we are pleaed with the Work, we light and et little by the Workman or Artit himelf: as for intance, in Perfumes and Purple-dyes, we are taken with the things themelves well enough, but we look but meanly upon Dyers and Perfumers, as a ort of pitifull Trademen and orry Mechanicks. Whereupon it was not amis aid by Antithenes, when people told him that one Imenias was an excellent
Fidler or Piper; It may be o, aid he, but he is but a wretched paltry Fellow for all that: for otherwie he would not have been o excellent a Fidler; meaning that he would have found ome better buines to have employ'd himelf about than fidling and piping. And King Philip to the ame purpoe told his Son Alexander, who once at a merry meeting had ung with great pleaure and skill; Are not you ahamed, Son, to ing o well? For it is enough for a King or Prince to find leiure ometime to hear others ing; and he does the Mues no mall honour, when he pleaes to be but preent at uch exercies and trials of skill. Now he who buies himelf in mean employs, doth but bring that pains he takes about things of little or no ue, as an evidence againt himelf of his negligence and lothfull indipoition to vertuous and uefull practices. Nor would any generous and ingenuous young man, who hould behold the Statue of Jupiter, which tands in the City Pia, deire to be a Phidias, or that of Juno in the City Argos, to be a Polyclete, (the Workmen of thoe Statues;) or to be as good a Poet as Anacreon or Philemon or Archilochus, who had been delighted in reading of their Poems. For it doth not necearily follow, that if a piece of Work pleae for its gracefulnes, therefore he that wrought it deerves
our regard or envy. Whence it is that neither do uch things profit or advantage the beholders, upon the ight whereof there doth not arie a zeal which may put them upon imitation, nor an impule or inclination, which may move a deire and raie an endeavour of doing the like. But in ooth it is Vertue, which doth preently by the bare propoal of its actions o dipoe men, that they do at once both admire the things done and deire to imitate the doers of them. For as to the goods of Fortune, A Comparion betwixt the goods of Fortune and thoe of Vertue. we are fond of the poeion and enjoyment of them; but as to thoe of Vertue, we are in love with the practice and exercie of them: and thoe we are content to receive from others, but thee we had much rather our elves to impart and communicate to others. For that which is honet and vertuous doth by a practical force move men toward it elf, and doth intantly infue into them a trong inclination to practice, moralizing and influencing the beholder not with imitation but with the Hitory of the thing done, exciting and tirring up his reolution to doe it.

Wherefore we alo have thought fit to The reaon of the Parallel. pend our time and pains, and to continue them on in writing of the Lives of famous Perons; and we have compoed this Tenth Book upon that Subject, wherein are contained
the Life of Pericles and that of Fabius Maximus, (who managed and carried on the War againt Hannibal) men alike, as in their other vertues and good parts, o epecially in their mild and upright temper and demeanour, and in their being able to bear the cros-grain'd humours and foolih carriages of their fellow Citizens the Commoners, and their fellow Rulers, who hared with them in the charge of the Government; by which means they became both of them very uefull and erviceable to the interets of their Countries. Whether we do take a right aim at our intended purpoe it is left to the Reader to judge by thoe things he hall here find et down.

For as to Pericles, he was of that Tribe Pericles his Extraction. or Ward in Athens called Acamantis, and of that Company or Society of people called Cholargia, and of one of the chiefet Families and decents of the whole City both on his Father's and Mother's ide. For Xanthippus his Father, he who defeated the King of Peria his Lieutenant-Generals in the Battel at Mycale, took to Wife Agarite the Niece or Grand-child of Clithenes, who, like a brave Man as he was, drove out the race of Piitratus, and diolv'd and detroyed their tyrannical Uurpation, and moreover made a body of Laws, and ettled
uch a model of Government as was excellently well tempered and uited for the agreement and afety of the people.

She (his Mother) being near her time fancied in a Dream that he was brought His Mothers Dream. to Bed of a Lion, and within a few days after was delivered of Pericles, in other repects as to the hape of his Body without His Shape. fault; onely his Head was omewhat longih and diproportioned. For which reaon it was that almot all the Images and Statues that were made of him, have the Head covered with a Helmet: the Workmen belike not being willing to expoe him by hewing his deformity. But the Poets The Wits play upon his Head. of Athens plaid upon him, and called him < in non-Latin alphabet > , Schinocephalos, that is, Onion-pate, or Squill-pate. For that which in common language goes by the name of < in non-Latin alphabet > , a Squill or Sea-Onion, the Atticks do in their Dialect ometimes term < in non-Latin alphabet > , Schinos. And one of their Comick Poets Charinus in his Play called Chirones, that is to ay, The Racality or The worer ort of people, ays thus of him,
Old Chrone his Sire and Faction his Dam
In mutual embraces got this Sham;
The greatet Tyrant that we read of all,
Whom Gods above Iolt-head or Ioller call:
And again in another Play of his called Nemeis or The Revenge, he in this manner bepeaks him,
Advance thou Jove to entertain thy Guets,
And bring thy bleed Logger-head to th' Feats.
And Teleclides another of thoe Poets aith in mockery of him, that one while
Puzzled with nice affairs of State and Town
His grout-Head being overet hangs down.
And that another while
Onely from that long over-growing Pate
There doth arie much trouble to the State.
And Eupolis a third Poet in a Comedy of his called Demi, that is, The People of the Borroughs, making inquiry concerning every one of the Demagogues or Leading-men, whom he makes in the Play to come up from Hell, as Pericles comes to be named lat, he replies,
Why in the Devil's name 'mongt all the Dead
That lie below, hat brought us up the Head?

The Mater that taught him Muick, His Muick Mater. mot Authours are agreed was one Damon;
(whoe name they ay ought to be pronounced with the firt yllable hort.) Though Aritotle tells us that he was thoroughly practied to Muick with one Pythoclides. And as to Damon, it is not unlikely, that he being a hrewd cunning Sophiter as he was, did out of policy helter himelf under the name and profeion of a Muick-mater, on purpoe to conceal from the vulgar his ubtilty and skill in State-affairs. So that under this pretence he attended Pericles to intruct him in Politicks, and to teach him the myteries of Government, in the ame manner as the Anointer or Mater in a Fencing School ueth to wait upon a young Scholar that learns to Wretle. Yet for all that Damon did not o ecape publick notice, how he made ue of his Lyre or Harp for a covert and blind of another deign, but that he was banihed the Country by Otracim for ten years, as a bigotted intermeddler in the Government, and one that favoured arbitrary Power; and by this means gave the Stage occaion to play upon him. As for intance; Plato one of thoe Play-wrights brought in a peron putting the quetion to him, (under the name of Chiron, who had been Achilles his Tutour likewie in Muick) in this manner,
Firt I beeech thee, tell me, if thou can:
For, Chiron, thou, they ay, bredt up the Man.
meaning Pericles.

Moreover Pericles did by natches and by His Philoophy Reader. the by hear everal Lectures of Zeno Eleates, who dicoured and treated of natural Philoophy much at the ame rate as Parmenides did; onely that he had by exercie and practice gotten a kind of habit or knack of confuting any opinion right or wrong, and of baffling people by thwarting and oppoing whatoever they aid, and o running them aground that they did not know which way to turn themelves. And accordingly Timon the Phliaian hath given the account of him in this pair of Veres,
Zeno's great force, who poke to either part:
Confuted all, and never fail'd in's Art.

But he that was mot converant with His chief Tutour. Pericles, and furnihed him mot epecially with a weight and grandeur of Sene, and a more grave and olid reearch of thoe Arts by which the Populace is to be managed, and in the main heightned his Spirit and advanced the majety and grace of his addres and deportment, was Anaxagoras
the Clazomenian: whom the men of thoe times called by the name of < in non-Latin alphabet > , Nous, that is, Mind or ndertanding, whether in admiration of his great and extraordinary skill and knowledge, as it clearly appeared to be, in the affairs of Nature, or whether it were becaue that he was the firt of the Philoophers, who did not commit the Government of the World to Fortune or Chance, nor to Fatal Neceity, as the principle of that order we find things in; but preferr'd to the rule and manage of all other things, that are jumbled and huddled together, a pure and clear ndertanding, which ifts and culls out the parts alike from amidt thoe confuions.

This man Pericles did extraordinarily His accomplihments. eteem and admire, and being fill'd up to the brim with that they call lofty way of peaking and dicouring as it were on tiptoe, he not onely was, as we may judge, mater of brave and bold reentments, and of uch a train of harangue as was high in it elf and free from the taint of plebeian prate and lewd knavih buffoonry: but alo beide that, the very air of his Face and compoure of his Countenance grave and not any way moved to laughter, and the gentlenes and lownes of his pace and gate, and the decent ordering of his Apparel, o that no accident could dicompoe him in
the delivery of himelf, and the even unditurbed fahioning and tuning of his voice, and whatever other the like advantages he had, did make wonderfull impreions even to atonihment in all perons that either aw or heard him.

See but his patience and greatnes of An intance of his patience. mind! One time being reviled and ill poken of all day long in his own hearing by a villainous and ill-tongu'd Racal that cared not what he aid, he bore it patiently all along without returning him one word; all this in the open Court or the Aembly of the people, where he was at the ame time ingaged in the proecution and dipatch of ome weighty urgent affair. In the evening he went home in very good order, as one unconcerned, this Fellow dogging him at the heels, and pelting him all the way he went with all the hard words and Billingate language he could rake up. As he was ready to go into his Houe, it being by this time dark, he ordered one of his Servants to take a light and to go along with the man and ee him afe home: which was all the notice he took of him.

Now Ion the Poet aith that Pericles his His defence againt Ion's cenure. convere and carriage in company was haughty and urly, uperb and full of huff, and that he had a great deal of lightingnes and corn of others intermixt with his tate
and high thoughts of himelf; and on the other hand he commends Cimon's exact civility and eay compliance and gentile well-fahioned behaviour at every turn in all his converations. Well! but let us leave Ion to himelf, who eems to take it for granted, that Vertue hath by all means omewhat of the Satyrical part in it, as Tragedy hath: but as for thoe who micalled Pericles his gravity by the name of an affected otentation and grandeur of tate, Zeno advied uch perons, that they alo would try to affect the like garb of greatnes, inamuch as the very counterfeiting and aping of good qualities doth in time by tealth procure and beget a kind of emulation for thoe things and a familiarity with them.

Nor were thee the onely advantages Another advantage of his education. which Pericles had of Anaxagoras his acquaintance and keeping him company: but he eemed alo to be advanced by his intructions far above all that upertition, whatever it is, which as to Meteors and the like trange Appearances doth with frightfull apprehenions poes the minds of people, who are ignorant of the true caues, by which uch effects are naturally produced, and are mad as if the Devil were in them, and in great agony and diorder upon occaion of thee divine Prodigies by
reaon of their ignorance and want of skill about them: which ignorance natural reaon dicharging and freeing men from, intead of a dreadfull and unquiet troubleome upertition, works in them a free and generous devotion, together with good hopes and kindly aurances.

There is a tory that on a time Pericles A prodigy of a Ram with one Horn. had brought him from a Countryfarm of his a Ram's Head with one Horn, and that Lampon a Diviner or Fortune-teller, upon eeing the Horn grow trong and firm out of the midt of the Fore-head, gave The meaning of it. this for his judgment, that there being at that time two potent Factions, Parties or Interets, in the City, the one of Thucydides and the other of Pericles, the Government would come about to that one of them, in whoe Ground or Etate this token or indication of fate had happened: But that Anaxagoras, when he had cleft the The reaon of it. Skull in under, hew'd to the tanders by that the brain had not fill'd up its pan or natural place, but being harp, of an oval figure, had roll'd it elf together, from all parts of the veel which contain'd it, in a point to that place, from whence the root of the Horn took its rie; which was the reaon it grew ingle. And that for that time Anaxagoras was much admired, for
the account he gave, by thoe that were preent at the operation; and Lampon no les a little while after, when Thucydides being outed and laid aide all affairs of the State and Government came intirely into Pericles his hands and menage.

And yet in my opinion it is no aburdity The caue and end of Prodigies ought both to be heeded. to ay that they were both in the right, the natural Philoopher and the Fortune-teller, the one o luckily hitting upon the caue of this event, by which it was produced; the other upon the end, for which it was deigned. For it was the buines of the one to find out and give account, out of what it was made and in what manner and by what means it grew as it did; and of the other to foretell to what end and purpoe it was o made and what it might mean or portend. Now as to thoe who ay that to find out the caue of uch prodigious events is in effect to detroy any ignification they may be uppoed to have; thee men do not take notice, that at the ame time together with divine Prodigies (the tokens of God's pleaure or dipleaure) they defeat and render of no ue thoe igns and marks which are contrived by art; uch as are for intance, the clahings and clatterings of Quoits or Trenchers, and the lights of Watch-towers along the Seaide, and the hadows of the Pins of Sundials;
every of which things is made by ome caue and contrivance to be a ign of ome other thing. But thee are ubjects that peradventure would better befit ome other conideration than what we are now upon.

Now Pericles, being yet but a young man tood in great awe of the people and His reemblance of Piitratus. was mightily afraid of giving them any occaion of offence: foramuch as he appear'd in hape and feature to be very like the Tyrant Piitratus, and the grave Seniours of the Town, who remember'd that man, when they took notice of the weetnes of this man's voice and the volubility and readines of his tongue in dicouring, were truck into amazement at the mere reemblance of this to the other. But he conidering that he had a very fair Etate, and was decended of a noble Family as any, and had tore of Friends who bore the greatet way, was o far from truting to thee advantages, that he apprehended they might procure him to be banihed as a dangerous peron; and for this reaon he medled not at all with State-affairs, but in the ervices of War he hew'd himelf a brave man and one who with undaunted courage would expoe himelf upon all occaions.

But as oon as Aritides was dead, and His firt rie in the State. Themitocles turn'd out of the Saddle, and eeing that Cimon was for the mot part kept abroad by thoe expeditions he made in foreign Parts out of Greece, then did Pericles eeing things in this poture apply himelf to the State, intead of the rich and the few great Dons, making choice of uch matters and caues wherein the common people and poorer ort were concern'd, and ided with them; which was a thing omewhat beide his natural temper, for he was not of himelf given to popularity or mean compliances. But, as it is very likely, fearing he might by reaon of thoe advantages we mention'd fall under a upicion and jealouy of etting up for Kinghip or arbitrary Power, and eeing how Cimon courted the Aritocracy or chief men of the Government and was mightily beloved by all honet men and people of fahion, he took another way to the wood and helter'd himelf among the croud and herd of the common people: by which means he did at once both ecure himelf and procure an interet to erve him, when time hould be, againt Cimon.

And beides preently upon his application His reervednes. to State-affairs he took a quite different coure from what others and himelf had ued as to his order of life and management
of himelf. For he was never een to walk in any treet or way at Athens, but onely that which led to the Court or Town-hall, where the people aembled, and to the Senate or Parliament Houe, where the Lords ate in Council; and he avoided and left off the invitations of Friends to upper and all uch kind of friendly treatment and neighbourly acquaintance: o that in all the time he had to doe with the publick, which was not a little, he was never known to have gone to any of his Friends to a upper; onely once and that was at a Wedding, when his near Kinman Euryptolemus, his Siter's Son, married, he taid till the ceremony of the Drink-offering, and then immediately roe from Table and went his way. For thee friendly Meetings and Treats are hrewd things to get the upper-hand of an affected greatnes, and are apt to dicompoe a tarcht gravity and put it out of countenance; nor can the olemnity of a man's reputation be well preerv'd and maintain'd by ordinary convere and familiarity. And yet in that which is Vertue free and open. true and genuine vertue, thoe things appear the fairet, which are mot apparent and leat reerv'd; and there is not of good and brave men any thing o fit to be admired by trangers, as their daily life and converation is by thoe of their family and
who keep them continual company. But our States-man here to avoid the throng and glut of the people, did as it were by intervals, by natches and fits, come among them, not peaking to every buines, nor at all times coming into the Aembly, but, (as Critolaus aith the Athenians did with the three-oar'd Galley of Salamis,) reerving himelf for great occaions, other matters of leer importance he dipatch'd by Friends or by other Counellers at the Bar his Cronies. And of this number we are told Ephialtes made one, he who broke up the power of the Areopagites, the Council Ephialtes a Friend of his. that ate on Mars his Hill, and by that means (according to Plato's expreion) gave the Citizens a large and racy draught of liberty, which et the people o a-gog, as the Play-wrights inform us, that like a wild unruly Hore, that had flung his Rider, they would be ruled no longer, but champed and bit Euboea, and flounced and curvetted upon the other Iles.

Now Pericles deigning to fuit the gravity His Rhetorick or way of expreing himelf. of his life and the greatnes of his pirit and ene with a befitting character of peech, he to put that as it were a muical Intrument in tune, put his Tutour Anaxagoras often upon the tretch, and by a kind of Bow-dy glos et off thoe accounts he
gave of Nature with artificial Rhetorick. For having beide his great natural parts by the tudy of nature attained this height of undertanding and ability of turning and winding every thing to his own purpoe (to ue the words of divine Plato) and drawing whatever might be of advantage into the Art of peaking, he got the tart of all others by much.

Upon which account they ay he had Why called Olympius. the irname or nickname of Olympius given him, (the ame title that Jupiter himelf was called by;) though ome are of opinion he was o named for thoe famous works and publick buildings, wherewith he adorn'd the City, others would have him o called from the great power he had in publick affairs whether of war or peace. Nor is it unlikely or aburd to imagine, that from the confluence of thoe many good qualities, which belonged to the man himelf, the glory of uch a Title might be conferred upon him. However the Comedies of the then Maters of the Stage, who both in good earnet and out of merriment too, let fly many hrewd words at him, do plainly hew that he got that appellation epecially upon the account of his being an able Speaker, by aying that he thunder'd and lightned, when he harangued the people, and that he carried a dreadfull Thunderbolt in his Tongue.

There is a aying alo of Thucydides the Thucydides his Remark upon him.
Mileian tands on record, poken by him pleaantly enough upon Pericles his hrewdnes of peech. For Thucydides was a peron one of them of great credit and repute, and one who had for a very long time bandied againt Pericles in the Government. Now when Archidamus the King of the Lacedaemonians asked him, whether he or Pericles were the better Wretler, he made this anwer; When I, aith he, have thrown him and given him a fair fall, he by tanding out in the denial aying that he had no fall gets the better of me, and peruades people into a belief of what he ays whether they will or no, though they aw the quite contrary.

Howbeit the truth of it is that Pericles His care of peaking in publick. himelf was very wary and carefull what and how he was to peak, inomuch that always whenever he went up to the Tribunal or into the Pulpit to deliver himelf, he prayed to the Gods, that no one word might unawares againt his will lip from him, which hould be misbecoming or unuitable to the matter in hand and the occaion he was to peak to.

Indeed he hath left nothing in writing Some of his notable Sayings. behind him, ave onely ome popular Decrees or Ordinances. And there are but few in all of his notable Sayings which are recorded;
recorded; as this for one, that he gave order that they would take away the City and Ile of Aegina (then poet by the Enemy) as an Eye-ore from the Piraeum, a port of Athens; and this for another, that he fancied he aw a War coming along towards them out of Peloponneus (now called the Morea.) Again, when on a time Sophocles, who was his Fellow-commiioner in the Generalhip, was going on board with him, and praied the beauty of a Boy they met with in the way to the Ship, Sophocles, aith he, a General ought not onely to have clean hands, but eyes too; meaning that a peron in uch an office and charge hould not give way even to the temptations of ight. And moreover Steimbrotus hath this paage of him, that as he was in an encomiatick Oration peaking of thoe who fell in the battel at Samos, he aid they were grown immortal, as the Gods were. For, aid he, we do not ee them themelves, but onely by thoe honours we pay them and by thoe good things which they do injoy, we gues and judge them to be immortal. And the very ame cae it is, went he on, with thoe that dye in the ervice and defence of their Country.

Now whereas Thucydides makes uch a decription of Pericles his Aritocratical An account of his Politicks.
government, that it went by the name of a Democracy, but was indeed a government by a ingle peron, to wit under the conduct and at the pleaure of one man who was chief; and many others ay that by him the common people was firt brought on and led along to the haring of Lands by lot, taken from the Enemy, and to the dividing of publick moneys (formerly reerved for the ues of war) to be allowed them for eeing of Plays and Shows, and to ditributions of Salaries, by which means being ill accutomed, of a ober, modet, thrifty people that maintained themelves by their own labours, they became riotous and debauched through the methods of policy then ued; let us conider the caue of this change in the things themelves as to matter of fact.

For indeed at the firt (as hath been aid) His rivalling of Cimon. when he et himelf againt Cimon's great authority, he did cares the people what he could and under hand curry favour with them. But finding himelf come hort of his Competitour in wealth and moneys, by which advantages the other was inabled to take care of the poor, inviting every day ome one or other of the Citizens that was in want to upper, and betowing cloaths on the aged people, and breaking down the hedges and incloures of Grounds, to
the intent that all that would might freely gather what fruit they pleaed; Pericles being nubb'd and kept under by thee popular arts did by the advice of one Demonides Ienis, turn himelf to the ditribution of the publick moneys, as Aritotle hath told His dipoal of publick moneys among the people. the tory; and in a hort time having decoy'd and won the people what with thoe moneys allowed for Shows and for Courts of Jutice, and what with other bribes and largees and upplies, he made ue of thee methods againt the Council of Areopagus,
His deign againt the Council of Areopagus. of which he himelf was no member, as having not been choen by lot, either Annual Magitrate, or Guardian of the Laws, or King that is Governour of the acred Rites, nor Chieftain of the Wars. For of old thee Offices were conferr'd on perons by lot, and they who had acquitted themelves well in the dicharge of thee truts were advanced and taken into the Court of Areopagus. Whereupon Pericles having gotten o great a power and interet with the Populace, imbroiled and routed this Council, o that mot of thoe Caues and Matters which had been ued to be tried there were through Ephialtes his aitance dicharged from the cogniance of that Court, and Cimon was banihed by Otracim upon pretence of his being a favourer of the Lacedaemonians
He procures Cimon to be banihed. and a hater of his own people
of Athens, notwithtanding that he was one who came behind none of them all for greatnes of etate and noblenes of birth, and that he had won everal famous and ignal Victories upon the Barbarians, and with a great deal of monies and other poils of war taken from them had mightily inriched the City; as in the hitory of his Life hath been et down. So vat an authority had Pericles gotten among the people.

The Otracim, or banihment by Shells, I mentioned, (which they us'd in uch Trials) was limited by Law to ten years, during which term the peron banihed was not to return. But the Lacedaemonians in After a battel with the Lacedaemonians, the mean time making an inroad with a great Army on the Country of Tanagra, (which lay upon the Attick borders;) and the Athenians going out againt them with their Forces, Cimon coming from his banihment before his time was out, put himelf in arms and array with thoe of his Fellow-citizens that were of his own tribe, and reolved by his deeds to wipe off that fale accuation of his favouring the Lacedaemonians, by venturing his own peron along with his Country-men. But Pericles his Friends gathering in a body together drove him away as one under the entence of exile, and forced him to retire. For which
caue alo Pericles eems to have laid about him the more, behaving himelf very valiantly and toutly in the fight, and to have been the gallantet man among them all in the action of that day, having expoed himelf to all hazard and hardhip. All Cimon's Friends alo to a man fell together in that Battel, whom Pericles had impeached as well as him of taking part with the Lacedaemonians. And now the Athenians heartily wherein the Athenians had the wort, repented them for what they had done to Cimon and long'd to have him home again, being in the cloe of this Fight beaten and worted upon the confines and borders of their own Country, and expecting a ore war to come upon them next Spring or Summer eaon. All which Pericles being he recalls Cimon from banihment. enible of did not boggle or make any delay to gratify the peoples deire, but having wrote an Edict or Order for that purpoe himelf re-call'd the man home. And he upon his return concluded a peace betwixt the two Cities: for the Lacedaemonians had a repect and kindnes for him, as on the contrary they hated Pericles and the ret of the Demagogues or Leading-men.

Yet ome there are do ay that Pericles did not write that Edict or Order for Cimon's He and Cimon reconciled upon terms, revocation and return, till ome private Articles of agreement had been made
between them, and that by means of Elpinice, Cimon's Siter. Which were that Cimon hould go out to Sea with a Fleet of two hundred Ships and hould be Commander in chief of all the Forces abroad, with a deign to harras and lay wat the King of Peria's Countrys and Dominions, and that Pericles hould have the power at home and govern in the City.

This Elpinice, it is thought, had before having hewn him favour before for his Siter's ake. this time procured ome favour for her Brother Cimon at Pericles his hands and made him more remis and gentle in drawing up and etting home the charge, when Cimon being tried for his life ecaped the Sentence of death and was onely banihed. For Pericles was one of the Committee appointed by the Commons to implead him. And when Elpinice made her applications to him and beought him in her Brother's behalf, he with a mile in merriment aid, O Elpinice, you are too old a woman to undertake uch buinees as this is. Moreover when he came to the Bar to impeach him, he tood up but once to peak, as if he made light of his commiion playing booty as it were, and went out of Court having done Cimon the leat prejudice of any of his Accuers.

How then can one believe Idomeneus,
He is clear'd from the upicion of Ephialtes his death. who charges Pericles, as if he had by treachery
contrived and order'd the murther of Ephialtes the Demagogue or Couneller of State, one who was his Friend and of his Party in the menage of the Government; out of a jealouy forooth, aies he, and an envy of his great reputation. This Hitorian, it eems, having raked up thee Stories I know not out of what Kennel, has thrown them up like vomiting tuff to bepatter this worthy man, one who perchance was not altogether free from fault or blame, but yet was one who had a generous noble pirit and a oul that affected and courted honour; and where uch qualities are, there can no uch cruel and brutal paion find harbour or gain admittance. But as to Ephialtes the truth of the Story, as Aritotle hath told it, is this, that having made himelf formidable to the Oligarchits (thoe who would have all the power lodged in ome few hands) by being a evere aerter of the peoples rights in calling to account and proecuting thoe who any way injured them, his Enemies lying in wait for him did, by the means or help of Aritodicus the Tanagrian, privately rid themelves of him and dipatcht him out of the way.

Now Cimon while he was Admiral ended After Cimon's death his days in the Ile of Cyprus. And the Aritocratians (thoe who were for the
Nobles) eeing that Pericles was already even formerly grown to be the greatet and formot man of all the City, and being withall willing there hould be ome body et up againt him to give him check and to blunt and turn the edge of his Power, that it might not without more adoe prove a Monarchy; they et up Thucydides
he hath Thucydides et up againt him. of Alopecia, a ober dicreet peron and a near Kinman of Cimon's, to take up the Cudgels againt him. Who indeed though he were les skill'd in warlike Affairs than Cimon was, yet was better vered in the Courts of Law and buines of State; who keeping cloe guard in the City and being ingaged with Pericles in the pleading place, where the publick Harangues were made, in a hort time brought the Government to an equal interet of parties. For he would not uffer thoe who were call'd the Honet and Good (perons of worth and fahion) to be catter'd up and down and jumbled in a huddle with the Populace as formerly, by that means having their honour and credit mutted and darkned by the mixture of the Rabble: but taking them apart by themelves and gathering into one the power and interet of them all, which was now grown coniderable, he did as it were upon the balance make a counterpoie to the other party.

For indeed the contrat of the two parties They become Heads of two Parties. at firt was but as a thing of ecret grudg, that made but a hallow impreion, like a thing cut upon Iron, and barely ignified the difference of a Popular and an Aritocratical deign; but the open quarrel and canvaing ambition of thee two men, gave the City a very deep gah, o that the one Party was called the Populace or Commons, the other the Few or Great ones; Whiggs and Tories.

Upon which account Pericles, at that Pericles his arts to cajole the people. time epecially, letting looe the reins to the people, managed things all to their content, contriving continually to have ome great publick hew or feat or olemnity, ome entertainment and divertiement or other in Town, to pleae them, wheedling and cokeing the Citizens, as a School-mater doth his Boys, with uch delights and carees, as were not unediying neither. Beides that every year he ent out threecore Galleys, on board of which there went everal of the Citizens, who were in pay eight months, learning at the ame time and practiing the Art of Navigation, that they might prove good Seamen.

Moreover he ent a thouand of them He ends Plantations abroad. into the Cheronee in the nature of Planters to hare the Land among them by lot, and
five hundred more into the Ile of Naxos, and half that number into the Ile of Andros, and a thouand into Thrace to dwell among the Bialtae a people there; and others into Italy, when the City Sybaris was to be re-peopled, the inhabitants whereof went by the name of the Thurians. And this he did to eae and dicharge the City of an idle, and by reaon of their idlenes, a buie meddling rabble of people, who, having little to doe of their own, would have made work by giving diturbance to the publick; and withall at the ame time to provide for the neceities of the poor Townmen by upplying them and etting them to rights, and to put an awe and a guard upon their allies from attempting any thing of change by ending them to dwell among them.

But that which gave mot pleaure and He raieth tately Buildings in the City. ornament to the City of Athens and the greatet admiration even to atonihment to all Strangers, and that which alone doth ufficiently witnes for all Greece, that that power of hers that is o much talk'd of, and her ancient wealth was no Romance or idle Story, was that glorious apparade and furniture of thoe tately publick Buildings and Dedications which Pericles caued to be raied and made there. This was that For which he is hardly poken of. of all his actions in the Government which
his Enemies look'd aquint at and fell foul upon in the popular Aemblies, crying out how that the Commonwealth of Athens had lot its reputation and was ill poken of abroad, for removing the common Bank and publick Moneys of all the Grecians from the Ile of Delos, where it was to have been kept, and taking it into their own cutody; and how that that, which was the fairet excue they had to plead for their o doing, to wit, that they took it away thence, for fear of the Barbarians let they hould eize it, and on purpoe to ecure it in a afe place, Pericles had broke the neck of that pretence by putting it to other ues; and how that Greece cannot but reent it as an unufferable affront, and mut needs look upon her elf as treated after a tyrannical manner, when he ees that that Treaure which was upon a neceity contributed by her for the ue and maintenance of War is wantonly lavihed out by us upon our City to guild her all over, and to adorn and et her forth, as it were ome proud tately Dame, hung round with pretious Stones, and Statues, and umptuous Temples, which cot a world of Money.

Wherefore Pericles on the other hand informed His Apology and Vindication of himelf. the State, that they were no manner of way obliged to give any account of
thoe Moneys to their Friends and Allies, inamuch as they fought and maintained a War in their defence and kept off the Barbarians from attacking them and haraing their Country, while in the mean time they did not o much as et out Hore or Man or Ship, but onely found Money for the Service; which Money, ays he, is not theirs that give it, but theirs that receive it, if o be they perform the conditions upon which they receive it. And that it was good reaon, that the City being ufficiently provided and tored with thoe things that are neceary for the War, they hould convert the overplus of its Wealth to uch undertakings and deigns, as would hereafter, when they were finihed, eternize their fame, and for the preent, while they are a doing, will readily upply all the inhabitants with plenty; there appearing uch variety of all kind of workmanhip and everal orts of occaions for ervice, which being they do ummon all Arts and Trades and require all hands to be imployed about them, they do actually put the whole City in a manner into State-pay; o that at the ame time he is beautified and maintained by her elf at her own cot and charge. For as thoe who are of age and trength for War are provided for and maintained in the Armies abroad by their pay out of the
publick Stock; o it being his deire and deign that the rude multitude that taid at home and were vert in Handi-crafts hould not go without their hare of publick Salaries, and yet that they hould not have them given them for itting till and doing nothing, to that end he thought fit to bring in among them, with the approbation of the State, thoe vat projects of Buildings, and deigns of Works, that would be of ome continuance e'er they be finihed, which will imploy undry Arts and Occupations. That o that part of the people, that taid in the City and kept home, might, no les than thoe that were at Sea or in Garrion or under Arms, have a fair pretence and jut occaion of receiving the benefit and having their hare of the publick Moneys.

For here in this cae the Materials or The advantage of thoe publick Works to the people of the Town. tuff were Stone, Bras, Ivory, Gold, Ebony, Cypres; and the Arts or Trades that wrought and fahioned them were Smiths and Carpenters, Image-makers and Plaiteres, Founders and Braiers, Stone-cutters or Carvers and Maons, Dyers and Stainers, Gold-miths, Ivory-cutters, Painters or Picture-drawers, Embroiderers, Turners: now thoe that imported thee things and conveyed them up to Town for ue, were Merchants, and Mariners, and Maters of Ships
by Sea; and thoe who brought and help'd to bring them by Land were Waggoners and Cartwrights, Carriers and thoe that let Hores to hire, Carters and Muletiers, Ropemakers, Workers in Stone, Shoe-makers and Leather-dreers, Surveyours and Menders of High-ways, Pioneers and Diggers in Mines. Now every Trade and Mytery, in the ame nature, as a Commander or Captain in an Army hath his particular Company of Souldiers under him, had its own hired and peculiar Company of Journey-men and Labourers belonging to it banded and pack'd together as in array, to be as it were the intrument and body for the performance of the ervice. To ay all in a word, the occaions and ues they had for men to thee publick Works did ditribute and catter the plentifull advantage and benefit of them among the people of the Town through all ages and conditions; of whatoever Trade and Occupation they might be.

As the Works then grew up being as The admirable peed they made in thee Works. tately and extraordinary for bulk and greatnes o inimitable for beauty and gracefulnes, the Work-men triving to out-vy the matter and grandeur of the Work with the neat contrivance and artificial beauty of it; the thing that was mot to be admired was the hate and peed they made. For of
thoe things, which every one of them ingly they did imagin could hardly be finihed and brought to an end in everal ucceions of Governours and ages of Men, all of them had their complement and perfection in the height and prime of one man's Government. Although they ay too, that about the ame time Zeuxis having heard Agatharchus the Picture-drawer boat himelf for dipatching his Work with peed and eae, replied, But I am a long time about mine. For the eaines and hatines in doing of a thing doth not put upon the Work a lating olidity or exactnes of beauty: but time being allow'd to a man's pains aforehand for the production of a thing doth by way of interet return a vital force for the preervation of the thing after it is once produced. For which reaon Pericles his Works are the more admired, having been done o well in a little time as to hold good for a long time. For every everal Piece Yet the latingnes and frehnes of them. of his Work was immediately even at that time for its beauty and elegance Antique, as if it had been performed by ome ancient Mater; and yet for its vigour and frehnes it looks to this day as if it were pick and pan, and newly wrought: There is uch a kind of flourihing glos upon thoe Works of his, which continually preerves the ight of them from being ullied by
time, as if they had an ay-green pirit and a never-fading oul mingled in the compoition of them.

Now Phidias was he who had the overight An account of the Workmen and of everal of the Buildings. of all the Works and was his Surveyour-general, though in the everal Deigns and Pieces there were great Maters and rare Artits imployed. For Callicrates and Ictinus built the Parthenon (that is, the Temple of the Virgin Pallas) which was in meaure an hundred Foot every way; and the Chapel at Eleuin (where the acred Rites of the Goddes Ceres were celebrated) was begun by Coroebus, who alo placed the Pillars that tand upon the Floor or Pavement and join'd them with Architraves: but after his death Metagenes the Xypetian rais'd the Girth or Wate of it, and et up the Pillars that are above, and Xenocles the Cholargian roofed or arched the Lanthorn or Loover on the top of the Temple of Cator and Pollux.

As for the Long Wall, which join'd the The Long Wall. Port or Harbour with the Town, concerning which Socrates aith he himelf heard Pericles deliver his opinion and give order about it, Callicrates took that a-great. This brave piece of Work Cratinus, like a Poet as he was, neeringly flouts at, by reaon it was o long a finihing; aith he,
'Tis long ince Pericles, if words would do't,
Talk'd up the Wall; but yet ets no hands to't.

q.l: Here comes along our goodly Jove, (God bles!)
Who's that, I pray'? Iobbernoll Pericles.

l.hi: The Shells being cap'd, he now has got the Moddle
O'th' Muick-room (help Goddes) in his Noddle.

div.p:
Then Pericles out of an ambition to doe Muick Games intituted. omething to be talk'd of, did firt enact or make a Decree, that a Prize hould be plaid in the Science of Muick every year at the olemn Feats of Minerva, which lated five
days together, called Panathenaea, whither all the people of City and Country were ued to reort, and he himelf being choen Judge of the Prizes and Betower of the Rewards gave order, after what manner thoe who were to play the Prizes were either to ing with the Voice, or to play upon the Flute or upon the Cittern or Guitarr. And both at that time (to wit, at the Feat) and at other times alo they were wont to it in this Muick-room and ee and hear thoe Prizes and trials of Skill.

Further the Foregate and entrance of the The Acropolis or Cittadel. Cittadel or Catle were finihed in five years time, Mneicles being the chief undertaker of that Work. Now there was a trange A trange accident. accident happened in building of the Cittadel, which hewed that the Goddes was o far from diliking the Work or being avere to it, that he help'd to carry it on and to bring it to perfection. For one of the Artificers, who was the quicket and the handiet Work-man among them all, with a lip of his Foot fell down from a great height and lay ill of it in o mierable a condition, that the Phyicians and Chirurgeons gave him over, having no hopes of his recovery. Pericles being at a los and not knowing what to doe, Minerva appeared to him at night in a Dream and order'd a Medicine, which Pericles applying to the Man did in
a hort time and with great eae cure him. And upon this occaion it was that he et up a bras Statue of Minerva, called hence the Statue of Health, in the Cittadel near Minerva's Statue. an Altar, which as they ay was there before. But it was Phidias, who wrought the Goddees Image in Gold, and hath his name incribed on the Pedetal as the Workman thereof. And indeed the whole Work in a manner was under his charge, and he had (as we have aid already) the overight over all the Artits and Workmen, becaue Pericles had a kindnes for him.

And this made the poor man to be much envied, and his Patron to be very ill poken Several landers and abues put upon Pericles. of and horribly abued with tories, as if Phidias had been his Pimp and took up Ladies and Gentlewomen that came to ee the Works, for Pericles his ue. The Comick Wits of the Town, when they had got this tory by the end, made much of it and bedah'd him with all the ribaldry they could invent, as if he had been the arrantet Whoremater that ever liv'd; charging him falely with the Wife of Menippus one who was his Friend and had been a Lieutenant General under him in the Wars; and with the Volaries or Bird-cages of Pyrilampes, who being an acquaintance of Pericles, they pretended, and made as if he were
wont to preent Peacocks and uch fine Birds to Pericles his Mies, the Women whom he gallanted and kept company with. And why hould one wonder at what uch Fellows ay, who play the Satyrits upon other mens Lives, and daily upon all occaions with their reproaches and evil peeches acrifice the reputations of their Superiours, the Great and the Good, to the envy and pite of the Rabble, as to ome evil Genius or wicked Spirit; when as Steimbrotus the Thaian hath dared to broach a dimal and incredible Villany againt Pericles, as if he had committed Incet with his own Son's Wife.

By this means it comes about, that it is a Why hard to find out Truth in Hitory. very difficult matter to trace and find out the Truth of any thing by Hitory, when on one hand thoe who undertake to write it, living o long after the things were done, cannot arrive at the certain knowledge of uch tranactions as pat in the times before them; and on the other hand that Hitory which is contemporary and of the ame tanding with thoe Actions and Lives, which it reporteth, doth partly through envy and ill-will, partly through favour and flattery, diguie and pervert the truth.

Now when the Oratours, who ided with Thucydides and were of his party, were at one time bawling (as their cutom was)

Though otherwie he was not altogether His thrifty management of his own Etate. idle or careles in looking after his own advantage, but as to his paternal and peronal Etate, which of right belonged to him, he o order'd it, that it might neither through negligence be wated or leen'd, nor yet, he being o full of buines as he was, give him any great trouble or cot him much time with taking care of it, and put it into uch a way of management as he thought to be the mot eaie for himelf, and the mot exact for thrift. Upon which account it was, that his Children when they grew to age were not well pleaed with his menage, and the Women
that liv'd with him were treated with little cot, inomuch that they complain'd of this way of expence in his Houe-keeping, His Houe-keeping. which was ordered and et down from day to day and contracted to the greatet exactnes of thrift; ince there was not there, as is uual in a great Family and a plentifull Etate, any thing to pare or over and above, but all that went out or came in, all his disburements and receipts, were book'd and carried on as it were by number and meaure.

The Lacedemonians beginning to hew A great project of Pericles for a Convention of all Greece. themelves troubled at the greatnes of the Athenians and to be jealous of the increae of their power, Pericles on the other hand to advance the peoples pirit and buoy it up yet more, and to put them upon great actions and exploits, propoeth an Edict or Decree in writing to ummon all the Grecians, in what part oever they dwelt whether of Europe or Aia, and that every City, little as well as great, hould end their Deputies to Athens to a general Aembly or Convention of Etates, there to conult and advie concerning the Grecian Temples which the Barbarians had et fire to and burnt down, and the Sacrifices which they were indebted upon vows they made to their Gods for the afety of Greece, when they fought againt thoe Barbarians, and the Sea-affair, that they might henceforward all of them pas to and fro and trade ecurely and be at a contant peace among themelves.

Howbeit Pericles would receive none He refueth it. of all this, but after he had taken that coure with the Samians, as he thought fit, and et up a Democracy among them, he ail'd back to Athens.

But they immediately revolted, Piuthnes They revolt. having privily convey'd away their Hotages for them, and provided themelves with all things neceary for the War. Whereupon Pericles came out with a Fleet a econd time againt them, whom he found not idle with their hands in their pockets, nor in a neaking poture as if they were daunted at his coming, but altogether manfully reolved to try for the dominion of the Sea.

The iue of it all was, that after a brisk They are beaten in a Fight at Sea. and harp Sea-fight about the Iland called Tragia, (that is, the Ile of Goats) Pericles obtain'd a gallant Victory, having with forty and four Sail, took, routed and unk, threecore and ten of the Enemies, whereof twenty were Men of War.

And together with his Victory and puruit They are block'd up in Town. having made himelf mater of the Port or Harbour he laid Siege to the Samians, and block'd them up, who yet notwithtanding for all that were o hardy and venturous as to make allies out and fight under the City-walls. But after that another greater Fleet, ent as a freh upply from Athens, was arrived, and that the Samians were now hut up with a cloe Leaguer on every ide, Pericles taking with him threecore Pericles goes off with 60 Gallies. Galleys, ailed out into the main Sea; with a reolution, as mot Authours give the
account, to meet with a Squadron of Phenician Ships, that were coming for the Samians relief and aitance, and to fight them at as great ditance as could be from the Iland; but, as Steimbrotus will have it, with a deign of putting over to Cyprus: which doth not eem to be probable. But which oever of the two was his intent, 'tis plain he was in an errour and by his doing as he did gave occaion to a curvy micarriage.

For he being put out to Sea, Melius the The Samians take the advantage, and get a victory. Son of Ithagenes, a man of parts and a Philoopher, being at that time Admiral of Samos, made but little reckoning either of the Ships that were left in repect of their mall number, or of the Commanders themelves in regard of their want of skill, and upon this account prevail'd with the Citizens to attack and et upon the Athenians. And the Samians having won the Battel, and taken everal of the men prioners, and unk and poil'd everal of the Ships, were maters of the Sea, and brought into Port what necearies they wanted for the War and had not before. Aritotle aith too, that Pericles himelf had formerly been worted and beaten by this Melius in a Sea-fight.

Now the Samians, that they might requite an affront which had before been put
upon them, mark'd (either by an Incription They mark the Athenian prioners with an Owl. or Brand) thoe Athenians whom they took prioners in their Foreheads with the Picture of an Owl, (which is their City-Cret.) For o the Athenians had mark'd As the Athenians had done them with a Samaena. them before with a Samaena, which is a ort of Ship, omewhat low and flat in the forepart of it, o as to look nut-noed, but wide and large and well-pread in the hold, by which it both keeps nug upon the Water and proves a wift ailer beides. And it was o called, becaue the firt of that kind was een at Samos, having been built by order of Polycrates the Tyrant. To thee marks or brands upon the Samians foreheads they ay that that paage in Aritophanes hath a ecret alluion, where he aith,
The Samian people (fy for hame!)
For tore of Letters have great fame.

Pericles, as oon as news was brought Pericles relieves the Army. him of the diater that had befaln his Army, made all the hate he could to come in to their relief, and having got the better Beats the Samians. of Melius, who bore up againt him, and having put the Enemies to flight, he preently Incloeth them with a Wall. hemm'd them in with a Wall, reolving to mater them and take the Town,
rather with ome cot and time, than with the wounds and hazards of his Citizens.

But inamuch as it was a hard matter to keep in or hold back the Athenians, who were vexed at the delay, and were eagerly bent to fight, he dividing the whole multitude into eight parts or bodies of men, ordered the buines by lot o, that that He orders a Lottery by a white Bean. part which had the white Bean hould have leave to feat and take their eae, while the other even were buie a fighting. For which reaon they ay alo, that people, when at any time they have been merry and enjoy'd themelves, call uch a day a white day in alluion to this white Bean.

Ephorus the Hitorian tells us beides, Engines of Battery. that Pericles made ue of Engins of Battery in this Siege, being much taken with the trangenes of the invention, and that he plaid them in preence of Artemo himelf the Engineer; who being lame was ued to be carried about in a Litter or Sedan upon occaion of buines where his attendance Artemo why called Periphoretus. was required, and for that reaon was called Periphoretus. But Heraclides Ponticus diproves this out of Anacreon's Poems, where mention is made of this Artemo Periphoretus Another account of him. everal Ages before the Samian War or any of thoe paages. And he ays that Artemo being a man who lov'd his Belly and his eae, and had a tender apprehenion
of danger o as to be truck down with fear at the very thoughts of it, did for the mot part keep cloe within door, having two of his Servants to hold a brazen Shield over his Head, that nothing might fall upon him from above; and if he were at any time forced upon neceity to go abroad, that he was carried about in a Pallankeen or little hanging Bed, cloe to the very ground almot, and that for this reaon he was called Periphoretus.

In the ninth month the Samians urrendring Pericles takes the Town. themelves and delivering up the Town, Pericles pull'd down their Walls, and eis'd their Shipping, and et a Fine of a great um of money upon them; part of which they paid down upon the nail, and the ret they agreed to bring in by a certain time and gave Hotages for ecurity.

Now Duris the Samian makes a Tragical Duris gives a tragical account of it. outcry of this Story, charging the Athenians and Pericles with a great deal of cruelty, which neither Thucydides, nor Ephorus, nor Aritotle hath given any relation of: (but it is likely enough that that Authour had little regard to truth in his o doing;) as how that he brought the Captains of the Galleys and the Sea-men into the Market-place at Miletum, and there having bound them fat to Boards for ten days, he then gave order to have them, poor Wretches,
who were already as good as half dead, to be kill'd by beating out their Brains with Clubs, and their dead Bodies to be flung out into the open Streets and Fields unburied.

But as for Duris, he being one, who even And is cenfured for it. where he hath no private concern of his own, is not wont to keep his hitorical accounts he gives within the compas of truth, it is the more likely that upon this occaion he hath aggravated the calamities which befell his Country, on purpoe to draw an odium upon the Athenians.

Pericles, after the overthrow of Samos, Pericles takes care for the burial of his dead. as oon as he returned back to Athens, he took care that thoe who died in the War hould be honourably buried, and made uch a Funeral Harangue, as the cutom is, in their commendation at their Graves and Monuments, that he was highly admired and eteemed for it.

As he came down from the Pulpit (or The Ladies complement him. place where they delivered their Speeches) the ret of the Ladies came and complemented him taking him by the hand, and crowning him with Garlands and Rubans, as they ued to do with Gameters that won the publick Prizes: onely Elpinice Elpinice privately quips him. coming near to him, aith he, Thee are brave things, Pericles, that you have done, and uch as deerve our Chaplets, who have
lot us a many brave worthy Citizens, not in a War with Phoenicians or Medes, (Enemies and Foreigners) as my Brother Cimon wont to doe, but for the overthrow of a City, that was in alliance and of the ame Country and Kindred with us. As Elpinice poke thee He anwers her pleaantly. words, he gently miling, as 'tis aid, returned her this Vere of Archilochus for anwer;
Old Woman, as you are,
You hould not powder Hair,
Nor, as you walk, perfume the Air;
Leave thee things to the Young and Fair.
Now Ion aith of him, that upon this exploit He is aid to have been conceited of this Victory. of his conquering the Samians, he entertain'd a trange and high conceit of himelf, in that, whereas Agamemnon was ten years a taking a barbarous City, he had in nine months time vanquihed and taken the chiefet and the mot powerfull people among all the Ionians. And indeed it was As he had reaon. not without reaon that he aumed this glory to himelf; for, to ay the truth, there was much uncertainty and great hazard in this War, if o be (as Thucydides tells us) the Samian State were come to that pitch, that they were within a very little of wreting the whole power and dominion of the Sea out of the Athenians hands.

After this was over, a War from Peloponneus
The occaion of the Peloponneian War. being already breaking out in full tide, he advied the people to end help and aitance to the Corcyraeans, (the people of the Iland now called Corfu) who were invaded and et upon by the Corinthians, and to take into their protection and alliance an Iland o trengthened, as that was, with naval power; eeing that the Peloponneians were already, more than ever, made Enemies againt them.

The Commons readily conenting to the Pericles ends aid to Corcyra, by Lacedaemonius. motion, and voting an aid and uccour for them, he dipatch'd away Lacedaemonius, Cimon's Son, having onely ten Ships along with him, as it were out of a deign to affront and abue him. For there was a great kindnes and friendhip betwixt Cimon's Family and the Lacedemonians; wherefore His pite to Cimon's Family. that Lacedaemonius might lie the more open to a charge or upicion at leat of favouring the Lacedemonians and playing booty with them, if he performed no coniderable or handome exploit in this conduct and ervice, he allowed him uch a mall number of Ships, and ent him out againt his will: and indeed he did wholly by all means he could make it his buines to hinder Cimon's Sons from riing in the State, pretending that by their very names they were
not to be look'd upon as natives of the Country or right-bred Athenians, but foreigners and trangers, inamuch as one's name was Lacedaemonius, another's Thealus, and the third's Elius; and they were all three of them, as it was thought, born of an Arcadian Woman.

Wherefore Pericles being but ill poken of He ends more help but too late. upon the account of thee ten Galleys, as having afforded but a mall upply to the poor people that deired it, and given a great advantage to thoe who might call him in quetion, he ent out ome more other Ships afterward to Corcyra, which arrived after the Fight was over, that is, as we ay, came a day after the Fair, when it was too late.

Now when the Corinthians being deadly Several complaints from the other Greeks againt the Athenians. angry with the Athenians accued them publickly at Lacedaemon, the Megarians joined with them, complaining that they were, contrary to common right and the articles of peace agreed upon oath among the Grecians, kept out and driven away from every Market and from all Ports, where the Athenians had to doe, to the hindrance of Commerce and the decay of their Trade. And thoe of Aegina, appearing to have been grievouly ill ued and treated with violence, made their upplications in private to the Lacedemonians for redres, as
not daring openly to call the Athenians in quetion. In the mean time the City Potidaea, (being under the dominion of the Athenians then, but a Colony formerly of the Corinthians) having revolted was beet with a formal Siege; which prov'd an occaion of hatning on the War.

Nay and yet notwithtanding all this, The buines of Megara the main occaion of the War. there being Embaies ent to Athens, and Archidamus the King of the Lacedemonians endeavouring to bring everal of thoe complaints and matters in dipute to a fair determination and deciion, and to pacifie and allay the heats of the allied parties, it is very likely that the War would not upon any other grounds of quarrel have faln from all ides upon the Athenians, could they have been prevail'd with to repeal that Ordinance and Decree of theirs againt the Megarians, and to be reconciled to them. Upon which account, ince Pericles was the man, who mainly oppoed it, and tirr'd up the people, continuing in his peevih and tubborn reolution of unkindnes and quarrelomenes againt thoe of Megara, he alone bore the blame and was look'd upon as the onely caue and promoter of the War.

They ay moreover that Ambaadours Ambaadours ent from Lacedaemon about it. went by order from Lacedaemon to Athens about this very buines, and that, when
Pericles pretended a certain Law, which forbad the taking down the Tablet, wherein the Decree or publick Order was written, one of the Ambaadours, Polyarces Polyarces his device to re concile the quarrel. by name hould ay, Well! do not take it down then, but turn the Tablet inward; for there is no Law, I uppoe, which forbids that. This though it were prettily aid, and might have erv'd for a handome expedient, yet Pericles did not at all relent nor bate an ace of his reolution.

There was then, in all likelihood, ome The ground of the Athenians quarrel againt the Megarians. ecret grudge and private animoity, which he had againt the Megarians. Yet he upon the pretence of a publick and manifet charge againt them, as that they had cut down a holy Grove dedicated to the Gods or imbezilled a piece of ground conecrated to pious ues, writes an Order, that a Herald hould be ent to them, and the ame peron to the Lacedemonians, with an accuation of the Megarians. This Order of Pericles, truth is, hews an equitable and friendly proceeding enough.

But after that the Herald which was ent, The quarrel improv'd by the Herald's death, who was ent to them. by name Anthemocritus, died, and it was thought that the Megarians had contrived his death and made him away, then Charinus writes a Decree againt them, that there hould be an irreconcileable and implacable enmity thenceforward betwixt the
two Commonwealths; and that if any one of the Megarians hould but et his foot upon any part of the Attick Territories, he hould be put to death; and that the Commanders, when they take the uual Oath, hould, over and above that, wear that they will twice every year make an inroad into the Megarians Country; and that Anthemocritus hould be buried near the Thriaian Gates, which are now called the Dipylon or Double Gate.

On the other hand the Megarians utterly The Megarians reflexion upon the Herald's death. denying and diowning the Murther of Anthemocritus, throw the whole buines and the guilt, if any, upon Apaia and Pericles, to which purpoe they make ue of thoe famous and commonly known Veres out of a Play of Aritophanes, called the Acharnes.

lg.l: Youngters of Athens went to Megara,
And tole Simaetha the Town-Whore away.
Nettled at this, Megarian Youths did plot

l.hi: Reprial, and to Town by tealth they got,

lg.l: Where two Apaian Harlots went to pot.

div.p:
The true rie and occaion of this War, Pericles hindred the raing of the Decree againt the Megarians, and why. what it might be, is not o eaie to find out. But that that Decree, we mentioned, was not repeal'd and annulled, all do alike charge
Pericles with being the caue of that. However there are ome who ay that he did out of a great ene and height of pirit tand it out tiffly with a reolution for the bet; accounting that the Precept and Order of thoe Embaies was deigned for a trial of their compliance and yieldingnes, and that a conceion would be taken for a confeion of weaknes, as if they durt not doe otherwie. And other ome there are who ay that he did rather in an arrogant bravado and a wilfull humour of contention, to hew his own gallantry and power, light and et little by the Lacedemonians.

But that which is the wort caue and The likeliet reaon why Pericles hindred it. charge of all, and which is confirmed by mot witnees, we have in a manner uch an account as this given of it. Phidias the Platerer or Image-maker had, as hath before been aid, undertaken to make the Statue of Minerva.
