Now he being familiarly acquainted with Pericles, and a great Favourite of his, had many enemies upon his account, who envied and maligned him: who alo, to make trial in a cae of his, what kind of Judges the Commons would prove, hould there be occaion to bring Phidias a favourite of Pericles accued by Menon. Pericles himelf before them, having tampered with Menon one who had wrought with Phidias, they place him in the Court
with a Petition, deiring publick ecurity upon his dicovery and impeachment of Phidias for things done by him againt the State. The people admitting of the man to tell his tory, and the proecution being agreed upon in the Aembly, there was nothing of theft or cheat charged againt him. For Phidias had immediately from the very firt beginning o wrought and wrapt the Gold, that was ued in the work, about the Statue, and that by the advice of Pericles, that they might take it all off and make out the jut weight of it; which Pericles alo at that time bade the accuers to doe.

But the glory and reputation of his His main crime, the rarity of his Work. Works was that which burthen'd Phidias and cruh'd him with envy; epecially this, that where he repreents the Fight of the Amazons upon the Goddees Shield, he had expres'd a kind of Figure or reemblance of himelf like a bald old man holding aloft a great Stone with both hands; and had put in a very fine Picture of Pericles fighting with an Amazon. And the fahion and poture of the Hand which held out the Spear, over againt Pericles his Face, was with that curious art contrived, as if it meant to hide the likenes, which by the by hew'd it elf on either ide.

Well! poor Phidias was carried away to He is entenced to Prion and there dies. Prion, and there died of a Dieae or ome
other Sicknes; but, as ome ay, of Poion, to raie a lander or a upicion at leat upon Pericles, though it were by the procurement and preparation of his enemies.

As to the Informer Menon, upon Glycon's Menon's reward. propoal, the people made him free from payment of Taxes and Cutoms, and ordered the Commanders to take care of the man's afety, that no body might doe him any harm.

About this time Apaia was indited of Apaia impeached. Impiety or Irreligion, upon the complaint of Hermippus a writer of Comedies, who alo laid further to her charge, that he was Bawd to Pericles and entertained Citizens Wives and Daughters for his ue. And Diopithes propoed a Decree, that information hould be given in againt uch perons as deny a Deity, and thoe who teach or make Dicoures concerning Meteors and other appearances in the Sky; by thee lat words reaching Pericles a box on the ear over Anaxagoras his houlder.

The people receiving and admitting all Pericles order'd to bring in his Accounts. accuations and complaints, as they came, at length by this means they came to enact a Decree, at the motion of Dracontides, that Pericles hould bring in the accounts of the Moneys he had expended, and lodge them with the Prytanes, the Magitrates and Judges of the Treaury; and that the
Judges carrying their uffrage from the Altar hould examine and determine the buines in the City. This indeed Agnon This order put into general terms. took out of the Decree, but moved that caues hould be tried before the 1500 Judges, whether one would name it an action of robbery, or of bribery, or of any whatever injutice.

As to Apaia, Pericles made hift to beg Apaia begg'd off by Pericles. her off, having hed abundance of tears at the Trial, as Aechines makes the relation, and beought the Judges in her behalf. But fearing how it might go with Anaxagoras,
He ends away Anaxagoras. he ent him away and brought him onward on his way out of the City. And whereas he had in Phidias his cae micarried and found the people awkward and avere, being afraid of a Court of Judges, He promotes the War. he et fire to the War, which hitherto had lingered and mothered, and blew it up into a flame; hoping by that means to catter thoe mits of impeachments which they were raiing againt him, and to lower that envy which hung over him; the City uually throwing her elf upon him alone and truting to his ole conduct, upon the urgency of great affairs and publick dangers, by reaon of his authority and the way he bore.

And thee are given out to have been the caues, for which Pericles would not uffer
the people of Athens to comply with the Lacedemonians or yield to their propoals. However the truth of it, whether it were o or no, cannot be well known.

The Lacedemonians for their part having A meage from the Lacedemonians to the Athenians. an aurance, that if they could pull him down and remove him out of the way once, they might be at what terms they pleaed with the Athenians, they ent them word, that they hould expiate and drive out from among them that horrid crime (meaning the rebellion of Cylon) wherewith the kindred of Pericles on the Mother's ide was tainted, as Thucydides hath told the tory. But the buines prov'd quite contrary to what thoe who ent this meage expected. For intead of bringing Pericles under a upicion It doth not ucceed. and a reproach, they brought him into a far greater credit and eteem with his Citizens, as a man whom their Enemies did mot mightily hate and fear. Wherefore Pericles prevents upicion of compliance. alo before that Archidamus, who was at the head of the Peloponneians, made his incurion upon Attica, he told the Athenians aforehand, that if Archidamus, while he laid wate and made havock of every thing ele in the Country, hould forbear and pare his Etate, he had there, either upon pretence of ome friendhip or right of hopitality, that was betwixt them, (as
having been one anothers Guets at ome time or other) or out of purpoe to give his enemies an occaion of traducing and peaking evil of him, that then he did freely betow upon the State all that his Land and Houes in the Country to be imploy'd in the publick ue and ervice.

Well, the Lacedemonians together with The Lacedemonians come in with a great Army. their allies come with a great Army and invade the Athenian Territories, under the conduct of King Archidamus; and laying wate the Country marched on as far as Acharnae, and there pitch'd their Camp; preuming that the Athenians would never endure that, but would come out and fight them for their Country's and their honour's ake. But Pericles is not for giving them battel.
Pericles look'd upon it as a dangerous and dimal adventure, to ingage in Battel, were it in defence of the City it elf, againt threecore thouand armed men of Peloponneians and Boeotians, for o many they were in number, that made the inroad at firt: and he endeavoured to appeae thoe, who were deirous to fight and were griev'd and dicontented to ee how things went, and gave them good words, aying, that Trees, when they are lopt and cut, grow up again in hort time, but Men being once lot and poil'd cannot eaily be recovered again.

He did not convene the people into an He minds the publick buines without Aembly, for fear let they hould force
him from his own reolution or drive him conulting the publick or taking notice of peoples dicontents. beide his own purpoe; but like a skilfull Steerman or Pilot of a Ship, who, when a torm arieth or a udden gut of wind ets hard at Sea, having put all things on board to rights and fitted his tackle, he makes ue of his art of Navigation, and minds the buines of the Ship, taking no notice of the tears and intreaties of the Sea-ick and fearfull paengers: o he having hut up the City-gates, and placed Guards at all Pots for ecurity, made ue of his own reaons and purpoes, little regarding thoe that bawl'd out againt him and were angry at his management. Although there were a great many of his Friends that lay hard at him, requeting him to doe otherwie; and many of his Enemies, threatning and accuing him for doing as he did; and many made Ballads and Lampoons and Libells upon him, which were ung about Town to his digrace, reproaching his Generalhip for being cowardly and throwing up tamely or treacherouly all their concerns into the Enemies hands.

And Cleon alo, having got into credit Cleon a Ringleader of the Malecontents. and favour with the people o as to et up for a Demagogue, and eeing how the Citizens were dipleaed with him, tuck cloe to him and gave him broad ides; as Hermippus hath made it appear in thee Anapaets
of his, a kind of Comick or Lyrick Veres,
King of Satyrs, Woman-haunter,
In thy words of War a Vaunter;
Why, as to action, dot thou aunter?
Why wilt not carry Lance or Spear?
Or heave up Pike? what makes thee fear,
As if thou didt the Soul of Teles A notorious Coward. wear?
Brave Cleon raps thee to the Bone,
As Morglay's edge is harp'd with Stone;
Whet, Whet, he cries; Courage. O Hone! O Hone!
However Pericles was not at all moved by any of thee practices of theirs, but took all patiently, and in ilence underwent the digrace they threw upon him and the ill will they bore him. And ending out a Pericles ends out a Fleet to the Enemies Country. Fleet of a hundred Sail to Peloponneus, he did not go along with it in peron, but taid behind, that he might look after home and keep the City in order, till the Peloponneians hould break up Camp and be gone. Yet to court and cares the common people, who were jaded and in diorder about the War, he reliev'd and refreh'd them with He divides Moneys and Lands among the people. ditributions of publick moneys, and made a Law for the diviion of Lands by lot and
the plantation of Colonies. For having turn'd out all the people of Aegina, he parted the Iland among the Athenians, according as their lot fell.

And it was ome comfort to them and The Enemies ufferings equal to theirs. eae in their mieries, even from what things their enemies endured. For they in the Fleet ailing round the Peloponnee, ravaged a great deal of the Country, and pillaged and plundred the Towns and maller Cities. And by Land he himelf went with an Army into the Megarian Country, and made havock of it all. By which means it appears, that the Peloponneians, though they did the Athenians a world of michief by Land, yet uffering as much themelves from them by Sea, would not have drawn out the War to uch a length, but would quickly have given it over, as Pericles at firt foretold they would, had not ome divine power crot humane purpoes.

Now in the firt place there was a petilential A great Plague breaks out. Dieae or Murrain, that eiz'd upon the City and ate up all the flower and prime of their youth and trength. Upon occaion of which Ditemper, the people, being afflicted in their Souls as well as in their Bodies, were utterly inraged like Madmen againt Pericles, and in the ame nature as Patients being grown delirious in a high
Fever ue to behave themelves toward their Phyician or be it their Father, were ready to fall foul upon him and doe him a michief. For it had been buzz'd in their ears The caue of it imputed to Pericles. by his enemies, as if he were in the fault, perwading them that the occaion of the Plague was the crowding of o many Country people together into Town; in that they were forced now in the Summer time in the heat of the weather to dwell a many of them together higgledy piggledy in pitifull little Tenements and ultry Hovels, enough to tifle them; and to be tied to a lazy coure of life within doors, when as before they lived in a pure, open and free air. The caue and authour of all this, aid they, is he, who upon the account of the War hath poured a multitude of people from the Country in upon us within the Walls, and puts o many men as he has here upon no imploy or ervice, but keeps them pent up like Cattel in a pound, and lets them be overrun with infection from one another, affording them neither hift of quarters nor any refrehment.

He deigning to remedy thee things, He goes out with a great Fleet. and withall to doe the enemy ome inconvenience, got a hundred and fifty ail of Ships ready and fill'd them with men, and having imbarked a many tout Souldiers both Foot and Hore was about to weigh
Anchor, giving great incouragement of hope to his Citizens and no les an alarm of fear to his Enemies, upon the ight of o great a force. And now the Veels having their complement of men, and Pericles being gone aboard the Admiral his own Galley, it happened that the Sun was in an An Eclipe of the Sun happens. Eclipe and it grew dark on a udden, to the extreme affrightment of them all, looking upon it as a dimal token and an unlucky ill-boding Omen. Wherefore Pericles perceiving His device to cure the Pilot of his fear. the Pilot or Steerman eis'd with a great fear and at a tand what to doe, he took his Cloak and put it before the man's Face, and muffling him up in it that he could not ee, he ask'd him whether he did imagine there was any dreadfull thing or great hurt in this that he had done to him, or whether he thought it was the ign of any hurt; he anwering, No; Why? aid he, and what does that there differ from this, onely that that which hath caued that darknes there, is omething greater than a Cloak? But thee are things fit to be dicoured in the Schools of Philoophy.

Well, Pericles, after he had put out to Sea, as he eems not to have done any other exploit befitting uch an apparade and equipage; o when he had beieged the holy He beiegeth Epidaurus, but micarries. City Epidaurus, which gave him ome hope as if it would or might be taken, he
micarried in his deign by reaon of the Sicknes. For it did not onely eie upon the Athenians and detroy them, but alo without any difference any others that upon any occaion mix'd with them or had ought to doe in the Army it carried them off too for company.

After this finding that the Athenians were He cajoles the people in vain. very ill affected towards and highly dipleaed with him, he tried and indeavoured what he could to appeae them by giving them good words and to reincourage their confidence in him. But he could not pacifie or allay their anger, nor perwade them to any thing or prevail with them any way, till they freely pat their Votes upon him, and taking the taff into their own hands He is turn'd out of Office and fined. they took away his command from him and fined him in a round um of money; which by their account that ay leat was fifteen Talents, and they which reckon mot name fifty. Now he who was et down at his Trial to be his Accuer, was Cleon, as Idomeneus tells us; but Simmias, according to Theophratus; and Heraclides Ponticus has named Lacratidas for the man.

After this the publick heats and affairs too might quickly come to a repoe and be at quiet, the Commonalty having dicharged His dometick misfortunes. their pleen and paion upon him (as Waps
do their ting) together with the mortal wound they gave him. But his private dometick concerns were in a wretched untoward condition, he having lot not a few of his Friends and acquaintance in the plague time, and thoe of his Family having long ince been in diorder and in a kind of mutiny againt him. For the eldet of his lawfully His eldet Son's quarrel to him. begotten Sons, Xanthippus by name, being both by nature given to expene, and marrying a young and cotly Dame, the Daughter of Iander (who was the Son of Epilycus) was highly offended at his Father's niggardly thrift, making him but a canty bare allowance, and giving it him by little and little at a time. Wherefore he ent to a Friend one day and borrow'd ome money of him, in his Father Pericles name, pretending it was by his order. But the man coming afterward to demand the debt, Pericles was o far from yielding to pay it, that he arreted the man and entred an action againt him. Upon which the young man Xanthippus thought himelf o heinouly ued and highly diobliged, that he openly reviled his Father.

And firt by way of droll and raillery He abueth his Father with tories. he ridicul'd him by telling tories, what his carriages and converations were at home, and what kind of dicoures he had with the Sophiters and Scholars that came to his
Houe. As for intance, how, Epitimius A Law cae about the death of a Hore. the Pharalian (one who was a practier of all the five Games of Skill) having with a Dart or Javelin unawares againt his will truck and kill'd a Hore that tood in the way, his Father pent a whole day with Protagoras in a erious and learned dipute, whether the Javelin or the Man that threw it or the Maters of the Game, who appointed thee Sports, were according to the trictet and bet reaon to be accounted the caue of this michance or Hore-laughter: whereas, and make the wort of it, it was but chance-medley. Further, beide this, Steimbrotus tells us, that it was Xanthippus elf, who pread abroad among the people that infamous tory concerning his own Wife, how his Father hould make him Cuckold: and that this untoward grudge of the young man's againt his Father, and unnatural breach betwixt them, which was never to be healed or made up, continued with him till his very dying day. For Xanthippus died in the Plague-time of the Sicknes.

At which time Pericles alo lot his Siter Pericles his los of friends by death. and the greatet part of his Kinsfolks and Friends, and thoe who had been mot uefull and erviceable to him in managing the affairs of State. However he did not hrink or give out upon thee occaions, nor His unconcernednes.
did he betray or lower his high pirit and the greatnes of his mind under all his mifortunes and thoe calamities which befell him. Nay, o unconcern'd and o great a mater of his paions he was or at leat eemed to be, that he was never known to weep or to mourn and pay the Funeral Rites to any of his dead Friends, nor was o much as een at the Burial of any of his Relations, till at lat he lot the onely Son which was left of thoe who were lawfully begotten, his Son Paralus. This touch'd His younger Son's death troubles him. him home and made him bow and relent; and yet he triv'd what he could to maintain his principle of gravity and to preerve and keep up the greatnes of his Soul: but all would not doe; for when he came to perform the ceremony of putting a Garland or Chaplet of Flowers upon the Head of the Corps, he was vanquihed by his paion at the ight, o that he burt out a crying and pour'd forth abundance of tears, having never done any uch thing in all the ret of his life before.

After all, the City having made trial of He is invited again to the Government. other Generals for the conduct of War and Oratours for buines of State, when they found there was no one who was of weight enough to counterballance uch a charge, or of authority ufficient to be truted with
o great a Command; then they hankerd after their old Friend and Servant Pericles, and olemnly invited him to the Tribunal or pleading place, and deired him to accept of the Office of General or Commander in chief again. He was then in a very penive condition, and kept in at home, as a cloe Mourner; but was perwaded by Alcibiades and others of his Friends to come abroad and hew himelf to the people: who having upon his appearance made their acknowledgments and apologized for their ingratitude and untowardly uage of him, he undertook the publick affairs once more, He undertakes it. and being choen Praetor or chief Governour, he brought in a Bill that the Statute concerning Batard-iue, which he himelf had formerly caued to be made, might be repealed: that o the name and race or offpring of his Family might not, for want of a lawfull Heir to ucceed, be wholly and utterly lot and extinguihed.

Now the buines of that Statute or Law The Law of Batardy. tood thus. Pericles when long ago he flourihed in the State and had (as hath been aid) Children lawfully begotten, propoed a Law that thoe onely hould be reputed true Citizens of Athens, who were born of uch Parents as were both Athenians. After An Intance of its inconvenience. this the King of Egypt having ent to the Commons, by way of preent, forty
thouand Buhels of Wheat, which were to be ditributed and hared out among the Citizens, there prung up a great many Actions and Suits againt Batards, by vertue of that Edict, which till that time had not been known, nor taken notice of; and everal perons beides were trepann'd and innar'd by fale accuations. There were little les than five thouand, who were caught in this State-trap, and having lot the freedom of the City were old for Slaves; and thoe who induring the tet remained in the Government and pat muter for right Athenians, were found upon the Poll to be fourteen thouand and forty perons in number.

Now though it look'd omewhat odd and trange, Pericles his propoal to repeal it. that a Law, which had been carried on o far againt o many people, hould be broken and cancell'd again by the ame man that made it; yet the preent calamity and ditres, which Pericles labour'd under as to his Family, broke through all objections and prevail'd with the Athenians to pity him, as one who by thoe loes and misfortunes had ufficiently been punihed for his former arrogance and haughtines. And therefore being of opinion, that he had been hrewdly handled by divine vengeance of which he had run o evere a Gantlop, and that his requet was uch as became
a man to ask and men to grant; they yielded that he hould inroll his Batardon His Batard Son legitimated. in the regiter of his own Ward by his paternal name. This very Son of his afterward, when he had defeated the Peloponneians in a Sea-fight near the Ilands called Arginuae, was put to death by the people together with his fellow-Captains, his Colleagues in that Commiion.

About that time, when his Son was inroll'd, Pericles is ick of the Plague. it hould eem, the Plague eis'd Pericles, not with harp and violent fits, as it did others that had it, but with a dull and lingring Ditemper, through various changes and alterations, leiurely by little and little wating the trength of his Body, and undermining the noble faculties of his Soul. So that Theophratus in his Morals, having made a moot-point, Whether mens Manners change with their Fortunes, and their Souls being jogg'd and diturb'd by the ailings of their Bodies do tart aide from the rules of Vertue; hath left it upon record, that Pericles, when he was ick, hew'd one of his Friends that came to viit him an Amulet or Charm, that the Women Wears an Amulet about his Neck. had hung about his Neck; as much as to ay, that he was very ick indeed, when he would admit of or indure uch a foolery as that was.

When he was drawing on and near his time, the bet of the Citizens and thoe of his Friends, who were left alive, itting about him, were dicouring of his Vertue As his Friends were dicouring of him, and Authority, how great it was, and were reckoning up his famous Actions and Atchievements and the number of his Victories; for there were no les than nine Trophies, which he as their chief Commander and Conquerer of their Enemies had et up for the honour of the City and State. Thee things they talk'd of together among themelves, as though he did not undertand or mind what they aid, but had been utterly bereft of his enes. But he had litned all He overhears them and makes a worthy Reply. the while and given good heed to all the paages of their dicoure, and peaking out among them aid, that he wondred they hould commend and take notice of thoe things in him, which were as much owing to Fortune as to any thing ele, and had happen'd to many other Captains in former times as well as to him; and that at the ame time they hould not peak or make mention of that which was the mot excellent and greatet thing of all. For, aid he, there was never any of all my Fellow-Citizens that ever wore Black or put on Mourning upon my account or long of me: meaning that he had not in all his Government been the caue of any ones death, either by ordering or procuring it.

A brave Man, a wonderfull great Peronage, An Encomium of him. without all peradventure! not onely upon the account of his gentle behaviour and mild temper, which all along in the many affairs of his life and thoe hrewd animoities which lay upon him he contantly kept up and maintain'd, but alo of his generous great pirit and high entiment, that he eteem'd that to be the bet of all his good qualities, that having been in uch an abolute uncontrollable power, as he had had, he never had gratified his envy or his paion in any thing to any other man's hurt, nor ever had treated any enemy of his, as if he were incurable, that is, unreconcileable and one who in time might not become a friend. And to me it His good qualities made him deerve the title of Olympius. appears that this one thing of him did make that otherwie childih and arrogant Title they gave him in Nicknaming him Olympius (that is, the Heavenly or Godlike) to be without envy and truly becoming him; I mean his kind and courteous carriage and a pure and untainted unblemih'd converation in the height of power and place: According to thoe apprehenions and reentments we have of the Gods themelves in their kind; whom, upon this account that they are naturally the authours of all good things and are not the authours of any evil, we do think worthy to rule and govern the World.

Not as the Poets rudely fancy, who confounding us with their foolih unmannerly The Poets mitake who acribe paions to the Gods. conceits and opinions, are taken tardy in their own Poems and fictious Stories, when they call the place indeed wherein they ay the Gods make their abode, a ecure and quiet eat, free from all hazards and commotions, not troubled with Winds, nor darkned with Clouds; but at all times alike hining round about with a oft erenity and a pure light, inamuch as uch a temper'd tation is mot agreeable and utable for a bleed and immortal nature to live in: and yet in the mean while do affirm that the Gods themelves are full of trouble and enmity and anger and other paions, which no way become or belong to even Men that have any undertanding. But this will perhaps eem a ubject fitter for ome other conideration, and that ought to be treated of in ome other place.

Well! the ucces of publick affairs after Pericles is mit after his death.
Pericles his death did beget a quick and peedy ene of his los, and a want and deire of uch a conduct as his had been. For thoe who, while he lived, ill reented his great authority, as that which ecliped them and darkned their lights, preently after his quitting the Stage makeing trial of other Oratours and Demagogues, did readily acknowledge that there never had been in
nature uch a dipoition as his was, either more moderate and reaonable in the height of that tate he took upon him, or more grave and olemn in the methods of that mildnes which he ued. And that invidious His eeming Arbitrarines excued and commended. pretended arbitrary power, about which they made uch a plutter and formerly gave it the name of Monarchy and Tyranny, did then appear to have been the chief rampart and bulwark of afety, which the Government and Commonwealth had. So great a corruption and murrain and uch abundance of wicked ill humours had got into publick affairs, which he by keeping them weak and low did cover and diguie from being much taken notice of, and by nubbing of them did hinder them from growing incurable through a licentious impunity.

div.head: The Tranlatour of Pericles's Life his Advertiement to the Reader.
div.p: OR great Authour having a peculiar Idiom of his own and a propriety of tyle by himelf, in the ue of uch Words and Phraes, as are hardly to be met with in any other Greek Writer; it would require as much pains and take up as much paper to jutifie the Tranlation, as it did to make it. I hall onely charge this vacant Page with two or three brief Notes of that nature.

Caear eeing belike—took occaion to ask.] In the Greek it is, < in non-Latin alphabet > . Where < in non-Latin alphabet > , tanding in the middle as it doth, is referible to both Verbs: that he aw them as it hapned, that is, belike; and that, as it was meet or apt for one to doe, he askt them, that is, as I expres it, he took occaion to ask.
Io • t-head.] < in non-Latin alphabet > , Clot-head, in alluion to < in non-Latin alphabet > i. e. Cloud-gatherer, an Epithet given by Homer to Jupiter.

Bitch-fac'd.] So properly < in non-Latin alphabet > ignifies. That which follows, and Born without a Maiden-head, alludes to a paage in Petronius Arbiter, where Quar • illa, I take it, peaking of her elf aith thus; Junonem iratam habeam, i me unquam memini fuie virginem: meaning, that he had been a Whore time out of mind, and could not her elf remember that ever he was a Maid.

div.head: THE LIFE OF FABIUS M.
div.byline: Englihed from the Greek, By John Caryl, Eq
div.p:
HAving related the memorable actions of Pericles, let us now proceed to the Life of Fabius. It is aid, that the firt of the name was a Son of Hercules, and of a Nymph, or ome Woman of that Country, who brought him forth on the banks of Tyber, and that he was a Peron famous and powerfull in Rome: Others will have it, that they were firt called Fodians, becaue the Race of them
delighted in digging pit-falls for wild Beats, and that in proces of time, and by corruption of language, they grew to be called Fabians. But thee things be they true or fale, certain it is, that this Family hath for a long time yielded great tore of eminent Perons; Our Fabius, who was fourth in decent from that Fabius Rutilianus, who firt brought the honourable irname of Maximus into his Family, was alo by way of nick-name called Verrucous from a Wart on his upper Lip, and in his Childhood they in like manner named him Ovicula, by reaon of his extreme mildnes of Nature. His lownes in peaking, his long labour and pains in learning, his little concern in the ports and divertiements of his equals, his eaie ubmiion to every body, as if he had no will of his own, made thoe who judged uperficially of him (the number of which ort of Judges is always the greatet) eteem him inenible and tupid; And few were they, who could penetrate into the firmnes of his Courage, and greatnes of his Mind. But as oon as he came into Employments, his Vertues exerted and hewed themelves; his reputed Dulnes did then appear to be the teddines, and intrepid bravery of his Soul; his lownes in words, and actions, to be the effect of a conummated Prudence, which always laid them by,
till they were thoroughly ripe; and his eaie compliance to the bent of others, to be a noble pride of his heart, thinking it beneath him to contend about trifles.

Fabius, conidering that the grandieur Fabius by generous purpoes apires to renown. of Rome proceeded from Military Vertue, and was by the ame means to be preerved, did therefore inure his Body to labour and exercie, wiely judging, that natural trength was the bet Armour: He alo trained himelf in the Art of Speaking and Perwading; For words and dicoures are the Engines, by which Minds are moved; And he attained to uch a kind of Eloquence, that his manner of peaking, and of acting was perfectly the ame; for although it had not much of Ornament, nor Artifice, yet there was in it great weight of Sene; it was trong and ententious; much after the way of Thucydides. We have yet extant his Funeral Oration upon the death of his Son, who died Conul, which he recited before the People.

He was five times Conul, and in his firt Conulhip he had the honour of a Triumph for the Victory he gained upon the Ligurians, whom he defeated in a et Battel, and drove them to take helter in the Alpes, from whence they never after made any inroad, nor depredation upon their Neighbours. After this Hannibal came into Italy,
who at his firt entrance having gained a great Battel near the River Trebia, travers'd Hannibal's firt prodigious march into Italy. all Tucany with his victorious Army, and deolating the Country round about, fill'd Rome it elf with atonihment and terrour. Beides unuual Thunder and Lightning then happening, the report of everal ill-boding Portents did much increae this popular conternation. For it was aid, that ome Targets did weat Bloud; that at Antium, when they reap'd their Corn, many of the Ears were fill'd with Bloud; that it had rained Fire; that the Phalerians had een the Heavens open and everal Scrolls in form of Lots falling down, in one of which it was plainly writ, Now Mars himelf does brandih his Arms. But thee Prodigies had no effect upon the impetuous and fiery temper of the Conul Flaminius, whoe natural promptnes had been much heightned by his late Victory over the Gauls, though he fought them contrary to the order of the Senate and the advice of his Collegue: o that nothing would atisfie him but a Battel with Hannibal. Fabius on the other ide thought it not eaonable to engage with the Enemy; not that he much regarded thoe talk'd of Prodigies, which he took to be either fictitious or caual; but in regard the Carthaginian Army was in a wating condition, without a poibility of recruits,
without Magazines, the Souldier unpaid; o that their onely hope and afety was in a Battel: But if let alone, watch'd and oberved, the neighbouring Garrions in the mean time being well ecur'd and the Roman Allies defended, their vigour would oon expire, like a Flame for want of Aliment. Thee weighty reaons prevail'd not with Flaminius, who proteted, he would Fabius's deliberate advice ineffectual to move Flaminius. never uffer that the Enemy hould advance one tep farther, and that he would not be reduc'd, like Camillus in former time, to fight for Rome within the Walls of Rome. Accordingly he ordered the Tribunes to draw out the Army into the Field; and as he would not be diwaded by the reaons of his Collegue from this precipitous reolution, o neither was he deterr'd by an ill preaging accident which befell him at his etting forth; for he no ooner got on Horeback, but the Beat fell into o violent a fit of trembling and bounding that he cat his Rider headlong on the ground. This notwithtanding, away he marcheth up to Hannibal, who was poted near the Lake Traimena in Tucany. And it is to be oberv'd, that during the ingagement, there hapned o great an Earthquake, that it detroyed everal Towns, altered the coure of Rivers, tore off the tops of Mountains, yet uch was the eagernes of the
Combatants, that they were enible of no other concuion or agitation, but what themelves made.

In this Battel Flaminius fell, having given He dies courageouly. many proofs of his trength and courage, and round about him lay all the bravet of the Army: In the whole fifteen thouand were killed, and as many made prioners. Hannibal, deirous to betow Funeral Honours upon the Body of Flaminius, made diligent earch after it, but could never find what became of it. Though the los was o coniderable, yet there was no art ued to diemble it at Rome; as there had been, upon the former Ingagement near Trebia; for then, neither the General who writ, nor the Expres who told the news, related it otherwie than as a drawn Battel, with equal los on either ide: But now, as oon as Pomponius the Pretor had the intelligence, he caued the People to aemble, and without diguiing the matter, told them plainly, We are beaten (O Romans) our Army is defeated, the Conul Flaminius is kill'd; think therefore, what is to be done for your afety. The ame commotion, which a furious Wind doth caue in the Ocean, did thee words of the Pretor raie in the minds of o vat a Multitude: But the rage of their grief being a little over, the danger at hand did at lat awaken their
judgments into a reolution to chue a Dictatour, who by the Sovereign authority of his Office, and by his peronal capacity of wiedom and courage might be able to manage the publick affairs, become almot deperate, and to it at Helm in o great a Storm. Their choice unanimouly fell upon Fabius by general conent choen Dictatour.
Fabius, in whom was joyned a venerable gravity of manners with a pirit not to be daunted with any difficulty or danger; whoe Age was o far advanced as to give him Experience, without taking from him the vigour of Action; o that his Body could execute what his Soul deigned; and in him was the happy mixture of Caution and Boldnes. Fabius being thus intalled in the Office of Dictatour, in the firt place he gave the Command of the Hore to Lucius Minutius; and next he asked leave of the Senate for himelf, that in time of Battel he might erve on Horeback, which by an ancient Law amongt the Romans was forbid to their Generals; whether it were, that placing their greatet trength in their Foot, they would have their Commanders in chief poted amongt them, or ele to let them know, that how great oever their authority were, the People and Senate were till their Maters, of whom they mut ask leave. But then again, to make the authority of his Charge more awfull, and to render
the People more ubmis and obedient to him, he caued himelf to be accompanied with four and twenty Lictours; and when the Conul came to viit him, he ent him word, that at his audience he hould dimis his Lictours with their Faces (the enigns of authority) and appear before him onely as a private peron.

The firt olemn action of his Dictature His zeal for the performance of religious duties. was to order publick Prayers to be made to the Gods, and to admonih the People, that their late overthrow did not befall them through want of courage in their Souldiers, but through the neglect of Divine Ceremonies in the General. He therefore exhorted them not to fear the Enemy, but by extraordinary honour to appeae the Gods. This he did, not to fill their minds with upertition, but onely to raie their courage, and leen in them the fear of the Enemy, by making them believe, that Heaven was on their ide. In order hereunto the Sibyline Books were conulted, in which they conceived, the ecrets of detiny and future events were to be learnt; but whoever look'd into them, was under a tye of ecrecy not to reveal what they found. After this he aembled the People, and made a Vow before them to offer in Sacrifice the whole product of the next Seaon all Italy over, of the Cows, Goats, Swine, Sheep,
both in the Mountains and the Plains; and the more to olemnize this great Vow, he commanded the precie um of 333 Seterces, and 333 Pence, and one third of a Peny to be expended upon fetival Games in honour of the Gods. What his mytery might be in that number is not eaie to determine, unles it were in regard of the perfection of the number of three, as being the firt of odd numbers, the firt that contains in it elf multiplication, with all the other properties belonging to any whatoever Number beides.

In this manner Fabius having raied the He prudently manages the War with Hannibal. hearts of the People, by making them believe, that the Gods took their part, and by the ame means having made them upple and pliant to his will, he, for his own part, placed his whole confidence in himelf, believing that the Gods betowed victory and good fortune onely upon the valiant and the prudent. Thus prepar'd, he et forth to oppoe Hannibal, not with intention to fight him, but to wait upon him, to traiten his Quarters, to cut off his Proviions, and by o doing to make his victorious Army molder away, and conume with penury and want. With this deign he always incamp'd on the highet grounds, where their Hore could have no acces to him. He till kept pace with
them; when they marched he followed them; when they incamped he did the ame, but at uch a ditance as not to be compell'd to an Ingagement, and always keeping upon the Hills, free from the inults of their Hore; by which means he gave them no ret, but kept them in a continual Alarm.

But this his dilatory fencing way gave occaion both at Rome, and even in his own Camp, to upect his want of Courage; and this opinion prevail'd alo in Hannibal's Army, who was himelf the onely man who was not deceived, and who clearly aw his own Ruine in his Enemy's Conduct. Wherefore he reolved with all the Hannibal politickly provokes the Romans to engage. arts and ubtilties of War to break his Meaures, and to bring Fabius to an Ingagement; like a cunning Wretler, who watcheth every opportunity to get good hold and cloe with his Adverary. Sometimes he draws up his men to the very intrenchments of the Enemy, reproaching the Romans with their Cowardie, o to exaperate and incene them againt their General; then again he makes a retreat to a good ditance, that o he might draw them out to fall upon his Rere. At other times in ight of the Roman Camp he wates and burns the Countries round, to increae the clamour of the People againt Fabius. All
this artifice though it had no effect upon the firmnes and contancy of the Dictatour, yet upon the common Souldier, and even upon the General of the Hore himelf it had too great an operation: For this Minutius, began to have a contempt of the General and his way of proceeding, which he micontrued to be a timorous cunctation; o that in his harangues he humoured the Souldiery in their mad fondnes of coming to a Battel, and in their corn and reproaches which they cat upon Fabius, calling him the Pedagogue of Hannibal; ince he did nothing ele but follow him up and down, and look and wait upon him. At the ame time they cried up Minutius for the onely Captain, worthy to command the Romans, whoe vanity and preumption did thereupon well to that degree, that he inolently rallied Fabius's Incampments upon the Mountains, aying, that he lodged them there, as on a Theatre, to behold the flames and deolation of their Country. And in his vain fit he would ometimes ask the very Friends and Dometicks of the General, Whether it were not his meaning by o leading them from Mountain to Mountain, to carry them at lat (having no hopes on Earth) up into Heaven, and hide them in the Clouds from Hannibal's Army? When his Friends related thee
things to the Dictatour, perwading him that, to avoid the general obloquy, and the danger that might thereupon enue, he would ingage the Enemy; his anwer was, I hould be more faint-hearted than they make me, if through fear of idle reproaches, I hould abandon my own reaon. It is no inglorious thing to have fear for the afety of our Country. That man is not fit to rule others, who hall be tartled and give ground upon the noie of rumours and calumnies; for in o doing he ubjects himelf and his government to the fancy of thoe whom he ought to command.

But an overight of Hannibal, at this time Through unskilfulnes in the Language he commits a great errour. committed, did happily allay thee ditempers in the Roman Camp: For he, deirous to refreh his Hore in ome good Paturegrounds, drew off his Army, and ordered his Guides to conduct him to Cainum, they mitaking him, by reaon of his ill-pronouncing the Latin Tongue, led him and his Army to the Town of Cailinum, near Campania, which the River Vulturnus divides in two: The Country about it is a Valley circled round with Mountains, which inlargeth it elf towards the Sea, near which that River overflowing, caueth a great deal of Marih ground, and at lat dicharging it elf into the Sea, makes a very unafe Coat, without any Harbour. As oon
as Hannibal was entred into this Valley, Fabius dipatch'd four thouand choice men to eie the entrance into it, and top him up; and lodged the ret of his Army upon the neighbouring Hills in the mot advantageous places; but at the ame time he detacked a commanded Party of his lightet armed Men to fall upon Hannibal's Rere; which they did with uch ucces, that they cut off eight hundred of them, and put the whole Army in diorder. Hannibal, finding the errour and the danger he was fallen into, immediately caus'd the poor Guides to be hang'd, which atisfy'd his revenge but did not leen his danger: For his Enemies were o advantageouly poted, that there was no hopes of breaking thorough them, and his Souldiers began to depair of ever coming out of thoe Straits.

Thus reduc'd, Hannibal had recoure to His Stratageme to regain the Paes. this Stratageme; he caued two thouand head of Oxen, which he had in his Camp, to have Torches and dry Bavens well fatned to their Horns, and lighting them in the beginning of the night, he ordred the Beats to be fair and foftly drove on towards the paages out of the Valley; when this was done, he made his Army with great ilence march after them. The Oxen at firt kept a low, orderly pace, and with their lighted Heads reembled an Army
marching by night, frighting onely the Shepherds and Herdmen of the Hills about. But when the fire had burnt down the Horns of the Beats to the quick, they no longer oberved their ober pace, but unruly with their pain, they ran dipers'd about, toing their Heads, and cattering the fire round about them. This became a urpriing pectacle to the Romans, epecially to thoe, who guarded the Paages, who being at ome ditance from their main Body, and eeing the fire on the udden dipering it elf on every ide, as if the Enemy had deign'd to urround them, in great fright and amazement, quitted their Pot, and precipitouly retir'd to their Camp on the Hills. They were no ooner gone, but a light Body of Hannibal's men, according to his order, immediately eis'd the Paages, and oon after the whole Army, with all the Bagage, came up and afely marched through the Paes. Fabius, before the night was over, quickly found out the trick; for ome of the Beats with their flaming heads fell into the hands of his Men; but for fear of an Ambuh in the dark, he kept his men all night to their Arms in the Camp: And as oon as it was day, he charged the Enemy in the Rere, where many fell, and by reaon of the Straits, and unevennes of the Paages, the
diorder had like to have been general over the whole Punick Army, but that Hannibal peedily detached from his Van a Body of Spaniards, who of themelves active and nimble, were accutomed to the climbing of Mountains; Thee briskly attacked the Roman Troops, who were in heavy Armour, and routing the foremot, gave uch a check to Fabius, that he was no longer in condition of following the Enemy. This Fabius upon divers accounts evil poken of. action brought a trange obloquy and contempt upon the Dictatour; They aid, it was now manifet, that he was not onely inferiour to his Adverary (what they always thought) in Courage, but even in Conduct.

And Hannibal (maliciouly) to improve their hatred againt him, marched with his Army cloe to the Lands and Poeions of Fabius, and then giving order to his Souldiers to burn and detroy all the Country about, he forbad them upon pein of death to doe the leat damage in the Territories of the Roman General, and placed Guards for their ecurity. Thee matters reported at Rome, had that effect with the People, which Hannibal deired. Their Tribunes raied a thouand tories againt him, chiefly at the intigation of Metellus, who not o much out of hatred to him as out of friendhip to Minutius, whoe Kinman he
was, thought by depreing Fabius to raie his Friend. The Senate on their part was alo offended with him, for the bargain he had made with Hannibal, about the exchange of Prioners, of which the conditions were, that after the exchange made of Man for Man, if any on either ide remained, they hould be redeemed at the price of two hundred and fifty Drachms a Head; and upon the whole account there remained two hundred and forty Romans unexchanged. They not onely refued to allow money for the Randomes, but alo reproached Fabius for making a Contract o contrary to the honour and interet of the Commonwealth, in redeeming thoe men at o dear a rate, who had cowardly uffered themelves to be taken by the Enemy. Fabius heard and endur'd all this with invincible patience; but having no money by him, and on the other ide being reolved to keep his word with Hannibal, he dipatch'd his Son to Rome, to ell Land, and to bring with him the price, ufficient to dicharge the Randomes; which was punctually performed by his Son, and accordingly the Prioners were delivered to him; amongt whom many that were able, offered when they were releaed, to repay the money of their Randome, but Fabius would not permit them to doe it.

About this time Fabius was called to Rome by the Priets, to ait (according to the duty of his Office) at ome of their olemn Sacrifices; whereby he was forced to leave the command of the Army with Minutius; but before he parted, he charged him, and intreated him, in his abence, not to come to a Battel with Hannibal: His commands, his intreaties, and his advice Minutius in Fabius's abence attacks the Carthaginians. were lot upon Minutius; for his back was no ooner turn'd but the new General immediately ought all occaions to fight the Enemy. And notice being brought him, that Hannibal had ent out a great part of his Army to forage, he fell upon a coniderable Party of them, doing great execution, and driving them to their very Camp, with no little terrour to the ret, who apprehended their breaking in upon them: but in the mean time Hannibal had drawn his men up into a Body, and Minutius without any los made his retreat. This ucces did much increae the boldnes and preumption of Minutius, and fill'd the Souldiers minds with a contempt of the Enemy, and with a longing deire of a Battel. The news was uddenly pread about Rome, and then was Fabius heard to ay thoe memorable words, That he dreaded nothing more, for the afety of Rome, than the ucces of Minutius. But the People were mad with
joy, and Metellus, who was then their Tribune, made an Oration to them, in which he infinitely extolled the valour of Minutius, and fell bitterly upon Fabius, accuing him not onely for want of Courage, but even of Loyalty; and not onely him, but alo many others of the mot eminent and coniderable perons in Rome; that by their means the Carthaginians had brought the War into Italy, deigning thereby to oppres and detroy the Liberty of the People; for which end they had put the upreme Authority into the hands of a ingle peron, who by his lownes and delays might give leiure to Hannibal to etablih himelf in Italy, and thoe of Carthage time and opportunity to upply him with freh uccours in order to a total Conquet. At this, Fabius tep'd forth, but didain'd to make any reply to his accuations; he onely aid, That they hould expedite the Sacrifices, that o he might peedily return to the Army, to punih Minutius, who had preumed to fight contrary to his orders. He had no ooner pronounced thee words, but the People were immediately poes'd with the belief, that Minutius tood in danger of his life: For it was in the power of the Dictatour to imprion, and to put to death; and they feared, that Fabius, though of a mild temper to outward appearance, would be
as hard to be appeaed when irritated, as he was low to be provoked. And yet no Fabius oppos'd by the Tribune Metellus. body dar'd to contradict the orders of the Dictatour, but Metellus, whoe Office of Tribune gave him ecurity and liberty to ay what he pleaed; for in the time of a Dictature that Magitrate onely conerves his Authority. He therefore boldly apply'd himelf to the People, in the behalf of Minutius, that they hould not uffer him to be made a acrifice to the enmity of Fabius, nor permit him to be detroyed, like the Son of Manlius Torquatus, who was beheaded by his Father for a Battel fought and won againt order: Then he exhorted them to take away from Fabius that abolute power of a Dictatour, and to put it into more worthy hands, which might better manage it for their afety and publick good. Thee impreions very much prevail'd upon the People, though not o far, as wholly to dipoes Fabius of the Dictature: But they decreed, that Minutius hould have an equal authority with the Dictatour in the Army; which was a thing then without Precedent, though, not long after, it was alo practied upon the overthrow at Cannes, when, the Dictatour Marcus Junius being with the Army, they choe at Rome Fabius Buteo Dictatour, that he might create new Senatours, to upply the places
of thoe who were kill'd, which could be performed by no other Magitrate. But as oon as, being entred into the Senate, he had fill'd thoe vacant places with a ufficient number, he immediately dimied his Lictors with their Faces and all his Attendance, and mingling himelf like a common peron with the ret of the People, he quietly went about his own affairs. The Enemies of Fabius thought they had ufficiently affronted and dejected him, by raiing Minutius to be his equal in authority; but they mitook the temper of the man, who look'd upon their madnes as more injurious to the Commonwealth than to himelf; in imitation of Diogenes, who being told, that ome perons derided him, made anwer, But I am not derided, meaning in a Philoophical ene, that a good and a wie Man was not capable of being affronted, or digraced, becaue uch injuries made no impreion upon him. Thus Fabius, with great lenity and unconcernednes, ubmitted to this mad Vote of the People; but, let the rahnes of Minutius hould be thereby inabled to run headlong upon ome dangerous enterprie, with all privacy and peed he return'd back to the Army; where he found Minutius o big and elevated with his new dignity, that a joint-authority not contenting him, he required by turns to
have the Command of the Army, every other day. This Fabius rejected, as of too He divides the Army with Minutius. dangerous conequence, but was contented (to comply with his imperious humour) that the Army hould be divided, and each General hould command his part. The firt and fourth Legion he took for his own diviion, the econd and third he delivered to Minutius; o alo of the Auxiliary Forces each had an equal hare.

Minutius thus exalted, could not contain himelf from boating, even in the preence of Fabius, that now he had humbled the mighty man, who o lately trampled on their Lives and Fortunes: To whom the Dictatour mildly replyed, Minutius, you mitake your Enemy; 'tis Hannibal, and not Fabius whom you are to combat; but if you mut needs contend with your Collegue, let it be in diligence and care for the preervation of Rome; that it may not be aid, a man o favour'd by the People, erv'd them wore than he who had been ill treated and digrac'd by them.

Our young General depiing thee admonitions, as the dotage of upercilious Age, immediately remov'd with the body of his Army, and incamped by himelf. Hannibal, who was not ignorant of all thee paages, lay watching his advantage from them; It happen'd, that between his Army
and that of Minutius there was a certain eminence which eem'd a very advantageous Pot to incamp upon, it had the propect of a large Plain about it, and the Fields appear'd to be all level and even; and yet there were a great many Ditches and hollownees in them, not dicernible to the eye at a ditance. Hannibal had he pleaed, could eaily have poes'd himelf of this ground; but he reerved it for a bait or train, in a proper eaon, to draw the Romans to an Ingagement. Now that Minutius and Fabius were divided, he thought The dangerous conequence of Minutius's rah eparating from Fabius. the opportunity fair for his purpoe; and therefore, having in the night-time lodged a convenient number of his men in thoe Ditches and hollow places, early in the morning he ent forth a mall detachment, who in the ight of Minutius poeed themelves of that riing ground. According to his expectation, Minutius wallowed the bait, and firt ends out a Party of Dragoons, and after them ome Hore, to dilodge the Enemy. And at lat, when he aw Hannibal in peron advancing to the aitance of his men, he marched with his whole Army drawn up, reolving to make himelf Mater of that Pot. The combat for ome time was equal between the foremot Troops; but as oon as Hannibal perceived, that the whole Army of the Romans
was now ufficiently advanced within the toils he had et for them, o that their Backs and Flanks were open to his men, whom he had poted in thoe low places; he intantly gave the ignal, whereupon they ruhed forth, and furiouly attacked Minutius in the Rere. The urprie and the laughter was o great, that it truck an univeral terrour through the whole Army. The bravet amongt them, and Minutius himelf were in uch atonihment, that they were as uncapable of giving orders as the Souldiery of obeying them. Thoe who ought to ave themelves by flight, were intercepted and cut in pieces by the Numidian Horemen, who for that purpoe had dipers'd themelves about the adjacent Plains.

Fabius was not ignorant of this danger of his Country-men; He well foreaw what would happen from the rahnes of Minutius, and the cunning of Hannibal; for which reaon he kept his Men to their Arms, in a readines to wait the event; nor would he trut to the reports of others, but he himelf upon an eminence in his Camp, viewed all that paed. When therefore he aw the Army of Minutius incompas'd by the Enemy, and that by their countenance and hifting their ground, they were more dipoed to flight than to reit;
with a great igh, triking his hand upon his Thigh, he aid to thoe about him, O Hercules! how much ooner than I expected, and yet how much later than he would have done, hath Minutius detroy'd himelf! He then commanded the Enigns to march, and the Army to follow him, telling them; we mut make hate to recue Minutius, who is a valiant man, and a lover of his Country; and if he hath been too forward to ingage the Enemy, at another time we will tell him of it. Thus in the head of his men Fabius marched Fabius uccours Minutius. up to the Enemy; and in the firt place he cleared the Plains of thoe Numidians, and next he fell upon thoe who were charging the Romans in the Rere, running down all that made oppoition, and obliging the ret to ave themelves by a haty retreat, let themelves hould be environed as the Romans had been. Hannibal eeing o udden a change of affairs, and the great execution done by Fabius beyond the force of his age, opening his way thorough the Ranks that he might joyn Minutius, warily commanded a Retreat, and drew off his men into their Camp: The Romans on their part were no les contented to retire in afety. It is reported that upon this occaion Hannibal aid to his Friends; Did not I tell you, that this Cloud which always hover'd upon the Mountains, would at ome
time or other come down with a Storm upon us? Fabius, after his men had pick'd up the Spoils of the Field, retired to his own Camp, without aying any harh or reproachfull thing to his Collegue; who alo on his part gathering his Army together, in this manner delivered himelf to them. Never to commit a fault is above the force of humane Nature; but to learn and improve by the faults we have committed, is that which becomes a good and a prudent man. Some reaons I may have to accue Fortune, but I have many more to thank her; for in a few hours he hath cured a long mitake, and taught me, that I am not the man who hould command others, but have need of another to command me; and that we are not to contend for a victory over thoe to whom it is our advantage to yield. Therefore for the future the Dictatour mut be your Commander; but in gratitude towards him I will till be your Leader, and always be the firt to obey his orders. Having aid this, he commanded Minutius enible of his errour ubmits to Fabius. the Roman Eagles to march forward, and all his men to follow him in their orders into the Camp of Fabius. The Fabians tood amazed at the novelty of the ight, and were anxious and doubtfull what the meaning might be. When he came near the Dictatour's Tent, Fabius went forth to meet him, and he preently laid his Colours
at his Feet, calling him with a loud voice his Father, and the Army commanded by him, the Patrons of his Liberty; and after everal civilities and congratulations, he thus addreed himelf to the Dictatour; You have this day (Fabius) obtain'd a double Victory; one by your Valour and Conduct upon your Enemies, and another by your Humanity and Compaion upon your Colleque: you have at once preerved us and intructed us; and when we were hamefully beaten by Hannibal you retor'd us to our honour and our afety; and intead of him, Fabius more honourably is now our Victor. Wherefore I can call you by no other name but that of a Father, ince you have not onely at this preent given life to me, but (as a common Parent) to all thee who are under me. After this, he threw himelf with great tendernes and ubmiion into the Armes of the Dictatour; and in the ame manner the Souldiers of each Army embraced one another with an exces of gladnes and tears of joy.

Not long after, Fabius laid down the Dictature, and new Conuls were created. Thoe, who immediately ucceeded, oberv'd the ame method in managing the War, and avoided all occaions of fighting Hannibal in a pitch'd Battel; they onely uccour'd their Allies and preerv'd the
Towns from falling off to the Enemy. But The indicreet behaviour of Terentius Varro the Conul. afterwards, when Terentius Varro (a man of obcure Birth, but very popular and bold) had obtain'd the Conulhip, he oon made it appear, that by his rahnes and ignorance, he would expoe the Commonwealth to the lat hazard: For it was his cutom, to declaim in all Aemblies, that as long as the Counels of Fabius prevail'd in Rome, there never would be an end of the War; and he made his brags, that when ever he hould get ight of the Enemy, he would free Italy from the Arms of Strangers. With thee promies he o prevail'd with the credulous multitude, that he rais'd a greater Army than had ever yet been ent out of Rome. There were lited fourcore thouand fighting men; but that which gave confidence to the populace, did at the ame time very much terrifie and deject the wife and experienced, and none more than Fabius; For if o great a Body, and the flower of the Roman Youth hould be cut off, they could not ee any reource for the afety of Rome. Wherefore they addres'd themelves to the other Conul, Paulus Aemilius, a man of great experience in War, but hated by the common People; who formerly upon ome dipleaure had et a Mulct upon him. This other Conul they incourage to withtand the temerity of his Collegue,
telling him, if he will profitably erve his Country, he mut no les oppoe Varro than Hannibal, ince both conpired to decide the fate of Rome by a Battel. It is more Fabius's weighty intructions to Paulus Aemilius. reaonable (aid Fabius to him) that you hould believe me than Varro in matters relating to Hannibal, when I tell you, that if for this year you abtain from fighting with him, either his Army will of it elf moulder away and be detroyed, or ele he will be glad to depart and free Italy from thoe troubleome Guets. This evidently appears, inamuch, that, notwithtanding his Victories, none of the Countries or Towns of Italy come in to him, and that now his Army is not the third part of what it was at firt. To this Paulus Aemilius is aid to have reply'd, Did I onely conider my elf, I hould rather chue to be expoed to the Weapons of Hannibal than to the Suffrages of my fellow Citizens, whoe rancour I am ure to increae againt me if I avoid ingaging the Enemy; yet ince the life of Rome is at take, I will rather in my conduct pleae and obey Fabius than all the world beides. But thee good meaures were broken by the ambitious importunity of Varro; for when they were both come to the Army, nothing would concent this Favourite of the People but a eparate Command, that each Conul hould have his day; and when his turn came, he poted his Army
cloe to Hannibal, at a Village called Cannas, Varro's fatal ingagement with the Carthaginians at Cannas. by the River Aufidius. It was no ooner day, but he et up the red Flagg over his Tent, which was the ignal of Battel. This boldnes of the Conul, and the numerounes of his Army (double to theirs) tartled the Carthaginians; but Hannibal commanded them to their Arms, and with a mall train he went forth to take a full propect of the Enemy, upon a riing ground not far ditant. One of his followers, called Gico (a Nobleman of Carthage) told him, that the number of the Enemy was very atonihing; to whom Hannibal reply'd, with a erious countenance; There is omething yet more atonihing, which you take no notice of; that in all that Army there is not one man whoe name is Gico. This jet of their General made all the company laugh, and as they return'd to the Camp, they told it to thoe whom they met, which caued a general laughter amongt them all. The Army, eeing Hannibal's attendants come back from viewing the Enemy in uch a laughing condition, did verily believe, that from the good poture of their affairs, and from the contempt of the Enemy this laughter had proceeded; which did not a little erve to raie the drooping pirits of the Souldiers. According to his uual manner, Hannibal fail'd not by his
Stratagemes to advantage himelf. In the firt place, he o drew up his men, that the wind was on their backs, which was at that time very violent; and by reaon of the great plains of and, carried before it a great cloud of dut, which triking upon the faces of the Romans, did very much diable them in the fight. In the next place, all his bet men he put into his Wings; and in the Body, which was omewhat more advanced than the Wings, he placed the wort and the weaket of his Army. Then he commanded thoe in the Wings, that when the Enemy had made a thorough charge upon that middle advanc'd Body, which he knew would recoile, as not being able to tand their hock; and that, when the Romans, in their puruit, hould be far enough ingaged within the two Wings, they hould, both on the right and the left, charge them in the Flank, and endeavour to incompas them. This deign had all the ucces imaginable; for the Romans preing upon Hannibal's Front, which gave ground, reduced the form of his Army into a perfect half Moon; and blinded with the dut, they followed on o far, that they gave room for the Enemies Wings to join behind them, and o to incloe and charge them both Flanks and Rere; which they did with an incredible flaughter of the Romans: To
whoe Calamity, it is alo aid, that a caual mitake did very much contribute; For the Hore of Aemilius receiving a hurt, Aemilius the Conul dimounted. and throwing his Mater, thoe about him immediately alighted to aid the Conul; the Roman Troops eeing their Commanders thus quitting their Hores, took it for a ign that they hould all dimount and charge the Enemy on foot. At the ight of this, Hannibal was heard to ay, This pleaeth me better than if they had been deliver'd to me bound hand and foot. For the particulars of this Ingagement, we refer our Reader to thoe Authours who have writ at large upon the Subject.

The Conul Varro with a thin company fled to Venutia; and Paulus Aemilius, unable any longer to oppoe the flight of his men, or the puruit of the Enemy, his Body all covered with wounds, and his Soul no les wounded with grief, ate himelf down upon a Stone, expecting the kindnes of a dipatching blow. His Face was o disfigured, and all his Armour o tained with Bloud, that his very Friends and Dometicks paing by knew him not. At lat Cornelius Lentulus, of a Patrician Race, perceiving who he was, alighted from his Hore, and tendring it to him, deired him to get up, and ave a life o neceary to the afety of the Commonwealth, which at this time
would dearly want o great a Captain. But nothing could prevail upon him to accept of the offer; with tears in his eyes he obliged young Lentulus to remount his Hore; then tanding up, he gave him his hand, and commanded him to tell Fabius Maximus, that Paulus Aemilius had followed his directions to his very lat, and had not in the leat deviated from thoe meaures which were agreed between them; but that it was his hard fate, to be overpower'd by Varro in the firt place, and econdly by Hannibal. Having dipatch'd Lentulus with this Commiion, he mark'd where the laughter was greatet, and there threw He dies valiantly. himelf upon the Swords of the Enemy. In this Battel it is reported, that fifty thouand Romans were lain, four thouand Prioners taken in the Field, and ten thouand in the Camp of both Conuls.

The Friends of Hannibal earnetly perwaded him to follow his Victory, and purue the flying Romans into the very Gates of Rome; auring him, that in five days march he might up in the Capitol: Nor is it eaie to imagine, what hindred him from it. I am apt to believe, that the exces of his good fortune, or ome Tutelary God of the Romans blinded his reaon, and made him loiter away his time; which made Barcas, a Carthaginian, tell him with
indignation; You know, Hannibal, how to get a Victory but not how to ue it. Yet, though he failed in making the bet advantage of o mighty a Victory, however it produced a trange turn and improvement in his affairs; For he, who hitherto had not one Town, nor a Sea-port in his poeion, who had nothing for the ubitence of his men but what he pillaged from day to day; who had no place of Retreat, nor any reaonable hopes to make the War continue, nor his Army to hold together, now became Mater of the bet Provinces and Towns of Italy, and of Capua it elf (next to Rome Capua revolts to Hannibal. the mot flourihing and opulent City) all which came over to him, and ubmitted to his Authority.

It is the aying of Euripides, that a man is in no good condition when he is obliged to try a Friend, nor a State when it tands in need of an able General. And o it was with the Romans; who (before the Battel) branded the counels and actions of Fabius with the infamous note of cowardie and fear, but now in the other extreme, they admire and adore his prudence, as omething divine, that could ee o far, and foretell what would happen o contrary to, and o much above the judgment of all others. In him therefore they place their onely hope; his wiedom is the acred Anchor, which fix'd
them in o great a fluctuation, and his Counels alone preerve them from dipering, and deerting their City; as in the time when the Gauls took poeion of Rome. He, whom they eteemed fearfull Fabius of an even temper in the greatet conternation. and puillanimous, when they were (as they thought) in a properous condition, is now the onely man in this general dejection, who hews no fear, but walking the Streets with an aured and erene countenance, comforts the afflicted, invigorates the weak, and incourageth all to a brave and reolute defence of their Country. He caued the Senate to meet, he heartned the Magitrates, and was as the Soul of their Body giving them life and motion; He placed Guards at the Gates of the City, to top the frighted Rabble from flying; He regulated and confin'd their Mournings for their lain Friends, both as to time and place; That each Family within its own Walls, and not in Publick, hould perform uch Obequies; and that the ceremony of them hould continue onely the pace of one Month, and then the whole City hould be lutrated and purified. The Feat of Ceres happening to fall within this time, it was decreed, that the Solemnity hould be intermitted; let the fewnes and the orrowfull countenance of thoe who hould celebrate it, might too much expoe to the People the greatnes of
their los; Beides, the worhip mot acceptable to the Gods, is that which comes from cheerfull hearts; But thoe Rites which were proper and peculiar for appeaing their anger, and procuring aupicious igns and preages, were by the direction of the Augurs carefully performed. Alo Fabius Pictor (a near Kinman to Maximus) was ent to conult the Oracle of Delphos; and about the ame time, two Vetals having been detected to have been violated, the one kill'd her elf, and the other according to cutom was buried alive.

But now let us admire the moderation An Intance of a generous dipoition in the Romans. and generoity of this Roman Commonwealth; that when the Conul Varro came beaten and flying home, full of infamy and hame, after he had o foully and calamitouly managed their affairs, yet the whole Senate and People went forth to meet him at the Gates of the City, and received him with all the honour and repect due to their Conul: And ilence being commanded, the Magitrates and chief of the Senate, and principally Fabius, commended him before the People, for that he did not depair of the afety of the Commonwealth after o great a los, but was come to take the Government into his hands, to execute the Laws, and comfort his fellow-Citizens, by this means not yet abandon'd and forlorn.

When word was brought to Rome that Hannibal, after the Fight, had marched with his Army into the remoter parts of Italy, the hearts of the Romans began to recover again their ancient vigour and reolution; they ent forth an Army under the command of Fabius Maximus, and Claudius Marcellus choen joint-Commander with Fabius. Marcellus; both great Generals, equal in Fame, but very unlike and oppoite in their ways. For Marcellus, as we have formerly et forth in his Life, was a man of action, bold, vigorous and enterpriing, and (as Homer decribes his Warriours) fierce, and delighting in fights. So that having to doe with Hannibal, a man of his own temper, they never failed upon all occaions to come to an Ingagement. But Fabius adher'd to his former principles, till perwaded, that by following cloe and not fighting him, Hannibal and his Army would at lat be tired out and conumed; like an able Wretler, who with too much exercie and toil grows languid and weak. Wherefore Poidonius tells us, that the Romans called Marcellus their Sword and Fabius their Buckler; and that the vigour of the one mixt with the teadines of the other, made a happy Compound, very alutiferous to Rome. So that Hannibal found by experience that incountring the one, he met with a rapid impetuous River, which drove him
back and till made ome breach upon him; and by the other, though ilently and quietly paing by him, he was inenibly wah'd away and conumed: at lat he was brought to this, that he dreaded Marcellus when he was in motion, and Fabius when he ate till. During the whole coure of this War, he had till to doe with one or both of thee Generals; for each of them had been five times Conul; and either as Praetor, or Proconul, or Conul, they had always a part in the government of the Army; till at lat Marcellus fell into the trap He is circumvented and lain by Hannibal. which Hannibal had laid for him, and was kill'd in his fifth Conulhip. But his craft and ubtilty was unuccesfull upon Fabius, who onely once was in ome danger of being caught; For he had ent counterfeit Letters to him from the principal Inhabitants of Metapont, wherein they ingaged to deliver up their Town if he would come before it with his Army: This train had almot drawn him in, for he had reolved to march to them with part of his Army, but was diverted onely by conulting the flight of the Birds, which he found to be inaupicious: And not long after he came to undertand that thoe Letters had been forged by Hannibal, who for his reception had laid an Ambuh to entertain him. This perhaps we mut rather attribute to
the favour of the Gods than to the prudence of Fabius.

But in preerving the Towns and his Allies The winning behaviour of Fabius towards his fickle Allies. from revolting, with fair and gentle uage, and in not uing rigour, or hewing a upicion upon every light uggetion, his conduct was very ingular. It is reported of him, that being informed of a certain Marian (an eminent Man for his courage and quality) who had dealt underhand with ome of the Souldiers to make them deert, Fabius was o far from uing everity againt him, that he called for him, and told him, he was enible of the wrong which had been done him, and that his merit and good ervice had been neglected, which he aid was a great fault in the Commanders, who reward more by favour than by deert; Therefore, when ever you are agrieved (aid Fabius) I hall take it ill at your hands, if you apply your elf to any but to me; when he had o poken, he betowed an excellent Hore and other good gifts upon him: And from that time forwards, there was not a faithfuller and more truty man in the whole Army than this Marian. With good reaon our General did judge, that if thoe who have the government of Hores and Beats, endeavour by gentle uage to make them tractable and fit for ervice, rather than by cruelty and beating; much more
thoe who have the command of Men, hould bring them to order and dicipline by the mildet and fairet means; not treating them wore than Gardiners thoe wild Plants, which by carefull looking to and good uage, looe the avagenes of their nature, and bear excellent fruit.

At another time, ome of his Officers A pleaant fetch of his to reduce a common Souldier. inform'd him, that one of their Men did very often depart from his Colours, and lie out at nights; he ask'd them what kind of man he was; they all anwer'd, that the whole Army had not a better man; that he was a native of Lucania; and o they fell relating everal actions which they had een him perform. Immediately Fabius made a trict inquiry to find what it was that led him o often out of the Camp: and at lat he dicover'd, that his frequent excurions were to viit a young Woman, with whom he was in love. Hereupon he gave private order to ome of his men, to find out the Woman and ecretly to convey her into his own Tent; and then ent for the Lucanian, and calling him aide, told him, that he very well knew how often he had lain at nights out of the Camp, which was a Capital trangreion againt military Dicipline and the Roman Laws; but he knew alo how brave he was, and the good ervices he had done, and therefore in conideration
of them he was willing to forgive him his fault; But to keep him in good order, he was reolved to place one over him, to be his keeper, who hould be accountable for his good behaviour; having aid this, he produced the Woman, and told the Souldier, (terrified and amazed at the adventure) This is the peron who mut anwer for you; and by your future behaviour we hall ee whether your night rambles were upon the account of love, or upon any other wore deign.

Another paage there was, omething of His Policy in regaining Tarentum. this nature, which alo fell under the management of Fabius, and proved highly advantageous to the Roman affairs, whereby he gain'd Tarentum. There was a young Tarentine in the Army, that had a Siter in Tarentum (then in poeion of the Enemy) who entirely loved her Brother and wholly depended of him; He being inform'd, that a certain Brutian, whom Hannibal had made Governour of that Garrion, was deeply in love with his Siter, conceived hopes, that he might poibly turn it to account in behalf of the Romans. And having firt communicated his deign with Fabius, he left the Army as a Deerter (in hew) and went over to Tarentum. At his firt coming, the Brutian abtain'd from viiting the Siter; for neither of them knew that
the Brother had notice of the Amour between them: whereupon the young Tarentine took an occaion to tell his Siter, how he had heard, that a man of quality and great authority had made his addrees to her; Therefore he deired her to tell him who it was; for (aid he) if he be a man that has bravery and reputation, it matters not what Country-man he is; ince at this time the Sword mingles all Nations and makes them equal; and an alliance with uch a peron, in this Reign of Mars, is both honourable and profitable. Hereupon the Woman ends for her Gallant, and makes the Brother and him great Friends: and whereas he henceforth hew'd more countenance to her Lover than formerly, by the ame degrees that her kindnes increaed did his friendhip alo with the Brother advance. So that at lat our Tarentine thought this Brutian Officer well enough prepar'd to receive the offers he had to make him; and that it would be eaie for a Mercenary Man, who was in love, to accept (upon the terms propoed) of great Sums promied by Fabius, and of a Mitres whom he paionately loved.
