In concluion the bargain was truck, and the promie made of delivering the Town. This is the common tradition, though ome relate this tory otherwie, and ay, that this Woman, by whom the Brutian
was inveigled to betray the Town, was not a native of Tarentum but a Brutian born, and that he had been kept by Fabius as his Concubine; and being a Country-woman and an acquaintance of the Brutian Governour, he privately ent her to him to corrupt him.

Whilt thee matters were thus brewing, to draw off Hannibal from centing the deign, Fabius ends orders to the Garrion in Rhegium, that they hould wate and poil the Brutian Country, and hould alo lay iege to Caulonia, and torm the place with all poible vigour; Thee were a Body of eight thouand men, the wort of the Roman Army, who had mot of them been runaways, and had been branded by Marcellus with the ignominious note of Cowardie; o that the los of them would not be great, nor much lamented by the Romans. Fabius therefore threw out thee men as a bait Hannibal diverted by a ubtilty of Fabius. for Hannibal, to divert him from Tarentum; who intantly bit at it, and led his forces to Caulonia; and in the mean time Fabius lay down before Tarentum. The ixth day of the Siege, his young Tarentine lips by night out of the Town, and having well oberved the place where the Brutian Commander, according to agreement was to let in the Romans, he gives an account of the whole matter, as they had laid it to Fabius;
who thought it not afe to rely wholly upon the information given him, and the bargain which was made, but went himelf with great privacy to take a view of the Pot and the avenue; and then gave order for a general aault to be made on the other ide of the Town, both by Land and Sea. This being accordingly executed, when the Tarentines, and mot of the Garrion ran to defend the Town on that ide where the attack was made, Fabius with the men reerved for that purpoe cales the Walls at the place deign'd, and enters the Town without oppoition.

Here we mut confes, that the Ambition The inhumane cruelty of Fabius at the acking of Tarentum. of Fabius was both cruel and unfaithfull; For to make it appear to the world, that he had taken Tarentum by force and his own prowes, and not by treachery, he commanded his men to doe execution upon all the Brutians, and not to pare a man of them; many of the Tarentines were alo kill'd, and thirty thouand of them were old for Slaves. The Army had the plunder of the Town, and there was brought into the Treaury three thouand Talents: whilt they were thus ordering and ditributing the Spoils, the Officer who took the Inventory, ask'd what hould be done with their Gods, meaning the Statues and Images in the Temples; to whom Fabius anwer'd,
Let us leave their angry Gods to the Tarentines. And yet one Statue of Hercules, which was of extraordinary bignes, he caus'd to be et up in the Capitol, next to his own in Bras, which tood there on Horeback. The evere and anguinary proceeding on this occaion, as it reflects on the memory of Fabius, o alo it did very much et off in the eyes of the world the clemency and humanity of Marcellus, as in his Life we have already hewn.

When Hannibal had the news brought Hannibal in vain attempts to relieve it. him that Tarentum was beieged, he marched with great diligence to relieve it; and being come within five miles, he was inform'd that the Town was taken; which made him ay, that Rome had alo got a Hannibal, and by the ame Art Tarentum was lot, by which he formerly had gain'd it: And being in private with ome of his Confidents, he plainly told them, that he always thought it difficult, but now he held it impoible with the Forces he then had to mater Italy.

Upon this ucces, Fabius had a Triumph decreed him at Rome, much more plendid than the former; for they look'd upon him now as a Champion who had clearly worted his Antagonit, and been too hard for him in his own way and at his own Weapon: And indeed the Army of Hannibal
was at this time partly worn away with continual action, and partly become oft and diolute with great opulency and luxury. When the Senate had before them the buines of this Triumph, Marcus Livius (who was Governour of Tarentum when it was betrayed to Hannibal, and then retired into the Catle, which he kept till the Town was re-taken) openly declared, that by his reitance more than by any action of Fabius, Tarentum had been recovered; to whom Fabius, laughing at his envy and ambition, reply'd; You ay very true, for if Marcus Fabius's jocular reply to Marcus Livius. Livius had not lot Tarentum, Fabius Maximus had never recover'd it. The People of Rome thought no honour too great for him; they gave his Son the Conulhip of the next year; who when he was entred upon his Office, there being ome buines then on foot about proviions for the War, his Father, either by reaon of Age and infirmity, or perhaps out of deign to try his Son, came up to him on Horeback. Whereupon the young Conul preently bid one of his Lictors command his Father to alight, and tell him that if he had any buines with the Conul he hould come on foot. This infinitely pleaed the old man, and although the tanders by eem'd offended at the imperiounes of the Son towards a Father, o venerable for his age and his authority,
yet he intantly lighted from his The trancendent dignity of a Magitrate. Hore, and with open armes and great peed, came up and imbraced his Son, telling him, Now thou art my Son indeed, ince thou dot undertand thy elf in the Authority thou hat received, and knowet whom thou art to command. This was the way by which we and our forefathers have advanced the dignity of the Commonwealth, in preferring that to our own Fathers and Children.

And indeed it is reported, that the great Grandfather of our Fabius, who was undoubtedly the greatet man of Rome in his time, both in Reputation and Authority, who had been five times Conul, and had been honour'd with everal Triumphs for as many Victories obtained by him, took pleaure in erving (as Legate) under his own Son, when he went Conul into his Province: And when afterwards his Son had a Triumph betow'd upon him for his good ervice, the old man followed on Horeback his triumphant Chariot, as one of his Attendants; and made it his glory to be the greatet man in Rome, and to have uch a Son, and yet to be ubject to the Law and the Magitrate.

But the praies of our Fabius are not bounded here; his manly courage in bearing his loes, more eminently hew'd the greatnes of his Soul than his properous
uccees. For looing this Son of his in the flower of his age, and in the height of his promotion, with wonderfull moderation he did the part of a pious Father and of a Heroe, whom nothing could daunt. For as it was the cutom amongt the Romans, upon the death of any illutrious peron, to have a Funeral Oration recited by ome of the nearet Relations, he himelf took upon him that office, and delivered himelf upon the ubject to the great atisfaction and applaue both of Senate and People.

After Publius Cornelius Scipio, who was ent Proconul into Spain, had driven the Carthaginians (defeated by him in many Battels) out of that Province, and had reduced everal Towns and Nations under the obedience of Rome, he was received at his coming home with a general joy and acclamation of the People; who to hew their gratitude and high eteem of him, deign'd him Conul for the year enuing. Knowing what high expectation they had of him, he thought the deign of onely driving Hannibal out of Italy, not great enough to anwer the hopes and the happines they promied themelves from his Conulhip. He therefore propos'd no les a task to himelf than to make Carthage the eat of the War; and o to oblige Hannibal, intead of invading the Countries of
others, to draw back and defend his own. To this end he made ue of all the credit and favour he had with the People; and aiduouly courting them, left no popular art untry'd that he might gain them to econd his deign. Fabius on the other ide Scipio thwarted in his deigns by Fabius. oppos'd with all his might this undertaking of Scipio, telling the People, that nothing but the temerity of a hot young man could inpire them with uch dangerous Counels, which by drawing away their Forces to parts o remote, might expoe Rome it elf to be the conquet of Hannibal. His authority and perwaions prevail'd with the Senate to epoue his Sentiments, but the common People thought that he envied the Fame of Scipio, and that he was afraid let this young Conquerour hould have the glory to drive Hannibal out of Italy, and to end the War, which had for o many years continued and been protracted under his Government.

To ay the truth, when Fabius firt oppos'd this project of Scipio, I believe he did it in conideration onely of the publick afety, and of the danger which the Commonwealth might incur by uch a way of proceeding: but when he found Scipio every day increaing in the eteem of the People, envy then and ambition took hold of him, which made him o violent in his oppoition.
For he apply'd himelf to Craus, the Collegue of Scipio, and perwaded him not to yield that Province to Scipio, but that (if his inclinations were for that War) he hould himelf in peron lead the Army to Carthage. He alo hindred the giving money to Scipio for the War, who was forc'd to raie it upon his own credit and interet, and was upply'd by the Cities of Hetruria, which were wholly devoted to him. On the Craus no promoter of martial exploits. other ide, Craus would not tir againt him, nor remove out of Italy, as being in his own nature an Enemy to trife and contention, and alo as having the care of Religion, by his Office of high Priet. Wherefore Fabius try'd other ways to break the deign; He declaimed both in the Senate and to the People that Scipio did not onely himelf fly from Hannibal, but did alo endeavour to drain Italy of all their Forces, and to pirit away the youth of the Country to a Foreign War, leaving behind them their Parents, Wives and Children a defenceles Prey to the Enemy at their doors. With this he o terrified the People, that at lat they would onely allow to Scipio for the War the Legions which were in Sicily, and three hundred of thoe men who had o bravely erved him in Spain. In thee tranactions hitherto Fabius onely eem'd to follow the dictates of his own wary temper.

But, after that Scipio was gone over into The deerved renown of Scipio in Africk. Africa, when news was brought to Rome of his wonderfull exploits and Victories (of which the fame was confirm'd by the Spoils he ent home) of a Numidian King taken Prioner, of a vat laughter of their men, of two Camps of the Enemy burnt and detroy'd, and in them a great quantity of Arms and Hores; when hereupon the Carthaginians had been compell'd to end their Envoys to Hannibal to call him home, and leave Italy, to defend Carthage; when for o eminent and trancending ervices, the whole People of Rome, with no les gratitude than acclamation, cry'd up and extoll'd the Actions of Scipio; even then did Fabius contend He is envy'd by Fabius. that a Succeour hould be ent in his place, alledging for it onely the old thredbare and pitifull reaon of the mutability of Fortune, as if he would be weary of long favouring the ame peron. But this too manifetly laid open his envious and moroe humour, when nothing (not done by himelf) could pleae him; Nay, when Hannibal had put his Army on Ship-board, and taken his leave of Italy, and when the People had therefore decreed a Thankgiving-day, did Fabius till oppoe and diturb the univeral joy of Rome, by preading about his fears and apprehenions, and by telling them, that the Commonwealth was never more in danger than now,
and that Hannibal was a more dreadfull Enemy under the Walls of Carthage than ever he had been in Italy; that it would be fatal to Rome when ever Scipio hould encounter his victorious Army, till warm with the bloud of o many Roman Generals, Dictatours and Conuls lain. Some of the People were tartled with thee declamations, and were brought to believe, that the farther off Hannibal was the nearer was their danger. But Scipio afterwards fought Hannibal and defeated him, and ufficiently humbled the pride of Carthage; whereby he rais'd again the drooping pirits of the Romans, no more to be dejected; and firmly etablih'd their Empire, which the tempet of this Punick War had o long caued to fluctuate.

But Fabius Maximus lived not to ee the properous end of this War, and the final overthrow of Hannibal, nor to rejoyce in the well etablih'd happines and ecurity of the Commonwealth; for about the time that Hannibal left Italy, he fell ick and died. We find in the Hitory of Thebes, Epaminondas died o poor that he was buried upon the publick charge: Fabius, on the contrary, died very rich, yet uch was the love of the People towards him, that every man of them, by a general Tax, did contribute to defray his Funeral; thereby owning him their common Father; which made his End no les honourable than his Life.

div.head: THE COMPARISON OF FABIS with PERICLES.
div.p:
YOU have here had the Lives of two perons very illutrious for their Civil and Military Endowments; Let us firt compare them in their warlike Capacity. Pericles preided in his Commonwealth, when it was in a mot flourihing and opulent condition, great in Power and happy in Succes; o that he eem'd to tand rather upported by, than upporting the Fortune of his Country. But the buines of Fabius, who undertook the Government in the wort and mot difficult times, was not to conerve and maintain a well etablih'd felicity of a properous State, but to raie and uphold a inking and ruinous Commonwealth. Beides the Victories of Cimon, of Myronides and Leocrates, with thoe many famous exploits of Tolmides, were made ue of by Pericles onely to entertain the People at home, and to pleae their Fancy with Triumphs, Feats and Games of the Circus
and Theatre; not to inlarge their Empire by proecuting the War: Whereas Fabius, when he took upon him the Government, had the frightfull object before his eyes of Roman Armies detroy'd, of their Generals and Conuls lain, of all the Countries round trew'd with the dead Bodies, and the Rivers tain'd with the Bloud of his fellow Citizens; and yet with his mature and olid Counels, with the firmnes of his Reolution, he, as it were, put his Shoulders to the falling Commonwealth, and kept it up from foundring, through the failings and weaknes of others. Perhaps it may be more eaie to govern a City broken and tamed with calamities and adverity, and compell'd to obey by danger and neceity, than to rule a People pamper'd and rety with long Properity, as were the Athenians when Pericles held the reins of Government. But then again, not to be daunted nor dicompos'd with the vat heap of Calamities under which the people of Rome did at that time grone and uccumb, argues the temper of Fabius to be invincible, and his courage more than humane.

We may et Tarentum re-taken, againt Samos won by Pericles, and the conquet of Euboea we may put in balance with the Towns of Campania; though Capua it elf was afterwards ubdued by the Conuls Furius
and Appius. I do not find that Fabius won any et Battel, but that againt the Ligurians, for which he had his Triumph; whereas Pericles erected nine Trophies for as many Victories obtain'd by Land and by Sea. But no action of Pericles can be compar'd Pericles's numerous Victories ecliped by one of Fabius's. to that memorable recue of Minutius, when Fabius redeem'd both him and his Army from utter detruction; an Action, which comprehends the height of Valour, of Conduct and Humanity. On the other ide, it does not appear, that Pericles was ever o over-reach'd as Fabius was by Hannibal with his flaming Oxen; never was there o certain, and o great an advantage lot over an Enemy: For in the Valley of Cailinum Hannibal was hut up without any poibility of forcing his way out, and yet by Stratageme in the night he frees himelf out of thoe Straits, and when day came, worted the Enemy, who had him before at his mercy.

It is the part of a good General, not onely to provide for, and judge well of the preent, but alo to have a clear foreight of things to come. In this Pericles excell'd, for he admonih'd the Athenians, and told them beforehand, what ruine their lat War would bring upon them, by graping more than they were able to manage. But Fabius was not o good a Prophet, when he denounced to the Romans, that the undertaking
of Scipio would be the detruction of the Commonwealth. So that Pericles was a good Prophet of bad ucces, and Fabius was a bad Prophet of ucces that was good. And indeed, to looe an advantage through diffidence, is no les blameable in a General than to fall into danger for want of foreight; For both thee faults, though of a contrary nature, pring from the ame root, which is want of judgment and experience.

As for their Civil Policy; it is imputed to Pericles that he was a lover of War, and that no terms of Peace, offer'd by the Lacedemonians, would content him. It is true, that Fabius alo was not for yielding any thing to the Carthaginians, but would rather hazard all than leen the Empire of Rome; yet this difference there was between them, that Fabius made War onely to preerve and recover his own, and Pericles to gain what belong'd to others. But then, the mildnes of Fabius towards his Collegue Minutius does, by way of comparion, highly reproach and condemn the eager proecution of Pericles, and his practices to banih Cimon and Thucydides, who held with the Nobility, and were true lovers of their Country. Indeed the authority of Pericles in Athens was much greater than that of Fabius in Rome; for which reaon it was more eaie for him to prevent micarriages commonly
ariing from weaknes and inufficiency of Officers, ince he had got the ole nomination and management of them; onely Tolmides broke looe from him, and contrary to his orders, unadviedly fought with the Boeotians, and was lain: whereas Fabius, for want of that general power and influence upon the Officers, had not the means to obviate their micarriages; but it had been happy for the Romans if his Authority had been greater; for o we may preume, their diaters had been fewer.

As to their liberality and publick pirit, Pericles was eminent in never taking any gifts, and Fabius for giving his own money to ranome his Souldiers; though the um did not exceed ix Talents. This right we mut doe Pericles, that no man had ever greater opportunities to enrich himelf (as having had preents offer'd him from o many Kings and Princes, and States of his Alliance) yet no man was ever more free from corruption. And for the beauty and magnificence of Temples and publick Edifices, with which he adorn'd his Country, it mut be confet, that all the Ornaments and Structures of Rome, to the time of the Caears, had nothing to compare, either in greatnes of deign or of expence, with the lutre of thoe which Pericles onely erected at Athens.
